PETITION.TITLE: Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable, the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully call on the Minister for Foreign Affairs to recall Australia's Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, (Mr Brian Burke) and suspend his appointment while matters of propriety relating to his actions as Premier and subsequently which have been referred to the Minister are investigated, and moreover during the term of the Royal Commission into W.A. Inc.
And your petitions as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecommunications
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that there is widespread community concern over the introduction of competition into Australia's telecommunications industry, and that ordinary consumers may be faced with higher prices and reduced services as a result. In particular, we are concerned about the impact on the affordability of telephone services for low income earners and rural consumers.
The petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should introduce legislation to:
(a) protect ordinary consumers from increasing prices and decreasing service and to ensure that the telephone remains an affordable utility
(b) clearly define community service obligations of all telecommunications providers

(c) ensure that, regardless of the structural arrangements, a strong and viable government telecommunications carrier is maintained and continues to provide a universal, affordable service to all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Middle East: Australian Military Personnel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The hasty deployment of Australian military personnel to the Middle-East at the request of the President of the United States has involved Australia in an undeclared war with potentially disastrous consequences for Australia and the people of the Middle-East.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:
Immediately withdraw all Australian military personnel from the Middle East and pursue a foreign policy designed to secure justice and human rights for all of the people of the Middle-East.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I am giving notice today because such notices must be given within 15 sitting days. The Committee is concerned that one of these instruments relates to defective drafting, possible invalid subdelegation, absence of review rights and a misleading explanatory statement. Other apparent defects are a possibly harsh penalty, a strict liability offence, mandatory provisions with unclear effect and possible lack of protection for Commonwealth revenue. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the usual short statement of the matters raised by the Committee in respect of these instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN HORTICULTURAL
CORPORATION (EXPORT
CONTROL) REGULATIONS
STATUTORY RULES 1990 N0.422

The Australian Horticultural Corporation (AHC) licenses exporters of fruit under provisions of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987 and regulations made under the Act. The Explanatory Statement for the Regulations advises that they will increase the simplicity, flexibility and objectivity of the export licensing procedures of the AHC.

Perhaps the most important provision of the Regulations contained a typographical error. The Committee does not usually draw attention to such errors, unless they affect the sense of a provision or unless there are other matters which the Committee wishes to raise. However, in this case the substance of the regulation could have been affected. The Regulations also misspell the name of a friendly Pacific region country.

Another regulation provided for the AHC to charge such fees as it considers necessary to enable it to recover costs. It is possible that this is an invalid subdelegation of the power in the parent Act to make regulations with respect to fees. The Committee always carefully scrutinies any apparent unauthorised subdelegation. The Committee on 29 November 1990 presented a Report to the Senate on Subdelegation of Powers.

In addition, the fees did not appear to be subject to gazettal, tabling, disallowance or any other form of parliamentary scrutiny. Here again the Committee is also particularly vigilant. In the present case the fees relate to charges by a statutory authority on individuals earning a livelihood in the export of horticultural products and the Committee would normally expect that such fees be subject to scrutiny.

The Regulations provide a right of review to the AAT for a number of discretions. However, there are several important discretions with commercial and livelihood implications which do not appear to have such a right. These include the determination of financial rating for a licensee, decisions on reasons for failure to comply with certain conditions of a licence and a failure by the AHC to approve credit assessors.

The Explanatory Statement is defective in that it does not provide an explanation of the various clauses in the Regulations. More importantly, the Explanatory Statement advises that the Regulations may be extended to cover horticultural products listed in a Schedule. However, this does not appear to be possible under present provisions. Again, the Explanatory Statement advises that licences are not required for some destinations listed in a Schedule, although such a Schedule neither exists nor apparently is provided for in the Regulations.
AUSTRALIAN NATIONAL MARITIME
MUSEUM REGULATIONS
STATUTORY RULES 1991 NO.10
These Regulations, made under the parent Australian National Maritime Museum Act 1990, provide for security, control of access and commercial activities in relation to the Museum.

There are 10 offence provisions in the Regulations, each of which provides for a penalty of $500. This penalty in most cases appears appropriate, relating to offences such as unauthorised exploitation of Museum material, sale of liquor to persons under 18 years, interfering with exhibits and similar type activities. However, one provision appears to impose a $500 penalty for a parking offence. The Committee is concerned that penalties for offences should be set at an appropriate level. A penalty which is out of proportion to the offence committed may be a breach of personal liberties. In the present case it appears as if the wilful destruction of a valuable relic of Australia's maritime heritage may attract the same penalty as failing to park a motor vehicle in accordance with the directions of a security officer. Such a level of penalty may well be appropriate but the Committee has sought the advice of the Minister.

The Regulations further provide that a person must not, without consent, make, print, publish or sell any replica, photograph, or copy of any maritime historical material in the ownership or possession of the Museum. As it stands this is a strict liability offence. As this material is by definition historical, it is possible and even probable that copies of photographs and other documents are in existence outside the Museum. It would therefore seem possible for a person quite innocently to reproduce or publish such material without knowing that he or she was breaching the Regulations. There is no defence provided for such a situation. The Committee always looks closely at strict liability offences and raises the matter with the Minister. The Committee only accepts strict liability provisions after full explanation. In this case it would seem appropriate to amend the Regulations to provide a defence of knowingly breaching the regulation.
CATTLE AND BEEF LEVY
COLLECTION REGULATIONS
STATUTORY RULES 1991 N0.4

These Regulations effect new arrangements for the collection of levies and charges imposed under a number of Acts. These arrangements are intended to provide a more equitable division of payments between industry sectors by clarifying the relative contributions of each sector.

The Regulations provide a penalty of $3,000 for a person who fails to make certain records and prepare accounts. However, there are other mandatory provisions which do not appear to attract a penalty. These provisions require the payment of levies and charges, require a person to provide information to the Secretary and require a statement to be given to a processor. The Committee has written to the Minister asking whether it was intended that there should be penalties for a breach of these provisions. In particular the Committee wishes to know whether there are penalties for failure to comply with the mandatory requirements prescribed in the Regulations for the payment of revenue owing to the Commonwealth or its instrumentalities.

The Committee appreciates that penalties may be provided elsewhere for these apparent offences, such as in the parent Act or in other Acts. If this is the position then the Committee believes that penalties should preferably be explained in a note in the instrument itself, as has been done in a number of recent instruments. At the least, such penalties should be set out in the Explanatory Statement. It may be a breach of personal liberties for delegated legislation to include offence provisions with no clear indication either on the face of the instrument or in the Explanatory Statement that a penalty exists.
CUSTOMS (PROHIBITED IMPORTS)
REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT)
STATUTORY RULES 1990 N0.460
These regulations give effect to a resolution of the Australian Police Ministers Council.

The Regulations prohibit absolutely the importation of all firearms, including copies of military style firearms, apart from certain exemptions. Some of these exemptions are expressly provided, such as recreational rifles and shotguns, which are defined in detail, and stapling guns, flare guns, tranquilliser guns and similar devices. However, with respect to handguns there are no defined exemptions. Instead, the only exemption provided is a statement in an approved form by or on behalf of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police or of the police force of a State or Territory that there is no objection to the importation by that importer of the handgun.

There are no criteria to guide and control a Commissioner in the exercise of this discretion to refuse the importation of handguns. More importantly, neither the instrument itself nor the accompanying Explanatory Statement advises whether there is a right of AAT review of an adverse decision.

The Committee appreciates that this is an important and sensitive area. Nevertheless, in any case such as the present where there is an open-ended discretion with a public official which may affect a person's livelihood, or even affect the leisure or recreation of individuals, then it is usually appropriate that external independent review is available.

In the present case there is the additional consideration that the instrument confers discretions not only on the Commissioner of the AFP, but also on State and Territory Commissioners, who are not Commonwealth officials.

In its letter to the Minister the Committee foreshadowed that it might write again on the effect of operation of the instrument. Although the formal date of effect of the regulations is the date of gazettal, there is the question of the effect on prohibited guns which may have been in transit to Australia or waiting to be unloaded at an Australian port at the date of gazettal.

SPEECH.PARA: That Regulations 5, 61, 63, 68, 71, 82, 85, 88 and 95 of the Austudy Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1990 No. 443 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish briefly to present to the Parliament the reasons for this action and why the Australian Democrats are sincerely hopeful that the coalition will join with us in this action. I will move to disallow regulations 5, 61, 63, 68, 71, 82, 85, 88 and 95 of the Austudy regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: Regulation 5 is concerned with the age limit on eligibility for Austudy. We will seek to disallow that because we believe it should be changed from 16 years to 15 years of age or starting in year 11, the relevant year of study, to remove discrepancies between the States.

Regulation 61 concerns Austudy living allowance, which is still less than the unemployment benefit for students over 21. From January 1991, regulation 63, which concerns the special rate of benefit for people who have been unemployed for six out of the last nine months and who transfer over to Austudy, will no longer apply to a married person with no children.

Regulation 68, which relates to the qualification for the independent living allowance on the basis of age, we believe should be reduced from 25 years of age to the normal legal age of adulthood, which is 18 years.

Regulation 71 concerns the qualification for the independent living allowance on the basis of periods in the work force. Presently this must be full time employment for three out of the last four years. We believe this should be decreased to two years out of the last three years.

Regulation 82 concerns the personal income test, which is currently $4,000 and includes income earned during the long vacation. We believe this should be increased and, depending on the new threshold, should exclude pay over the long vacation.

In relation to regulation 85, under the Budget changes this year a step-parent who is normally in the same house has his or her income and assets taken into account in assessing a stepchild for Austudy. It might seem logical to assume that a step-parent contributes directly or indirectly to a stepchild's study and living expenses. However, it is inappropriate to infer an imposition of that sort and, therefore, impose an obligation as a result when a step-parent does not normally have any legal or financial obligation toward the stepchild.

Regulation 88 is a parental income test of $19,300, which is far too severe compared with average earnings in Australia in August 1990 of $29,260. Regulation 95 concerns a spouse income test where the threshold has been reduced to $12,150 from the previous $18,150, which is less than the poverty line for a couple with no children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill gives effect to the Government's pledge to work towards prohibiting mining in Antarctica. On 17 August 1990 the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade announced the Government's decision to introduce legislation to ban all mining in Antarctica to the extent of Australia's legal capacity to apply such a ban. This Bill achieves that objective.

This Bill will prohibit minerals activity in the Australian Antarctic Territory, and will prohibit Australian nationals and corporations from undertaking minerals activities elsewhere in the Antarctic region. The Bill is a first key step towards achieving our objective of comprehensive and legally binding protection of the Antarctic environment.

The Antarctic environment is unique. It represents the world's greatest pristine wilderness. The processes of nature are still taking their course largely unaffected by mankind. The Antarctic is not isolated, however. It is fundamentally linked to the global environment through, for example, complex interactions in the global atmospheric and oceanic circulation. Pollutants generated elsewhere in the world are now detectable in Antarctica. The rapid growth in recent years in countries wishing to be present in Antarctica has also brought additional stresses on the environment. But these impacts are negligible compared to the potential damage that could be caused by minerals exploration and development.

Antarctica is portrayed as a harsh place. But the delicate balance of life forms show that despite Antarctica's harsh image the environment is exquisitely beautiful and fragile. The scientific work that has been done in Antarctica over many years, in which Australians have taken a lead role, show that Antarctica still has much to teach us. The Government firmly believes that Antarctica's extraordinary environmental and scientific values must not be put at risk. Thus Australia, together with France, Belgium and Italy, is asking the Antarctic Treaty parties to agree on a means for permanently protecting Antarctica by declaring it a Nature Reserve, and a Land of Science.

I am pleased to report that Australia is making progress towards its objective of securing the agreement of its Antarctic Treaty partners to a new legal instrument that will achieve effective protection of Antarctica. The recent Antarctic Treaty Special Consultative Meeting in Chile saw encouraging movement towards our objectives. A significant number of countries are now supporting the thrust of our proposals.

This Bill will assist in achieving a prohibition on all mining and related activities in Antarctica by banning mining, by Australians and nonAustralians alike, in the Australian Antarctic Territory. This is some 42% of the Antarctic continent. In addition, the legislation will prohibit Australian nationals and corporations from engaging in mining activity elsewhere in Antarctica.

The Bill recognises the need to allow for activities in support of scientific work. The legislation is targeted at commercial minerals activity and has been drafted so as not apply to scientific research and building and maintenance activities in support of scientific stations. The Government recognises the importance of Antarctica for scientific research and, for example, will not stand in the way of legitimate geological and geophysical research.

Nor does the legislation apply to foreign nationals or corporations of countries which have enacted similar legislation. The reason for this is simple: the Government is seeking to encourage other countries to put in place similar legislation binding on their nationals. It is pleasing to see that a number of other countries have already moved in this direction.

The penalties for contravention of the legislation are, in the case of an individual, a maximum of one hundred thousand dollars; and for a body corporate, five hundred thousand dollars. Offences are indictable, although provision has been made for proceedings to be heard summarily if it is proper to do so and both the defendant and prosecutor agree. In that case the maximum penalties are correspondingly reduced.

In conclusion, the Government's stand on protection of the Antarctic environment has been strongly supported by the Australian community, and I believe this legislation will be widely welcomed. I urge the Opposition to be equally firm in their support of it.
I commend the Bill to the Senate, and present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Active Citizenship Revisited.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have pleasure in tabling the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Active Citizenship Revisited. The report reviews the extent to which the recommendations of our 1989 report, Education for Active Citizenship, have been implemented, as well as raising several other issues which I will touch on shortly.

On the evidence of nearly 150 submissions received during the inquiry, it is clear that much more attention is now paid to citizenship education than was the case at the time of our previous inquiry. Some of the more formal indicators of this are the various policy and curriculum statements that have been developed by the State education departments and other school systems which identify citizenship as a particular goal. At the national level, Goal 7 of the Hobart Declaration of National Goals for Schools in Australia addresses itself to citizenship education and gives school systems the encouragement and the imprimatur to do likewise.

Although these are important developments-as I said, the Committee was impressed with a lot of the initiatives that have been taken-it is fair to say that there is still a significant gap between curriculum theory and classroom practice in this area. Good practices in the schools are dependent upon support for teachers through innovative learning materials, carefully devised teaching strategies and good in-servicing arrangements. In all these areas, there is still a lot of work to be done.

On the matter of curriculum materials, the Committee is pleased to report that the work of our Parliamentary Education Office (PEO) in the national Parliament is very highly regarded by students and teachers. We recommend, in fact, that the PEO be given even greater support by the Parliament in future to enable it to extend its important role.

Citizenship education is more than knowing how parliamentary democracy operates, and that is where a lot of the cracks start to appear. By and large, teacher education institutions are still not developing in teachers the participatory skills, the knowledge and the confidence that will enable them to go into schools and develop those same skills and attitudes in students. In the report we have tried to bring good ideas and practices to the attention of teachers so that they can translate those ideas into their own work. These are ideas about orienting young people towards their communities and getting them involved in real life public activity. They are ideas which belong across the curriculum and not just in some special subject called `active citizenship'.

We have raised the issue of learning about values and argued that this has a legitimate place in the school curriculum. It is an area that some teachers and parents have traditionally felt rather uncomfortable about. But the ability to reflect on and critically examine our values is fundamental to the way we make choices and the way in which we create our futures. Let me say again: a lot of valuable guidance about these matters in many of the school education curricula has been developed by the States. It is now a matter of applying the necessary resources and training to convert those curriculum documents into living practices in schools.

Of course, schools are not the only agencies of active citizenship education. We have highlighted quite a few initiatives which we think are worthy of replication by local governments, community organisations and professional associations. The various State parliaments are paying more attention to their educative role, though I must say that some States seem to be putting more into it than others. We have made various recommendations about the way legislatures might proceed in this area.

It is clear from the evidence that there is still a fairly strong sense of alienation in young people from the formal, institutionalised aspects of citizenship. Their knowledge of politics and parliament remains poor and there is a fair degree of cynicism about the democratic process as they see it paraded before them. It is worth noting that most of their information comes to them via the media, especially television, so if they are not getting the opportunity to participate in public and political activity in their own schools or communities, they are certainly constructing their own meanings and images of politics from what they see and hear in the media. Some of the meanings they construct, particularly about parliamentary politics and the processes of government, should be of particular concern to us as politicians.

The Committee has also commented on the role of the media in political eduction, and has expressed its concern about the focus on conflict and a limited range of key political figures at the expense of issues-based political debate, and often without giving a context and grounding for the conflict being reported. We could find very little by way of hard research evidence on how young people learn from the media and the extent to which their political understandings are affected by it. We hope that will change in the future. There is also a strong case for some kind of ongoing survey-based research on the political knowledge and attitudes of young people.

In summary, there are many excellent initiatives being taken in citizenship education and many of these have their roots in the recommendations of our 1989 report Education for Active Citizenship. There are a lot more policy pegs in place on which to hang citizenship education than there were back in 1989.

By the same token, there are still some major obstacles to overcome before we can be confident that our young people are being equipped with the skills and the attitudes to enable them to be effective, critical and creative participants in their communities. We have made 23 recommendations which have arisen out of the issues examined in this inquiry. Many of these recommendations are quite specifically targeted. We hope that the agencies to which they are directed will give them the consideration which we believe they deserve. I commend the report Active Citizenship Revisited to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday when I commenced my remarks concerning this Bill I said that the Loan Bill over the years has been a normal mechanism for allowing the proper functioning of government and it has usually gone through without much comment. I said that on this occasion I was using my speech to condemn the Government for its failure to properly manage the economy which is highlighted by the introduction of this Bill and, indeed, is reinforced by the amending motion moved by Senator Short.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has touted itself as being such a competent manager in producing a continuing number of surpluses, it has not required the mechanism of this Bill since 1987. Thus, we have seen the surplus of $8.1 billion disappear down to $1.7 billion; in all likelihood to become a nil surplus or, indeed, to go into deficit. This Bill allows the opportunity for members of this place to put on record once again the fact that this Government has badly managed the economy and, of course, planned the recession in which all Australians are suffering.

I also dealt yesterday with the Advance to the Minister for Finance and the way that its operation had changed as a result of the report of the Public Accounts Committee report which was brought down in 1988 and the Department of Finance agreeing to the recommendations that it made which, in fact, created a new category under which advances can be applied for and made. This is the category of a department or agency having erroneously omitted or understated the amount required in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1).

As one goes through looking at the various backup documents supporting an application under the Advance, I have yet to see-and somebody may correct me if I am wrong-an application come because the department or agency has erroneously omitted or understated the original bid. Yet, if one looks at the nature of many of those applications, one could find that the proper category would be that one, as distinct from the category of urgent and unforeseen-both criteria needing to be satisfied.

Yesterday, I drew attention to a further application in February for some $28m worth of advance for Export Finance Insurance Corporation (EFIC). I think I said yesterday that that amount had not been dealt with in Appropriation Bill (No. 3), but in fact it has. But the more important fact that arises concerning EFIC is that the industry statement-the so-called blueprint for some sort of recovery which at best has had a lukewarm response and has seemed, as I heard one commentator say this morning, to not only fail to win new friends but in fact alienate old friends-has indeed set aside what one could perhaps describe as a slush fund of some $200m for EFIC.

The baseline is that, very simply, it means that, on a continuing basis, the Government will not have to publish yet another application to the Advance to the Minister for Finance and have it subject to the scrutiny of the Parliament. It has had this fund put aside, which will mean that it is pushed out of scrutiny and away from public accountability. This $200m will no longer be subject to our scrutiny when they have to come cap in hand asking, on a regular basis, for additional funds.

The general signals that have been sent out by the introduction of this Bill are that we are finally seeing the death knell of this weary, and what some, indeed many, may consider this wearisome, Labor Government. It confirms the incompetent management and, indeed, looking at the broader picture, becomes a highlight focusing on the bad planning for the Budget that we saw come down in the third week of August where the Treasurer (Mr Keating) was still continuing to claim that the Government was in charge, on track and running the country in a competent way.

We saw the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer continue to make claims that the economy was being well run, until they finally had to come and say they had got it wrong, that we were in recession and, indeed, that the so-called soft landing that we were supposed to have became a very hard landing indeed, which has been illustrated and felt by ordinary Australians who are suffering bankruptcies; no longer able to keep paying their children's school fees; no longer able in some cases to buy shoes; no longer able to pay for school excursions; and, of course, are no longer able to meet mortgage payments. Ordinary Australia is hurting very badly.

All of this, of course, has resulted in well publicised internal spats within the Australian Labor Party (ALP). We have had many examples in this chamber of Keating versus Button, Hawke versus Keating, Button versus Crean, Kelly and Richardson versus Griffiths, and Walsh versus the rest of the world. Outside the Labor Party, outside this chamber, we have seen the Labor Party's new found friends or the people who claim to have put this Labor Party back into government, the greens, now totally disenchanted.

This morning there is news of a major union, which pays an affiliation fee to the Labor Party of $90,000 a year, disaffiliating and reportedly getting calls from its union members saying, `Well done! Well done!'. That union no longer wishes to be associated with this failed Government. The flirtation with business and industry has turned sour. No longer is the Treasurer anxiously sought to be consulted or heard from. No longer is there any respect for the Ministers who said that they were competent. That too has come to an end.

By trying to be everybody's mate, the Prime Minister and his team are nobody's mate. They have dragged themselves down the dangerous path of trying to appease everyone and gone into a path of cowardice and contrition, and that is even apparent with regard to our role in the Kuwait conflict. Our role at best was seen as useful because we sent our ships in early, but the international judgment is that the Labor Party was fettered by its own left wing into not making a more substantial contribution. This has meant that, in terms of being involved in the reconstruction period of Kuwait and in being considered as an important partner, we lost ground. So again, by trying to appease the left wing, by trying to be everybody's mate, the Labor Party has failed to serve Australia's interests.

I prefaced my remarks by saying that this Bill was an opportunity to again highlight the failures of the Government. John Cain in Victoria was once a much-vaunted Premier. John Cain is now totally discredited, just as this Government is discredited, simply because they are bad managers and have left the economy in tatters. John Cain used a prime pumping approach for his troubled economy. Hawke, Keating, Button and Willis have continually opened the public purse for those that the Government has been keen to appease. We saw $36m go to Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd; we saw $59.34m go to Dupont; and we saw $31m go to the tourist industry. Yet they have not succeeded in buying the support that they so desperately required, and we have not seen Australia's interests served.

For industry, the Government embarked on a program of tariff reduction; for that, we applaud it. Yet it has been at the expense of strong and sustained growth by attempting to appease its union friends, who, as I said, are now starting to show finally that they, too, are disgruntled; and one of these unions has taken the decision to disengage and disaffiliate from the ALP.

The Government has failed to deliver on the highly important question of micro-economic reform and deregulation of the labour market. Until we see those two things done, tariff cuts alone will not solve our problems. The Labor Party can never deliver in those areas because it is its own constituency and will not cannibalise it. So all the self-pleading that says that the Labor Party has a special relationship with the union movement and, therefore, is the better manager has now been proved, after eight long and hard years, to be totally and utterly wrong. It is the servant of the movement, not the guider and master of it.

The essential point now is that the Government lacks the unity, conviction and, of course, the ability to rescue the Australian economy from the recession which is the one the Treasurer told us that we had to have-the one that the Government planned, engineered and delivered to the Australian people. The election day cannot come too soon to see a change of government to give this economy and the Australian people a chance to get back on the road to recovery and to see in place sound economic policies which will allow Australia to finally and properly compete internationally and have a chance to re-establish and maintain living standards.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Loan Bill, of course, should not exist. Any government that had any competence at all would not be required to change the whole basis of its economic approach, as this one has, by being required to bring in a Loan Bill when it had boasted that the main thrust of its economic policy was to avoid having to borrow money and to maintain restraint and that it knew what it was doing. We on this side of the House have been telling the Government for quite some time that it does not know what it is doing. It gives us no comfort to be proved right in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that what one has to recognise now is that not only is this Loan Bill needed, but an economic statement was needed. It was not the economic statement we got, because this economic statement is obviously too little too late. But at least we have had a recognition by the Government that it has made a mess of things and that it has had to introduce this economic statement.
But the statement does not grasp at the heart of the real problems. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) said:

The statement will not make Australia strong again. In fact, it fails to come to grips with the reality of our economic circumstances or to have any appreciation of the magnitude of the task that has to be done in terms of boosting our national production, boosting our exports, boosting our import capabilities so that we can both eliminate inflation and bring our debt under control ultimately to reduce it.
That is import replacement capability. The other point that Dr Hewson made is as follows:

Mr Hawke has only gone as far as the union leadership will let him go. All the key areas that relate to waterfront reform, transportation reform, telecommunications reform, public sector reform, labour market reform and so on are all areas which have been effectively vetoed by the union movement.

In other words, this economic statement depends more on wishful thinking than reality. One could say that it is a bit like the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself-all wishbone and no backbone. I like Senator Walsh's comment about Mr Hawke. I think he referred to him as `Old Jellyback'. I would like to see less jelly in this economic statement and more backbone-less wishbone, more backbone. That is what is needed in this Government, but I am afraid that it has now reached the degenerative point where the bones are too brittle to carry any flesh whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not much marrow either.

—And there is not much marrow. I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. I want to deal, however, with the major disaster that is hitting young Australians as a result of this Government's economic mismanagement. In my role as shadow Minister for youth affairs, I unfortunately come across these problems. The reality of this disaster seems to have escaped this Government. The youth jobless figures are appalling. There will be more coming out today, I think at 11.30 a.m., when the labour force figures come out. As it is, according to the January statistics, an average of 25.8 per cent of young Australians throughout the nation are unable to find jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: When we look at the individual States, we find that this is a fairly uneven problem. The situation is far worse in some States than in others, and it is no coincidence that the worst States are the Labor States and the best State in terms of the lowest level of youth unemployment is the Liberal State of New South Wales. That State traditionally, no matter who is in government, has a relatively high unemployment rate.

We note from these statistics the huge gap between youth unemployment and adult unemployment. I am dealing only with the published statistics, and I will demonstrate later in my speech that the published statistics massively understate the real level of youth unemployment of young Australians in this nation. Frankly, these official statistics have been subject to statistical gimmickry and have been diminished by multimillion dollar taxpayer funded Government schemes-some of which I hope are working-to enhance the opportunities of young people and to increase their skill levels. But a lot of them, regrettably, appear to be little more than some kind of unemployed teenager sitting ventures aimed at hiding the real level of youth unemployment.

While dealing with the official statistics, let us recognise the dreadful gap that exists between youth and adult unemployment. Let us also recognise the hierarchy of disaster in young people's unemployment which starts off-I notice a colleague from Tasmania, Senator Calvert, here-with Tasmania, which has the highest unemployment rate for people looking for full time work aged between 15 and 19, those in the under-20s bracket, at 31.7 per cent. Almost one in three young Tasmanians cannot find a job.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thirty-nine per cent in Hobart.

—In the city of Hobart itself, as Senator Calvert interjects, it is 39 per cent. This sort of appalling situation is, I fear, what is to become commonplace; it is becoming commonplace around Australia. In the Illawarra region of New South Wales, where I have my office, it is about one in three-about 33 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we find that Queensland-another good Labor Government-has the next highest rate of 27.8 per cent of young Australians out of work. We have South Australia, 27.1 per cent; Western Australia, 25.5 per cent; and Victoria, 25.1 per cent. While Victoria is only the second best, after New South Wales, can I say that in Victoria that unemployment rate has just about doubled over the last 12 months, as Victoria Inc.-the Labor Government's disaster-has decimated the economic strength and jobs in that State. It has gone up from 12.7 per cent for youth unemployment in January 1990 to 25.1 per cent in January 1991. In New South Wales, where things are naturally getting worse in line with the rest of Australia, the youth unemployment rate in January was 23.4 per cent, just a slight rise from the 20.6 per cent of the previous January, but nothing like the sort of blowout, the sort of disaster, that has hit Victoria.

Then if one looks at the sort of relationship between that and adult unemployment, one sees that in Victoria, for example, the adult unemployment rate is 8.1 per cent and the youth unemployment rate is 25.1 per cent-three times as bad as for adults. Yet this Government still refuses to look at the concept of a training wage so that young people would have greater prospects of getting jobs and being trained without imposing the sort of burden on employers, who are facing severe economic difficulties, as, say, an adult worker. At the moment the wage differentials are so small that it is simply uneconomic for employers, as these figures indicate, to take on unskilled, untrained young people so that they can get a start in life when in fact their wage rates are just so close to adult wage rates and yet their productivity difference is enormous.

That is the figure as we see it now. Let us look to what the reality is. I should just mention in passing, while still dealing with the figures, that the adult figures are horrendous and getting worse. I was not trying to suggest that the adult figures with which I was comparing the youth figures were wonderful. Even though the youth figures are three times as bad, the adult figures are terrible. As the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) pointed out only the other day, there are now 24 people competing for every available job. This is a long way from the 7 : 1 ratio that was recorded less than two years ago. This is because there are something like three-quarters of a million jobless and an estimated 31,000 job vacancies. That situation is, of course, disastrous.

Let us look at how even more serious the youth unemployment figures are when you examine them closely. As I mentioned, this combination of statistical gimmickry and multi-million dollar taxpayer funded schemes and the disappearance of tens of thousands of 15- to 19-year-olds from the official statistics really means that the actual level of youth unemployment could be as much as 50 per cent worse than the current horrific under-20-year-old jobless rate of more than one in four. The January 1990-91 labour force statistics reveal the loss of 84,000 full time jobs for 15- to 19-year-olds over the past 12 months. This, of course, leaves the full time unemployment rate at 25.8 per cent, which is the worst January level for six years anyway.

At this stage I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a set of statistics based on Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the unemployment rate in Australia for persons aged between 15 and 19, the number of unemployed persons and the number of employed persons in that category, along with a table showing the 15- to 19-year-old job scene.

TALK.START.PARA: —These statistics reveal that on top of these full time jobs that have just disappeared, have been lost, over the last 12 months as the number of young people employed full time has collapsed from 471,000 to 387,000, a further 23,600 part time jobs were wiped out, giving a total job loss for the year of 107,200. Those jobs for young people existed in January 1990 but do not exist today. But even though 107,000 jobs were lost, the figure for the people unemployed rose only by 42,800. This is less than half the number of jobs lost. What happened to the remaining 64,400 young Australians whose jobs were wiped out? Most of them-almost 40,000-just disappeared out of the work force, with the remaining 25,400 accounted for by a reduction in the 15- to 19-year-old population. A proportion of that extraordinary number of 64,000 who disappeared can be explained by a change in the population, but the great bulk is unexplained.

SPEECH.PARA: Although these `disappearers' have not been able to get jobs, they have not been included in the unemployment figures as a combination of a statistical gimmick and Hawke Government multi-million dollar schemes combined to push the potentially unemployed out of sight. As a result of this, the participation rate-that is, the percentage of youth population in the work force, either in or looking for a job-has dramatically fallen in the latest year. I have never seen such a fall in the participation rate. It has fallen from 66.1 per cent to a lowest ever January figure of 62.7 per cent.

These latest disappearing jobless figures continue a trend that was reinforced in 1986 when the Hawke Government not only began paying Austudy to secondary students to encourage them to stay at school rather than joining dole queues but also changed the definition of being unemployed-listen to this definition-so that an unpaid family helper working only one hour a week is no longer classified as being unemployed. All a person has to do is work for one hour a week in a corner store or on a farm and get no pay and, according to these statistics, the person is not included in the unemployment list. This is just a farce.

It certainly had an impact. In the five years since then the result has been that an increase in the 15- to 19-year-old population of 53,400 has added only 4,000 young people to the work force; the remaining 49,400 have just disappeared from the employment-or more likely the unemployment-figures. Paying Austudy to more than 150,000 secondary students aged 15 to 19 now costs more than $300m a year and is clearly aimed at removing some of the unemployment problem into the classroom. For some it will bring greater educational opportunities and broaden their options. To that extent, there is clearly a benefit. For others it is little more than an expensive teen-sitting exercise that fiddles the jobless figures as young Australians who would rather be working for a wage get paid simply to fill in time at school.

There is also a huge number of under-employed young people, whose only opportunity to work is part time as the number of full time jobs available for 15- to 19-year-olds has collapsed. It is now far harder for young Australians to get a full time job than it was in recession-hit 1983, as the number of under-20s in full time work has slumped by 77,000 since 1983 to only 387,000.

We keep on hearing about the Fraser Government's recession; how terrible it was; how it was as a result of the Fraser Government's incompetence. We never hear anything about the worst drought in 50 years. But right now there are 77,000 fewer young people employed in this country than in the 1983 recession despite the big increase in the population of 15- to 19-year-olds. We do not hear that sort of statistic from this Government. In fact, this statistic is despite a rise of almost 100,000 in the 15- to 19-year-old population, three quarters of whom have not even bothered to join the work force which rose during this period from 1983 by only 24,300. There are now 861,300 young Australians wanting to work but only 387,000 full time jobs for them. As a result, eight years of hard Labor has meant that the number making do with part time jobs has soared from 156,400, or 25 per cent of the job market, to 277,400 or 42 per cent. They cannot get full time jobs so they have to make do-those that have been lucky enough-with part time jobs. Yet the official statistics, which show the full time 15- to 19-year-old unemployment rate of 25.8 per cent, which is still a little below the January 1983 level of 29 per cent, do not tell the real story of the hidden army of unemployed young Australians that lifts the real unemployment level of 1991 far above the drought-affected recession of 1983. Yet it was Mr Hawke, who, when dealing with Australia's problems, then said that there was:

. . . none worse than the disastrous unemployment situation, particularly that facing young Australians . . . Levels of unemployment anything like those of the past couple of years cannot and should not be tolerated . . . No Australian Government should ever be forgiven for creating . . .

Yet the Hawke Government has created them, and not because of the century's worst drought, as in 1983, or a world recession or an oil shock, but almost entirely through its own mismanagement of the boom and bust economy it fostered. The Hawke Government, in Mr Hawke's own words, `should never be forgiven' for the blight of worsening unemployment, both evident and hidden, that it is imposing on young Australians. What will it do about it?

TALK.START.PARA: —No child will live in poverty.

—As Senator Calvert says, no child will live in poverty. I suppose the way to ensure that is to bring about greater population control. That is the only way that this Government can ensure no child poverty.

SPEECH.PARA: But what is the Government doing about youth unemployment? It is doing a little lateral thinking. During the next three years it will spend $15m to boost lagging school retention rates in rural areas. To the extent that encouraging young people to go to school increases their job options, their job opportunities and their skill levels in the long run, it is marvellous. But it is interesting-the Government thinks that moving young people out of the labour market is the only way to resolve this problem.

After all, the Government has managed to fiddle the figures for the last five years by doing it, so why not try it now? It is $15m to encourage young people in rural areas to stay at school. I think it was Mr Dawkins who noted in his statement that although educational authorities have achieved success in recent years in raising retention rates, particularly in the crucial Year 12 level, country schools are still experiencing problems retaining students. The national discrepancy between urban and rural retention rates is about 5 per cent. In some country areas of New South Wales the gap is even wider.

I will tell the Senate what the Austudy situation now is. As I said, Austudy was introduced in 1986. Austudy is available, subject to certain academic criteria, to fulltime secondary students aged 16 years and over undertaking an approved secondary course. Assistance is targeted to low income groups through income and assets tests applying to the students and, for dependent students, to parents as well. In other words, quite properly this assistance is aimed at lower income groups, the very area from which the highest level of unemployment among young people is likely to emerge. We can see that from the regional unemployment statistics. Clearly, the target of such a program is those young people who would be more likely to be joining the unemployment pool. As I said, while I welcome the fact that some of them may receive clear benefit as a result of this change, others may not.

According to the Budget Papers, altogether it is estimated that, in 1991, 36 per cent of secondary students aged 16 years and over will be assisted by Austudy. It is interesting to look at that figure because the retention rate has just about doubled. It used to be that about 35 per cent of students would stay at school for Year 12. I believe it is now 60-odd per cent. It is interesting to query whether Austudy for secondary school students has in fact been such a factor in their retention.

However, the clear impression from the Government's response in the statement on lagging retention rates in rural areas is that it sees Austudy as a way of doctoring the unemployment figures. There has been a trend, evident for something like 10 years, toward a reduction in youth employment and, as a result, a change in the figures. I am not suggesting that this trend has suddenly emerged, because it has been there for 10 years. What I am saying is that the huge acceleration in job loss among young people in the last 12 months is a condemnation of this Government's policies, is clear evidence of its incompetence, of its lack of direction and of its having created an atmosphere of hopelessness among young people about what lies before them.

I suggest to people that, when they are looking at the unemployment figures and saying to themselves, `Well, the unemployment rate does not look as bad as it did back in 1983', the reality is far worse. The outlook for young people is dreadful. What young people desperately need is a government with a sense of vision, with a sense of purpose and with the policies to turn the economy around to give them a fair go, a real opportunity to develop their skills and to be useful contributors in the workplace. This Government has provided them with nothing apart from gimmicks and schemes. It has provided them with little hope.

I certainly hope that the widespread concern about the Government's capacity, expressed following the March statement, will ultimately be translated into a massive rejection of the Government at the polls so that a government under John Hewson, which knows what it is doing, which has a sense of direction and purpose and which has the capacity to take hard and proper decisions, will replace this present dreadful, directionless government.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, the March statement is like Mr Hawke-all wishbone, no backbone. I hope that we will get a change of direction, a change for the better; a genuine change in economic approach which will in fact restore hope and restore the prospect of employment to the hundreds of thousands of young Australians who, under this Government, face a bleak future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up, I should say that there would be little point in replying to the somewhat colourful rhetoric used by Senator Michael Baume. This Bill is simply to authorise the issue of moneys from the Loan Fund to cover any shortfall from consolidated revenue. I do not think there is any big deal about that. It is quite normal. It has been done by governments for years. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
