DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SELECTION OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the fifth report of 1991 of the Standing Committee for the Selection of Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the report incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The report read as follows-
The Selection of Bills Committee reports that it has considered the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill 1991 and recommends that the Bill not be referred to a committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill has the support of the Opposition, which is not surprising because, in fact, the Government has simply followed the Opposition's policy concerning the Antarctic. We led the way in this matter. The main features of Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill 1991, which was introduced into the House of Representatives on 6 March 1991, are to prohibit mining and related activities in the Australian Antarctic Territory and to prohibit such activities by Australian nationals and corporations anywhere in Antarctica.

SPEECH.PARA: The principal features are that mining activity by Australians anywhere in Antarctica will be prohibited. Mining activities in the Australian Antarctic Territory will be prohibited. Mining activity will be given a wide definition to include any activity, such as prospecting and exploration, which could lead to the recovery of minerals. An exemption is made for scientific research and investigation and any activities supporting or associated with such activity.

The Australian Antarctic Territory has been defined to include the adjacent continental shelf. In this area mining by any persons or companies is to be prohibited with two exceptions: persons who are excluded by the Antarctic Treaty-designated observers or scientific personnel exchanged under the provisions of the treaty-will not come within the scope of this legislation unless their acts cannot be regarded as legitimate for the purposes of the treaty; and persons who are exempted from the operation of the legislation if they are nationals of a country which has enacted similar legislation. The maximum penalty provided is $100,000 but, if dealt with summarily, the penalty reduces to $10,000 for an individual and $50,000 for a corporation. That, I might say, was a problem which did concern us in the House of Representatives.
When dealing with this matter only yesterday, Mr Chaney said:

. . . we are dealing with the issue of mining, and if it did take place-there has even been talk of the possibility of subsidised mining activities in the Antarctic by people anxious to establish some position-the sort of penalty that is laid down might be regarded as a mere flea bite. When compared with penalties in the Trades Practices Act for other offences it is comparatively light. I would like the Government's considered view on the adequacy of penalties so that we can consider that view and perhaps look to moving amendments in the other House.

In fact, we will not be moving amendments here. Just before I rose to speak Mr Chaney received a letter from Mrs Kelly, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, in these terms:
I am responding to your request for further information on the penalties provided for in the Antarctic Mining Bill.

Clauses 6 and 7 of the Bill provided for a maximum penalty of $100,000 for offences against these provisions. Due to the operations of the Crimes Act 1914 this is an amount of $500,000 if the offender is a corporation.

The penalties were established following consideration of similar offences in other legislation and the amount has been set at this level on the basis that the Great Barrier Marine Park Act 1975 provides for a penalty of $50,000 if the offender is an individual ($250,000 for a corporation). The trend in environmental legislation is to impose higher penalties and the penalty in the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill reflects this.
You should also appreciate that the offence is indictable and the Proceeds of Crime Act (1987) operates so that the court can order profits to be forfeited and/or additional pecuniary penalty orders.

Clause 8 provides for minor offences to be dealt with in a court of summary jurisdiction if it is proper to do so and both the defendant and the prosecutor consent to this. A lower penalty reflects the fact that this will occur in circumstances where the offence is of a minor nature. However, it is still indictable so that the Proceeds of Crime Act is applicable.
I have confirmed this advice with the Attorney-General's Department.
On that basis, the Opposition will not proceed with its foreshadowed amendments in this area.

I want to mention a bit of the background to this legislation. The coalition has taken a very high profile against any form of mining in Antarctica. We were ahead of the Government when it was divided over whether or not to sign the proposed Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. Mr Keating was reported to be opposed to signing, but Senators Richardson and Evans leaned the other way. On 2 May 1989, almost two years ago, the coalition formally decided to oppose Australia's signing the convention and called on the Government to take immediate action to seek an international regime providing for a total prohibition on mining in the Antarctic. The next day, former Senator Chris Puplick successfully moved in the Senate a motion which included the following points:
the Antarctic continent should be protected as fully as possible from threats to its unique environment
it is incompatible with the above to allow any mining activity to take place in the Antarctic

Three weeks later, under increasing political pressure, the Government at last said it would not sign. The Opposition's current environment policy expresses strong support for the Antarctic Treaty as providing the most effective method for the control and protection of the Antarctic environment, and opposes any attempt to alter substantially the provisions of the Antarctic Treaty. The policy also reaffirms our opposition to signing the minerals regime. We have opposed the world park concept floated in some quarters, preferring instead what we have called an Antarctic Treaty park operating within the framework of the treaty and involving no abrogation of claims of sovereignty.

Australia has obtained the support of France in its opposition to mining. The most recent international development was a meeting in Chile in December last year of the Antarctic Treaty parties. Mrs Kelly and Senator Evans hailed the outcome of that meeting as a major step towards an international ban on mining in Antarctica. The meeting agreed to a draft negotiating text for the development of a legal instrument to protect the environment. That text provides that any activity relating to mineral resources, other than for scientific research, would be prohibited. The Ministers concede that a long and difficult period of negotiation lies ahead.

There is no doubt that the aim of this Bill is clearly to strengthen Australia's moral position in terms of its campaign to achieve a mining ban-a position, I might say, that the Government came to belatedly after what has clearly been a large amount of division within its ranks. It is essentially an exercise in setting an example demonstrating Australia's willingness to take as much action as lies within its power to do what it wants the rest of the world to accept.

There would be considerable difficulties in enforcing the proposed ban on mining activities by other nations in Australia's claimed territory, which covers about 40 per cent of the Antarctic continent, and we should recognise that. While there is cooperation between the treaty countries and territorial claims, other nations do not recognise those claims, and effective action against transgressions by foreign nationals would inevitably be a long and difficult process. Against this, the mounting of any exploration or mining activity in the Antarctic is a very difficult undertaking, and any such activity is said to be easily detectable. The Government announced in August last year that it would legislate to ban mining. Senator Chaney, as he was at the time, issued a statement, after consultation with Senator Hill, welcoming any effective action that would further protect the Antarctic environment.

As I said, the Opposition supports this Bill. I mention in passing that Mr Chaney in the other place commended a speech given by the Australian Ambassador for the Environment, Sir Ninian Stephen, on 24 October last year which is reported in the monthly Record. It sets out at some length the possible environmental consequences of mining activity. Unfortunately, the Ambassador's speech omits in his chronology of events the Opposition's stance on this matter, which we in the Opposition are quite sure was very important in terms of the Government's own decision making. The Government, in my view, would not have come to this decision without the strong public view expressed by the Opposition of total opposition to mining in the Antarctic.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will probably come as no surprise to anyone that the Australian Democrats fully support the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill 1991. We are very encouraged by the Opposition's support for the Bill also, although we share some of its concerns about the size of fines. Having listened to Senator Baume, I think we agree that there are good reasons at the moment at least for the size of those fines.

SPEECH.PARA: Australian legislation to prohibit all mining in Antarctica is, of course, only the very first part of what we hope will be an eventual decision by international agreement for the establishment of a world park over the entire continent. The Democrats welcome the Australian Government's decision in May 1989 to reject the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities and work instead for an Antarctic wilderness park. We acknowledge that we were surprised, but very pleased, that the Opposition also took that stand and, in fact, took it a little before the Government did. We have been taking that stand for a long time.

That resolution and this Bill represent important decisions in Australian Government policy towards Antarctica-decisions which we have long advocated, which we now support and which we feel demonstrate to the world that Australia is serious about protecting the Antarctic environment. The uniqueness of Antarctica lies in the fact that the Antarctic region of the world encompasses a huge wilderness which remains substantially unaffected by human activity. It is, in fact, the only continent on which human impact has been minimal.

Millions of people around the world already believe that Antarctica and its surrounding seas should remain the world's greatest wilderness area, protected from mining and preserved for the benefit of future generations. Antarctica and its surrounding seas hold a unique place in the history of the world. Rich in animal and marine plant life, the region provides an opportunity for scientists and the world to better understand the extraordinary ecosystem that makes up the continent. Until recently, of course, it appeared likely that Antarctica would be treated with the same indifference as the rest of the world and be made available for mining.

The Democrats are very pleased that the Australian Government's opposition to mining appears to have stopped the Antarctic Minerals Convention so far in its tracks. Without the support of countries such as Australia, France and New Zealand, the existing Minerals Convention cannot hope to become international law. Nevertheless, as the recent meeting of Antarctic Treaty nations in Chile last December showed, it will not be easy to achieve the international agreement needed to completely rule out mining in Antarctica. I understand that there are still deep divisions among the Antarctic Treaty nations over a permanent ban on mining.

Despite the support Australia and France have gathered for their proposals, a small number of countries, including Britain and the United States, remain opposed to a mining ban. We suspect that, ultimately, the outcome of these negotiations will depend a good deal on the strength of international public support for the idea of preserving the Antarctic environment and for the world park concept. A loss on this issue, where the case for environmental protection is so powerful, would be seen as a major setback for the environment generally and, of course, for Antarctica in particular. Regardless of that outcome, we believe that the moratorium on mining activity in Antarctica which has existed since 1977 must be allowed to continue.

At present, treaty members are exercising voluntary restraint on mining activity on the continent until the current consultations on the mining convention are completed. Pro-mining members, including the United States, Britain and Japan, have unfortunately in the past used the threat of ending their voluntary restraint in order to force discussions on mining to their advantage. Obviously such a tactic is unacceptable and should occasion strong international condemnation. Here, the support of other claimant states, such as France and New Zealand, is crucial because, like Australia, they too have the capacity to prevent mining in the areas they claim in much the same way as this Bill seeks to do.

However, as I said earlier, the Democrats hope that, ultimately, the world will not just place a permanent and longstanding ban on mining in Antarctica, but will eventually embrace the concept of a wilderness park for the entire continent. A permanent international ban on mining is an important step forward, but an Antarctic wilderness park would take the matter further by recognising the importance of the area for conservation and for important scientific research.

Only this week, six Australian scientists completed a 5,000-kilometre crossing of previously unexplored regions of Antarctica. The team, led by Australian glaciologist, Dr Robert Kiernan, managed to collect information on ice sheet movement, snow accumulation and atmospheric conditions around Lambert Glacier, which is the world's largest glacier. This sort of information is important in assessing changes to the region's climate over hundreds of years and for better understanding the present changes in the earth's climate.

Therefore, in view of the information which such scientific research can provide, and given the fact that recent international attention has been focused on the greenhouse effect and the problem of global warming, one can easily understand why Antarctica should be protected from all mining activity. Naturally, the establishment of an international wilderness park for Antarctica would offer increased protection and give the continent a status equivalent to that of national parks in many countries, including Australia. Such a declaration would be a legal instrument to establish the absolute priority of nature conservation of Antarctica while continuing to allow compatible uses, such as science and some very controlled tourism.

Antarctica's unique qualities are its wildlife, its ice scenery and its wilderness. By emphasising the maintenance of the wilderness condition, all of these qualities can be protected. The fact is that there will never be another Antarctica. If we choose to save it, then it will become a living reminder of human ability to preserve our past, present and future, and to live in harmony with our environment. A ban on mining provided by this Bill is a very welcome and important part of a total strategy to protect the Antarctic environment forever.

The Democrats hope this legislative move will gather widespread international support, particularly from the other Antarctic Treaty nations. It is recognition of the fact that Antarctica is an area of heritage which must be protected and saved for ongoing generations for all time. On this basis, we give it our full support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the two previous speakers have stated, the principal feature of the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill 1991 is to prohibit mining and related activities in the Australian Antarctic territory and to prohibit such activities by Australian nationals and corporations anywhere in Antarctica. As a result, mining activity by Australians anywhere in Antarctica will be prohibited. In addition, the activity of mining per se in the Australian Antarctic territory will also be prohibited.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Bill's guidelines, the definition of a mining activity will be given a broad recognition so as to include any activity, such as prospecting and exploration, which could lead to the recovery of minerals. However, an exception is made for scientific research and investigation and any activity which may be supporting or associated with such research.

The Antarctic continent has been described as the world's last great wilderness. This has been referred to by Senator Bourne. It is certainly the highest, oldest, windiest continent on earth and its relative isolation has afforded it a unique opportunity to survive in an almost pristine environment. I think that Mr Gary Nehl and Mr Jim Snow-one of Senator Richardson's colleagues-in the other place could attest to the wilderness and wildness of the place. They have just returned from their voyage on the Icebird, which I believe was probably one of the worst they have ever experienced.

Honourable senators may be interested to know that ice covers 98 per cent of the continent and that most of that coverage is between 4,000 feet and 6,000 feet thick. It is also amazing to realise that Antarctica doubles in size and then halves again each year. It represents one of the most breathtaking and yet the most hostile environments on our earth. Within that environment, it encompasses a diverse range of wildlife ranging from blue whales, seals, penguins, krill and birds to a wide array of plant life such as mosses, lichens and algae. The food chain of the Antarctic is particularly fragile and the cold temperature and salty soils mean that the birds and seals rely on the rich resources of the ocean for their food.

Australia has always played a very important role in the Antarctic. We maintain three permanent bases at Casey, Davis and Mawson. A further permanent station is located on Macquarie Island and four temporary summer bases are located in the Larsemann Hills, the Bunger Hills, on Heard Island and at Commonwealth Bay. It is important to remember that Australia claims almost 42 per cent of the Antarctic continent. That claim was reasserted in the provisions of the Antarctic Treaty Act 1960. The total area of our claim is approximately 6.1 million square kilometres. Eventually, the vast size and isolated nature of Antarctica posed the question as to the possibility of it containing mineral resources. As a result, the early 1970s saw the first international discussions regarding the possible consequences of exploitation of Antarctic resources.

At the same time, it should be acknowledged that our understanding of Antarctica's mineral and hydrocarbon potential is limited. The vast expanses of ice cover and the extremes of temperature make assessment difficult. What information there is appears to suggest that minerals of value do exist in the region, both on the continent and in surrounding waters. To date, traces of cobalt, promium, nickel, titanium, uranium, silver, gold, coal and iron have been located, but the quantities of such deposits have been very limited.

In 1985 a United States government report stated that the likely recoverable reserve of oil in promised offshore areas could be in the order of tens of billions of barrels. Previously, a Gulf oil executive had placed on the record his company's views that the two most promising areas in the Ross and Weddell seas were in the range of 50 million barrels, but could be much more.

In the early 1970s, Soviet geologists predicted that the oil resources of Antarctica would exceed those of Alaska. Of concern, of course, is the fact that several nations have made no secret of their interest in Antarctica's mineral resources. The Soviets established Druzhnaya station in the Weddell Sea in 1975 as the first base in the region particularly set aside for mineral prospecting. The Japanese conducted a 3-year survey in 1988 and West Germany, Norway and the United States have undertaken seismic surveys with a view to ascertaining mineral potential. Whilst Antarctica's isolation acted as a barrier, technological advances and an increasing presence of scientists on the Antarctic continent have rekindled the debate regarding mining in the region.

I should make it quite clear at this point that the coalition's position in regard to Antarctic mining has been unequivocal. This compares with the Government's position which has involved much posturing by various Ministers and caused considerable disquiet in the community. It is fair to say that the Government has repeatedly followed the Opposition's lead in relation to Antarctic mining and, in fact, the banning of it. The Opposition believes the area must be protected for the future and that any mining presents a threat to the fragile environment.

One only needs to consider the tragic consequences of the Exxon Valdez accident to appreciate man's total inability to regulate his activities. As tragic as the consequences of the Exxon Valdez accident were, and as much as the company concerned has been prepared to allocate millions of dollars to clear up the problem-and that is not to mention the fines that we heard on the news this morning of billions of dollars-the catastrophe of the situation in the Antarctic, should such an incident occur, would be multiplied many, many times over. Not only would the consequences be much worse, but the chances of restoring the situation would be virtually impossible.

There is some background to the Mining Prohibition Bill which I believe warrants considerable attention by the Senate. In June of 1988 the Convention of the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities, known as CRAMRA, was adopted by the Antarctic Treaty consultative parties. The aim of CRAMRA was to provide a mechanism for assessing the impact on the Antarctic environment of mining activities to decide whether they were acceptable and, if so, to regulate those activities.

Between 25 November 1988 and 25 November 1989, the 16 countries involved in the consultative process were invited to sign the convention. By May 1989, only Australia and France had signed. For the convention to come into effect, it required the signatures of all member countries. This situation resulted in a period of public debate within our country and whilst the Government was trying to decide its position, the then shadow Minister for the Environment, Senator Puplick, made the Opposition's position very clear.

On 2 May 1989, the coalition formally decided to oppose the signing of the convention and, at the same time, called upon the Government to take action for a total prohibition of mining in the Antarctic. On 3 May, Senator Puplick successfully moved in this place, with the support of the Australian Democrats and I believe Senator Vallentine, a motion which sought to ensure that the Antarctic continent remained fully protected from any possible threat to its unique environment. That motion reaffirmed the belief that it was incompatible to allow any mining activity in Antarctica.

It is fair to say, though, that while this was occurring, the Government vacillated. It became apparent that there were certain divisions between the then Environment Minister, Senator Richardson-who is at the table-and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, who was openly canvassing the view that Australia should sign the convention. At the same time, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, and the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, were offering a very different view even to the point of suggesting a world park for the region.

The matter became further complicated for the Government when on 14 April the then Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business, Mr Jones, expressed support for the development of the CRAMRA regime. The Opposition held the view that there were significant deficiencies in the CRAMRA; that the guidelines were far too loose; and that the convention, as it had been drawn up, effectively encouraged and facilitated mining activity to take place in Antarctica.

It is significant that some three weeks after the Senate had passed the Opposition's motion, the Government also announced that it would not be signing the agreement and that, as a result, the agreement would not come into place. I believe the point which best emerges from the events which occurred in May of 1989 is that despite what the Government may choose to say to the contrary, it is clearly being left behind by the Opposition in terms of recognising the worth of the Antarctic region.

Following the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 22 May 1989 that the Government would not sign the CRAMRA, and following what will undoubtedly be the successful passage of this legislation through the Parliament, Australia will be in a creditable position to take our views on the prohibition of mining in Antarctica to the rest of the world. With this commitment behind us, Australia can seek to ensure that other Antarctic nations provide a similar commitment for the areas which they have under their control. I know that this view is also shared by France.

I am also aware that there have been some preliminary discussions between Antarctic Treaty parties on the negotiation of an instrument which would set up a regime for a comprehensive Antarctic environmental protection. As I understand it, there has already been a number of points of agreement as to what such an instrument should contain. It appears that there is general agreement that human activities in Antarctica should be planned and conducted with a view to limiting the impact on our environment, and that such activities should only be on the basis that there is sufficient information to enable informed judgments to be made about the impact on the region.

I would like to congratulate the present management of the Antarctic Division for the wonderful work it has done over recent times in cleaning up the Antarctic. In fact, Senator Puplick and myself viewed a load of garbage and old rubbish that had been brought back from the Antarctic a couple of years ago down in Hobart on the Lady Franklin. I know it is a very important part of the Antarctic Division at the moment to clear up the wreckage that has been left behind from many parties that have gone there over the years.

Unfortunately, there have been a couple of oil spills in the Antarctic, which I have mentioned before. I place on the record once more that I hope such oil spills do not occur again. The Antarctic Treaty consultative parties have now recommended that a special meeting be convened to further discuss the issue of mining. The joint efforts of Australia and France have already been successful in attracting the support of New Zealand, Belgium and Italy. It is also well-known that other nations such as India and Germany are sympathetic.

Regrettably, however, I understand that to date there has been no agreement between the Antarctic Treaty partners as to whether the proposed international instrument should ban mining. I know that I safely speak on behalf of the Opposition when I say that the Government can rely on bipartisan support for whatever measures it may believe are necessary to obtain international support for Australia's position. The importance of this Bill passing through our Parliament must not be lost to the general international community and I believe that every avenue should be explored to promote Australia's views.

I referred earlier to a number of misconceptions which have been deliberately supported by this Government in relation to the coalition's record on the environment. I have no doubt that the Government's desire to discredit the Opposition through its contacts in the media and its own propaganda organisation, the National Media Liaison Service, has been motivated purely by reasons of electoral expediency.

The Government has sought to present itself as the unquestioned protector of the environment and the Opposition as a group with no such concerns. This most definitely has never been the case and never will be the case. If we need any better example of the Government's environmental hypocrisy, we need only to refer to the economic statement which occurred earlier this week. Those who were promised no resource security legislation have been left wallowing as the Government realises that commonsense must prevail at the end of the day.

There is a very valid argument for maintaining our environment for the future. Indeed, contrary to what the Government may suggest, many of those reasons are economic. No industry deliberately sets out to destroy its own livelihood, and I think it is fair to say that over recent years, with the excellent work which has been done by the member for Pearce, Fred Chaney, our shadow Minister for the environment and his predecessor from this chamber, Senator Chris Puplick, that both the public and the conservation groups are starting to realise that it is the Opposition which has now taken a clear lead on environmental matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I haven't met anyone in that category yet.
—The Minister ought to go out and talk to a few of them. He is now in Social Security anyway, so he has lost track of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in this speech, I referred to the lead given by the Opposition on mining in the Antarctic, and the Government cannot deny that. But the coalition's record on the environment goes much deeper and, to me, one of the most important aspects of the success which previous coalition governments have achieved is that it has been achieved without drastic State-Federal conflicts. It is on the record that coalition governments have worked with State governments to achieve very meaningful objectives in the environmental arena.

We can look back with due pride at our record during our periods in government and I instance the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. It was the coalition which initially proclaimed this area as a park, recognising its importance to our country and to the rest of the world.

It was a coalition government which moved to prohibit sand mining on Fraser Island and it was a coalition government which proclaimed the Kakadu and Uluru parks. The Christmas Island National Park and the many marine nature reserves, which were established under the Coral Sea proclamation, all owe their origins to previous coalition governments. In addition, it was a coalition government which secured the listing of the Willandra Lakes and it was a coalition government which originated the proposals for the listing of the Lord Howe Island group and the Western Tasmanian Wilderness Park in 1982. As a member of the coalition, I am proud of our environmental record and I am prepared to put that record up against the temporary political expediency of this Government at any time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The trouble is that Australia just didn't agree with you.

—In 1989 it was the coalition which first targeted the reduction of greenhouse gases as being a matter of priority. In my own State of Tasmania it was a Liberal government with Robin Gray as Premier and Peter Hodgman as the Minister that first brought in legislation to achieve that aim. I would ask those present to compare this with the headline-grabbing of the present Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) who, rather than tackling the issues by legislation, seeks to make her contribution by purportedly downgrading her ministerial vehicle only to find that the savings which she announced will not occur.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one particular aspect of the coalition's environment policy which I would like the Government consider, and that is our belief that there should be a massive national approach to the issue of soil degradation. The coalition went into the last election with a program which would have seen the amount of money allocated to soil degradation doubled. I acknowledge though that the Government has increased funding in this area but the fact remains that the increase pales into insignificance compared to that suggested by us at the last election.

Only yesterday, I read in the Australian a very disturbing article on the problem of salinity, which is devastating the Murray-Darling Basin. Some senators may not be aware that the Lowbidgee is eastern Australia's most significant wetland. It is the inland sea which was sought by the early explorer, Oxley. Salinity is devastating this area. In fact, the small Victorian community of Kerang has already been destroyed. The area is becoming a testimony to man's desire to change the environment rather than to live with it. The consequences are disastrous. This is the most important breeding area of native water birds in eastern Australia, but large scale clearing and irrigation systems have changed the natural balance. These are the sorts of issues which this Government should be addressing.

Another area of some concern is the tropical forests and their survival. This is another area where the Government could well learn from the coalition. I understand that our present shadow Minister has already had discussions overseas with our Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) neighbours and that they are keen for Australia to become a member of a regional initiative to address the problem of dwindling tropical forests. I commend this initiative by our shadow Minister for the environment, the honourable member for Pearce.
In conclusion, I trust that we may reach a situation where the Government is prepared to accept that the Opposition is ready to play its part in the environmental future of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is good indeed to be able to support this environmental legislation put forward by the Government, especially as the Opposition and the Australian Democrats are supporting it. It is nice to have bipartisanship on this important issue because it is an issue which is beyond party politics. So I am not going to say too much on the comments that Senator Calvert made about the Opposition's record as opposed to the Government's record, but suffice to say that the Greens of Western Australia (WA) certainly support the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill, which of course follows on in a very logical way from the Government's rejection of the Convention for the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activity (CRAMRA) agreement in May 1989. I would point out though that I well remember, as Senator Calvert documented, that it was the Opposition, encouraged by environment groups, that really gave the Government the nudge on that occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: It was also good at that time to be working with France, with whom we have many environmental disagreements, particularly over the question of nuclear testing in the South Pacific. But here we are able to work with France and, of course, New Zealand came to this particular party as well, and this is all very good for Antarctica, which is for the world to enjoy not just the countries close to it.

So I should like to commend the Bill both for prohibiting mining in the Australian Antarctic territory, for the prohibition of mining by Australian nationals and corporations in any part of Antarctica and for the very clear signal that this gives to the rest of the world that Australia is serious about its intention to pursue adequate protection of Antarctica. It is certainly a very clear message to some of the countries already mentioned that are proponents of mining in Antarctica, like the United Kingdom, the United States and Japan. We need to send them that very clear message through this national legislation as well as through the work that is done in international meetings on this subject. So I should like to encourage the Government to maintain its support for a comprehensive agreement on environmental protection for Antarctica, the prohibition of mining activity being just one aspect of that.

My only concern with this Bill is that it may still see some forms of mining exploration continue under the guise of scientific research. There is a place for genuine research, but too much seems to be motivated by the prospect of commercial gain. This Bill, and Australia's continued efforts to gain comprehensive protection for the Antarctic environment, should help ensure Antarctica retains its wilderness qualities and is valued for that, rather than being seen as a resource to be exploited.

John Burgess, the Assistant Secretary for the Environment and the Antarctic in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, said just before the Chile meeting of the Antarctic treaty nations last year that the most immediate threat to Antarctica is from the effects of scientific bases and tourism. This is why Australia needs to be resolute in pursuing the protection of Antarctica, not just on the question of mining.

Unfortunately, Casey Station is one of the several bases in the Antarctic which has experienced an oil spill. The potential for environmental problems increases with the proliferation of bases, many of which are there largely for a political stake in Antarctica's future as well as those of course that are genuinely conducting scientific research. A large question mark still hangs over the prospective tourism developments, which should be subjected to very limited access under stringent guidelines if allowed at all.

The main strength of this Bill is the recognition that there are some areas on planet earth that are too significant and too fragile to be put at risk by the exploitative mentality. There is a global responsibility to protect such areas, and I am glad that Australia is playing a prominent role in that attempt to protect these very fragile areas of which there are too few left. In fact, it could be argued that the Antarctic is the only real wilderness area left available for the global community to work together to protect.

I look forward to the day when similar protection is afforded to all areas of global environmental significance. The protection of Australia's national parks and nature reserves would be a good starting point. This is where I need to say something about the Government on those issues, and it is especially relevant with the decision about to be made on mining at Coronation Hill in the Kakadu National Park and World Heritage area. We are in the run-up now to the next very important environmental decision to be made in the national context. Considering the debacle that we have seen with Cabinet divided over the resource security legislation and the complete sell-out that that is quite rightly judged to be, it will be very interesting indeed to see whether the Government is prepared to afford to our own special areas of environmental significance within Australia the same kind of importance that it is prepared to attach to Antarctica.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —In summing up what has been occurring here during the last 45 minutes or so, it is pleasing to note that a Bill on the environment can at least be going through with bipartisan support. It is a comparatively rare event--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —There are more than two, I agree: with all parties supporting it. I stand corrected. It is pleasing that this is not a matter of controversy, nor should it be. For those who attempt to score points looking at what people have previously said on this, in terms of whether to sign mining conventions or not, it should always be noted that not one person who was ever advocating the signing of a convention wanted to see mining in the Antarctic. It was always an argument about whether or not there would be a regime in place to protect the environment if a country proceeded to do the wrong thing and mine. The same objections that were made on that score two years ago are alive and well today because there is still no regime that would prevent a country marching in and doing something truly horrible in the Antarctic. That is a matter of regret for us all. Australia is working very hard to ensure that we do come up with some sort of instrument which will provide long term protection for the Antarctic and mining.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to Senator Vallentine's comments, it is worth remembering, whenever one speaks of the Antarctic and of research, that the Japanese Government can still manage to kill hundreds of whales each year-always in the name of research. That is a tragedy on a world scale which still goes on and one which we should all keep uppermost in our thoughts and attempt to stop.

In specifics, the position that Australia took was regarded as somewhat radical at the time. France, Belgium and Italy have joined us now as full co-sponsors of our proposal and, at the Antarctic Treaty meeting in Chile in November last year, 12 of the 39 parties to the treaty were calling for a prohibition on mining in Antarctica. That is a considerable improvement in the space of two years, but a long way short of where Australia-and the world, I hope-would like to see it. The treaty parties are meeting again in Madrid in just over a month's time to continue those discussions. As we approach that meeting, I hope that more of our treaty partners follow the lead which Australia has taken on the issue. How meaningful a country's commitment to the Antarctic is will be determined by the stance it takes in these discussions in Madrid next month. I hope that more of the 27 parties to the treaty who still have not embraced this cause will do so very shortly.

I will not attempt to speak on Senator Calvert's rather extraordinary and irrelevant contribution. As I said by way of interjection, the people of Australia have had ample and perfect opportunity to judge between the records of the coalition and the Government on the environment, and did so resoundingly. I think that not only do the records of the two parties speak for themselves on that question, but so does the verdict of Australia. The verdict was way against Senator Calvert. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That this Bill be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Meat Chicken Levy Act 1969 to increase the maximum rate of levy for exotic disease. The funds raised are utilised to finance the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account.

Currently the maximum rate of levy permitted to be collected from the meat chicken industry is set at 0.005 cents per head. Due to a drafting error it is necessary to amend this to the correct rate of 0.05 cents per head.
This matter has been discussed with the relevant producer interests and the National Farmers' Federation (NFF) has formally indicated its support for the amendment.

Operative levy rates will continue to be set by regulation under the Meat Chicken Levy Act 1969, on the recommendation of the relevant industry committee of the NFF in accordance with the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989. This Government has given a commitment to match these industry funds on a dollar-for-dollar basis up to a maximum of $750,000 pa for the livestock industries. The additional funds raised through the setting of the correct levy rate on meat chickens in 1991/92 are estimated to total $27,000.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button)-by leave-agreed to:

That Government Business order of the day No. 2 (Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1991), Government Business order of the day No. 3 (Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill 1990) and Government Business order of the day No. 6 (Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill 1991) may be taken together for their remaining stages.

DEBATE.TITLE: MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1991DRIED VINE FRUITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990AUSTRALIAN HORTICULTURAL CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5, 6 and 12 March, on motions by Senator Gareth Evans, Senator Cook and Senator Tate:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1991 is to correct a drafting mistake that was made in the 1989 amendment to the Meat Chicken Levy Act 1969. The Act, together with the Meat Chicken Levy Collection Act 1969, provides for the collection of a levy on meat chickens. The funds raised are for research via the Chicken Meat Research Trust Account and the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1989 amendment accidentally set the maximum rate of levy for the exotic disease purposes at 0.005c per head instead of 0.05c. The 1991 amendment is to correct the drafting error and to set the rate at 0.05c per head. Additional funds raised by the collection of the correct levy rate will be matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar-for-dollar basis and the additional funds are estimated to total $27,000 in 1991-92. On behalf of the Opposition, I support the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill 1991.

The purpose of the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill and the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 is to restructure the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation and the Australian Dried Fruits Board and place them under the wing of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The Bills will deregulate the domestic market by removing the domestic component of the sultana equalisation scheme but continue export underwriting for another three years to minimise the impact of the changes.

These Bills are in response to the Industries Assistance Commission 1989 report on the dried vine fruits industry, which recommended the reform of existing levels of government assistance arrangements for the dried vine fruits industry. The legislation is very similar to that of the wheat industry in that the domestic market is to be regulated but export controls are to continue. The Government will continue its current underwriting scheme for another three years.

The two pieces of legislation will change the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation into a board and place it under the umbrella of the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The dried fruits industry would prefer not to be tied to the Australian Horticultural Corporation because it does not believe that it would receive any additional benefits. Instead, it will have additional costs to the tune of $60,000 per year for the next three years and, while there will be some subsidy to the Australian Horticultural Corporation, after that the cost to the dried fruits industry could double. This is a concern.

The Government has forced the industry into the changes in order to preserve its export power. The dried fruits industry has had a long history of competing successfully in export markets, with Australian fruit attracting the highest prices on world markets. The Government has agreed to the industry retaining its independence within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill will deregulate the domestic market and remove the domestic component from the sultana equalisation scheme. The sultana equalisation scheme was first introduced in 1982, when the world was oversupplied with sultanas and prices were extremely low. The scheme paid out $1.3m or $16 per tonne in its first year, but this has not been repeated.

In 1986 the scheme was changed to reduce the level at which the Government would underwrite. The level was set at 80 per cent of the free on board export return for the past three years and a sunset clause inserted so that the scheme finished at the end of December 1990. This legislation will continue underwriting for another three years to help the industry adjust to the deregulation of the domestic market. The sultana equalisation scheme was introduced many years ago to equalise the domestic and export markets so that farmers could be paid the same price for their product. Legislation in 1986 set a cap on the equalisation payment that could be made over and above the average export return. Because the domestic price in most years was above the export price, the Government and the Industry Commission believed that this was a consumer transfer. It should be noted that neither the Dried Fruits Corporation nor the Australian Dried Fruits Association actually market fruit on the domestic market.

Because of this perceived transfer, the Government is removing the domestic component from equalisation but will continue it on the exports. This means that equalisation will be on a reconciliation of export returns at the end of each season. There will be no levies and no government financial involvement. The industry is not happy to be losing equalisation of the domestic market. It rightly points out that it is already competing on the domestic market against the heavily subsidised product from Greece and cheap, poor quality fruit from Turkey. This is with the aid of a low, decreasing tariff, which by July 1992 will be 15 per cent on a normal basis and 10 per cent on a developing country basis.

The Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill 1991 will provide for the establishment of an Australian Dried Fruits Board within the Australian Horticultural Corporation. This will be done by changes to the structure of the Horticultural Corporation to provide for product boards. It is necessary because the Government will allow the dried fruits industry more autonomy than other industries currently connected to the Horticultural Corporation enjoy. This is in recognition of the excellent export marketing operations of the current Australian Dried Fruits Corporation. It should be noted that to date the Australian Horticultural Corporation has done nothing of note in the way of marketing for the industries which are currently participating under its control.

The second part of the Bill sets out how the product boards will operate. The Dried Fruits Board will be the only product board, but the framework will mean that other industries can be accommodated. The product board will be a body corporate which will assist in the longstanding arrangements that the dried fruits industry already has with a number of overseas agencies and groups.

The Government says that the board will not interfere with the active private industry marketing program that the dried fruits industry runs in Australia because it will operate only on export markets. The product board will have an independent chairperson selected by the Australian Horticultural Corporation in consultation with the relevant producer organisation, and five other members selected by the relevant industry body. Three of the five must have expertise in the industry while the other two members can be drawn from more general areas. While the industry does not like being forced into the Australian Horticultural Corporation, it recognises that in order to hold its export control it must agree to the legislation. It is reasonably happy with the final structure of the board and the degree of autonomy. Its one reservation is the money it must pay to the Australian Horticultural Corporation. The Opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill, the first Bill referred to by Senator Brownhill, the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, is the result of a drafting, printing or typographical error. I am tempted to ask what happened the first time around. The Senate, as a House of review, failed to do its job. But I am not surprised, given the performance of the coalition this morning where a good deal of the coalition's chamber time was devoted to an examination of Australian Democrats' diaries and misguided reference to our policy direction. Really, such action as this is a total waste of time. It does not improve the welfare of this nation and it is really self-indulgent in the extreme. If the coalition did what it was paid to do and occasionally read some of the legislation, the Senate might be able to act as a true House of review and we would not need to waste further time in retrospective amendments such as this. I must say though, after that, that Senator Brownhill has now adequately described the amendment contained in the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill and I will not further detail that.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn briefly to the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill. I must say that, although the dried fruit industry will be incorporated into the Australian Horticultural Corporation, nevertheless it will retain a high degree of independence, particularly over its export marketing operations, while it is within the Horticultural Corporation.

It is apparent that this arrangement does reflect the industry's long history of competing successfully in export markets. That is a record of achievement which unfortunately has not always been matched by Australia's other horticultural industries.

In considering the status of other industries I refer to a press release of the National Farmers Federation of 20 December 1990. It is quoted in the House of Representatives Hansard of 21 February 1991. The press release stated that the Industry Commission had miscalculated levels of assistance between agriculture and other industries throughout the economy. It stated:

In essence, the Commission has failed to recognise that agricultural industries are being penalised by inefficiencies in other sectors in the economy, particularly in the transport, irrigation, financial services and electricity industries . . .
It went on to read:

The rate of assistance, or the aggregate effect of Government intervention in industries such as sugar, rice, dairy and dried fruits, is much lower than is indicated by the Commission's current methodology.
It further stated:
NFF is calling on the Industry Commission to change the methodology it uses when calculating effective rates of industry assistance so that all industries are treated equally.

To me perhaps the most important word was the very last word, the word `equally'. What is meant by equally? Perhaps some have painted that `equally' as the cliche `the level playing field'. However it is described, the Australian Democrats do agree with the concept of equally.

When importing goods to this country we need to take into account the costs of production in the country of origin. For example, in Australia, electricity producers are required to consider the environmental effects of their activities. This society, as a whole, agrees that environmental protection measures are appropriate, and that our energy supply costs include the costs of those environmental protection measures. These environmental protection measures, of course, have been applied to those producers for the benefit of Australia as a whole.

Therefore, Australia as a whole should accept the responsibility of applying similar economic constraints to competing importers. In the same way, the other benefits of Australian society which would add to our costs of production should be paid for by the whole of society. It is important that as consumers we should not take advantage of cheap imports produced in countries that do not provide their citizens with the same sorts of social benefits that have been established in Australia. We could ensure that that advantage is not taken by applying a charge to imports equivalent to the difference between producing in Australia and producing in a country without our social benefits and obligations.

In that very old debate about free trade versus protectionism, the question should be asked: what is it that we are protecting? The answer is not that we are protecting just industries or producers. The whole style of Australian living and the fundamental privileges and obligations of being a member of our society are what we should be protecting. I cannot pretend to introduce a comprehensive list into this short debate, but such a list would include our award wages, sickness benefits, superannuation, levels of income tax, company tax, payroll tax and fuel tax, training guarantee schemes, research levies, inspection fees, contributions to municipal rates and taxes, and the costs of compliance with other socially endorsed policies such as the equal employment opportunity policy. They should all be taken into account as part of the production costs.

We see no evidence in the Government's industry statement that this concept has been taken seriously. It has really been ignored. Even worse, the general level of tariffs is being reduced. It is being reduced with little regard being paid to the defence of those benefits of Australian society that I have just described. In this set of Bills, we see support for, and reinforcement of, some of those benefits. The problem is that other Government policies do not complement that direction.

While we support these Bills, because they tidy up and emphasise some of the benefits that should be part of Australian society, we note that the Government is not supporting those that are the subject of this Bill through complementary legislation that actually recognises the benefits and obligations that are attached to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this cognate debate on the Meat Chicken Levy Amendment Bill, the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill and the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill, it is a great pleasure to speak to the Dried Vine Fruits Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 because the dried vine fruits industry is of great importance in Australia. It is the biggest single horticultural industry and it has a very important local influence on the area of Australia that it occupies. The 2,700-odd grower families have made an enormous contribution to the agriculture of Australia. The industry is people intensive and it is a very sound, solid and well-established modern business. A considerable number of the operators are operating on 25- to 30-acre properties, and they certainly deserve all the nationwide support that we can give them.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no better dried fruits operation in the world than here in Australia. It has become very fashionable to kick local industries and to complain about whether or not they are efficient, how efficient, and the standards by which their efficiency may be measured. But these people are real leaders in the world in many ways. They meet absolutely every criterion of efficiency that one could possibly give them. They are modern; they have excellent research and development; they use the latest methods; they are export oriented; they are well organised; they are well managed; they are most efficiently operated. I say to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table, that I am not sure what more one can ask.

The growers produced, as at the last year, 64,386 tonnes of sultanas, raisins and currants, of which we in Australia consumed 28,761 tonnes and 38,292 tonnes went for export. There is considerable fluctuation in this industry. It has good years and bad years and it has good prices and poor prices. Last year the price to the packer for sultanas averaged out at $1,415 a tonne which was slightly up on the year before. The price received depends, of course, largely on seasonal conditions, the world supply situation, the quality of the goods generally, the size of the Australian crop and its effect and, as with so many other commodities in Australia now, the value of the Australian dollar.

Having again been recently to have a look at some of the work that has gone on in the last few years, I was singularly impressed at the standard that those growers have now achieved relative to other growers in the world. The new developments that they have made as far as root stocks are concerned, the selection and improvement of various vines and their disease control, the total changes in irrigation methods and the use and conservation of water and fertiliser, the new methods of trellising and harvesting-all of these things show them now to be clearly leaders by miles in the world, and as such they deserve to have the full support and cooperation of Parliament and of the people generally and, hopefully, of the consumers too. I rate myself as one of the great consumers and I am pleased to go there and see the standards that they have maintained in looking after my interests as well.

The Bill extends the underwriting for three years and removes the domestic component for the equalisation arrangements. This does not please the growers and they are wondering why it became necessary for the Government to take this action. The Bill will remove the levy on the sales of domestic products. The industry deserves support, as I have said before, particularly in view of the international difficulties with competing countries. Greece and the United States of America have long been competitors, but now most of all it is Turkey that looks like being the problem. Of course, while our own production, particularly our export fruit, is under very close scrutiny for standards, I often wonder whether the same scrutiny is given to the growing quality and growing standards that are adopted in countries from which we import. I believe that, as we know what the quality of the fruit is and we know how it is produced in Australia, the Australian product deserves more consideration by the retailers, the manufacturers and by the customers themselves. There is no substitute for having the best product, and we certainly know where it comes from.

The industry will always face difficulties because of these international factors. I believe that it is one of those industries for which, in spite of our rush for changing anything that looks like support or protection or understanding of industries, there certainly needs to be some trigger mechanism which can be brought into play if and when it is necessary.

The cost of producing these products in Australia, of course, is not low. It cannot be low with the price structure under which we operate. But it is a price structure that the growers themselves had no part in developing and we do need to give credit for that, too. It is not reasonable to compare what something costs under Australian standards of growing with what it may cost in Turkey or Greece or somewhere else. So I just ask that the Government at all times take that into account. Those here in Australia who try to grind down the price-to subsistence level or below for many of the growers-are not the ones who have to pay the ultimate price. They really would do better to make sure that they keep the industry in a healthy condition. The Opposition does not oppose the legislation; it gives its support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the Senate for its support of these Bills. As Senator Archer and others have said, these are important industries. I think it is good that we have a mutual view about the contents of these Bills. I am happy to commend them to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a Bill to amend section 50 of the Trade Practices Act 1974, which relates to mergers and acquisitions. The aim of section 50 is to prevent mergers and acquisitions which are likely to have an adverse effect on competition. It provides for the prohibition of mergers and acquisitions which would result in a corporation being in a position to dominate the market or, if it already dominates a market, that domination being strengthened. In determining whether a position would be strengthened, the section permits the aggregation of market shares of companies that are related to or associated with the acquiring corporation. The Trade Practices Commission encourages parties to contentious mergers to consult with it early and to seek authorisation. If they do not, and if the Commission believes that the merger would breach the Act, it has no option but to contest the matter in court.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has apparently introduced this Bill as a result of the events leading to the case of Trade Practices Commission v. Australian Iron and Steel and Others-reported in 1990 ATPR at page 41. It is otherwise known as the New Zealand Steel case. In its annual report of 1988-89 the Trade Practices Commission mentioned its concern that the acquisition in July 1989 of 100 per cent of New Zealand Steel by Helenus Corporation, a New Zealand consortium headed by BHP, would strengthen BHP's dominance of the Australian market for some steel products. New Zealand Steel was a boutique producer with serious operational problems and debt of around $600m. BHP, through its wholly owned subsidiary Australian Iron and Steel, acquired 31 per cent of Helenus.

The National Secretary of the Federated Ironworkers Association, Mr Steve Harrison, immediately accused BHP of deliberately restricting the amount of steel production in Australia, thereby creating shortfalls to justify importing huge amounts of steel. He described BHP's investment in Helenus, to double the output of New Zealand Steel and meet a steel shortage in Australia, as scandalous. BHP's chief executive confirmed that steel produced in New Zealand would be used to bridge a shortage of about 100,000 tonnes of coated steel products.

The Trade Practices Commission noted that New Zealand steel was at that time a very small supplier to the Australian market, but that it had expansion potential to supply a significant proportion of the market for hot rolled, cold rolled and coated steel products.

In August 1989 the Trade Practices Commission applied to the Trade Practices Tribunal for a declaration under section 50a (1) that the acquisition would substantially strengthen BHP's dominance of the Australian market for some steel products. The Trade Practices Commission believed that BHP would effectively be able to control the Helenus consortium. This would have been the first testing of section 50a in court.

In early September the Trade Practices Commission withdrew its section 50a action against BHP from the Trade Practices Tribunal and began an action under section 50 in the Federal Court of Australia. The change of forum was due to fresh legal advice which pointed out that the only remedy available under the untested section 50a was the prevention of the operation of the Australian subsidiary of New Zealand Steel; whereas under section 50 the remedy sought could be the forced divestiture of BHP's shares in New Zealand Steel.

The issue of the New Zealand Steel case centred on the prohibition in section 50 against a corporation directly or indirectly acquiring shares in a body corporate if this would lead to market domination. It was held by Mr Justice Lockhart at first instance that a corporation does not indirectly acquire shares in a body corporate where the shares are acquired by a subsidiary, unless that subsidiary acts as agent for the corporation. In this case, it could not be said that BHP or Australian Iron and Steel directly or indirectly acquired shares in New Zealand Steel as there was no allegation that Helenus acquired the shares as agent for any other corporation.

The Commission formed the view that the Act required amendment to deal with this problem. In the end it discontinued proceedings in the New Zealand Steel case, having come to a settlement in which the Trade Practices Commission, BHP and Australian Iron and Steel gave various undertakings to the court. Although to continue the case would have provided an opportunity to test fully the adequacy of section 50 in these situations, the Commission decided that a settlement was a satisfactory market solution and a means of avoiding protracted and costly litigation.

The Trade Practices Commission and the Government have persisted in the view that the finding in the New Zealand Steel case opened a loophole and exposed an inadequacy in section 50 which had not hitherto been apparent.

The Opposition does not share this view. The case followed previous authority and confirmed the existing state of the law, although it has been treated by the Government as though it had disclosed a major defect in the legislation which required urgent remedial action in the national interest.

The Commission has since been pressing the Government for an amendment addressing the situation where mergers are sought through indirect acquisitions. Indeed, the Commission went so far as to encourage speculation that the case had opened a loophole of which News Ltd could take advantage to acquire the Fairfax newspaper group.

It is noteworthy that News Corporation has not at any stage since the New Zealand Steel case evinced any intention of using that decision as a basis for attempting acquisition of Fairfax. This, in any case, would have been prevented by the current law. It could not acquire assets or shares in Fairfax directly; it could not acquire them through subsidiaries acting as agents of News Ltd, and even an attempt to acquire shares or assets through subsidiaries not acting as their agents would be thwarted by the aggregation provisions.

The Opposition has concerns about the Trade Practices Commission's playing the role of initiator in the policy making process to this extent. Naturally, the Commission has a role in commenting on the operation of the Trade Practices Act; but it should not lose sight of the fact that it is primarily a law enforcement body and not a policy making one.

In response to the agitation of the Trade Practices Commission, the Government has introduced this Bill. Under proposed new subsection 50(1aa) the prohibition on acquisitions which would lead or would be likely to lead to market domination is extended to apply to bodies corporate which are not corporations but which are related to or associated with a corporation. The market position of all such related bodies corporate can be taken into account and aggregated in assessing dominance.

The object of the new provision is to prevent bodies corporate which are not corporations acquiring shares or assets where a corporation itself would be prohibited from acquisition. This is in order to prevent the use of bodies corporate that are not corporations to avoid section 50. It is interesting that the Government has not given any examples of non-corporations which are bodies corporate being used by a corporation to acquire shares or assets in contravention of the section. It would seem that the chances of this happening are very slight.

Although the Opposition accepts that there is a need, however slight, for the substantive change introduced in proposed subsection 50(1aa), the Opposition has serious reservations about its retrospectivity. These concerns are shared by the Law Council of Australia which stated in a submission to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy):

Retrospectivity in legislation of this kind is always objectionable and the practice is especially objectionable where, as in the original announcement, the public was not given any indication of the nature of the changes which were proposed.

The Attorney-General announced last October that legislation was to be introduced which would take effect from the date of the announcement. There was no explanation of the proposed content of the Bill. In the Bill, as eventually proposed, the commencement date was given as the date of the second reading speech, which was 21 December. This was later adjusted to 22 December.

When the Bill was actually introduced, it did not even address the problem which the Attorney-General had announced needed to be rectified so urgently. It is likely to affect so few cases that the Government has not so far given any examples of the situations in which it would apply.

There is also a question relating to the constitutionality of the new provision in proposed subsection 50(1aa) in that it seeks to regulate bodies corporate which are not corporations. Thus it cannot logically fall within the Commonwealth power to make laws with respect to corporations.

This Bill also makes other changes with respect to section 50. The Law Council has made a detailed submission in relation to those changes, arguing that the need for most of them is not apparent and, further, that they could have unforeseen effects on the delicate balance of section 50 and could create commercial uncertainty.

My colleague the shadow Minister for corporate law reform and consumer affairs, Mr Costello, raised each of the Law Council's points in his speech on the second reading in the other place. The Attorney-General addressed these issues in some detail in his reply, and I do not propose to canvass them again at this stage.

These comments in relation to the defects of this Bill should not be taken as detracting from the Opposition's basic position in relation to legal constraints on market monopolisation in a free market economy, which is that there is a place for establishing rules so that the market operates in a fair and efficient way, and so that free and open competition is promoted. We have in the past supported trade practices provisions which are designed to promote these objectives.

For these reasons, and because the substantive change in proposed new paragraph 50 (1aa) does close what could in the future become a loophole which would be useful to those who are seeking to avoid the anti-monopolisation provisions in section 50, the Opposition is not opposing this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order, we will now move to matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —A major change is under way in the Parliament of one of our Pacific neighbours and I consider that it should not go unnoticed in our chamber. The nation to which I refer is Western Samoa-a country of about 163,000 people. Western Samoa's islands are part of the Samoan archipelago, which was first surveyed by the French during the late eighteenth century.

SPEECH.PARA: Relations between the Samoan islands and Western powers during the first century of contact were dominated by missionary and trading activities. Internal conflict and disruption caused by rival Western powers in the late nineteenth century led to the island group becoming controlled by the United States in the east and by Germany in the west. Following the outbreak of World War I, Western Samoa was controlled by New Zealand, first as an occupied area, then as a territory, and finally as a United Nations trust territory.

After Western Samoa became independent from the New Zealand administration in 1962, it adopted a unicameral Westminster-style parliamentary democracy. But there was one major concession to tradition in that, with one minor exception, only the nation's chiefs were allowed to stand and vote in general elections. The Legislative Assembly, or Fono, has 47 seats, of which two are reserved for non-Samoan citizens; the other 45 may be contested by chiefs only. The chiefs, referred to as matai, are heads of extended family groups and are leaders in a country which adheres rigidly to the traditional Polynesian way of life. The matai hold great authority, and that authority begins at the village level, which is the heart of all Samoan political, social and economic life. It extends to all sections of the Samoan commercial, public service and political structure.

Last year the Prime Minister of Western Samoa, Tofilau Eti Alesana, called on Western Samoan adults to decide whether universal suffrage should be introduced. Voting in the referendum to gauge opinion on this matter was open to all Western Samoans of age 21 and over. The Prime Minister noted that there had been a big rise in the number of matai and this had diluted their authority. Some matai with political ambitions apparently had created new titles for family members to win more votes. It seems to be the equivalent of branch stacking in Australia.

After a short campaign in which the pros and cons were debated, a one person, one vote system was approved by a narrow majority. The Western Samoan Parliament has now been dissolved and next month a new parliament will be elected by universal suffrage. An estimated 60,000 adults will be eligible to vote compared with 20,000 matai who previously had sole voting rights. Perhaps to those of us who are accustomed to a system of universal suffrage, this does not seem to be a major step; but it certainly is for a country whose whole culture has been based on the family and extended family groups and the authority of the matai.

Although the forthcoming election will be held under a system of universal suffrage, except for the two non-Samoan seats the right to stand as a candidate will remain restricted to matai. This restriction may appear undemocratic if the situation is viewed from a Western perspective. But having taken what is for Western Samoa a major step towards democracy, it seems reasonable to support a statement by that country's Prime Minister. On the matter of retaining the exclusive rights of parliamentary representation to the matai, he is reported to have said, `You can't overnight change the whole system. Let's take it easy this time'. The Prime Minister, however, has not ruled out that there could be non-matai candidates in future elections.

In 1989 I had the opportunity to visit Western Samoa twice. I found the people and the country delightful. There is little wonder that Robert Louis Stevenson chose Western Samoa to be his home. Between 1892 and 1896 he completed eight works in Western Samoa. Two were unfinished at the time of his tragic early death. If he had not been stricken by a cerebral haemorrhage at the age of 44, Western Samoa through Stevenson would have made a considerable further contribution to English literature.
