Much of Western Samoa's agricultural land is held for the production of subsistence crops, but bananas, cacao and copra are among the nation's exports. Dominated by two major islands, Upolu and Savai'i, the nation's economy is largely based on agriculture, fishing, timber getting and tourism.

Despite a relatively low cash income, the people of Western Samoa maintain a high standard of both health and literacy due to the provision of good health and educational services by their Government.

The traditional Polynesian culture and Christianity are strongly supported by the Government of Western Samoa. Examples of the influence of Christianity on the people of Western Samoa are the strict observance of Sunday and evening vesper curfews in the villages. Indeed, on the first occasion on which I visited Western Samoa, I arrived on a Sunday morning. On the long drive from the international airport to the capital, Apia, it was delightful to see so many Western Samoans, in their Sunday best, walking to their local church. I did not count those churches, but there were scores on that 40-kilometre drive.

On my second visit to Western Samoa, in a memorable ceremony Senator Reid and I were inducted as chiefs. My title was `Ulufanua' or, in English, `head of the land', and Senator Reid's was `Suailefanua' or `juice of the land'-slightly more prosaic. After acquiring this chiefly status, I asked whether I was then eligible to take a seat in the country's Legislative Assembly. Our hosts had probably never been asked that before, but remarked that there was probably a constitutional provision preventing it.

Many observers will be interested in the outcome of the forthcoming elections in Western Samoa. Whatever the results, I am sure that many people will wish Western Samoa well as it involves all adults in the parliamentary process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak briefly about Dr Eugene Forsey, a man who has been described as one of Canada's foremost experts on that country's constitution. I first came into contact with Dr Forsey's writings when he wrote the epilogue to Sir John Kerr's famous book Matters for Judgement. I was sorry to read in a recent edition of Time magazine of his death on 27 February at the age of 86. Time magazine described him as Canada's foremost constitutional expert and a prolific author of scholarly books.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the importance of his work and his links with Australia, it is appropriate that Dr Forsey's passing be noted by the Senate. Dr Forsey was a committed socialist, and senators will not be surprised that I have been more attracted by his constitutional writings than by his party philosophy.

Eugene Forsey was born in Newfoundland in 1904. He was a Rhodes scholar for Quebec in 1926 and took his MA at Oxford in 1932. On his return to Canada, he became actively involved in politics. He was one of the founders of the Cooperative Commonwealth Federation which later became the New Democratic Party.

He was one of those socialists who combined a zeal for social and industrial reform along socialist lines with a reverence for the constitutional heritage which all the Commonwealth countries inherited from Great Britain. In particular, Dr Eugene Forsey was an ardent supporter of the institution of the monarchy and regarded the sovereign and the governors and governors-general of the Commonwealth as an essential part of a system of responsible democratic parliamentary government. He believed this to be the finest system of government ever devised, and with that view I have some sympathy.

He wrote a great deal on constitutional and political subjects. His most famous work, published in 1943, is The Royal Power of Dissolution of Parliament in the British Commonwealth. This was a detailed treatment of the power of the Crown in the constitutional arrangements of Commonwealth countries, particularly as it relates to the granting of dissolutions of parliament. In compiling this work-which is still, I believe, regarded as an authoritative treatment of the subject-Dr Forsey had the benefit of a scholarly work by another well-known socialist and constitutional lawyer. It will not be a surprise to you, Mr Deputy President, that this man was Dr H.V. Evatt, who had published his equally well known book The King and His Dominion Governors in 1936.

The two books, one by Dr Evatt and the other by Eugene Forsey, became associated as the great works on the subject of the reserve powers of the Crown, and in 1990 they were reprinted in a single volume with an introduction by Dr Forsey providing an up-to-date summary of the subject. Dr Forsey's constant theme was that the reserve powers of the Crown, particularly in granting a dissolution, were an essential safeguard of democratic constitutional government. He attacked what he called the `rubber stamp' theory of the Crown-the theory that the head of state is always obliged, regardless of the circumstances, to act on the advice of the ministry of the day. He amassed a vast collection of precedents from all around the Commonwealth to support his defence of reserve powers.

In this chamber a debate on reserve powers has extended over a long period. It is worth recording in this chamber the views of Dr Forsey on this subject. In scholarly discussion and political controversy, Dr Forsey always had at his fingertips telling examples of cases in which reserve powers had been exercised properly or improperly. He was always able to pose embarrassing questions, supported by practical examples, for the proponents of the `rubber stamp' theory. What if a government refused to resign or to go to an election when it lost its majority in the Lower House? What if it lost an election but insisted upon holding another election? Dr Forsey saw these reserve powers of the Crown as a safeguard against such unconstitutional actions, and he employed his great skills as a writer and as an advocate to hammer home his views far and wide. It is of interest to quote from him directly on the use of the reserve power:
The reserve power is, indeed, under our Constitution, an absolutely essential safeguard of democracy . . .

It is the rubber stamp theory which is undemocratic. It makes existing governments irremovable except by their own consent. Such a doctrine is a travesty of democracy. It delivers every Opposition gagged and bound into the hands of its opponents. It delivers the people gagged and bound into the hands of any jack-in-office.
To use Dr Forsey's terms,

The jack-in-office may, of course, loosen the gag and the ropes. He may loosen them so much that we don't realize they're there. But he can tighten them again whenever he pleases, and as tight as he pleases. This is not democracy. It is despotism; more or less benevolent, perhaps, for the moment; but despotism none the less.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about, Senator, with this `Jack-in-office' stuff?
—I do not know whether the Minister feels that the `jack-in-office' refers to him personally. It was not meant in that personal sense-but if you feel that, Senator, please take it on.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of Dr Forsey's great interest in constitutional history and doctrine, he became involved in the debate over the 1975 constitutional crisis in Australia. Although he might have been expected to be ideologically in sympathy with the Labor Government, he unreservedly supported the correctness of the action of Sir John Kerr in dismissing the Whitlam Government to allow the electorate to determine the deadlock between the two Houses of Parliament. In an epilogue to Sir John Kerr's book Matters for Judgment, which I have mentioned, Dr Forsey wrote:
Never for a moment did I doubt the correctness of the action Sir John Kerr took. For the life of me, I could not see, and still cannot see, what else he could have done in the circumstances.
He went on to say:
The duty of a Prime Minister denied supply by an Upper House is either to resign, or to advise a dissolution of the Lower House.

Dr Forsey was appointed to the Canadian Senate in 1970 by Prime Minister Trudeau. As a senator he diligently applied the doctrine of the accountability of the executive government to Parliament. He was particularly active in seeking to reassert parliamentary control over delegated legislation.

In his retirement he continued to take part in constitutional controversies. He strongly opposed the 1987 Meech Lake accord, which would have recognised Quebec as a distinct society in Canada. The accord, as we know, failed to gain the required approval; and as senators will be aware, the Quebec issue in Canadian politics is still unresolved.

Dr Eugene Forsey had a great affection for Australia and for Australians, I understand, and a great interest, as I have shown, in Australian affairs. It is fitting that we should mark his passing and remember his work in the Australian Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I am sure you will be interested in the issue that I want to raise in the Senate today. It concerns natural disaster relief arrangements, and relates particularly to the extensive damage that we know has been suffered by local councils around Queensland following the quite unusual heavy rainfall over the last few months. I emphasise at the outset that we are talking about a very exceptional year when it comes to the kind of damage that has been done by rainfall, and I believe that the natural disaster relief arrangements should take this into account.

SPEECH.PARA: In this place on 13 February I raised with my colleague the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, the question of whether the assistance measures that have been agreed to by the Federal and State governments should perhaps be more flexible and should include assistance for damage caused to roads and other areas by saturation. Under the current guidelines, flooding is flooding and relates to water that floods across roads and is responsible for damage; but rain saturation is another issue entirely and does not qualify for any relief. This is a considerable source of concern and frustration to local government. Frankly, unless people can see the examples, it is very difficult to comprehend this subtle difference between flooding and saturation; but one can certainly see it when one inspects the damage, as I am sure many of us have done in recent weeks.

Following my raising this issue in the Senate, Senator Button indicated that the Department would investigate the need for some kind of flexibility, and the issue has been taken up by the Department of Finance on the instructions of the Minister for Finance, Mr Willis. I take this opportunity to thank Minister Willis for his interest. Officers of his Department subsequently met with me to gain some greater detail of what the concerns were. I asked the Local Government Association of Queensland to document, from their point of view, their understanding of the frustrations of councils, with some hard evidence of the kinds of claims that had been rejected in the past. I have, as honourable senators can see, several examples from all over Queensland.

I would like to read into the Hansard a copy of the letter from Greg Hoffman, the Executive Director of the Local Government Association of Queensland, because it indicates that this is not a one-off short term problem that has just been experienced by one council.

I refer to our recent conversation on the shortcomings of the natural disaster relief arrangements. These arrangements are a constant source of concern to local government in Queensland and we fully support your initiative to have them reviewed following the exceptional damage caused in Queensland during the current wet season.
The particular problem of rain water damage has been raised on previous occasions and attached are documents to this effect.
The other elements of the guidelines which are of concern are firstly, the exclusion of damage to water and sewerage facilities because they are regarded as business undertakings-

I ask honourable senators what their view is of that particular decision, water and sewerage facilities being regarded as business undertakings. I would have thought that they were fundamental to public health and should not be regarded as business undertakings.

The second point in the letter is that the beach restoration programs arising from damage caused by tidal surge are also excluded from the guidelines and therefore no financial assistance can be given to councils for restoring the coastline. Given our increased level of commitment and awareness of environmental issues, I think that is certainly an area for review. The third thing mentioned is the removal of concessional loan facilities to local government for the establishment of permanent water augmentation facilities necessitated by extreme and protracted drought. Having talked about the problems of flooding, that is another issue that Mr Hoffman wishes to raise.

I want to get back to this apparent anomaly in regard to damage caused by flooding and damage caused by saturation. I would like to read from another letter from the Local Government Association of Queensland, this one sent two years ago to the Director-General of the Premier's Department in Queensland following the flooding after cyclone Charlie. The councils' grievances then were similar. They mainly concerned certain sections of the guidelines for natural disaster relief arrangements which they believe are too stringent. They wrote:
The Association hopes that your office will take this matter into consideration during the next review of the guidelines.

By far the most frequent complaint had to do with problems in the definition of drainage systems. Under the guidelines councils can only claim damage to that caused by water crossing roadways rather than damage resulting from longitudinal flow.

Councils said that during heavy rain watercourses change direction of flow and create new watercourses along the roads. The longitudinal flow of water along a road causes scarring to the roadway pavements but this damage is not eligible for flood relief.
Some councils complained that the definition of flood submergence was too severe in that damage can still occur to road surfaces during periods of cyclonic rains.

I must confess that the response from the Premiers Department at that time, in 1988, was less than satisfactory, from both a State point of view and a Federal point of view. The then Acting Director-General replied:
Damage from heavy rainfall resulting in longitudinal water flows or pavement break-up is presently ineligible as the guidelines restrict eligible restoration works to damage caused by flooding.
By way of explanation the Commonwealth determination of the terms and conditions of natural disaster assistance only recognises flooding (and not rainfall run-off) as eligible for assistance.

Approaches to Canberra for inclusion of rainfall/saturation damage have received negative responses. The Commonwealth contends that damage of this nature indicates a deficiency in design or construction standard.

I am afraid that that sort of statement would be absolutely rejected by councils and would, I am sure, be absolutely rejected by anybody who has lived through extensive flooding in tropical areas of Queensland.

It is very easy to make those comments from a government department here on the shores of Lake Burley Griffin, where people do not experience tropical downpours. Obviously this has been a longstanding problem, and it is long overdue for reconsideration. Therefore, I am pleased to be able to advise that following that initial question and the discussions of a few weeks ago, the Department of Finance has now written to its equivalent Queensland department stating:

We seek your advice as to how the arrangements regarding submergence/saturation are being or will be applied in the current exceptional storm/cyclonic events in northern Queensland, and your views as to whether some additional flexibility in the arrangements as practised in the past is warranted.

I think the complaint of the Local Government Association is that that flexibility has not been present, because the guidelines have been too stringent, and rain damage and the effect of watertables rising has not been recognised. The letter continued:

We also note in a recent phone conversation you indicated that assistance would be provided to Mackay due to the extent of submergence in the wake of Cyclone Joy. A request for assistance for rain damage . . . was apparently judged not to meet existing guidelines. Details on this development, particularly in respect to Mackay and Townsville regions, would be appreciated as part of your response to this request.
As previously discussed, an officer of the Department of Finance is available to visit affected areas to examine damage first hand.

I am pleased to inform the Senate that it appears that after a number of years of bureaucratic rigidity and lack of understanding the quite different conditions that apply in tropical Australia at times such as we have had over the last couple of months will perhaps at long last be recognised. This does not mean that every time it rains, in Queensland or anywhere else, councils can rush in with special claims. There would have to be a declaration of a natural disaster, and the level of rainfall during that disaster would have to be examined so that it could be determined whether it qualified for consideration as an exceptional period of rain. But I hope that there is a positive outcome to the work that a number of people have been doing on behalf of local government; because if people had seen the conditions that have resulted from this absolutely unprecedented level of rainfall, they would understand why councils will have to undergo very serious financial hardship to start to repair the damage. When we are dealing with roads, obviously, if we do not repair the damage that is a risk to the community. Our road toll is high enough as it is, without any delay in repairing such flood damaged or rain damaged roads.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure many Queensland councils will be interested in that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems rather appropriate, Madam Acting Deputy President, that you are occupying the chair at this time. I want to bring to the Senate's attention a number of points. I begin with a quote from an article from yesterday's Australian, `Kerin defends decision on wheat submission'. I find in it a very remarkable statement, which needs correcting and refuting. Talking about Minister Kerin, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: He said farmers had to realise that it was not easy to introduce microeconomic reform quickly in the area of off-farm costs when the Government naturally had to represent union interests.
That is an absolutely extraordinary statement in terms of where we are, and I want to go through that a little.

I want to remind the Senate that, during recent elections since the Hawke Government has been in office, I have seen the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stand up in front of the television cameras and say, `We are now elected as the Government of Australia and we are here to govern for all Australians'. I have also seen it in Western Australia with our Premiers; both the now infamous ex-Premiers Burke and Dowding have made similar statements. I view this as a very serious situation. The impact of it, if it is taken a little bit further, is that in essence it is including not just farmers but all non-unionists.

I would like to run through some of the impacts of these sorts of statements on the community. Firstly, they create a compromise. They denigrate a percentage of Australians by classifying them as second-class citizens. They mean that effective micro-economic reform will be compromised in such areas as labour market reform, the waterfront, transport industries, trans-Tasman shipping, coastal shipping, airlines and communications.

In the context of the debate on that particular subject, I think Minister Kerin should publicly disown or withdraw that statement, or he should identify the Ministers who perpetuated it. It is that type of statement from a key resource Minister that makes it very difficult for Australia to tackle some of its serious problems.
I wish to use the remainder of my time to comment on what Mr Kerin said in the press release on the wheat industry assistance package. In the second paragraph of the media release it states:

``I am well aware of the serious difficulties being faced by many wheat farmers in Australia. These have been caused by the severe drop in world prices resulting from record world production and the aggressive production and export subsidy practices of the EC and US,'' Mr Kerin said today.

First of all, in terms of record production, there is no question that there has been a good year in terms of production, but what we have to look at, to keep it in context, is that on the last figures I had there were less than 50 days supply of wheat around the world. So the problem is not overproduction through the good harvest. The problem relates back first of all to the practices of the European Economic Community (EEC) and the United States (US) and our failure to address effectively some of the things that I identified earlier.

I want to comment on the basis of a submission from the Grains Council of Australia. I do not want to talk about it in the context of arguing for or against it, but in the context of what it is doing to Australian industry. In terms of the practices of the EEC and the US, we saw that the dairy industry was first hit. If we go back 10 or 12 years ago, Australia had a thriving export dairy industry. Many people were involved in that industry. Through the policies that have been developed through the common agricultural policy (CAP) program and the other programs in the US, we have slowly seen our dairy industry totally destroyed as an export contributor. We are now seeing a similar situation in the wheat industry.

The argument that the Grains Council put, which as I understand it was developed with the Minister's office, was that it was asking in principle for some system to give it a defence against price injury caused by the secondary effects of countervailing or dumping actions by overseas countries. I believe that we need to look very carefully at this. It certainly has to be looked at carefully by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) as Minister representing Minister Kerin in this place. Particularly now that there is an effective program in place in terms of lowering tariffs, one has to ask what will be the next industry affected. Will it be the car industry? Will it be the steel industry? Will it be the timber industry? One by one they can get picked off.

I recognise the efforts that are being made through the Cairns Group, but at this particular time its efforts are not sufficient. We have to come up with a mechanism to protect our wheat industry at this particular time because of actions which are totally outside its control.

I shall just run through the figures of the contribution the wheat industry has made to our export earnings over the last 10 years. It amounted to $2.17 billion in 1979-80; $1.72 billion in 1980-81; $1.79 billion in 1981-82; $1.44 billion in 1982-83; $1.813 billion in 1983-84; $2.86 billion in 1984-85; $2.9 billion in 1985-86; $2.1 billion in 1986-87; $1.774 billion in 1987-88; and $2.1 billion in the season just past, 1988-89. We have not as yet got the figures for the crop that has just been harvested. We are looking at an industry that has been consistently in the top three or four, and often at the top of our list, in terms of the earnings of export dollars. The challenge we have currently is how we are going to give that industry a defence mechanism to get over the activities that are occurring in the trade war.

As I said, it has to be looked at in the context of the damage that can be done to other industries. One could certainly run into the horticultural industries, and it has absolutely decimated our dairy industry. That has had particular effect in a number of States but I guess the principal one would be Victoria.

As we move to a more competitive Australia-hopefully-if we do not work out how we are going to handle this particular problem and have a defence mechanism there in terms of anti-dumping and countervailing provisions, it will be only a matter of time before we will see other countries get into this. I am not suggesting when I mention some countries that they may or may not do it, but one can well imagine, for example, what Japan could do to our car industry, when it starts exporting, if it wanted to adopt the same type of policies, if we have not worked out a strategy by which we are going to handle it.

I move now to the other points that I wanted to raise in terms of the wheat industry assistance statement. In the fourth paragraph it says that approximately $100m will be injected into the industry through an extension of the Government's guarantee of Australian Wheat Board borrowings. I want to explain precisely what that means. It means that growers will receive approximately $6 per tonne for ASW wheat of 10 per cent protein, which is the bulk of Australian wheat. It does not mean, because it is a guarantee on borrowings, that there will be any Government hand-out in it. And while the industry appreciates the fact that the Government has made this facility available, it does mean in the long term that that $6 will be discounted to make up for the costs of servicing that particular loan.

But the question that I address to the Government here, particularly in the knowledge that we have seen the price this year on their original estimates fall some $40-odd per tonne, is why could not this facility also be put in place to inject income into the industry, into the growers' pockets? That would enable them to start planning for their program this year. It would restimulate our various businesses that supply the wheat industry, whether they be in the country towns or in the metropolitan areas, with regard to the 1988-89 pool and the 1989-90 pool, because a significant amount of equity is left in that. If the same provision could be applied to those two particular pools, it would significantly improve the prospects of many of the service industries that service the wheat industry and, of course, the wheat growers in it.

The survey figures show that in the present circumstances we are looking at a planting reduced by about 35 per cent on the current harvest; that is, a 35 per cent reduction for the current seeding program which goes into next year's harvest. The figures average out somewhere just over $2 billion per annum over the last 10 years, but this has the potential to reduce that figure to the lowest it has been for many years, to probably about $1.3 billion. This would have a disastrous impact on our current account figures for the year.

The next point I want to raise in terms of this statement-and it has been raised here in questions-relates to the shortfall on the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation (EFIC) payment on wheat which was sold to Iraq prior to sanctions being imposed. A significant amount of wheat was sold there. Payments were held up by virtue of the fact that the assets of Iraq were frozen in the United States of America. The Government needs to give the industry a straight answer in terms of that $123m as to whether, as the Prime Minister said, the costs will be borne across the nation and not by any one individual industry or whether the wheat industry will have to pick up that $123m shortfall which is not covered by the EFIC insurance.
The last point I want to raise-and once again it relates to this particular media release and the Grains Council's defence strategy-is in the second last paragraph. It states:

The measures announced today are consistent with Australia's key role in the Uruguay Round negotiations which have reached a critical stage, and will ensure that our efficient grain producers will be able to respond to a future upturn in the world grains market.

I certainly do not deny that the Uruguay Round has reached a very critical stage; it is in its eleventh hour. If something does not come out of the next two or three months, I think this particular round will fail totally in addressing the problems of world trade in agriculture.

I point out here that inherent in that statement is a suggestion that if the Government had given consideration to this proposal, it would have been in breach of the rules of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. That is clearly not the case. Rule 4 covers quite precisely the proposition that was put forward as far as the Grains Council was concerned. The Government should have a second look at that particular aspect of the statement.

I return to the point I made at the beginning that Minister Kerin should either disown or withdraw that statement. Secondly, I want to put the emphasis on the necessity for Australia to get in place a strategy on how we are to handle the types of actions that are going on in world trade. As I said when I started, we have seen the dairy industry decimated, and we see the wheat industry being hurt very badly now. I wind up by posing the question: what will be next? Will it be the car industry, the steel industry, the timber industry or some other industry? Right now we are very vulnerable because we do not have a policy on it and we do not have a strategy on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to pay tribute to a great person, a great Australian, who died on 18 December last year. I refer to Commissioner Fred Brown of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Although Fred was a friend of mine for over 30 years, I do not intend to use words of my own on this occasion in this Parliament. Instead I intend to rely almost entirely on the eloquent tribute to Fred Brown delivered by his son Gerard at the requiem mass in Immaculate Conception Church, Hawthorn, on 21 December 1990.

SPEECH.PARA: Fred Brown was born in the Queensland sugar town of Nambour in 1928. He was the eldest of nine children and a seventh generation Australian. His ancestors arrived in Australia in 1792. His family grew up during the Depression and the Second World War. His mother died in 1941 when he was only 13 years of age. He was then already at work on the Brisbane waterfront as an apprentice shipwright, and his father was at war in the Persian Gulf and later in the North Sea and the Arctic Circle. Consequently, it was largely left to Fred Brown to support and hold together his family during and after the war years.

By the end of World War II, the work of a shipwright had been permanently changed by the demands of the war and the introduction of new materials and new technology. He worked hard to re-establish the craft and was elected State Secretary of the Shipwrights Union at 20 years of age. He was the youngest trade union secretary in Australia and was later made a life member of that union. At the same time, he became involved in the Labor movement in Queensland. He established Young Labor, of which he was elected State and then later Federal Secretary.

Subsequently, Fred Brown came to Melbourne to work for four years with a well-known Jesuit and lifelong friend, Father Desmond O'Connor, at Messenger House in Richmond. His reputation as an advocate and industrial officer resulted in his being recalled to Queensland.

Over the many years in Queensland he worked with the Federated Ironworkers Association under Laurie Short and Harry Hurrell, in the Clothing Trades Union, the Queensland Combined Industrial Unions Council, the Federated Clerks Union, the Australian Workers Union, and many other unions. During his travels in these years he met his wife Elsie in Melbourne.

In 1961 he was appointed the first full time union official in Papua New Guinea as General Secretary of the Public Service Association. His oft repeated aim in Papua New Guinea was to make himself redundant by so organising the workers and training the local people to run the PSA and to protect its own members as to make himself redundant. He headed the Papua New Guinea public sector union for four years and was the second Australian after Arthur Calwell to be made a life member of the Papua New Guinea Workers Association.

He returned to Queensland in 1964 and was elected Secretary of the Federated Clerks Union and President of the Queensland Combined Industrial Unions Council. He headed both organisations for almost a decade. For about four years, in the late 1960s and early 1970s, he served on the Immigration Advisory Council.

In 1972 Fred Brown was appointed to the Federal Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, one of only six members to be appointed under an application and selection procedure operating at the time. He was one of the Commission's youngest ever members. As indicated in the report that was presented to us last year by the Commission, Commissioner Brown at the time of his death was its senior Commissioner. He swore his oath of appointment on the Bible his mother had brought with her to Australia from Scotland. He was always immensely proud of his appointment. He had a dedication to the institution of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

For almost 20 years he was made responsible at different times for all of Australia's key industrial sectors. He was responsible for industrial relations on major national projects such as the North West Shelf, the Melbourne underground and the Westgate Bridge, and for a considerable period he was the Commissioner responsible in the area of the building of the new Parliament House, this Parliament House. For that reason, too, it is most fitting that we remember Fred Brown.

He convened the first joint sitting of the Federal Commission and a State industrial tribunal with Commissioner Bob Saker of the Victorian Commission, hearing building industry matters from November 1975 until November 1976. Whilst several of his decisions were appealed, none was ever overturned. That says a lot about Fred Brown's knowledge, experience and wisdom.

He had a great interest in the work of State industrial commissions. I know that when he visited Tasmania he would consistently contact members of the Commission there to see how things were going. He would consistently contact trade unions and employer organisations. He was deeply interested in ensuring that the system worked for the benefit of not only those who were parties to awards but also the community as a whole. Over many years he became involved in the education of industrial relations students and in 1989 was practitioner in residence at the University of Melbourne. He also participated in training overseas students brought to Australia for studies in industrial relations by the Department of Foreign Affairs.

I could add to Gerard's remarks by enumerating many other achievements of Fred Brown, but time does not permit that. And in any event, as Gerard said, a recitation of what Fred did does not really explain why he was the man he was. He was driven to sacrifice much of his private life to promote and defend and apply Catholic social justice principles which figured prominently in his life. It was the application of those principles in his life which earned him the affection of many and the respect of all, and it is that for which he will be remembered.

Although his working career was the public part of his life, his family, his religious convictions and his commitment to social justice were what he cherished most, and for which he will be most remembered. He was indeed a family man. He was a loving husband, father and brother to his extended family and a friend to many of us.

I simply convey-I am sure this would be echoed by people around the chamber-our deepest sympathy to his wife Elsie and to his daughters Catherine, Georgina, Helen and Philippa, to his son Gerard and to his sisters and brothers and extended family. Fred left his mark on all of us. He was indeed a good man, a good Australian. I was most honoured to be at his funeral, with the vast number of people who were there, praying and commending him to the faithful love of the Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse the remarks of Senator Harradine. I did not, in a personal way, have the knowledge of Commissioner Fred Brown that he had. At the time of his funeral, I did send condolences, as Minister for Industrial Relations, to his family; but I can say, from my knowledge of him on the Bench as a Commissioner, that he was a very fine example of what we in Australia aspire to as human beings and a fine example of the ideal of an arbitration commissioner, in that this was a man without a great deal of formal education, a man who was self-taught; a scholar notwithstanding the lack of formality to his scholarship, and therefore a learned person, but wise in the ways of the world and able to bring a street wisdom to his decisions which reflected an understanding of the life of the common person. I think that that shines through many of his written decisions and is a tribute to him, because he is indeed a model for what other Commissioners should be. I am happy to endorse the remarks of Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 1.42 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: does the Minister accept that some potentially efficient manufacturing businesses will go out of business or reduce their operations as a result of the tariff cuts which are unaccompanied by measures to cut costs outside their control, such as waterfront, shipping and other freight costs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind honourable senators, particularly those who may not have read the statement, that in the announcement which was made on Tuesday a program of tariff reductions was laid down, commencing in 1993. I again stress that it is very important to distinguish the consequences or effects of a recession from a program of tariff cuts, further tariff reductions which will commence in 1993. Senator Durack asks me if I accept that, as a result of the tariff cuts, some manufacturing establishments will go out of business. The answer to that question is yes, because in this country we cannot sustain-and I thought this was the view of the Opposition, expressed by Dr Hewson and Mr John Howard and others-businesses, for example, which have 100 per cent labour cost disadvantages with countries with which we trade. We cannot sustain in this country all the business infrastructure which we have had in the past for those sorts of reasons. What we can do is create new businesses and new industries, and indeed that process has been happening. Through a period of tariff cuts in the 1980s, we saw very substantial growth in some sectors of Australian business and particularly-
—Why has our manufacturing industry employment gone down to 15 per cent?
—Senator Boswell asks why our manufacturing industry employment has gone down 15 per cent?
—To 15 per cent.
—In the period from 1984-
—I am not interested in history. I have a vision for the future.

—The honourable senator ought to be interested. If he is not interested in history, he had better doze off again because I am going to give him a bit. The bit of history I am going to give him is that for the first time in 30 years, in the 1980s, manufacturing employment grew substantially in this country. If one looks at the consequences of the recession, of course, it has halted that growth and resulted in reduced employment. Until 1990-indeed, the end of 1990-manufacturing employment in this country grew for the first time. That was because there was a program of structural change in industry under way and because for the first time, year after year, manufacturing exports increased. If the honourable senator wants to know about it in any particular industry-if he is not interested in history-he should ask me as to how manufacturing employment has increased. The answer to Senator Durack's question is yes. Of course, with changes to the tariff regime which will commence in 1993, a whole range of other issues which are of importance to the competitiveness of manufacturers have to be continually looked at.

ANSWER.PARA: As I said in the statement: a competitive taxation regime, a competitive transport system and a competitive education sector are all relevant to the performance of manufacturing. The other issues which are relevant to the performance of manufacturing relate, of course, to the performance of individual firms. Governments cannot legislate for quality, for good management on the factory floor and for productivity on the factory floor. Firms can do those things and many of them have done them and are doing them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. When will the Government be setting deadlines for the general micro-economic reform to which the Minister has referred as being required?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a continual process of so-called micro-economic reform under way in taxation, in the transport system and in a whole range of areas. Those opposite have fallen for the two-card trick. People put up a few symbols and say, `These are the symbols which are of importance'. A whole range of symbols are important and there is a whole range of issues to be dealt with, and for these issues the Government has a continual program of micro-economic reform.

ANSWER.PARA: Although Senator Boswell is not interested in history, some honourable senators opposite might be. Thirty years of their governments never addressed those issues; 30 years of conservative governments never addressed those issues. When industry came to them to ask `Can we have a bit more higher tariff protection?' those opposite doled out to industry after industry made-to-measure tariffs. None of those issues were addressed because they were all masked by the abysmal failure of those opposite in addressing protection issues. Between 1973 and when they were thrown out of office there was not one percentage point change in industry assistance. They did nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs whether he is aware of a report by the Bureau of Criminal Intelligence and the Criminal Justice Commission which warns of suspected Yakuza activity in Queensland. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to demands by the Queensland-Japan Chamber of Commerce for references to be provided for Japanese businesses wishing to invest in Australia and, in particular, Queensland? What action is being taken by the Federal Government to protect Australian investment and business from Yakuza criminal gangs? Are the personnel of these highly organised criminal gangs known to the Australian police? Are any warnings issued by the Federal Government to Australian firms about the activities of these Japanese gangs? What measures are in place to stop the Yakuza entering this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answering Senator Jones, I know that his question is stimulated by a series of reports in the Queensland media concerning the supposed activity of Japanese organised crime figures in his home State. I know it is not fed by any anti-Japanese paranoia but from his interest in combating organised crime, which interest of course he takes into his membership of the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. I am not aware of the particular confidential law enforcement documents supposed to have been leaked, but if they have been leaked that itself would be of great concern. Quite clearly, it would affect the confidence in cooperative-
—A dorothy dixer always gets a line, doesn't it?

—It is not a dorothy dixer at all; it is obviously coming from Senator Jones's concern about the combating of organised crime. I am quite sure that he would agree with me that the leaking of police documents is abhorrent because it undermines confidence and trust between law enforcement agencies. I certainly do not know of any document or request for references from the Queensland-Japan Chamber of Commerce.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Jones has particularly asked about the action which the Australia Government might be taking to protect the community from the activities of the Yakuza criminal gangs from Japan. It is alleged that the gangs can launder money in legitimate business enterprises in order to disguise the origins of those funds in criminal activity in Japan. I must say that I am not aware of any particular threats to Australian investment and business from these Yakuza Japanese criminal gangs. Of course, should we become aware of such activity appropriate steps will be taken.

Certainly, wherever possible the Australian Federal Police monitors the presence and the activities of Yakuza criminal gangs should they enter Australia. It maintains very close liaison with other law enforcement agencies to achieve this. Of course, appropriate action will be taken should we become aware of the money laundering activities to which I think Senator Jones refers. Indeed, this Parliament has passed the most stringent laws relating to money laundering, including creating offences of bringing money into the country for the purposes of laundering and disguising the criminal origins of that money. In fact, the Parliament has passed laws which impose a fine up to $200,000 and a gaol term of up to 20 years for those people who bring money into the country for that purpose.

I am quite sure that we would take every step possible to monitor the activity of members of the Yakuza criminal gangs should they enter the honourable senator's home State or any other part of Australia. We are concerned to prevent money laundering, not only because it disguises the profits of crime which, of course, we would confiscate if they were identified but also it can undermine legitimate law abiding business and commercial activity. That cannot be tolerated either. We are keeping an eye on the matter. I can assure the honourable senator that the Australian Federal Police, in conjunction with the Queensland police, are keeping the matter under very close surveillance in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Leader of the Government representing the Treasurer. Given the Government's commitment to stabilising foreign debt by 1992, can the Minister quantify in any way how the industry statement will help correct Australia's major problems of debt and the current account deficit over the next 12 months? In particular, what role will the weakening of fiscal policy which has occurred play in addressing the problems brought on by this Government's economic mismanagement?

—As I have already said in Question Time today, the burden of the industry statement relates to matters which will take effect post-1992. I thought the honourable senator would have picked up that point if he had read the statement. In so far as the alleged weakening of fiscal policy is concerned, in terms of Government outlays I refer him to the Treasurer's statement made on Tuesday and the answer which I gave the honourable senator yesterday.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister has refused totally to answer the question that I asked, which related to the stabilisation of debt and the current account deficit, two of Australia's major problems. I ask: is it correct to assume from the Minister's answer that the Government has no idea at all what effect, if any, this economic statement will have on the critical issues of foreign debt and the balance of payments?
—The honourable senator asked me a question about the impact of the statement on the stabilisation of Australia's foreign debt. That was his question, and I have answered it.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Industrial Relations been drawn to reports suggesting that the Australian Council of Trade Unions believes that up to 40 per cent of employers have not paid into employee superannuation funds the contributions mandated by awards? Are these reports correct? If they are, can the Minister inform the Senate what action the Government is taking in regard to defaulting employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will be aware that the Government has been concerned to see superannuation extended to low and middle income groups which previously have had poor access to such schemes. By far the most important means of accelerating the spread of superannuation to date has been award based superannuation. The Government's submission to this year's national wage case proposed that the new wage fixing arrangements should provide a further round of 3 per cent award based superannuation to be phased in over several years.

ANSWER.PARA: About 80 per cent of Australian workers are covered by awards and, of those, about 80 per cent to 85 per cent have a superannuation entitlement provision inserted in them. This represents a total of about 65 per cent of employees in Australia. I have seen the report of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) suggesting that 40 per cent of employers have not paid the contributions required of them in the awards. A preliminary estimate by my Department indicates that this figure may be accurate. If this is the case, a significant number of companies, large and small, are, in fact, breaking the law and up to $700m in superannuation entitlements is currently being withheld from workers in this country.

Our evidence suggests that some companies are deliberately refusing to pay their workers superannuation. That is a serious state of affairs. We know that some companies are putting money aside, but not into superannuation funds. Some have raised ideological objections; some are ignorant; and some plead that in their circumstances there is not a capacity to pay.

The need to improve compliance with superannuation award provisions is recognised and the Government is acting accordingly. A national strategy involving education and enforcement activities has been developed in consultation with the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry. As honourable senators would know, the Industrial Relations Act 1988 has been amended recently to clarify and strengthen the provisions dealing with the enforcement of award based superannuation.

Results to date indicate the strategy's success in substantially raising compliance levels; for example, drives to improve compliance in the textile, clothing and footwear industries have resulted in compliance levels near 90 per cent. Similarly, compliance levels in the vehicle retail, service and repair sector and the furnishing and insurance industries have improved significantly. As to the hospitality industry awards, officers have contacted over 2,000 employers and have advised them of their obligations. My advice to employers is that they comply, and comply immediately. It is an entitlement of their workers at law and, by not paying, they are breaking the law.

I make these two concluding observations. I point out that a recent comment on superannuation was made by the superannuation services manager of KPMG Peat Marwick: for award employees, the industry funds provide one of the best, if not the best, alternatives for superannuation. I also say that there is an obligation on unions to enforce their awards. I have now directed officers of my Department-using the powers of prosecution and ultimately fining, if that prosecution results in a conviction-to pursue provisions to enforce the payment of superannuation and shift some of that $700m that must be out there to where it belongs-into the pockets of employees.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator, Milivoj Lajovic. On behalf of all senators, I wish him well on this visit to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators -Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the report on this morning's AM program that Australia has yet to commit itself to a contribution to the global environment facility (GEF) program of the World Bank and the United Nations, even though more than 20 nations have contributed funds since November last year? Will Australia be contributing to the GEF and, if so, how much? Given the vital importance of this fund in relieving pressures on global ecosystems, including tropical rainforests and international waters, will Australia take a leadership role by contributing a substantial amount before the first meeting of the GEF in May and thereby be involved in the deliberations of the GEF right from the beginning?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the report on this morning's Australian Broadcasting Corporation program that Australia is yet to commit itself to the contribution to the global environmental facility, or GEF as it is called. Australian participation in the GEF is still under active consideration by the Government. Of course, a number of portfolios are involved; but I would expect a decision to be made shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: The GEF was launched just at the end of last year, in November, as a three-year pilot scheme to provide funding to allow developing countries to incorporate environmental concerns in their development programs. Eastern European countries are also eligible. A number of developed and, as we understand it, developing countries have contributed to the scheme, although I cannot confirm right now that more than 20 have done so.

Australia has recognised the need for funding of the kind the GEF has been designed to meet, and we are certainly sympathetic to its aims. However, the point needs to be emphasised that the GEF is only one of a number of schemes for funding environmental programs that are currently littering the landscape. Demands for funds to tackle global environmental problems are growing and will unquestionably continue to grow. Australia will contribute its fair share to these global efforts. However, we may not be able to contribute to all the schemes that have been developed or are in the pipeline. We have a duty, especially in our current economic circumstances, to ensure that our funds and expenditure in this respect achieve maximum environmental benefit and effectiveness.

I want to emphasis that, quite apart from contributing in a policy sense to global environmental issues such as Antarctica, we have been putting our money where our mouth is in a number of quite specific programs. For example, in 1989 the Prime Minister announced a $20m four-year environmental development assistance program focused on our own region. We have already committed $6m to the Montreal protocol fund to protect the ozone layer; over $2m to environmental programs in the South Pacific, including $300,000 to the South Pacific regional environmental program, or SPREP; and $6.25m over three years to a project to install sea level monitoring stations in the region.

Last year we approved expenditure of an additional $5.2m to support international development cooperation on environmental global issues, which will be spent on activities such as population stabilisation, the protection of tropical forests, climate change and, again, the protection of the ozone layer. We are also contributing, as Senator Cook and others have made clear from time to time, to the International Tropical Timber Organisation.

I do not think it is fair to suggest that Australia has in any way resiled from its commitment to play a leading role in international efforts to find solutions to global environmental problems both in a policy sense and in a financial sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Has the Minister seen the comments by the Metal Trades Industry Association referring to initiatives for the advanced manufacturing technology (AMT) sector contained in Tuesday's industry statement? What is meant by advanced manufacturing technology in this context, and why has it been given such a prominent place in the industry statement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had those comments drawn to my attention. Advanced manufacturing technology relates to equipment which is generally computer controlled or microprocessor based, and it is used in the design, production, testing or handling of a product. For example, robotics, advanced machine tools, computer-aided design facilities and automated handling materials all fall into the category of advanced manufacturing technology. Advanced manufacturing technology has to go hand in hand with changes in the labour market in terms of multiskilling and increased skills. Just-in-time, total quality management and those sorts of things go hand in hand with the use of advanced manufacturing technology. It has application across all sectors of manufacturing and production. It is very relevant to industries such as the automotive, white goods and food processing sectors.

ANSWER.PARA: The take-up of advanced manufacturing technology in Australia has proceeded quite significantly in recent years, but it should be much higher. Australian firms still have a tendency to underinvest in technology. At this stage about 200 firms have been engaged in providing advanced manufacturing technology products and systems. These have benefited from things such as the bounty on machine tools and robots. The sector has gone through a period of rationalisation, and we now have some very good firms such as Laser Lab in Melbourne, Anchor in Melbourne, Kirby Engineering-Victoria, Farley Manufacturing and so on.

The industry statement is designed to see continued growth in the AMT sector because of its generic quality across industries. It is important to all industries. It is a key enabling technology. The development program announced in the industry statement will support producers of AMT products and services and help create linkages between the producers of those services and the users.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the Treasurer's statement to the Economic Planning Advisory Council on 22 February this year when he said that the expected Budget surplus for 1990-91 was now $1.7 billion compared with the estimate at the time of the Budget last year of $8.1 billion. Will the latest unemployment rate of 8.7 per cent announced today mean that the latest assumption of $1.7 billion will be severely reduced?

—In terms of projections of unemployment that were forecast in the Budget, we have now exceeded those projections. The unemployment rate is now 8.7 per cent, and that is in excess of the Budget forecast. That will mean-
—We are always fair, aren't we?

—Senator Hill interjects that I am always fair. I agree with that. I cannot be precise in terms of the announced figures today for unemployment and the effect it will have on the Budget, but it will increase or help reduce the Budget surplus.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to reported comments on changes to sugar assistance by Senator O'Chee in today's Australian Financial Review. I ask: has the Government altered industry assistance arrangements for sugar? What is the motivation for doing this?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statement indicates that the Government has altered the assistance arrangements for the sugar industry. That is consistent with the thrust of the whole statement. The point is that tariffs on agricultural products have exactly the same impact as tariffs on manufactured goods. While they provide some assistance to the protected industry, the higher prices caused by a tariff become an impost on consumers or businesses which buy those products.

ANSWER.PARA: The high rate of tariff on sugar was a classic example of this problem. The current tariff rate of $115 a tonne translates to over 35 per cent tariff. Consequently, sugar tariffs are being phased down ahead of the Government's consideration of post-1992 assistance arrangements.

The Government also believes that it is appropriate for assistance to the sugar industry to be brought back on track with the spirit of the 1988 decision. That decision, made in 1988, was altered following National Party inspired amendments-one might even say Senator Boswell inspired amendments-to the original legislation in the Senate.

The National Party does not realise that the sugar tariff phase-down is quite consistent with the tariff reductions, for example, on textile, clothing and footwear and motor vehicles-moves that are applauded by the farm sector which the honourable senator once used to represent. If these tariff cuts are, to use Senator O'Chee's words, `kicking the industry while it is down', I await with interest the development of a consistent line on tariffs from Senator O'Chee and, indeed, from the Opposition.

Senator O'Chee paints a nightmare scenario which will just not come about because by maintaining a specific tariff rate on sugar, the industry can be assured that it will remain protected in times of low world prices. At current world prices and exchange rate the new specific rates will equate to an ad valorem equivalent of 28 per cent in 1991 and 21 per cent in 1992. I am sure members of the National Party would be complaining very vigorously if there were tariff rates at that level on farm machinery or fertilisers.

Maybe I am misjudging members of the National Party; maybe they would not be complaining very vigorously-but they ought to be if they are representing the constituency they claim to represent. The cuts announced in the statement are very important to the food processing sector of Australian industry, which has to be given a fair go on international markets.

Let me just give the Senate some examples-and this is not history so Senator Boswell might be interested-of high protection for the sugar industry and the costs to the other industries in Australia. The current sugar pricing arrangements in Australia cost the food processing industry about $90m a year. The faster phasing arrangements should ensure further growth in this vital industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were you when the tomatoes were going rotten?

—I am interested that Senator Crichton-Browne should interject. I am not sure whether he is being dry or wet today, but he is normally fairly dry in these issues. I will give Senator Boswell an example which he will no doubt understand. It has been estimated that the current sugar pricing arrangements cost the confectionery industry $20m a year. Also, and Senator Boswell might remember this when he goes down to Aussie's, it costs the soft drink industry and ice-cream manufacturers very significant sums; for example, $3m are the current pricing arrangements in respect of ice-creams.
—Why do you hate farmers?

—Senator Boswell, I do not. Indeed, for all my period in this Parliament the one thing that the National Farmers Federation consistently advocated was that there should be reductions in tariffs in this country which were a burden on the farm sector. Senator Boswell wants it both ways.
—At a time when thousands of sugar canegrowers have had their crops flooded.

—As does Senator O'Chee, the putative leader of the National Party in the year 2000. When these sugar tariffs are finally phased out he will probably be leader and he will be able to contemplate a new world. But the sugar industry under this arrangement is still highly protected. It was a sensible and obvious phase down which is consistent with what the Government is doing throughout the statement.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister confirm that soon to be released figures from his Department show that the number of young Australians receiving the youth homeless allowance has increased by a massive 72 per cent over the year to February? Does the Minister acknowledge that such a dramatic rise in the number of young Australians being thrown onto the street and forced to survive on the youth homeless allowance is a direct result of his Government's economic mismanagement? What urgent action does the Government propose to take to ameliorate this tragic situation?

—The truth is that the figures about to be released show a slight reduction, I think, in teenage unemployment which runs contrary to the trend in unemployment nationally. So, I think Senator Alston is wrong again, but we are getting accustomed to his being wrong. When the figures come out, I will be very happy to comment on them.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I do not know whether it is ignorance or a wilful refusal to listen, but my question was directed to the numbers of those in receipt of the youth homeless allowance and nothing to do with youth unemployment. I would invite the Minister to pick up the right briefing note this time.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just thought I would pick up a briefing note. Why not? Senator Alston was talking to me about youth and unemployed youth and his concern. I want to say that Senator Alston ought to remember the line of his colleague Peter Reith:

ANSWER.PARA: The bottom line is we're saying to people: `Look, you can't leave school, go on the dole and stay there till you are ready for the age pension'.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President. This is a pathetic attempt to avoid answering the question, which relates to the youth homeless allowance. Could I invite you to direct the Minister that it is a very simple question and it deserves a very simple and straightforward answer.
—Order! The Minister shall answer the question.

—Thank you, Mr President. I can only say that if I was young in this country, I was unemployed or I was homeless, I would not be looking to Peter Reith or to John Hewson, who suggested I should live by my own means, and I certainly would not be looking to Senator Alston. But when those figures are released, I will be happy to comment on them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister will be aware of Public Sector Union criticism that the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is not fully committed to the principles of equal employment opportunity (EEO). Given the Federal Government's outstanding record in initiating three major pieces of legislation to raise the status of Australian women, is the Minister embarrassed that some senior public servants remain firmly entrenched in their view that the world of diplomacy is still a men's club? Will the Minister assist the Public Service Commissioner (PSC) by insisting that his Department put a higher priority on implementing legislation passed seven years ago?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of criticism expressed by the Public Sector Union (PSU) about my Department's equal employment opportunity record. The PSU and the Professional Officers Association (POA) on 27 February put out a joint statement critical of the Department's record. The union's criticism centred on two unrelated issues: restructuring in the management and information library area, which the unions believed had EEO implications, and the most recent promotion round to 11 Senior Executive Service (SES) band one positions in the Department.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the first one, the dispute over the library was heard in the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on 5 March. The matter was resolved by agreement of the parties on the basis of a proposal put forward by my Department. Despite all the fulminations before the event, EEO was not even raised by the POA as an issue at the hearing, nor should it have been because the proposed restructuring in no way contravened either the spirit or the letter of the Government's policy on EEO. I note again that the Public Sector Union appeared at the hearing on 5 March in support of the POA and its representative said nothing in that respect either.

On the latest SES promotion round, it is correct that none of those promoted were women. There is, however, a simple reason for this: the selection advisory committee, which included a senior female officer representing the Public Service Commission, came up with an order of merit which did not include any women among the top 11 applicants. The promotions were the result of a merit based, competitive process, as the law requires. Of the 163 applicants only 14 or about 8 1/2 per cent were in fact women. Less than 7 per cent of all applicants were promoted, and I think the process should be understood in that light.

More generally, I do accept that compared with the Public Service average, my Department has fewer women at middle and senior levels. It is by no means the worst offender or the only offender in this respect because the relatively low number of women at senior levels is common across most departments. To some extent this imbalance in the representation of women at the senior levels is the result of time lags in past recruitment practices. The Department has relatively few women in the SES and its feeder groups because its recruitment until the late 1970s was really quite unbalanced in gender terms.

There is another reason unique to my Department for the gender imbalance, and I refer to the added burden which overseas service does place on female officers balancing career and other aspirations. It is an unfortunate, but I think undeniable, sociological fact, that it does remain harder for married women than for married men to take overseas postings-certainly they perceive it in those terms.

The Department, with my full support, is working hard to find ways to eliminate or compensate for these factors. This includes efforts through the overseas allowance system to compensate for the loss of a second income and includes efforts to reach reciprocal arrangements on the employment of spouses overseas and also removing obstacles to the employment of spouses as locally engaged staff in our overseas posts.

It is also the case that recruitment practices have significantly changed. The graduate intake has had approximately equal numbers for the last several years. This year's intake, Senator Reynolds will be delighted to learn, had 17 females and only 10 males. The number of women in the SES feeder group-the senior officer grade B level-is also growing. Eight of the 20 most recent promotees to this level were females. This represented 40 per cent of promotees from a field in which female applicants were only 16 per cent. Female officers are well represented in the Department's training courses, which are of course crucial to career development. The gender balance in these programs is approximately equal.

In short, the world of Australian diplomacy-whatever it may have been in the past-is becoming less of a man's club, although obviously not as fast as my Department or I would like. The Department is committed to working with the PSU and other staff associations on EEO issues and a joint union-management working group has already been established to look urgently at further means of improving implementation of that program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: SHOW PROMOTION

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Why did his Department maintain a carnival-like stall last weekend at the Golden Grove Show in Adelaide's north-east suburbs with staff handing out balloons on sticks, plastic bags containing cardboard sunshades with the words `Social Security. We're here to help you' emblazoned thereon, two balloons, a 1991 year planner and a refrigerator magnet? I further ask the Minister the number and cost of these items; the number of staff involved and their overtime costs; where else this exercise has occurred or is planned; and the total cost to Australian taxpayers.

—I am going to admit that I did not know that my Department was at the Golden Grove Show last week. I am going to have to come out and admit it: I did not know. I did not know that it had two balloons at the show either. I really did not know that. I am told that it even had a magnetic sticker for the fridge; I did not know that. But I did know that it had a few of them. I recall that, in the Senate the other day, Senator Alston made some remarks about how we had spent $11.56m on balloons and stickers for the fridge. I think that I should give the Senate an idea of how that $11.56m was really spent. An amount of $1.04m was on Newstart--
—Just answer the question.

—These are the things that are handed out at the shows, you dill. The $1.04m was for publicity and pamphlets on Newstart, a very important program for the unemployed. Of the $11.5m, $2.93m was for three editions of Age Pension News. Half a million dollars was for a sole parents information kit. Four million dollars of it-and this is terrible!-was for television and print campaigns on family allowance supplement and family allowance. The amount of $350,000 was for a launch of financial information service for pensioners brochures so that we can get financial information out to pensioners. Another $1m was for the launch of the jobs, education and training program. Another $1.5m was for a superannuation campaign-television and print advertisements. Another $600,000 was for the upgrading of multilingual telephone information services. Most of the items that I have just mentioned are used by the Department for promotional purposes. I hope that the Department gets out to more and more shows. At a time when unemployment is rising in this country, and at a time when there are troubles, we have to be out there at the coalface talking to them--
—You would not know an unemployed person if you fell over one. That is the difference between you and this Department.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I regret that the Minister was unable to answer the specific questions that I asked-probably because he is more preoccupied with the internal factional wranglings of the Labor Party than with the administration of his own Department. In the light of his inability to answer the question in detail, I ask: does he really believe that the maintenance of a stall handing out cardboard hats, balloons and fridge magnets at a show is necessary to promote his Department when it has a number of highly visible regional offices? Further, is the whole $11m a year spent on promotion the best use of scarce welfare dollars, which could rather be paid directly to needy people in our community, whose numbers are increasing dramatically as a result of the recession which, in this Government's terms, `we had to have'?

—I would have thought, given that I had anticipated a supplementary question and had already gone through the $11 1/2m, that Senator Chapman would have saved himself the embarrassment of asking it. But now he has asked it, I will take the opportunity to bat on with it, because I think it is worth doing. The very idea that there is something wrong with the Department of Social Security actually spreading its message I find extraordinary. Not only are we going to continue to do what we are doing, but I intend to fight for more money to do more of it in the next Budget. I intend to make sure the message gets out to people right around Australia about the whole range of social security services that are available to them-particularly in a recession. If we were at the show, as I said, I will make sure we get to more of them. If there were only two balloons, I am going to ask, `Why two? Why weren't there more?'.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. It is not about balloons; it is about aeroplanes. Is the Minister aware of reports alleging that on 12 March this year three Australian Airlines aircraft without sufficient life rafts were flying illegally over water? Can the Minister confirm that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) is conducting an investigation into these allegations? Will the Minister advise what action will be taken against Australian Airlines if this alleged serious breach of regulations and disregard for passenger safety is proven to have occurred? What assurances can the Minister give the travelling public that this or any similar safety breaches are not occurring regularly on Australian Airlines and any other carriers?

—I was just having a grizzle to one of my colleagues that I have not seen my family in Darwin for three weeks, and he reminded me that today is a direct broadcast day. So, hello Rosemary, hello Libby, hello Robbie, hello Daniel. I will not do it again, Mr President.
—Order! I hardly think it is relevant to the question you were asked.

—It is relevant to me. Mr President, I know that I am a trial to you, but I will not do it again. I can, unfortunately, confirm these reports. But it was not the case that there were three aircraft involved; there was one. I am advised by the Chief Executive of Australian Airlines, John Schaap, that one Australian Airlines flight to Perth inadvertently carried two life rafts in its cargo hold, instead of where they should be properly stowed-in the cabin. Australian Airlines itself reported this incident to the Civil Aviation Authority. I have been assured by the CAA that this is an unusual incident. There are no regular breaches of this kind. I confirm that it is a serious problem. The CAA is examining the matter; it is investigating it. It will report to me when the investigation is completed. It will take whatever action with Australian Airlines as is considered necessary. I have been advised by Mr Schaap that Australian Airlines has also taken its own remedial action immediately to ensure this does not happen again.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations: as we find ourselves in the recession that his Government says we needed to have, what are the consequences for Australian women of the Australian Iron and Steel Pty Ltd v. Banovic matter? What is his Government's attitude to the conclusions in that case?
—I must say that I am not familiar with that particular case. If the honourable senator wishes to provide me with the details, I will respond to her question.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I ask the Minister, as the Minister for Industrial Relations, and with his self-professed expert knowledge on industrial law, much touted in this place, and as the Minister who constantly arranges dorothy dixers on status of women matters, whether he is really telling the chamber that he is not aware that this is the most important indirect discrimination case in Australia thus far. Is he not aware that it concerns the last-on first-off principle and the question of whether that can be a separate and independent act of indirect sex discrimination under his own Government's legislation?
