If he is not familiar with that, will he please cease pretending to have some interest in status of women issues and to have some knowledge of industrial law as it relates to women?

—Much of the supplementary question was devoted to making offensive remarks. Senator Vanstone is, of course, a specialist in doing that. I am not familiar with the judgment in this particular case in a detail in which I feel able to answer the question. I repeat the invitation: if the honourable senator wants an answer to the question in detail, which I will be happy to supply, then she can give me a copy of the judgment or I will in fact look up the reference and give her an answer myself. On the supplementary part of the question in which the honourable senator used words that I do not have some interest in equal opportunity for workers in Australia, let me say--
—I didn't say that. I said your much professed interest in the status of women.

—Thank you for the correction-my much professed interest in the status of women. I have a very great interest in the status of women in this country and I am proud to be a Minister responsible for the Affirmative Action Agency, which plays a role in ensuring that the status of women in this country is protected and that equality of opportunity in employment is open for them. That is legislation which, if it did not exist and which if the Agency over which I have ministerial responsibility did not pursue, then the status of women would be much less than it is now.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Given the role played in causing the Gulf war by Iraq's excessive arms build-up, I ask: what can the Government do to contribute to restraints on the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and excessive transfers of conventional arms, globally and in our own region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Gulf war and the massive arms build-up by Iraq in the years that preceded it do, of course, dramatically underline the need to reinvigorate international efforts to prevent nuclear, chemical, biological and missile proliferation and also to address the unrestricted sales of conventional arms. The scale of that build-up is, I think, amply appreciated by honourable senators but one recent statistic that makes it even clearer is that before the recent war, Iraqi military expenditure amounted to more than 27 per cent of its gross national product compared with 2.5 per cent for Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia does have a capacity and an international standing on arms control issues to play a helpful role in this respect. In consultation with other governments, we are actively pursuing a coordinated plan of action.

In the first place, there is an urgent need for measures to strengthen the existing export control regimes on items related to nuclear, chemical, biological and missile proliferation. We are working right now, in the nuclear suppliers group, the Australia group on chemical and biological weapons and the missile technology control regime to achieve that. We recognise, however, that the only feasible, long term answer to the proliferation of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons is through global multilateral agreements.

Therefore, secondly, we will work to revitalise and impart a new sense of urgency to the negotiations in Geneva on the question of a comprehensive chemical weapons convention. To this end, I have been in contact in recent days with other relevant foreign Ministers, suggesting a particular strategy for achieving just that. Thirdly, we are encouraging the countries of the Middle East to themselves reach their own regional measures, drawing some experience in this respect from our own efforts with the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone and with the regional chemical weapons initiative initiated by the Prime Minister.

Finally, the international community has yet to come to grips with the proliferation of massive amounts of offensive conventional weaponry. Australia again is a quite active participant in the growing exchanges between countries on this particular problem. The United Nations (UN) expert group on conventional arms transfers has been focusing on increasing the transparency of conventional arms transfers. Australia is a participant in that expert group and we are looking forward to the finalisation of its recommendations and their early implementation, especially on the question-as I have said in this chamber-of a UN register of arms transfers.

To conclude, it should also perhaps be said that the most enduring and satisfactory outcome for the Middle East would be the achievement of a political settlement, which would at least reduce the incentive to purchase arms and would hopefully include a regional agreement capping force levels. We strongly support efforts towards this end by countries of the region assisted by the United States and other key parties to the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. I intended to ask this question during the Budget session but refrained because of the Gulf conflict. However, as that situation is now largely resolved, I direct the Minister's attention to the fact that April to December this year will be the fiftieth anniversary of the siege of Tobruk, which must rank as one of the most gallant episodes involving Australian service men and women during World War II. I ask the Minister: what plans have been made by the Federal Government to recognise this significant event? Could these plans include a visit of selected members of the 9th Division to the battleground as a means of paying respect to the many Australians who lost their lives during this battle, which many believe marked the beginning of the defeat of Germany? I add that a visit of this nature by Australian returned service personnel could only add to the efforts of peace in the area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My Department is not directly responsible for this particular matter; it is a matter carried by a committee of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. But naturally we have a fairly substantial interest. Many matters are to be highlighted over the next two years in terms of fiftieth anniversaries of the Second World War. There is obviously the Coral Sea celebration and the anniversary of events concerning the Kokoda Trail. There is a whole range of things. In May this year Crete will be part of a particular event. I am not sure of the specific plans for Tobruk but I will find out and get an answer especially about the 9th Division.

ANSWER.PARA: Obviously in the next four years we will be going through a period of celebrating many of the events of the Second World War. I might say that 1992 will be more enjoyable than 1991 because we started to have some victories then. Albeit we want to celebrate victories, we also have to remember defeats and setbacks. I hope they can all be honoured with some sort of equal amount of attention. I think honourable senators will realise that it will be extremely difficult to commemorate every aspect of the Second World War. I will make inquiries of the Committee--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tobruk is very special.
—I do not think anybody would disagree with Senator Walters that Tobruk would easily rank certainly in the top 10 events of the Second World War in regard to Australia.
—After Collingwood's premiership.

—Collingwood never won a premiership during the war because all our blokes were away fighting. I will follow that up. As I say, the main focus over the next few months will be May in Crete. The HMAS Perth will be going over as part of those celebrations. I will get a full answer about Tobruk. I also put honourable senators on notice that things such as the Kokoda Trail and the battle of the Coral Sea will be major events.

—My question is directed to either the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or the Minister for Defence. It comes from one who supported the Government over the Gulf resolutions. I refer to reports that an Iraqi convoy retreating from Kuwait along a 90-kilometre sector of the Umm Qasr Road was bombed out by coalition forces with enormous loss of life. Does the Minister agree with me that this action should not be excluded from examination as to its legitimacy or efficiency? Why was the action taken? Whilst the rules of war permit the engagement of retreating fully armed forces who refuse to surrender, was there not considerable evidence that these Iraqi forces were confused about how to surrender? In this instance did the coalition forces ensure, by leaflet drops or otherwise, that the Iraqis evacuating Kuwait along that road were invited to surrender? In view of the fact of the supremacy of the coalition forces at the time and the fact that the northern end of the road was blocked off by coalition forces, could the bombing of the convoy be regarded as nugatory from a military standpoint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a terribly long question and trying to answer it in full will be difficult here. The parts of it that I cannot answer today, I will supply. My understanding is that constantly from 15 January onwards the whole of the war sector was leafleted with instructions in Arabic and drawings as to how people could best surrender. General Schwarzkopf also made absolutely clear at the start of the land offensive the conditions under which allied forces would not attack. That was simply that opposing forces would surrender their small arms, not be in a military group and make it absolutely certain by signalling with their hands up that they were surrendering.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not have enough information on the specific event, nor have I been briefed on it, to make an evaluation myself. It was a confusing time from an air war point of view especially, not the least of which we have seen blue on blue, that is, some of the coalition forces were hit from the air. There was an enormous amount of smoke haze around at the time. Therefore, I find it hard to make an evaluation. If I can get a better evaluation from our military advisers, I will forward the information on to Senator Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation in relation to a matter of fact in a question I asked yesterday of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). In that question I referred to convicted phone tapper Robert Martin. I should have referred to convicted phone tapper Robert Smith. Of course, I apologise to the Martin family for any hurt I have caused.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday Senator Macdonald asked me a question about a press report on Townsville Airport. I have obtained the following information. The Department of Defence has no present operational requirement to extend the runway at Townsville; nor is it considering any contribution to the present runway extension proposal. This matter has been thoroughly investigated in the past and Defence's position has been clearly enunciated in responses made by previous Defence Ministers, by local Government representatives and other members of Parliament. However, Defence is in the process of buying land at the end of the runway at a total cost of $26,000 to enable the runway to be extended in the future should such a requirement either for Defence or civil aviation needs arise.

ANSWER.PARA: This is the maximum contribution that Defence is to make at this time. A longer runway at Townsville will permit heavily laden military aircraft to operate from the runway at the increased margins of safety. I stress again that there is no current operational requirement for Townsville to have an extended runway. It is not cost effective to do so for present military purposes. In accordance with the agreed interdepartmental arrangements, any civil aviation need to extend the runway would be the responsibility of the Federal Aviation Authority. I understand that the support of the airlines would be required for any such proposal.

On a separate but related issue, the Federal Airports Corporation has written to my Department proposing the relocation of concrete barrier plinths which notionally reduce the operational length of the existing runway by 200 metres. The original RAAF arrester barriers on the runway were net barriers mounted on concrete plinths, about one metre high at the runway ends. With the installation of new hook cable barriers across the runway, the net barrier has been taken down. The Air Force retained the plinths so that the net barrier could be recommissioned for specific military operations. However, the Air Force is currently re-examining its requirement and the possibility of repositioning the plinths in the runway overrun.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, could I move that the Senate take note of that answer and could I seek leave to make a short statement about it?

SPEECH.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988 I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer to explain why answers have not yet been provided to question No. 333 and question No. 364, of which notice was given on 26 November and 5 December 1990 respectively, relating to child-care expenses, women in employment and equal employment opportunity matters, notice of which was given to the Minister's office yesterday.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Following Senator Newman's request yesterday, a further request was made of the office of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). We were assured that the answers would be available as soon as possible, if practicable today. They have not yet arrived. I will just have to pursue the question further with the Treasurer himself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has told us what he has done, I do not believe that can really be called an explanation. Therefore, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That there be laid on the Table of the Senate, on or before 9 April 1991, answers by the Minister representing the Treasurer to questions on notice Nos 333 and 364, together with an explanation for the delay in responding.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In answer to a question from Senator Faulkner today, Senator Button made certain comments in relation to the sugar industry and my press release of yesterday in relation to the same matter. During his answer, Senator Button said that the sugar industry was still heavily protected. He also made comments in his answer that suggested that I would support protectionism for the sugar industry at any cost. Those claims are a misrepresentation for the following reasons. Firstly, the sugar industry in this country is not heavily protected. In fact--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator O'Chee is now starting to transgress and to debate the matter. He is entitled to say where he has been misrepresented to correct the record, but he is not entitled to give a dissertation of several reasons as to his views on a particular matter.

—Mr President, I shall add to the point of order. There has been no misrepresentation alleged at this stage. Senator O'Chee is just a bit aggrieved by having the finger put on him. That does not amount to misrepresentation.
—Order! You must not debate the issue, Senator O'Chee. You must point out where you have been personally misrepresented.

—I have been personally misrepresented inasmuch as Senator Button has insisted that I would argue for protection for a sugar industry which is heavily protected. The substance of the explanation must therefore traverse the question of whether the sugar industry has been heavily protected. It is a matter of record that it is not. However, further to that, Senator Button did not acknowledge the reasons for my statement in the press release. I said what I have said because of the particular circumstances of the sugar industry at the moment.
—Order! Senator O'Chee, you are going beyond the point of a personal explanation.

—Mr President, I will therefore conclude my remarks very briefly by saying that Senator Button's aspersions are not correct and the comments that he has made are thoroughly inaccurate. I look forward to receiving a copy of the Hansard `pink' from Senator Button's office so that I may refute the allegations in more detail at another time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Senator Cook:
That the Senate take note of the statements and documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was to be an industry policy statement dealing with the Government's industry plans in relation to the car industry and like matters. But it was hijacked by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as an assertion of his leadership after the Press Club fall-out with Mr Keating and, more recently, as a political response to the disastrous Government-driven recession.

SPEECH.PARA: In classical Hawkespeak, it is yet another call to join together to meet a challenge-all the jargon of the past. He calls for the understanding and commitment of all Australians, as he puts it, as individuals and through their respective organisations, to act: the culture of a discredited accord; the language of a summit; all excuses for good leadership and direction. What was supposed to be an important industry statement-and that section of it which does actually relate to industry reform, in part, we support-was reduced sadly to a political stunt. It was quite understandable that Senator Button, refusing to be part of the charade, declined to read the Prime Minister's speech.

The package is titled Building a Competitive Australia, but fails to address major obstacles to achieving that goal, obstacles within the province of Government. There is no doubt that Australian business should be more outward looking, more aggressive and more adventurous, but it is so easy to knock our exporters without addressing the Government-imposed or Government-sanctioned burdens which limit their capacity to compete.

The Prime Minister seems finally to appreciate that we exist within a very competitive world, but fails to appreciate that we cannot expect our business to compete unless it is given a reasonable opportunity to do so. This is the major failing of this package. The Prime Minister claimed to look beyond the question of industry reform at the wider question of improving the productive capacity of the economy, an economy which he said needed to be more internationally competitive, but he failed to address the principal responsibilities of government.

In the macro sense business must operate within the government-determined economic settings, yet this Government adopted interest rate policies which crush domestic business, interest rates that are still in real terms at prohibitive levels. In the micro sense this Government has failed adequately to address the inefficient waterfront; prohibitive transport costs; stifling regulations; inflexible industrial relations structures; inefficient statutory corporations; big, expensive government; and a tax structure which destroys incentive.

These are the domestic issues that the Government must address if it is to give Australian business a fair chance at being internationally competitive. These are the major issues which are all but avoided in this statement. Rather than calling on Australians to be more competitive, the Government should have set down a much-accelerated program of reform of these inhibiting factors which are within its control. Its failure to do so demonstrates the shallowness of the package as a program of reform and accentuates its form as yet another political sham.

Madam Acting Deputy President, one should have guessed what was coming from the history of the document, and I invite you to recall the setting. After eight years of the Hawke-Keating Government, it had driven Australia into arguably the worst recession since World War II. It was desperate to hang on to power but incredibly uncertain as to its direction. Australian production had become so uncompetitive within the Government's economic parameters that foreign debt had quadrupled to over $164 billion, and every month the balance of payments was worsening by about $1.5 billion. The level of enlightenment of Mr Keating, the Treasurer, the architect of this economic disaster, was his assessment that the figures had moved from being beautiful to not bad.

The Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Government's economic partner in this disaster, was pressing its 10-point package for selective intervention with an increase in government spending of $227m. The Australian Labor Party's National Secretary, Mr Hogg, was pressing for a more interventionist policy in similar terms. The Treasurer and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) were quarrelling over who would have responsibility for assistance levels in the automotive industry.

At this time, Senator Button's Cabinet submissions were leaked. What were they? Tariff reductions and some specific assistance programs. To commentators his reported approach sounded very much like shifting the deckchairs on the Titanic. After all his time as Minister, for all the `good' years and his access to the highest echelons of industry and Australia's greatest thinkers, he could not shift beyond the myopic focus of industry policy.

It was then Hawke the politician who became nervous. His reaction was to invite Ministers to give their separate views on policy direction, so Cabinet kites were set flying in all directions. Button, Kerin, Keating and Dawkins all supported Government intervention to allow, in the words of Senator Button, `some benefit in selective correction of market failure in the manufacturing sector'. By November it was rumoured that the stage management of the statement would move from Button to Hawke. Senator Bolkus called for enlightened economic rationalism. In fact, the call for strategic intervention stormed in from the Left Ministers, Howe and Bolkus in particular. Keating called them the `new interventionists'.

Then Mr Crean got into the act of advocating sectoral policies. Mr Keating referred to this as the new McEwenism. The Left, as naive as ever, tried to draw a linkage between domestic reforms and reform in world trade-a sort of indexed reform of industry policy on a world scale. Mr Keating attacked the Crean proposal likening it to another Victorian Economic Development Corporation push.

By now, the resource protection issue was public. Mr Hawke in Tasmania said that it was not necessary; at the same time, Mr Griffiths was circulating a paper calling for it. As is not unusual, Mr Hawke back-pedalled. The real message in this sad sequence of events is that it evidences a shambles in government, confusion and uncertainty and a total lack of leadership at a time when Australia desperately needed real leadership. A master speech writer was then brought in to attempt to craft this mess into something saleable.

This is the behaviour of a government which no longer deserves to govern, which has lost confidence in itself and, therefore, cannot expect the confidence of others. This failure of confidence comes through the document. It should be blatantly obvious that to maintain standards of living in this country we need to be internationally competitive. That does not mean that we need to be more competitive than we were last year. We do not compete with ourselves; it is the international marketplace within which we must compete, and against which we must be tested.

So much material has been put before the Government of recent times to demonstrate the extent of failure in this regard. A lot of it has been collated for the recent conference of the Business Council of Australia `Developing Australia's Competitiveness'. Which unimaginative government sought to piggyback on this theme? It was the same business group which a year ago warned the Government of the threat to Australia of a prolonged build-up of debt-a message which was not heard as the position has further deteriorated in the meantime. On page 10 of its background paper, the Business Council said:

Our competitiveness provides the critical foundation for wealth creation and determines the ability of Australia to grow faster or slower than the rest of the world. Developing a strong base of internationally competitive businesses is therefore vital to the long term success of Australia.

That is clearly correct. The Business Council reminds us that the answer is not just in industry reform. If most Australian firms are to be successful, then the economy as a whole has to be improved. If we look at manufacturing examples alone, it is estimated that industry controls only about one-third of its total costs-the balance is beyond its capacity. That is why interest rates, high inflation and exchange rates are also vitally important; that is why transport infrastructure, the waterfront, the taxation regime and all of those micro-economic areas are vital. It is, in fact, why the Government's total economic package and its economic performance are so critical. It, again, demonstrates why this package fails.

The Business Council looked at Australia's competitiveness, and it is not a happy picture. For example, the Government should be aware that Australia rates poorly on a wide range of labour market measures-with high rates of absenteeism, high labour turnover, low willingness to accept new technology and a poor ability to adjust remuneration to economic circumstances and limited automation-because each day Senator Cook boasts about the claimed achievements of this industrial relations system which has let us down so badly. It should also be aware that regulations hampering business are also rated poorly by international comparison.

Let us look at other areas within the province of government. Studies by Professor Henry Ergas, the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development and Brian Haig suggest that Australia's utilities have labour capital productivity at levels at best 50 per cent of that overseas. This is, of course, an enormous extra cost for Australian business. Even in power production where we have great natural advantages, we are slipping.

In 1987 we were the second lowest cost power producer among 12 major countries but by 1989 we had fallen to sixth. In coastal shipping the Industries Assistance Commission estimated that foreign flag ships were 20 to 50 per cent cheaper than Australian flag ships. In rail transport the Industry Commission in its 1989-90 annual report estimated that 30.5 per cent overall cost reductions were possible from achieving international standard work practices.

The result of all this is that, whilst productivity levels in Australian agriculture and mining are high by world standards, in manufacturing we are 20 to 25 per cent below international best performances and in the private service sector often 10 per cent below the average international levels. When the Business Council compared productivity in around 15 manufacturing locations in Australia to the best performed in similar plants overseas, it concluded that productivity could be raised 25 per cent in Australia.

Senator Button would be aware of the Industry Commission draft report on the automotive industry which showed that labour productivity in Australia was less than half that in Japan and two-thirds of that in the United States. In cement, despite paying wages that were 75 per cent of US levels, low productivity meant Australian unit labour costs were 75 per cent higher than US levels, and so one can go on. What these dismal figures demonstrate is how far Australia has fallen behind and how desperate is the need for radical and fundamental reform; not the sort of tinkering around the edges contained in much of the statement we are debating today.

What is particularly disturbing is that for a long time our productivity growth has been slower than overseas, but since this Government has been in office the rate at which we are slipping further behind has in fact accelerated. This, one suspects, is because of the additional burden placed on business by the Government's failure to get its economic policies right. As is validly said in the Business Council background paper to which I have been referring:

In the end companies themselves will succeed or fail in international competition, but the competitive environment in which they operate is influenced by institutions, infrastructure and Government policies. The most important factors are not specific industry assistance, but those factors shaping the supply of quality of human resources and other basic infrastructure and institutions across the economy.
This is where the Government has failed business in this statement.

On the issue of comparative competitiveness, let me conclude with Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd and remind the Senate of the Bureau of Industry Economics research paper No. 34 which showed poor labour, capital and total unit cost performances for the Australian plant compared with Kodak's plants in Brazil, Canada and the United Kingdom (UK). Labour productivity per hour, in fact, was around 10 to 20 per cent lower than Brazil or Canada. Costs were higher partly due to the higher proportion of paid hours not involving production. Unit capital costs were almost double that of the United Kingdom and two-thirds higher than Canada. This company's inefficient work practices were recently rewarded by a payment by this Government of some $36m of taxpayers' money.

If the statement had announced commencement of the third runway in Sydney, mining at Coronation Hill, the scrapping of the illogical and irrational three mine uranium policy-which was raised during the discussion period leading up to this paper but then returned to the too-hard basket-or the reform of trans-Tasman shipping, or a goods and services tax which would have allowed the abolition of all the wholesale sales taxes, then the Government could have said that it was showing a lead. But as the public debacle of the months leading up to the statement demonstrated, the Government has neither the vision nor the courage to tackle the big issues.
The ICI experience being now so often quoted demonstrates how an efficient industry cannot overcome the competition gap unless government meets its share of the responsibility.
I conclude by stressing the close relationship between the domestic reform agenda and the need to make Australia internationally competitive. Garnaut in his report said:
Australia's poor productivity growth is closely related to its parochial economic orientation.
Later:
Australia's largest problem is that our isolation has been greatly compounded by exceptionally high costs at and inside our borders.
What is the result in international terms? Garnaut reminds us that:
Foreign trade accounts for much less of our production than in other advanced countries.
So it was a damning indictment that, when McKinsey looked recently at Austrade, the Government's principal promotion body, he found on the part of government:
an absence of a clear strategy that encourages development of exports.

This, of course, was denied by Senator Button. But in this statement we note that Austrade has been taken out of his hands and passed to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. Could there be any clearer acknowledgment of failure?

So the Government has let Australia down in the obstacles it has placed in the way of building competitive domestic industry, and it has let Australia down in not appreciating the linkage between domestic efficiency and international competitiveness.

This statement is to be condemned for what it has failed to do. The necessary reforms, which I have mentioned and which my colleagues will expand upon in speeches that are to follow, will not be achieved through this Government. This much we have now learned. But they will be achieved through the first Hewson government and only then will Australian industry be given a fair opportunity to be truly internationally competitive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill has given one of his usual fluent, elegant speeches. But when we read Hansard we will note that he said that Australia's problems are fundamentally the result of two sources: the Government and the ordinary working Australian, that is, those people who are presently in the public gallery listening to the speeches. They symbolise those Australians whom Senator Hill criticised as being lazy, failing to be productive and taking money which they really do not deserve.
—He never said anything of the sort.

—Senator Panizza says that Senator Hill did not really say that. I must have misunderstood the thrust of the statement by Senator Hill that our inefficient work force has taken $36m of the taxpayers' money. I am not sure what that meant unless it meant that the ordinary Australians, who have made this nation the highly successful place it has become over the past 200 years, are not worth giving $36m to.
—They are not the only ones that made Australia.

—Of course they are not the only ones. Senator Panizza is now taking me to task for saying that a lot of great, good, hard working people have contributed to Australia over two centuries. He seems to find that objectionable. If Senator Panizza and, through him, the Opposition want to criticise those Australians who have stood behind the plough, worked in factories, made cars, driven trams, conducted small businesses and taught in schools, then so be it. However, there is a big difference between the Opposition and the Government, and that is what Parliament is all about. The Government has a lot of respect for the ordinary men and women who go about their daily labours and do not enjoy the privileges that people like Senator Panizza and myself enjoy here. Those ordinary Australians have a fairly hard struggle. I simply say to Senator Patterson, who is trying to interject, that I do not-and I am sure that senators on this side of the chamber do not-object to giving to those people $36m in tax relief.
—Are you implying that we don't?

—I do not want to get into an argument. I simply say that, in so far as the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) has said that we have an inefficient work force and that this Government is wrong in, and is to be criticised for, giving $36m of taxpayers' money to them, that is a criticism that this Government accepts, because its position is that the ordinary working men and women who have made this country do deserve proper rewards.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true enough, as Senator Hill has said, that business has made a grand contribution. Firms like Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd and CRA Ltd are shining examples of what can be done in Australia. We simply say that it is not only management and the people who have taken the risks that are involved in business; the people who have worked behind the benches, in the offices and in the buses have also made a contribution. The difference between this side of the chamber and the other side of the chamber is that we accept that all citizens in this country are worthy of consideration; are worthy of proper pay; are worthy of proper conditions; and are worthy of proper dignity.

TALK.START.PARA: —So is primary industry.

—As Senator Panizza says, so is primary industry. Senator Panizza is one of the outstanding examples, together with Senator Crane, of the primary industry producers of this country. But we simply say that we should not look at particular groups; we should look at Australia as a whole and see what has been done. What happens on the other side? I think that Senator Hill, God bless him, has fallen into this trap. He has criticised the work force, which, through the trade unions and the peak organisation, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, has sought not only proper conditions for itself but proper conditions for the country. I simply invite the people on the other side to look at fact rather than fiction; reality rather than myth. Senator Patterson and Senator Watson would agree that it is better, if we are going to proceed to the proper solution to this country's problems, to look at fact rather than fiction; to look at reality rather than myth.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a popular view in this country that industrial disputes are widespread at Australian workplaces. There has been excellent work done recently by four young people in the Commonwealth Department of Industrial Relations who deserve great praise: Ron Callus, Alison Morehead, Mark Cully and John Buchanan. They have done great research in this area. What have they found? They have put on one side the popular view that people take and they have put the reality on the other side.

Their research shows that the popular view, as I said, is that industrial disputes are widespread at Australian workplaces. The fact is that 72 per cent of workplaces have never had an industrial action, according to their research. The next popular myth is that most Australian workplaces are unionised. The reality is that 57 per cent of workplaces have no union members. The next popular myth is that most unionised workplaces have many unions. Fact: only 2 per cent of workplaces have five or more unions. Popular myth: unions are quite active at workplaces in Australia. Fact: at most workplaces delegates spend one hour or less on union work; and there are no delegates at all at 34 per cent of unionised workplaces. Popular myth: very little changes at Australian workplaces. Fact: 86 per cent of workplaces had undergone some major organisational changes in the last two years.

Myth: industrial relations is seen by management as the major efficiency barrier. Reality: managers see financial and capital constraints as the major barriers. We are going to hear from a long list of very eloquent speakers from the other side of the chamber and from this side as well. I would be disappointed if I did not see Senator Watson's name on the list, and I am glad to see that he follows me. I am disappointed that Senator Crichton-Browne is not here. I think, with his ability in this area, he should put himself on the list.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have.

—That is good. I will be hearing the honourable senator. It will be interesting to hear and to see on the television screens in our rooms whether he is able to take the generous view of the issues that we do this side or whether he says, `Look, this is dreadful. The workers are not working properly; the unions are absolutely dreadful. This Government is hopeless and the Opposition is great; business is great, and all we need to do is change the Government'. That is going to the scapegoating process.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Patterson, with her background in psychology, would be the person to consult as to why her leader, Senator Hill, when talking of eminent people on this side, did not give them their titles but talked of Keating, Crean, Hawke, Dawkins and so on. I ask Senator Patterson whether that is consistent with this process of scapegoating that I have talked about or whether it is consistent with something else. If so, what is it consistent with? I ask why, when we are suffering the present quite severe traumas in the economy, those on the other side of the chamber go into scapegoating while on this side we are desperate to cooperate with everybody to see whether Australia can be rescued from its present predicament-and we are confident of that. Are we to have from now on a whole cacophony of finding people to blame, to attach guilt to, so we can drive them out into the desert; or are we, as this statement entitled Building a Competitive Australia so eloquently does, to set out a plan for doing things?

I say this about micro-economic reform: Senator Collins is much questioned about this, and he has produced great change on the waterfront. That is evidenced by the fact that all the stevedoring companies, all of which are in private hands, are in various stages of agreements with the waterside workers to produce the reform that is so much sought. National Terminals (Australia) Ltd already has; Conaust Pty Ltd is well down the line, and so is Strang Patrick, the Union Steam Ship Co. and Trans Ocean Terminals. I would ask those on the other side of the chamber, when they are berating the waterside workers-their fellow Australians, people who are suffering the same burdens as the rest of us and who are as interested as anybody in seeing reform carried out-to look at what sort of equipment they have. When honourable senators opposite compare Australia with Singapore, they should ask how many cranes per ship are available in the Singapore wharves. When those opposite are looking at what the waterside workers in Rotterdam do, let them ask what mechanisation is in place there. I do not ask them to withdraw criticism if it is deserved, but they should not, for heaven's sake, make criticism that is not properly directed.

I think the order of the day is that we keep our remarks to within a particular time frame so that everybody can have a go at this stage. The fundamental difference between this, the Government side of the chamber and the other side is that the Government wants reform, as the Opposition wants reform. The Government wants to see change in Australian attitudes, as does the Opposition. The Government wants to do it in a humane fashion, with people being entitled to be treated as fellow human beings. The Government wants to avoid the exercise of scapegoating and wants to see a truly united Australia. Unfortunately, from the remarks made by Senator Hill, that is not the proposition on the other side. What the Opposition wants is industrial war, where the last unionist or the last manager is left standing and then they fight it out and whoever wins, it is either a victory for labour or a victory for management. That is what is proclaimed on the other side and that will come out as an inference from the speeches members of the Opposition make.

The Opposition wants, in addition to loading up the work force with blame, to load up the Government. That is all right and it is a good political tactic, but this is the problem with it all: in blaming the Government, one overlooks the real needs that exist in this country and the real calls for reform which this document, Building a Competitive Australia, addresses. There is danger in the approach the Opposition takes of going back to how things were in the last century, of going back to the stage which led those great judges of the High Court, Mr Justice Isaacs and Mr Justice Rich, when dealing with a case called the Federated Municipal and Shire Council Employees' Union of Australia v. Melbourne Corporation to say:
What is called the `industrial revolution' of the latter part of the eighteenth century and particularly of the nineteenth century so transformed his-
that is the worker-
position as to drive him into combination. The details of the struggles which led to the Acts of 1825, 1871, 1875, 1896 and 1906 in England would be tedious.
Those are the Acts dealing with the development of industrial law in England. The judges go on:

But the broad fact that emerges is that the position of industrialists, by a singular reversal of what has been thought to be the general current of history, has been gradually changing from one of pure contract to one of status. This, which is the irresistible conclusion from a broad survey of the stream of industrial effort . . . is emphasised by the views of Mr Sidney Webb in a recent work . . . The `industrial revolution' for a long time . . . made the workman's labour a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers would permit.

That is exactly what is being proposed here, that the workman's labour should be reduced to a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers will permit.

When the honourable senators opposite are talking about this matter, I ask them-if any will address it-whether it is their position that the workman's, or now workwoman's, labour should be treated as a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers will permit. If that is what the Opposition does say it is differing in philosophy to the judges of the High Court because what they say, and I will finish on this, is:

The degradation and suffering that ensued, the revolt against the system, the repression of illegal acts, the amelioration of the law, the organisation of labour, the gradual recognition of collective bargaining, the introduction of private conciliation and arbitration as well as of industrial laws securing better conditions for workers, are all well-known historical facts.

I ask this question of all honourable senators on the other side of the chamber now, and Senator Crane in particular because he is very eminent in this field: is it the Opposition's proposition-and I will be listening carefully to see whether it is-the workman's labour be reduced to a mere marketable commodity to be bought at the lowest price that individual competition between workers will permit? If that is the situation, the Opposition is taking us right back to ancient times and we will have to have High Court judges in the future making judgments like that to try to cure the ills that will come about. I will be listening carefully because I would hate to see, because of the policies that the Opposition adopts, our going back to the High Court to see whether we can get some sort of order into society. It is this Parliament, and not the High Court, that should bear this responsibility. The High Court, no doubt, was very concerned that it should have to speak on those terms, but there was an occasion for it to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The 12 March statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is a minuscule attempt to address the most protracted recession that has gripped this country for the last 50 years. Everybody is asking for leadership to bring about the required structural change, but the Government response in this document has been one of lost opportunity. As with most Government budgetary, economic and other policy statements, the Prime Minister was left with very little that was new in his 12 March statement after a couple of weeks of leakings and pronouncements-another failed strategy. After the Government Budget last August, Paddy McGuinness made the comment:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Budget was the product of a Treasurer and a Government who have run out of ideas and who no longer have the courage of their convictions.

The same could be said for this March statement. The only reason we had to have a March statement was that the Government failed to address our economically disastrous situation in August. The unfortunate thing is that, having gone to the trouble of asking a range of Ministers to put forward their ideas for this particular statement and debating certain policy issues across a wide range of portfolios, and the compiling and delivery of this statement, it is not the sort of bold, revolutionary and visionary statement that Australia needs and Australia demands. The Opposition does concede that there have been some steps in the right direction. What we are complaining about is the very limited way in which the Government has picked up a few of the Liberal Party ideas and proposals. We must acknowledge that across the community there has been overwhelming support for change, overwhelming support for Liberal Party ideals and enunciations. The Australian Labor Party is never slow in identifying a good idea. But while a few good seeds have been sown, they are so sparse as not to constitute a viable crop when grown.

I have been interested to read so many writers describe this 12 March statement as, `a small step', `a modest step', and only `tinkering' at the changes. Perhaps if we had statements of this kind each month, we might be able to make some real progress within 12 months. The taxation system does have a major impact on firms. The Treasurer states that his objective must be to have the most competitive taxation environment possible. That statement conflicts with the reality of the situation, as taxpayers across Australia attempt to fathom what is really required of them in an environment of self-assessment.

If one compares the tax treatment of the environmental impact studies with the treatment of these studies by our Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) competitors one sees that again this Government has not gone far enough. In this statement the Government provides a write-off for initial environmental impact statements over 12 years, or the life of the project, whichever is the shorter. This Government's treatment is far less concessional than that of our OECD partners. Further, while on this subject, I ask the Minister: what is the position in respect of projects that have been abandoned? Is there an immediate write-off?

Basically, what is needed is for this Government to show a dramatically different attitude to change business confidence. Firstly there is a need to examine and to put forward a transitional arrangement for corporate tax payments. Surely, this is the most disappointing feature from the point of view of business and the corporate sector. The Government has failed to acknowledge the cash flow problems that will follow from this Government's demand of 85 per cent tax paid within 28 days of the end of the year. A transitional arrangement is necessary, given the state of business.

The corporate sector has experienced continual tax changes in terms of new legislation, regulation, court rulings and Commissioner rulings. There needs to be a greater element of certainty. This statement provides a small step in that direction, particularly in relation to depreciation. We welcome that. I remind the Senate that tax simplification is now seen as a priority by this Government. Simplification is an overdue recognition of previously destroyed taxpayers' rights by this Government. It is a pity that this Government has not grasped the nettle, so to speak, and made substantial instead of small-bit-at-a-time changes. Unfortunately, it is not only the corporate sector that is having difficulty coming to terms with the frequency of the tax changes; the tax professionals are in a dilemma.

The depreciation changes are welcome but are only a start. The Government should address a number of questions and should respond to them today in this Parliament. Clarifications are certainly needed in the areas of the technical life provisions introduced through this 12 March statement. In particular, I ask whether the Senate can be assured that the legislative provisions will describe the way in which the effective life of the plant acquired on or after 1 July 1991 will be determined to provide a degree of certainty required under self-assessment. The much heralded effective life provisions are really an update of the `special circumstances' that have been in law for a long time. Taxpayers, on application to the Commissioner, under special circumstances, could always get, if they satisfied the Commissioner, a higher than the prescribed write-off where special circumstances existed, and technical life is certainly one of them.

I was disappointed that the new depreciation rules, which were explained in a booklet and obtainable from Government bookshops on the afternoon of the March statement, were not made available to honourable senators in this chamber. I was informed of its existence by a businessman, who telephoned me from outside the Parliament with a query. That is not good enough. Surely the law makers of this land, the Parliament, have the first right to see an illustration of the new changes enunciated in this 12 March statement and to hear about them first from within the Parliament rather than from outside. Therefore I make a request of the Minister that in future where such publications are ready and available for public distribution at the time of the Government's announcements a copy be issued to the members of this Parliament, which would also include the House of Representatives.

However, I give full credit to the provision whereby small items of plant and tools under $300 can be written off for income tax purposes. This is a correct amendment and one which was greatly needed. We thank the Government for that.

With respect to the widening of exemptions introduced in the wholesale sales tax for business inputs, it is unfortunate that the opportunity to introduce a broad based goods and services tax was not grasped. I am sure that the Government's view that these wholesale tax concessions will undermine the need for a fair and efficient goods and services tax will not succeed. As one writer has put it: along with the United States of America and Switzerland, Australia is part of a tiny minority of countries continuing to resist the overwhelming international trend towards adopting a form of goods and services tax.

This Government's minuscule attempt at broadening the sales tax is an attempt to undermine what the Liberal Party of Australia is all about in tax reform. I acknowledge that this type of tax is not the full solution to Australia's economic ills, but it is one of a range of macro and micro measures that must be considered if we are to make an attempt to solve our present problems. It is quite ironic that in the Taxation Summit of 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) then described the tax system as being unfair and complex and as having adverse effects on incentives to work.

In 1985 Mr Keating strenuously pushed for a 12.5 per cent consumption tax on all goods and services to replace the existing wholesale sales tax. Then he believed that this tax was a matter of urgency. Today we have almost the entire business community calling for a goods and services tax, not as a panacea for the total remedy of Australia's economic plight, but as part of a total reform package to put Australia back on a sound economic footing. Basically, the changes instituted here offer certain concessions to primary and manufacturing industry without greatly reducing the enormous revenue raising capacity of the tax. The wholesale tax system still remains a cumbersome and outmoded tax.

The cost to revenue in this statement of these concessions indicates very graphically the limited nature of this concession to business. We have to acknowledge that the total industry sales tax input exceeds billions of dollars. So this $200m is but a small attempt to address a big problem for business. The existing wholesale sales tax is still a narrowly based tax which applies only to selected consumption goods and some intermediate goods. It has a lack of comprehensiveness in coverage. Therefore, the sales tax impacts differently on different commodities. It is only by having a goods and services tax that a fair go for the manufacturing sector and for Australia's international competitiveness will result. This piecemeal approach is not good enough. Classification issues will remain under the current arrangements.

They will continue to confuse and plague the productive sectors of Australia. I think it will be interesting to note how the Australian Taxation Office polices the new changes. Some tax experts express fears that there are a number of uncertainties as to how the tax will be applied and that it will merely add further interpretation problems to an already complex piece of legislation. Questions have been raised as to how the Australian Taxation Office will define the pre-production activities that have been announced. Further, the changes appear to have been confined to goods used by producers or contractors. Wholesalers or retailers of goods appear to derive few or no benefits.

A side effect apparently not thought of by the Government is that its new tax rules could result in a delay in short term investment. I have been told that tax advisers are informing corporations to put on hold any new investment plans until the tax changes are enunciated. It is important to note that the tax changes will come into effect only after royal assent is given to the legislation. That may not be until November 1991, or even later. There is obviously no immediate relief. I would like to repeat another question that I have asked in Question Time. I asked the Minister representing the Treasurer:
In view of the fact that the wholesale tax concessions will not take effect until several months after 1 July 1991, does the Minister agree that this delay will be a major disincentive for business-
in these recessionary concessions-
to lift its investment in the next four to eight months and that this delay will worsen the recession and delay improvements in Australia's productive capacity?

I posed this question yesterday. I was promised a quick response. The Treasurer has ignored the request of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce for that response. There is no liaison. There is inadequate communication. How can this country succeed with such a divided Cabinet in which Ministers will not communicate adequately, in which questions cannot be passed on properly from the Senate to the House of Representatives and answers send back?

Let us look at the luxury car sales tax. At last the Government has finally admitted to the huge blunder it made in relation to the luxury car tax. What a pity that the Government did not think through the full implications of its tax changes before its initial announcement some 12 months ago. At least this change is a sign that there is still some hope that this Government will recognise all its other stupid decisions and that it will have the guts, to use an Australian expression, to admit to its mistakes and make the appropriate changes. The sales of luxury cars actually surged in the period between Mr Keating's announcement in February 1990 and its implementation in May. We advised the Government of the consequences of that tax. It failed to note that warning.

Although I welcome some of the initial steps in taxation reform in the Government's industry statement, because of time constraints I have limited my response to the taxation aspects of that statement. I believe they are merely small steps. As I mentioned earlier, a hungry dog will accept any dry bone. The opportunity existed for extensive reform of the taxation system but, for political expediency, this Government has chosen to give only minor concessions shrouded in a veil of rhetoric.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The person who said that the function of socialism was to raise suffering to a higher level clearly had the Hawke Government in mind. Having raised the level of suffering in Australia to a peak of pain from which every sector of the community was screaming for relief, the Hawke panacea after 15 Budgets and economic statements in its eight years was Tuesday's industry statement. It was no more and no less than was expected from a Labor government aiming to appear strong, brave and visionary. I deliberately say `aiming to appear' rather than `aiming to be' strong, brave and visionary because by the end of a well crafted speech written by the speech writer to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), it was obvious the country was expected to accept the content at face value as a show of strength, bravery and vision. Sadly, it was much, much less than that. It was, in fact, 1985 revisited.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1985 deregulation of the financial market was not accompanied by deregulation of the labour market. Australia suffers every day from that half reform. This week, the end of protection was decreed. But the micro-economic reform package with which it must go hand in hand was conspicuous by its absence. This week extra sales tax exemptions on business inputs were delivered. But the country was denied the far greater benefits of a consumption tax. This week our small business community, the engine room of the economy, was ignored but for a few trite phrases about its worth. So much for the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall); when Mr Beddall fights, it seems that small business will lose. This week we had, yet again, another half reform package.

As a nation we will again suffer at the hands of a government which takes hard decisions only if they will not estrange it from its union base. This is a government which, by its failures this week, indicated it can never, despite rhetoric to the contrary, risk prescribing the necessary pain relief for Australia, which means labour market and fast-paced micro-economic reform, because, if it did, the Government may sever the Accord and alienate the union movement. Never has it been more vital to take the hard decisions than now.

Australia has sunk deeply in a morass of problems. Apart from the recession which we had to have, we have a severe shortage of venture and development finance. We are the only industrialised country in the world not to have increased its proportion of exports to gross domestic product. Only Spain invests less on research and development than we do. The Economic Planning Advisory Council says our labour productivity is still declining. Only 15 per cent of our manufacturers have total quality control. Our national inefficiency means that we are industrially out of date. Our goods cost too much and they do not match up to the quality of the goods we can buy from overseas. We need to speed up and clue up.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was absolutely correct when he said in his speech that the challenge for the foreseeable future is to produce more than we spend. The challenge was, therefore, to make the decisions and adopt the practices and attitudes which will enable this and succeeding generations to achieve those basic important goals. Where the Prime Minister lost me, and I am sure every economic commentator in Australia, was in espousing this as a new challenge, when it is a very old challenge indeed. It has always been the challenge for every single year of the Hawke Government-all eight of them. Therefore it is not new, no matter what great prose the Prime Minister's speech writer, Graham Freudenberg, can wrap it in. It is an unfulfilled challenge, one which the Hawke Government has not been able to meet. That ought not to be forgotten in any analysis of the industry statement.

The industry statement was delivered as a belated attempt to chart a course for Australia which should have been steered years ago. The general direction is to be applauded. The division of duties in the effort to get there is not. I happen to believe that most Australian industry will attempt and will be able to rise, albeit often with enormous difficulty, to the challenge presented to it in the form of surviving and competing profitably with greatly reduced tariffs and quotas. Basically, industry has no choice but to do so if Australia is to go forward into the next century with any economic strength in world markets.

Australia, and Australians, have expected to be shielded from the harsh realities of international competition with tariffs and quotas for far too long. Even with that protection, we have sunk to an all-time low where manufactured goods make up 70 per cent of our imports yet only 20 per cent of our exports. We are simply not competitive. We have a manufacturing sector which generally is not making an appropriate contribution, although there are companies which, against all the odds, have restructured and captured brilliantly strong markets for their products in America and Japan.

I refer to two South Australian manufacturing companies. They ought to be mentioned because their sheer determination in breaking into the international markets so successfully is an example for other sections of the manufacturing industry in this country. I talk about ROH Industries, which is selling mag wheels to Japan; Mitsubishi, which is exporting components to Japan to be built into Japanese models and motor vehicles; and, of course, Britax, with its production of rear-vision mirrors which are now being exported to the American market to be incorporated in American produced motor cars. They are examples of which Australia can be proud. They are examples which set the pace. They are examples where we need to give encouragement and direction for other sections of manufacturing industry to follow.

At the other end of the spectrum, the textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) sector is an excellent example of exactly what is wrong with Australia. It has generally made little attempt to restructure, has been happy to accept protection, and has outdated equipment and work practices which have not changed, in some instances, since the Second World War. Its unions have got off with far too much for far too long. There is more to this than meets the eye. After all, the Australian Labor Party has not wanted trouble in the Prime Minister's Victorian seat, where there is a proliferation of TCF factories. It brings back memories of the Kodak (Australasia) Pty Ltd bail-out-another peacekeeping operation for Labor voters in Mr Hawke's electorate. When asked by one of my colleagues the reason for the Kodak decision, one senior Minister replied, `God decreed that Kodak would receive the bail-out; and, what is more, God's country is the Prime Minister's electorate'.

Just as the TCF sector must recognise that we have moved on, Australians, after many decades of refusing to accept the inevitable, must face up to the fact that in areas where we discover that we cannot be internationally competitive we should not waste the time and effort of manufacturing locally. That means some adjustment. We also have to accept that, until our position in the free trade arena settles down, the foreign debt scales may tip more widely than we would like them to. Yet despite the moves in that direction by the industry statement, Australia has frustratingly been delivered only half-policies, which is not only a letdown to all those naive enough to have expected bravery in the face of crisis, but also an admission of cowardice which will go down in history as another Hawke failure.

The Prime Minister made much of the word `together'-I emphasise that word-throughout his speech. The philosophical dictionary that he uses seems very different from mine. In the Prime Minister's dictionary, `together' obviously equals not `we' but only `you'. In his speech there is no `together' which embraces the unions and what they must deliver if Australia is again to have a respected and competitive manufacturing sector by international standards. The speech was aimed at `you'-the business community; `you'-the manufacturing sector; `you'-the rural sector; and `you'-the exporters. There was no `together' with a changed transport industry to help `you' succeed; no `together' with a changed waterfront to save `you' money; no `together' with a program of privatisation; no `together' with changed fiscal policies. No, the weight of and responsibility for the package was thrown one way, and one way only.

The industry statement's direction presents an unfair challenge to those in our manufacturing sector who have shown willingness to restructure by not providing them the strength needed to succeed in what lies before them. Yet surely it cannot be lost on the Prime Minister that he is asking those in that sector to face the battle of the 1990s with one hand tied behind their backs. Where is labour deregulation? Only a change of government can deliver that. Where is the fast pace micro-economic reform? Only a change of government will deliver that. The changes expected from manufacturing industry over the next decade, because of the announced demise of protection, are acute.

That being the case, it is a reasonable expectation that the Hawke Government should lead by example, tackling the States to accelerate micro-economic reform and tackling the unions to put enterprise bargaining to work. Without changes to the labour market rules and reforms which embrace our decayed and inefficient transport system and our intransigent waterfront, we will not get the required result. Our manufacturing sector-for example, our motor vehicle industry and the component manufacturers to the motor vehicle industry-will continue to be handicapped in its efforts to restructure and perform competitively.

The car industry, as I mentioned, is an excellent example. It has shown willingness to restructure, to accept change, and to accept challenge. Faced with tariffs to be halved by the end of the decade, it has indicated that it believes it can deal with the rate of tariff reduction, but only in perspective and only as part of a far greater reform package. It is not asking for anything. That is unfair. It has simply stated that it wants both arms free to operate. The Government must provide it with reduced interest rates, deliver industrial relations reform, lower transportation charges and ensure a more efficient waterfront. If it is not delivered, who do we blame when, halfway through the decade-referred to by Senator Button as the decade of investment worldwide-our car manufacturers withdraw any further capital investment in the motor vehicle manufacturing industry in this country? Who do we blame for the impact that that would have on the component industry within this country?

If manufacturing is expected to shape up in the face of the end of protectionism, why are the inefficient service industries which supply it allowed to be left dragging behind? To achieve success, we must cut the overheads and costs of operating so that industry has the leeway to absorb the changed protection circumstances without damage. That is not asking for a hand-out, only for what is due, which so far the unions will not allow to be delivered. If the resistance to micro-economic and labour reform continues, Australia will remain in trouble. Where we are calling on manufacturing industry to meet the challenge, it will not be able to.

We must face the fact that lowering the protection barriers alone, without delivering the reform tools to balance the scales, can never provide us with the scope to increase efficiency and productivity to compete with trading partners such as Japan and Germany. While we may be changing, our rate of change will not keep up. Free of the British disease which has Australia still so much in its grip, these countries will be changing ever faster and the end result of that is that we in Australia remain behind: one step forward, two steps back.

The waterfront and the trans-Tasman shipping costs are probably the most effective examples of all that is ill with our country-ignored by the industry statement this week, yet crucial to the future of the car industry and every other export industry. It is a damning indictment of the snail's pace of labour reform to have South Australian car manufacturers considering moving stock out of Australia by air transport rather than face the wharf delays and trans-Tasman costs.

As I raised in the Estimates committees last session, the Tasman is the most expensive stretch of water in the world, courtesy of the Australian unions and their agreement. It is cheaper to ship to Europe than to Auckland, and it takes longer to have a truck of export materials processed through the Melbourne docks than it does to drive it from Adelaide to Melbourne. The status of the Australian waterfront as the bastion of all industrial evil displays to our trading partners that Australia remains affected by what I described earlier as that British disease-the disease of obstinate and bloody-minded union dominance over good sense and any commitment to real reform and progress for the sake of the country.

As we move to a post-protection era it would not be too cynical to say that only our wrapping has changed. The hard centre of union control and slow reform remains in place to shackle us. If we do not escape the chains we will never again take our rightful place as a major nation. There is too much at stake for a government which claims to really care about the future to have delivered such a half-hearted agenda for the future. This week's industry statement was proof beyond doubt that only a Liberal government can complete the necessary economic equation-the other side of the coin. We have the commitment, we have the strength and we also, incidentally, have the electorate behind us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days ago the Hawke Labor Government announced its long awaited industry statement entitled Building a Competitive Australia. I want to look briefly at the criticisms made of the statement by the Opposition and those commentators who came out against it, and then turn to the statement itself and explain why I believe it is an important step in the right direction by the Government and a good policy direction.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn first to the statement's critics. It seems to me that the nature of the criticism is very similar to the reaction of young children on their first visit to the royal show. Having worked themselves up into a lather of anticipation before the event, anything, no matter how good, is bound to disappoint their overambitious expectations. That is exactly what has occurred in this case. Despite clear warnings in the media by various Government Ministers of the limited scope of the policy before its unveiling, what the Government had been fearing occurred. Instead of being judged on its merits, the statement has been judged according to some unexplained, and apparently rather difficult to meet, criterion.

The statement has been found to be wanting according to this criterion and has, therefore, been condemned by the Opposition and some media commentators as not enough. It has been damned with faint praise. The most popular line in condemnation appears to be that there is nothing wrong with what is in the statement-just what has been left out. Such criticism is rather unfair. It was clear from the beginning that this statement was never intended to be a macro-economic cure-all-some type of patent medicine solution to the problems confronting our economy. Peter Reith, the shadow Treasurer, accused the Government of not addressing the macro-economic problems which are confronting this country. The simple fact is that the implementation of the new macro-economic policies such as a goods and services tax, a re-evaluation of the Budget strategy or any such nonsense was never intended to be part of this statement.

This is not a mini-Budget; it is not a proper Budget. It was never intended to be. The Government does not intend to make any dramatic policy shifts on a macro-economic level and, if it did, this statement is not the format for these alterations to policy. The Government has consistently rejected calls by the Opposition for a mini-Budget, and to judge this industry statement according to the criterion of a mini-Budget is simply silly and unproductive. This Government does have the right macro-economic policy settings in place. If we have failed in any way, it was by relying on our business community to come across with some initiative in pursuing investment opportunities.

I have no intention of even considering the question of a goods and services tax. Consumption taxes have been rejected by this Government as a policy option and have been debated ad nauseam in this chamber a number of times. To criticise this statement for not announcing such a tax is a clever political move by the Opposition in allowing it to put across its policies, but it does not really help in analysing the statement. If the shadow Treasurer is really disappointed at this omission, he must have cried an awful lot at the royal show as a child. Perhaps he still does. In any event, if anyone in this place needs reminding about why exactly this Government does not support a consumption tax, I would advise that person to get a copy of the answers that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) gave in the other place today on that very question.

There is one criticism that I wish to deal with at some length. It has been made by the Opposition and such impressive media commentators as the editorial writer for the Australian. It concerns the so-called reform of the labour market. For a definition of reform we can look in the dictionary under `deregulation' for here there exists a significant difference between the Government, the Opposition and, it appears, the leader writer for the Australian. This Government has undertaken, and continues to undertake, the most far reaching, important reforms of any government in the history of this nation. The accord process has provided a rational, sound and successful basis for determining wage outcomes in a fair and equitable manner. It has allowed the Government to exercise an unheard-of degree of control over outcomes, allowing for a predictable and settled labour market and a predictable and settled economic policy. It has also allowed for increases in productivity through successive trade-offs with the union movement, and has markedly decreased the rate of disputes in this country.

People seem to forget the appalling and destructive practices which occurred in this country before 1983, when industrial disputes often turned into bitter warfare between unions and employers. The accord has led to a radical re-evaluation of the way we operate within our industrial relations system. I do not think too many people on either side of this chamber would disagree with me when I say that we are now a far more mature nation industrially than we have ever been, and much credit for that goes to this Government and, in particular, its successive Ministers for Industrial Relations.

In contrast, the Opposition prefers so-called reforms of the labour market, and I use the phrase advisedly. What it means is to take on the unions, break the industrial muscle and force a process of voluntary unionism combined with enterprise bargaining. It all sounds very macho. Greater flexibility is the stated aim. By `greater flexibility' it means more power to the employer in any bargaining situation. When efficiency is the only aim people fall by the wayside. There can be no dispute that, no matter what the rhetoric, what the Opposition wants is to make the unions weaker.

The first point to be made in response to this is that it is highly unlikely that any government could succeed in decreasing the power of unions in the way that the Opposition would like to. When the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems looked at that proposal, it simply rejected it as being outside the scope of industrial reality. In fact, that was the phrase it used-`industrial realities'-being those things that are difficult, if not impossible, to change.

This leads to the second point. In even attempting to change the system in such a radical and extremist fashion, the dislocation that would conceivably be caused would be just too great to bear. Do we really want to return to the discredited path of industrial confrontation? It was tried before 1983 and it was a colossal failure.
