So what would actually be achieved by a coalition government in this area? It would be difficult to proceed with the hidden agenda of destroying the power of unions, as I explained a moment ago. But it would still probably go ahead with the second and more public plank of its labour market reform strategy, which is the destruction of the centralised wage fixing system in favour of enterprise bargaining. No doubt, some unions will be hurt by this, particularly industrially weak unions.

But there is an unpleasant side effect for the Opposition; that is, that industrially strong unions freed from the restraints of a centralised system would be able to write their own pay cheques, not because of greater productivity, but because of industrial muscle. Greater inequality would result, and wage outcomes would be determined by industrial muscle; there would be some reform. It is no wonder that major employer organisations supported the current system in submissions to the Hancock Committee, and it is no wonder that such a stupid policy did not get a run on Tuesday. I pray it never gets a run in this country.

I turn now to the statement itself. Before Peter Reith and certain unnamed leader writers got carried away with what should or should not have been included in the announcement on Tuesday, it all seemed pretty clear. In the Australian Financial Review of 27 February, Michael Stuchbury said:
The core of Canberra's March 12 economic statement will be cuts in manufacturing protection.
He then outlined some specifics, and went on to say:
If delivered, this would bend a century of failed protectionist economic development strategy in Australia almost to its breaking point.

This was delivered: a reduction of tariffs to 5 per cent by 1 July, 1996; a phase-down of tariffs to 15 per cent on passenger vehicles; a termination of global quotas in the textile, clothing and footwear industry; and an across the board reduction in tariffs in that industry. We will be one of the world's most well behaved nations in trade matters. Realistically, with our comparative disadvantage in financial ability compared with Europe and the Americas, we cannot afford anything else. We cannot compete with their subsidies and we cannot compete with their export enhancement programs. We can only compete on a level playing field, to use a much overused phrase.

These policy directions will give us a great deal of negotiating strength in the current round of General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations, which is where a level playing field will be achieved-if it ever is. We can be optimistic and hope that this leads to some countervailing action on the part of other important world traders to reduce their own inefficient protection.

The most important effect of these proposals is the effect that they will have in our domestic economy. No longer will we attempt to protect ourselves from the cutthroat nature of world trade. The years of hiding behind tariff walls and seeing our industries fail to compete-the black years of McEwenism-are over. We must either learn to compete as a nation or accept a decline in our relative standard of living. I honestly believe that we will learn to compete, that we can take on the world and, if not beat it, at least hold our own.

The fact that this Government has taken us so far along the path of competing internationally, the fact that as a society and as an economy we are so universally focused and aware of the job ahead, and the fact that this Government has put in place economic policy settings over a number of years which should allow us to compete effectively throughout the world is a great credit to this Government.
Micro-economic reform is under way. There is still much to do in this area, and no one statement can be expected to provide the answers. To quote an almost sympathetic editorial:
It-
the industry statement-

rightly rejects the newly fashionable arguments for protection. It largely ignores the demands for the Government to increase subsidies for exporters. And, in the midst of a recession, it takes politically difficult decisions to cut protection to the most inefficient sectors of manufacturing. It is a more courageous document that Australians once would have expected from their leaders.

Honourable senators would no doubt be surprised to learn that there was a time in this country's history when Australians were the highest per capita users of patent medicine in the world. We were the kings of snake oil. I think the criticism of the industry statement bears this out to a degree. There is an apparent desire for simple, one-stop solutions to the complex problems facing us. The Opposition, in the role of snake oil salesmen desperately trying to unload policies like deregulation of the labour market and a consumption tax onto an unsuspecting public, provides no answers that any sane society would be brave enough to try.

The policy settings are in place, the business community knows the task ahead, and the union movement is committed. Only a Labor government could achieve all that. There are no easy solutions. The snake oil salesmen cannot be trusted. This statement never set out to rectify our economic problems in one fell swoop and to criticise it on that basis is to commit an injustice upon it. This statement is a step in the right direction, but it was never going to be anything but a long, hard road.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was said by many before the industry statement was released on Tuesday that it would be important and would be examined as importantly and as closely for what it did not contain as for what it did. Today's debate on last Tuesday's industry statement by the senior Ministers of the Government has confirmed the paucity of the content in that statement. The statement is obviously a political document. It is particularly political in the sense that it is a lowest common denominator document. It is a document that was cobbled together to put together those elements that could be agreed between the different factions of the Australian Labor Party and that could be agreed between the Hawke Government and the trade union movement. The net result of that, of course, is that we have a statement which says very little indeed-it is far too little, too late. It has no coherent or cohesive strategy to it; it does not tackle the basic problems of micro-economic reform at all. To the extent that it does tackle micro-economic reform, it does so in a minimal way, and it tackles macro-economic policy not at all.

SPEECH.PARA: In the statement there is virtually no reference at all to the broad macro-economic policy issues that are required if we are going to have an environment in Australia in which industry is going to be able to compete productively, in which employment and investment are going to grow, and in which we are going to seriously tackle our huge foreign debt problem and our balance of payments crisis.

The main criticism I have of the statement is, as I have said, that it is a cobbled together statement of a whole mishmash of small bits and pieces with no real economic policy framework to put those pieces together. That is not to say that the statement is completely without merit. Of course, there are some very worthwhile movements and developments in the statement.

We have welcomed the changes to the depreciation arrangements, for example, although they do not go far enough. We have welcomed the Government's decisions in relation to the reduction in tariffs, although it has made a fundamental mistake in not making that tariff reform part of a wider reform based particularly around micro-economic changes; that is, changes to make our manufacturing industry and all other industries able to operate on a lower cost and more efficient basis. The Government has not removed any of the major impediments to greater production and productivity. Nevertheless, the tariff decisions are certainly in the right direction.

The tax deductibility changes for environmental impact statements are again in the right direction. The speeding up of and changes in the anti-dumping examination arrangements are sensible, and there are other measures about which one could comment equally favourably. But, as I said at the outset, those issues and those decisions are really very small beer in the totality of what is required to put this Australia right; to actually build a competitive Australia which the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) says the statements are all about. It does not do that at all and, as the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, said in his initial comment on the industry statement:

The statement fails to come to grips with the reality of our economic crisis and with the magnitude of the policy adjustment required to eliminate inflation, to boost production, to boost exports and to boost import replacement activity so as to stabilise and ultimately reduce our debt.

Today, in response to a question from me in the Senate at Question Time, Senator Button admitted that this industry statement really had nothing to do at all with trying to tackle our chronic current account deficit and the balance of payments, or our chronic debt problem. This debt problem now threatens to become built into our system in such an intractable way that it will hamper economic growth and development and employment and investment in this country between now and the end of the century.

It was only during the election campaign last year that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that by 1992 our foreign debt situation would be stabilised. What has happened since then is that the foreign debt situation has continued to deteriorate, but our foreign debt problem is not addressed at all in the industry statement. It was confirmed by Senator Button today that it was not intended to be.

I ask the Government as I have asked it on numerous occasions-as have many others from the coalition: what is the Government going to do in terms of strategies to tackle our foreign debt and balance of payments problem? Because if we do not tackle those problems, we are going to continue to be hindered, in terms of growth and development and employment, by bouncing up against a balance of payments crisis every time we get a healthy growth in demand in this country. The only way to tackle that problem is to free up the productive capacity of this country and to give the talents and skills of our people and the use of our resources free rein so that we can be a more productive, producing society; so that we can meet the demands that we, as Australians and consumers, very rightly expect of our economic system.

That is the fundamental problem that we have in this country. We have a perfectly understandable and correct demand situation. People do want to be able to buy, consume and invest. The only way one can do that is if one gets the supply side of the whole thing right. The fundamental flaw in the whole economic strategy of this Government is that it has failed to do that. Indeed, the policies which it has adopted have worked in the opposite way; they have been counterproductive.

I was delighted, but I must say surprised, to hear the Prime Minister admit for the first time on Tuesday in his statement that the Government had got its economic policy making wrong over the last two or three years by an excessive reliance on monetary policy. That reliance on monetary policy has forced interest rates to the highest level in the Western world. It has made investment in this country virtually out of competitive reach of most producers or investors, and it has put the Australian exchange rate to a level much higher than what its real value is.

All that has happened because the Government has failed, for whatever reason, to adopt other policies-particularly in terms of its Budget and wages policies-complementary to monetary policy. Instead, because it has failed so badly on Budget policy, because it has refused to free up in any significant way the wage fixing system in this country, and because it has refused to allow employers and employees to talk together, to negotiate together, to get together and agree together on proper, appropriate terms and conditions of employment, the Government has therefore been forced to have a monetary policy which is absolutely excessive and which has crippled development in this country. This policy has crippled development not just in terms of investment, manufacturing and productive activities, but it has also crippled scores of thousands of households in Australia, hundreds of thousands of individuals and has made life a misery for countless Australians-when there was never reason why that should have been the case.

If the Government was really serious in wanting Australians to believe that it was trying to produce and build a competitive Australia, the first thing it would have had to start with was to look at those fundamental broad policy directions that one needs to adopt and pursue if the other important policies-but of a lesser level-are going to have the impact that is necessary. That is a longish way of saying that one cannot get successful micro-economic reform-even if one tackles it seriously, which this Government is not doing-unless one has a proper macro-economic environment. Unless the broad brush picture is right, the smaller detailed picture will never be right.

That is being realised by more and more commentators and more and more industries in Australia. The only people who now do not realise that are the Government and the supporters of the Government. I am not a trade union basher, as I think my colleagues in the Senate would know, but it is a fact that the inability of the trade union movement to accept and adapt to fundamental necessary change in this country is reinforcing the rigidities and the problems that we have. Unless there is a fundamental change in attitude-throughout the trade union movement, and I must say throughout much of management as well and, indeed, much of the Australian community because it is not just a one-sided issue-then we are going to hobble ourselves quite unnecessarily and severely for the remainder of this century.

I return to the industry statement. Most people are now starting to realise many of those problems. The industry statement has had a dreadful response throughout the media, the community and most industry groups that stand to benefit or otherwise from the statement. For example, officials of the electronics industry-a key industry that the Government sees as one of the leading lights of development in the 1990s-describes the industry statement as:
. . . a piecemeal range of measures hardly sufficient to reduce existing impediments to development.
They also say:
It would not provide incentives for industry to increase investment, research and development or exports.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce says that the `Key issues fail to take the centre stage'. The Executive Director of the Australian Chamber of Commerce, Ian Fletcher, says:
The Prime Minister's industry statement is little more than a package of Band-aids.
When bold and decisive action was required to deal with our fundamental economic problems, the nation was presented with a statement long on rhetoric and short on real action.
Bearing in mind the old axiom `actions speak louder than words,' the statement is little more than a loud mutter.

The Confederation of Australian Industry, one of the major industry bodies in this country, said much the same. It drew particular attention to the position facing small business. Its Executive Director, Ian Spicer said:

By making only a cursory reference to Small Business Development in the statements made by the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and the Industry Minister, the Government confirms that it does not understand the critical function that small business must perform if the Government's ultimate goal of Building a Competitive Australia is to be achieved.

The Australian Mining Industry Council, which represents the major miners of this country and major contributors to our exports and therefore critical to our future economic development says the statement has `gone only halfway to establishing a dynamic economy'.

Representatives of the rural sector, which is in great and deep crisis, made similar comments. The former Minister for Science and Technology and a colleague of Senator Button and others in government, Barry Jones, who is still a member of this Parliament, put it very well when he was quoted in the press today as saying:
The manufacturing sector `would not make it' unless the Government's economic statement was immediately followed with stronger measures . . .
He also said:
The statement was a step in the right direction, but should have come eight years ago when the Government was first elected . . .

That is absolutely true. This Government is a government of inertia. It is not true, as the Prime Minister, Treasurer and other Ministers have tried to delude the Australian community into believing, that it has been an active or a proactive and initiating government. This Government has not been an initiating government.

If one looks at the policy changes that this Government has made during its eight years in office, one will find that almost without exception they have been decisions reacting to pressures that have been put on it. One can go right back to the 1983 or 1984 decision, admirable decision though it was, of floating the dollar back in the early period of the Government's tenure of office. That was a reaction to the recurring crises that were being caused by speculative raids on our currency. The Government did the right thing but it did it for the wrong reasons. It did it because it was forced into it, not because it was its own decision. One can level much the same comment at virtually everything that this Government has done.

It is not possible for this Government to say that it has been inactive and retarded in any way by the coalition. The Liberal-National Party coalition has, almost without exception over the last eight years, been positive in wanting to work with the Government to have the desirable and proper changes made to the structure of the Australian economy so that we can have, once again, the prosperous, flourishing and enterprising economy and society that we had particularly throughout the 1950s and the 1960s. That was a prosperity and a flowering of Australian economic history, which was crushed during the three years of the Whitlam Government and which it has taken a great deal of time to retrieve.

The Fraser Government had difficulty in doing that. So has the Hawke Government. But the Hawke Government has compounded the problems by its sheer refusal to take active measures to fundamentally change our economic structure. That has been due to the inhibitions that the very nature of the structure of the Australian Labor Party and the Labor movement in Australia imposes on Labor governments of the day.

The industry statement is a damp squib. It is far too little far too late. It does not acknowledge the need to paint a proper productive environment through the appropriate balance of macro-economic policies, and it is amazingly silent on the enormous task that the Government has now built for itself in terms of redeveloping or redirecting a fiscal and budgetary policy in tune with the needs of the times.

There has been an enormous, massive deterioration in the fiscal and budgetary position of the Government this financial year. From a Budget surplus of $8.1 billion, in all probability-indeed this is accepted even now by the Treasurer-the Budget outturn for 1990-91 will be a probable move into deficit. The Government-the public sector-has once again shown the colours of traditional Labor governments by getting its hands right into the cookie jar of the nation's savings. That is a budgetary situation which is totally inimical to the needs and the interests of the Australian community.

There is also one other aspect within that budgetary situation that the Government, for whatever reason I really do not know given the way that this was promoted by the Treasurer very rightly back in 1985, blindly refused to look at, and that was the introduction of a broadly based consumption tax. That is nothing short of disgraceful. As the Australian Financial Review said today in its editorial, which I commend to all senators, consumption tax is the missing link in the whole process of inducing a desirable restructuring of our economic policies, our taxation base and, therefore, the ability of the taxation system to aid rather than to hinder the further development of investment, savings and productive activity in Australia.

The changes that were announced in the industry statement to the wholesale sales tax, allegedly to remove some of the restraints or the costs on business inputs, are absolutely minuscule. A full year figure in 1992-93 will be only $375m. The wholesale sales tax raises something like $11 billion. Of that $11 billion something like $5 billion to $6 billion comes, in effect, through the tax on business inputs. The relief given in this industry statement is a whole $375m, something like 5 per cent or thereabouts of the real cost of the wholesale sales tax to business.

It will do virtually nothing to alleviate the tax cost pressures on exporters and yet it is a direction of productive activity more towards exports, which is the very thing that this nation needs. So I urge the Government again to look at its intransigent attitude towards a broadly based consumption tax or a goods and services tax because its failure to do so is costing Australia and all Australians very heavily indeed.

They are some of the things that I wanted to say about the industry statement. There are many things that could have been included in that statement, and should have been included in that statement, to make Australia truly the competitive Australia that the statement title very misleadingly purports it to be.

The coalition's policies in the areas of Budget policy, monetary policy, wages policy, privatisation and micro-economic reform-in a meaningful way, not just rhetorically-have been spelt out very clearly by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and other coalition spokesmen. They do not need repeating here today. But there is a better way for Australia; there is a way to build a competitive Australia. Regrettably, and to the great cost of all Australians, that opportunity was not taken up on Tuesday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two good things about the statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Firstly, the Prime Minister's statement and the accompanying statements by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and also, to some extent, by Senator Cook set out-as should be done from time to time-the position of the Government and the philosophy which guides it. It gives us an opportunity to see the philosophical position from which the Government is coming and from which it derives its industrial policy. After all, as an industrial society, our industrial policy is one of the things that we need to look at extremely closely.

SPEECH.PARA: So I welcome these statements and the opportunity that they provide to look more broadly at where this Government is taking us and to make some criticism of that. In the course of debating individual pieces of legislation, very often we are debating detail and the philosophical position lies hidden. Very often we come to apparently different conclusions because of those different philosophies and positions which we take. Those positions are not made explicit and I believe that they should be, because that, after all, is far more important than the conclusions which we draw from those positions. Given the right starting position, and given the right philosophy, we will all come to the same conclusions and there will be no differences between us.

The second reason that I welcome the statement is that the Prime Minister-not in the statement itself but outside the statement in press comments-said that he was looking at least 10 years into the future. We do need to look at least at a 10-year time span. I believe that we need to look much more extensively into the future-much further into the future. That, of course, is the right way to plan where we need to go; because unless we have a clear idea of where we are going as a society-as somebody once remarked- `you will finish up some place else'.

Having said that, one gets the clear impression from all these statements taken together that the Government has no clear idea of where it is going. It has no clear idea of the society that it wishes to construct: the society in which we will live 10 years hence. It is a society built entirely out of a disjointed, inappropriate econometric view of the world. I might describe the people who write a policy document like this not as members of the species homo sapiens but as members of a different species altogether: homo economus. In that group I would also put the members of the Opposition. They are working to exactly the same discredited model which simply does not fit with the world in which we must live into the next century. There is no wisdom in these statements at all. So the people who have spoken so far on this statement simply do not deserve the title homo sapiens, the Latin word for wisdom, of course, being `sapiens'. There is no wisdom in these statements and we have heard no wisdom from the Opposition.

It has been recognised by leading thinkers in recent times that the decade of the 1990s is indeed a major turning point in history. It is the decade in which major changes must be made in the relationship between industrial civilisations and the environment if any civilisation is to survive into the mid-term and certainly into the distant future. Nowhere in the Prime Minister's statement-and nowhere in any of the other statements-do we find even a suggestion that these people who now lead us recognise the environmental constraints which are looming very largely before us and which are recognised by most leading thinkers in the world today.

The econometric model which comes through in the Prime Minister's statement and the other statements is one of inhuman dimensions. It is one which is driven by an ideology in which humans are simply competitive units in an economically driven society in which competition is far more important than anything else. It provides us with a vision of human beings on a treadmill which is being driven faster and faster, on which we must run faster and faster merely to stay in the same position. And for what end? To serve inhuman and, ultimately, impossible economically determined ends.

There is a lot absolutely fundamentally wrong with these statements. The Prime Minister, Senator Button and the other Ministers who have presented these statements to us are leading Australia up a completely blind alley. This is unfortunate because the alternative vision is certainly present in Australian society. We have some of the leading edge technology which would fit with the new vision. We could, if we chose-if we were intelligent-pursue quite different directions.

As I have indicated in this place before, there is one index-if we wish to look for it-which must serve as a goal underpinning all industry. All industry depends ultimately upon the use of energy. The release of energy in industrial societies-industrial civilisations-around the globe has led us to a position where we face an imminent greenhouse warming of the planet with enormous and probably quite unpredictable consequences for every aspect not only of human civilisation but of life on the planet as a whole.

Globally we set up an inter-governmental panel on climate control comprising a number of experts in this area. The panel's recommendation-made only last year-was that as a matter of urgency the world had to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent, as rapidly as possible. That is not to bring the greenhouse gas levels down to the levels before industrialisation got under way; we need to do that simply to cause those levels to plateau, and to plateau at a level which inevitably will have quite far-reaching consequences.

If we translate that figure into the profligate release of these greenhouse gases by Australia, that means that Australia needs to reduce its greenhouse gas emissions by 92 per cent as rapidly as possible. That surely is the overriding factor which needs to be taken into account in designing industry over the next decade. That is totally ignored in the Prime Minister's statement. That view is shared by a significant number of Australians. I point to the Saulwick poll in the Age of 26 December 1990, which asked Australians a number of questions. One question asked: do environmental groups make reasonable demands? The poll found that 63 per cent of voters thought the demands made by such groups were reasonable. Only 28 per cent of Australians thought the demands made by environmental groups were unreasonable. Seventy-nine per cent of the voters said that the threat to the environment was real and had to be taken seriously, while fewer than one in five-fewer than 20 per cent-said that green activists made too much fuss about this threat.

The latest poll showed that 62 per cent of voters said Australia should concentrate on protecting the environment even if it meant some reduction in economic growth. If one looks at the age and gender distribution of these people, one sees that concern for the environment was higher among women, young voters and-need I say it?-supporters of the Australian Democrats and, to some extent, the Australian Labor Party. Eighty-two per cent of the people aged 18 to 24 said the demands made by environmentalists were reasonable, compared with only 47 per cent of those over the age of 55. If one were to look around this chamber-if honourable senators were in here-one would find a very unrepresentative group in terms of the declared concern by the Australian public over this very fundamental question, a concern which one finds nowhere expressed in the Prime Minister's statement. The Prime Minister has totally ignored the environment. In fact, the word `environment' appears in his statement only to the extent that he addresses the issue of so-called resource security, which is to parcel away parts of the environment for the exclusive, exploitative use of parts of the timber industry.

One finds the word `environment' in Senator Button's statement only linked to the word `economic'. Senator Button seems to be quite unaware that ultimately we are dependent upon the natural environment both for our survival and for the continuation of our industry. We are not separate living organisms who can build societies, who can build industry, detached from the realities of the real world. In order to recognise the constraints which the environment places upon us, I point to the German philosopher Haeckel who, way back in the middle of the last century, used one of the wisest aphorisms I have seen anywhere when he said that freedom is the recognition of necessity; in other words, one is free only to the extent that one recognises the constraints within which one operates.

We will be free in this country-and, indeed, in any other-to establish an industrial civilisation which is sustainable in the long term only to the extent that we recognise the constraints within which we operate. That major constraint which is looming large-which most experts recognise but this Government fails to recognise-is the constraint imposed by the use of fossil fuels and the release of carbon dioxide and other industrially generated gases to the atmosphere. What sort of a different society would this be? The Government in its statements clearly considers that in the next century we will live in a more global economy where there is more trade, particularly in goods. Informed people are already seriously talking about the imposition of a carbon emission tax.

Among the things that will be impacted upon most strongly as we come to recognise the inevitability of restricting our use of fossil fuels will be transport and trade, which will not expand. Transport and trade indeed will diminish. The world of tomorrow will not be a global community in which there is massive trade in goods; it will be a world in which peoples at all levels will be increasingly self-sufficient and the trade which will occur will be trade in ideas and information, which require increasingly less energy for their transmission. The bulk transmission of goods will become severely restricted in a greenhouse world. That suggests immediately that, in terms of the imbalance in trade at present, we should not look towards increasing exports but towards import replacement. That is the strategy which will fit the greenhouse world.

It means that we should not divide up our transport system in this country as we have, and say to Australian National, `You produce a profit at the bottom line and don't take into account any problems in relation to road damage or other modes of transport', so that we have Australian National closing railway lines, ripping up tracks and tearing down the bridges simply to make a profit and putting more energy intensive uses of transport onto our road system. It means that we should develop the technologies which are able to meet those sorts of greenhouse targets-and in this country we have leading edge technology in the area of transport. In the University of New South Wales we have produced the most efficient photovoltaic cells in the world. We have in Sydney a man who has been attempting to build an electric car for use in this country for over 10 years without government support-a well-known engineer who designed Sydney's double decker trains. We have in the University of Sydney a design for an electric vehicle which could meet 70 per cent of all private motor vehicle transport needs and be totally solar driven.

This technology is not receiving the support which it should be getting. This technology provides an industrial base which not only we but the rest of the world will need in the years ahead because it is technology which will meet that 92 per cent reduction in greenhouse gases of which I spoke earlier.

When we look at our balance of trade and our debt, we find that $27 billion, roughly a quarter of our total debt, is owed by State electricity utilities that have never looked to energy efficiency but have simply looked-like a lot of private industrial concerns-to expand their own hegemony over the provision of electricity, causing the most inefficient use of electricity. We do not find any remarks at all in the Prime Minister's statement about impacting on the massive debt, the increasing debt, borne by those State utilities, several of which want to continue to build unnecessary power stations. I point to Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia. We do not need these power stations which, if the best predictions in relation to greenhouse are correct, will never be able to generate the cash flow required to pay them off. We find that the Prime Minister fails to recognise this as any sort of a problem, because he is looking in a different direction.

I turn specifically to the Prime Minister's statement on the so-called resource security. We were promised a statement which would say a great deal about the detail in relation to the protection of the environment. What do we find? We find very little detail in the Prime Minister's statement and very little detail in the addendum to the Prime Minister's statement and we find a number of totally inaccurate statements and assertions. The Prime Minister says:
But we recognise that-in part due to this commitment-
that is, commitment to looking after the environment-
there has been a contraction of the forest resource allocated to existing operations in the industry. Concern about future access to the resource has made new investment uncertain.

When we look at the actual figures, we see that there has been an expansion in recent years in the amount of resource available to the forestry industry; there has not been a contraction at all. Moreover, the forestry industry is still well within the allocation of resource which it has available to it. Even with the increased areas set aside for conservation purposes, it would be some time before the forestry industry came up against any sort of limitation on access to resources, so the Prime Minister is quite wrong. The Prime Minister also said that he took this action of moving towards so-called resource security `only after receiving unqualified legal advice that it was the sole way the Commonwealth could provide a binding undertaking of the kind necessary to get major projects started which will provide new exports and new jobs'.

I ask the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, who is in the chamber, to table that legal advice. I, and many people in the environment movement, would be very interested to see that unqualified legal advice which said that that was the only way that these industries could be established. Frankly, I do not believe it. I do not believe that that was the reason for this action to be taken. On the same page in the Prime Minister's statement there is reference to becoming a `clever country'. The Prime Minister states:
This does not necessarily mean working harder; in Germany and Japan, both highly successful competitive countries, working hours are actually falling.

I would like to read some quotations from an article about Germany's secrets of success by Tim Colebatch in the Age of 19 February. He points to the massive investment which Germany is making in education and training, far greater than Australia. Germany is certainly becoming the clever country. The article states:
Remember the average factory worker with his six week's leave,-
the Opposition has made great play of the leave and other levels of support of workers in Australia, attempting to paint the Australian worker as some sort of a slacker who has a very easy time-
$32,000 award wage and huge pension? There's something else you should know about him. He was at school until he was 19: in an affluent state system run by some of the world's best-paid teachers.
This Government has contracted support for education-
Moreover, German schooling is tough. Each year he faced real exams, and those who failed-10 or 15 per cent-had to stay down and repeat.
Tim Colebatch continues:

The main reason for Germany's economic success is the quality of its products. German companies dominate four huge industries-motor vehicles, industrial machinery, chemicals and electrical apparatus-because they make the best products in the world. And they do so by investing heavily in new products and processes.

In 1986, on OECD figures, Australian manufacturers spent $1 in every $200 they earned on research and product development. German manufacturers spent five times as much; $1 in every $40 was ploughed into staying at the top of the learning curve. German business has very different priorities, and they have worked; German companies now supply one in five patent applications lodged in the Western World.

In relation to working harder, the Prime Minister clearly does not understand what that does in terms of global equity. There are two inputs to industrial production; there are two inputs to gross domestic product (GDP)-the measure which the Prime Minister and the Opposition wish to see grow-material resource input and labour input. Economic growth, as desired by the Government and the Opposition, meaning growth of gross domestic product, therefore means a growth in the consumption of one or both of these inputs. The question is: are there limits to growth in the consumption of either or both of these inputs?

As I have already pointed out in relation to the inputs-one of the inputs is the capacity of the atmosphere to absorb polluting gases which are causing the greenhouse effect-there are limits to the input of resources. We do, after all, live in a finite planet. Exponential growth in material consumption of resources clearly has limits. Energy consumption is a clear cause of greenhouse gas emissions and escalating changes in the composition of the global atmosphere. Energy use is closely linked with the extraction and use of all other material resources, so continued growth in the consumption of material resources is incompatible with ecological sustainability.

What of labour, the other resource that the Prime Minister mentions? The United States and Japan have recently experienced economies growing much more rapidly than the increase in their material resource use. Their material input to GDP has in fact declined. The labour content of GDP has increased far more rapidly, making a shift from material resource input to labour input. But labour is also limited. There are only 24 hours in a day and 8,760 hours in a year-the time interval over which GDP is measured. Everyone has the same number of hours available for work. People cannot buy hours and add them to their equitable quota.

There are only three ways in which an individual, a community or a country can increase the value of the labour component of GDP; work harder or more hours, increase the value of one's hours vis-a-vis the value of the work of others-and I stress that-or increase the value of one's work compared to the work of others. Working more hours or working harder at the same job clearly has strict limits. Moreover, one should seriously question the sanity of any society that sought merely to make its citizens work harder and harder merely to chase a growing GDP. Doing the same work or even doing different work and charging more for one's time involves taking an advantage over another in a zero sum game.
The zero sum nature of the labour component of GDP is important to grasp. It arises out of the fixed and equal number of hours available to everyone.

If a pilot charges three times as much per hour for his time as I do for my skill, then I must work three hours to buy one hour of his. As his fortune rises, so my fortune falls and in a precisely reciprocal way and to a precisely reciprocal extent. So it is between nations. If the Japanese charge more per hour for their time, Australians must spend more time to buy the products of Japanese labour. Inequity places strict limits on growth through this course.

This analysis also means that human inventiveness will not cause global economic growth but may allow one person, group or nation to grow at the expense of another. For those who are being left behind by competitive labour costs there is one temporary solution; that is, to attempt to feed their economic growth by increasing the rate of exploitation of material resources. As we have seen, that has strict limits.

Tonight we will debate the private member's Bill which I have introduced in relation to the importation of tropical rain forests. What we see there, par excellence, is an example of people being forced to over-exploit resources simply to continue to maintain some standard of living in a competitive world. So here we see how countries with growing economies, even those with relatively declining material input to their growth, exacerbate environmental despoliation and depress resource prices in those countries struggling but failing to make their economies grow. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), when he uses the oxymoron sustainable growth, does not know what he is talking about.

In conclusion, I welcome the opportunity to debate these fundamental philosophical matters. They are important. We should have more debate on these matters, but I am afraid that the Government has no clear idea of where it needs to position Australia in the future. Indeed, it is taking Australia up a blind alley because it has failed to recognise the imperative dictates of the environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Government's industry statement, which was put down two days ago. This statement, for which we have all been waiting, is truly consistent with the economic performance of the Hawke Government in its declining days. It is an exercise of too little too late. This is the resounding response not only from the business community but also from this Government's former science Minister. For a second I will concentrate on that one point. Not just the coalition is saying that the Government has not gone far enough; there are people in the Government who totally agree with that position.

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest burden hampering the private sector today is taxation and low productivity resulting from the lack of labour market reform. Where is the labour market reform in Tuesday's statement? It is absolutely nowhere to be seen. What has been said that will make it easier for employees to sit down with employers to work out their own agreements, not merely to save jobs in the recession that we `had to have', but also to build real productivity? Absolutely nothing has been said that will do any of that. At once the major differences between this tired Labor Government and the coalition become obvious. We got the message a long time ago that without the freeing of the labour market, reforms in tariffs or any other area would not allow Australia to compete and to survive.

Nothing in this statement will change the facts revealed in Perth last month that compulsory unionism, supported by the Hawke Labor Government and of course its political master, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), continues to perpetuate rorts in the multimillion dollar construction industry. A fourth year apprentice on a Perth construction site grosses $900 a week and the lollipop man with the Stop-Go sign clears $800 a week.

Yet week after week the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, gets up in this place and says how dreadful it is that the executive salaries and packages in this country are too high. If he can stand up here pretending to know all and say that he condones fourth year apprentices on construction sites grossing $900 a week and the lollipop men clearing $800 a week, I will go he. I asked him a question about this in the Senate only a few weeks ago, which naturally he refused to answer. This is his area, yet he completely ignores the realities of how he is crippling the construction industry.

I say again and again that these extortionate wage levels upheld by union muscle is the reason that business is struggling and a major reason why today we learn that in Western Australia one member in 10 of the work force is out of a job. Once again, we had another debate in this place only the other day. We talked about the realities and the concern that this recession-cum-depression is causing the people of Australia. Not one Government senator was able to recognise the realities of that concern in the community. We will not build any kind of clever country when our rigid and corrupt industrial relations system gives a Sydney crane driver a gross income of $130,000 annually compared with $120,000 for the captain of a 747.

Everyone in this country will remember a dispute not so long ago-about 18 months ago-when the Prime Minister of this country, Mr Hawke, absolutely condemned pilots for being lazy, for not earning their money. At that time most of those pilots were not earning anywhere near the $120,000 that a captain of a 747 earns today, let alone anywhere near the $130,000 that a crane driver earns. But do we hear the Prime Minister or Senator Cook saying that that is absurd and that the crane drivers should not be earning that amount of money? Of course not.

Only today it was reported in the Australian Financial Review that the ACTU is hoping to do a deal with the Australian Democrats to ensure that a centralised wage system endures beyond the inevitable demise of the Hawke Labor Government. This same Government will do all that it can to further this process. The sad reality is that the Australian Democrats will probably buy that argument from the ACTU because the Democrats do not have any policies. Their only policy is promising everything and anything to the world, knowing full well that they will never have to deliver. They can afford to pretend to be all things to all people. But at the end of the day, as with the Gulf war, we will see quite clearly where they stand.

We have of course heard all about productivity breakthroughs on the waterfront. The coalition welcomes every improvement to a situation that has proven a massive impost on our export industries. Nevertheless, there is a great deal of deliberate exaggeration as to the progress of reform when the productivity gains made by Conaust Pty Ltd have resulted from the sidestepping of the Government's own program.

Unfortunately, we do not have long to go before the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, will resign. As Senator Walters said, Senator Collins has of today only 53 more sleeps before he resigns because he has not been able to deliver true reform on the waterfront. The Government has failed to meet its targets in cutting the waterfront labour force. Of the 500 redundancies scheduled to be processed by the end of September, not one was achieved by that date.

The end of March will see 451 redundancies, not even the September target. And 213 new waterside workers have been employed. Some reform! Of course, productivity on the waterfront is improving. It had to. That is nothing to be proud of at the moment at least, because it simply had to. But it is lagging far behind such trading partners as Britain and New Zealand. This is the heart of the problem-this Labor Government does not have the intestinal fortitude to tackle the problem fully.

Only last month the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), whose area of responsibility is at the sharp end of waterfront costs, conceded that reform was proceeding too slowly. Sadly, he does not communicate that with Senator Collins, the Minister responsible. They both go off in their own ways, both leading the country down the mine, with no communication and no reform. It is all very fine for the Minister to deplore the attitudes of the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia, but when will the Hawke Labor Government do anything about it? This Government has decided on a conciliatory approach that in fact results in union veto over the pace and nature of reform. Needless to say, the statement does not tackle the related problem of the union-upheld trans- Tasman shipping monopoly. It will still be cheaper to ship a container from Melbourne to Auckland via Hong Kong than it is to ship it direct.

Lack of labour market reform is one glaring omission of the statement. Of course, lack of real tax reform is another. We hear all about changes to sales tax. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has not dared to brag about the end of the special 50 per cent punitive rate of tax on luxury cars. Have we heard one syllable from the Government that it goofed, that it made a mistake, that it was wrong and that it has cost this country and the people of this country millions of dollars? No. This Government now has to admit that it has destroyed jobs and businesses for no reason other than political grandstanding. It ignored the basic common sense rule that if taxes are raised arbitrarily, purchasing patterns will change and revenue collection will fall. This is quite apart from the economic damage that is done to a particular section of industry.

This result bears out exactly what the coalition was saying less than 12 months ago, that is, that this was a tax based on appeal to envy to reaffirm the support of Labor's grass roots. Of course, we know that the Australian Democrats are expedient in that regard also. They constantly use the yardstick of the politics of envy. They too supported this tax. Sometimes this Government cynically underestimates the good sense of its own supporters. As I say, the Democrats must share the blame for the pathetic outcome of such a move. The Government's stupid attack on luxury cars, with antique clocks carefully ignored, I might add, is a powerful illustration of the coalition case against sales tax and in favour of a fair, logical, goods and services tax.

Sadly of course for the people of Australia, probably they are not going to get a particularly fair debate on the subject of goods and services tax. It was only yesterday that I saw an article written by Senator Maguire in a Labor Party newspaper called the Herald. There were just so many untruths in that article that one cannot even begin to list them. But at a later date I will bring them before the Senate and attempt to counteract them. That is the type of campaign that the Government is going to undertake. It will not be telling the truth. It will simply exaggerate right the way down the line.

Sales tax is all about governments and officials making arbitrary and complex judgments about what constitutes a luxury or what is a so-called necessity. Businesses which actually pay the tax on behalf of the whole community know that it is about revenue; revenue that this Government has put up by 206 per cent since it came to office. How many people in the community realise how much sales tax they are paying? How many realise that they are now paying an additional 206 per cent more sales tax than they were in 1983 when this Government came to office?

Australia needs an indirect tax that is honest and visible so that all people will know how much they are paying, when the tax is increased, and on what products it is imposed. People need an indirect tax that is not subject to political whims or complex litigation as, for example, when confectionery manufacturers fought a fruitless and expensive legal challenge on the status of sugar coated nuts.

The Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) are, of course, bragging about other changes to sales tax, supposedly ending its application to business inputs. They are giving some recognition to another major scandal inherent in this unjust tax that costs exporters $1.2 billion. What we are being given is not real reform-just like the labour market saga-but window dressing that purports to have countered the coalition case for genuine reform that would exempt exports and levy the tax at the point of sale. We are told that sales tax revenue will be cut by $200m in the next financial year and by $375m in 1992-93. This latter figure amounts to less than 4 per cent of the sales tax revenue for 1990-91 anticipated in the Budget papers.

However, it is estimated that the actual amount of sales tax collected from business inputs is between $5 billion and $6 billion. Last year the Victorian Employers Federation estimated that half of total sales tax derived from inputs. Clearly, therefore, when the small print is made real for the business community it will be seen that tax will continue to be paid on a great many production costs. As before, the cost of compliance will be borne by businesses which will pay the extortionate penalties if they get it wrong. Not for the first time, tax reductions may be eaten up in increased compliance costs that weigh so heavily on smaller business.

It would have been too much for this Government to have asked the business community whether it wanted a complete change to the existing failed system of indirect taxation. The 1990 Arthur Anderson national small business survey showed 75 per cent support for the kind of goods and services tax that the coalition is proposing. It is no accident that the business associations calling for reform represent small business and service industries that are outside the scope of sales tax. These people know a bad tax when they see one.

This statement is not going to result in much change to the $1.2 billion paid in indirect taxation by export industries in 1990-91, including a tax rate of over 4 per cent on forest products and over 6 per cent on transport equipment. The cost effect of this latter figure, impacting on rural export, hardly needs to be spelt out. The farmers are struggling. The farmers are dying from the pressures put on them by this Government. They are walking off the land in unprecedented numbers. They are going broke at an unprecedented rate. As we have stated quite clearly in the Senate this afternoon, the Government does not seem to care about the future of our rural sector in Australia.

A cut of $375m-that would be proportionally less in the 1990-91 context-is still going to leave Australian exporters with an imposition from which they will be freed by the coalition alternative. All the tinkering with sales tax in the Government's industry statement points to one inescapable fact: the Hawke Labor Government knows that it has a rotting lemon on its hands, that it is being unfair and harmful to the very people such a statement is supposed to assist. The Government knows that the coalition is putting forward a concept similar to the 1985 plan that the Treasurer was forced to abandon. As with labour market reform, the Hawke Labor Government no longer has the courage, if it ever did have it, to institute reforms that it knows are right for Australia. Whatever happened to the 1984 principles for taxation reform? They were just thrown out of the window. Taxes must not add to the overall burden. They must be simple, fair, neutral, and make evasion more difficult. The coalition proposes such reform through a goods and services tax. This Government responds with cheap politics.

Stripped of the rhetoric, labor market reform and tax changes are the crucial needs of industry. Here the Government has failed. The coalition welcomes the commitment to lowering protection. But here the Government has simply moved towards the firm coalition commitment of eliminating protection altogether.

Resource security legislation is only a belated recognition that Australia's economic future and real sustainable development had earlier been sacrificed to the buying of green preference votes. It remains to be seen whether the actual legislation will deliver genuine resource security to export industries that ultimately provide the national wealth without which we cannot protect our environment.

This statement does not address the deepest problems that hamper our industry and its productivity. In pointing this out, I am proud to have been able to restate the fact that the coalition does have firm policies in the area of labour market and indirect tax reform. It is a pity that the Government has not seen fit to avail itself of the offer that is constantly being repeated by Dr Hewson of bipartisan support for policies that will get this country back on the road to success.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has waited with bated breath for the Government's industry statement. The need for direction from the Government is at a crisis point. No-one would argue with that. People in all walks of life are crying out for some positive Government direction. The Government has been active in providing policy and direction that have had a negative impact. The Government's policy of slowing the Australian economy by using high interest rates is exactly why Australia is in its present state. In Australia's economic environment high inflation has resulted in high interest rates. As a consequence there are the associated problems of trade imbalances, high exchange rates and spiralling wages and prices as well as other economic woes.

SPEECH.PARA: Ironically, the Government's approach to easing the balance of payments problem by raising interest rates may in itself have been the greatest single cause of the continuation of high deficits and growing debt levels. These massive and debilitating problems which all Australians face today are the reason the Government owed Australia a proper industry statement on Tuesday.

We are told that tariff levels are to fall across the board from the present 10 to 15 per cent to 5 per cent by 1996. While Australia is cutting its protection to primary industries, the rest of the world is increasing theirs, with America and the European Community (EC) outbidding each other on subsidies. Dr Blewett, the Minister responsible for trade, has already convinced the Government to lift the sugar embargo, to lower tariffs to 10 per cent on primary products-now being further lowered to 5 per cent-and to regulate our wheat industry. Had it not been for the vigorous defence of the Australian Wheat Board by the National Party, the Wheat Board would have lost its single seller export status. I can assure the Senate that the overseas wheat exporting countries would have congratulated Dr Blewett and told him what a great fellow he was. That would be to his face; behind his back they would have laughed at him.

The fact is that Australia has shown its hand and surrendered every bargaining chip that it has ever put on the table to try to take the world down the free trade path. But the world has not responded. The answers to our pleas have been that the EC has increased its subsidies by $5 billion to $23 billion this year, while America has introduced the 1991 Farm Bill, increasing its export enhancement programs by $425m to $900m this year and $1.2 billion next year. Last week we saw a bipartisan parliamentary delegation head off to America to plead with the American Administration to stop subsidising, as the world market is being driven down below the cost of production. We saw a spokesman from the American wheat lobby on television telling us to mind our own business and that the American Administration would make the decisions on how it would dispose of its grain.

That might be all right for the American wheat lobby and the American farmers, who are guaranteed $175 per tonne net, but our farmers are playing the game in the world market, receiving no guarantees for their crop and having to match subsidised world prices. The Australian net price to farmers is between $60 and $70 a tonne. A third of our farmers are so desperate that they will not have the cash flow to plant next season's crop. We have gone down the road to further reducing tariffs on agricultural products.

I want to raise the question of what could be called secondary dumping. I am glad that Senator Childs is in the chamber because he is one person who understands this, in his capacity as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I wish that Senator Button were here so that I could explain this to him. However, I will have to rely on Senator Childs getting him in a corner and explaining it to him.

There is immense corruption on the world market in primary industry commodities as the EC and America subsidise against each other in an ever increasing trade war. The world price of commodities is driven down; the prices are neither fair nor equitable; they are distorted and corrupted. These prices become world prices and ultimately become domestic prices-the prices that our farmers are paid for their domestic market products. The grossest trade distortion of all is when Australian farmers get prices which are less than the cost of their production on their own domestic market.

Our farmers are under tremendous pressure. They have to compete on overseas markets that are corrupted by subsidies. We have to wear that. That is part of the game, I suppose. But surely it is unreasonable for them to have to take the corrupt world market price as a domestic price. I hope that Senator Button is listening to this on his video. As the Minister responsible, I ask him to ask the Government committee on anti-dumping that was mentioned in the statement and also the Senate committee to take a reference on the hurt caused by secondary dumping of agricultural products. That is very important.

Primary industries and many other industries have already made the sacrifice of tariff cuts and are going through the pain of adjustment. They have already done their bit to enable the Australian Government to lead its crusade in the international arena for worldwide free trade. Everyone knows-if they do not know, they should know-that there is not a level playing field for Australia's unprotected industries. Australian industries are meant to play a virtuous role and to compete with highly subsidised United States and EC products and the government levies that they attract. Not only industry but the whole Australian economy will flounder as a consequence. Tariff cuts cannot be the only tool. To just cut tariffs is to sacrifice many more Australian industries, with resultant unemployment. Before the industry statement, industry made it known to the Government that what was needed was no more tariff cuts without meaningful reforms which would enable them to be more competitive.

Let us look at some of the impositions that industry has to work under. It must be remembered that this is in an immediate climate of impossible interest rates for investment, decreasing sales, decreasing profits and returns, and increasing bankruptcies. During the past two years wages have gone up 10.6 per cent. On-costs are now running at about 25 to 30 per cent, as a percentage of wages, to industry. Oncosts have been allowed to escalate while industry has been going through a massive decline. Bankruptcies have risen 56 per cent in the last quarter. It must be an indication to the Government that business cannot afford the impost of these ever increasing costs.

There are always new costs for industry to meet. The cost effect of the 38-hour week has added 5 to 6 per cent to wage costs after its introduction. Unfortunately, the effect of the 1987 radically different wage system is imposing very real and very large costs on industry. The aim of the accord was to lead to real improvements in productivity and efficiency with the elimination of inefficient and wasteful work practices. But what has happened is that industry has had to pay the money-that is, the wage increases-in return for a promise by the unions to look at efficiency improvements at some future time. I will concede that there have been some efficiency improvements in some of the bigger industries, but in small business they have not happened.

In real terms there has been little, if any, real improvement in efficiency and productivity coming from award restructuring. The present national wage system is imposing the following further costs for business, according to the paper on labour costs by the Queensland Confederation of Industry Ltd. I have explained these figures to some Labor people, who have looked at me and said that they do not really believe me. I shall put these figures on the record today so that Senator Jones and other people will be able to study them. I also recommend that Senator Bryant Burns study them.

The structural efficiency principle has cost 6.5 per cent. The classification creep that has been the unintended consequence of award restructuring adds a further one per cent. The increase in minimum wages adds a further 1.5 per cent. Wage drift accounts for a further 2 per cent. This sort of outcome will produce an inflation rate of about 10 per cent. On top of the structural efficiency principle-costs of about 11 per cent-there are other costs. These are genuine costs taken from the aggregate records of a number of Queensland firms. These costs include the introduction of the second tier wage increase, 4 per cent; superannuation, 3 per cent; shorter hours-the 38-hour week, which came into existence in Queensland only last year or the year before-5 per cent; and training tax, one per cent. That gives a total cost of 13 per cent. If we combine these costs with the extra costs for labour, as a consequence of the present award system, it represents a total increase in costs of about 22 per cent to 23 per cent-and one firm had even estimated an increase of 25 per cent. Despite the benefits that the present system has promised to return, it continues to generate large labour cost increases that are economically unsustainable.

In other words, we have given benefits beyond the capacity of industry to pay. That is why we are seeing so many bankruptcies. No industry can take the imposition of extra costs in today's poor economic times and then cop the reductions in tariffs that have just been introduced. It is impossible, it cannot happen and the results will be that many companies will go offshore. The people who welcome our blind faith in a reduced tariff policy are our competitors, who rush in and use Australia as a dumping ground for many of their varied products. To drop tariffs without getting productivity increases is suicide. There are specific industries in overseas countries that throw in an extra production run to dump on the Australian market. We find viable, efficient Australian industries suddenly forced to direct their resources, energy and money to establish anti-dumping cases.

It was with pleasure that I was able to move the motion that ensured that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology would investigate the suitability of the present anti-dumping regime. Anti-dumping procedures are allowable under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. If we are determined to lead the way in an anti-subsidy war, we should at least be looking at GATT-legal ways to save some of our industries from falling victim to unfair competition from overseas companies.

It is interesting that this Government has brought down an industry statement called Building a Competitive Australia while at the same time our greatest industries, the rural industries on which Australia has maintained its wealth, are struggling from the imposition of destructive Government policies. At this very moment our good old reliable wheat industry, on which Australia has prospered since its inception, is in the position where plantings will be reduced by 35 per cent this year because it will not be able to get any Government support. Six million tonnes of wheat will be lost from these reduced plantings. At a time of fierce and unfair competition from the United States of America and the European Community, Australia, because of this shortfall, will lose existing markets to these very same competitors. Wheat farmers must have enough resources available to them to enable the industry to keep up its supply level when essentially the world market is in a state of low supply.

The plea for compensation for losses arising from the trade sanctions against Iraq, estimated at $315m, is still there. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised this Parliament that the burden of the Iraqi war would fall equally on all Australians. But it has not; it has fallen firmly on the wheat farmers of Australia.

The thrust of the statement is directed at encouraging exports. Our traditional export industries must not be left to wither on the vine because of hope and unrealised fervour for potentially successful secondary industries. Across the whole range of primary industries trade promotion should be attacked in an aggressive manner. Australian farmers produce quality products in the most internationally effective manner. In the context of Australian industry, primary production is a winner but no industry, no matter how efficient, can compete against odds such as are determined by a war between the two biggest producers in the world.

The Prime Minister spoke on Tuesday of meeting the challenges of international competition. There is no international competition when our competitors do not compete fairly or do not even play on the same ground. There is no challenge in a marketplace that is absolutely corrupt. The desperate plight of rural Australians received a cursory acknowledgment in Tuesday's statement. The Prime Minister said that rural Australia in particular is experiencing a very tough time. I say to the Prime Minister that it is more than that. There is such an interdependence in rural areas that activities that have never been on the verge of collapse have reached that point.

Small business in the country is in an even more desperate plight than urban small business. Small business has such a capacity to employ Australians that it is vital it is not forgotten in any industry plan. Unfortunately, small business did not even get a guernsey yesterday. It was mentioned, and when it became too hard it was dropped altogether. The Government should at least accelerate its investigation and implementation of the Beddall report, which was tabled in the other place 10 months ago but has not seen the light of day in here as yet.

The announcement in the statement that there will be a reduction in general agricultural tariffs is an about-face for the sugar industry. The sugar industry since May 1989 has gone through massive changes in its contribution to industry deregulation. The industry is a major export earner for Australia, with 80 per cent of its yield being exported. The raw sugar industry was awaiting the terms of reference from the Industry Commission for an inquiry into sugar, which included the tariffs, when the new reduced tariff regime was suddenly imposed on the industry without notice on Tuesday.

The Government, when lifting the embargo on the importation of sugar which took effect on 30 June 1989, established a tariff regime. Following a Senate inquiry, the tariffs were set at $115 a tonne for two years, reducing to $95 a tonne from 1 July 1991, with a further reduction to $70 a tonne from 1 July 1992. As of Tuesday, the tariff will be reduced from $95 to $76 from 1 July 1991, and is to be further reduced on 1 July 1992 from the scheduled $70 a tonne to $55 a tonne. Surely the industry had a right to expect that the tariff would not be changed prior to the planned Industry Commission inquiry.

The immediate cost to the industry of the tariff reductions will be $16m a year. That will amount to a loss in Australian export earnings. The determination of the existing tariff system followed extensive input from industry. Senator Childs will remember going all over Australia taking evidence not only from industry and farmers but also from the many unionists who put submissions before that inquiry. Not only did the farmers and the industry have the right to expect the findings of that inquiry to be implemented and held to, but the Government has ripped that up. It is not only attacking the farmers; it is also attacking every worker employed in the sugar industry.

It is only another example, if another example is needed, of this Government making commitments and then breaking them. If we want to see evidence of that let us refer to the wool industry. Mr Kerin promised on 11 occasions that the 700c price would remain firm and then, at some whim, walked away from the industry. The inquiry is taken seriously. The statement has the result of changing an established and certain system midstream and requires some announcement from Government as to its real intentions and bona fides for the forthcoming industries.

The proper direction for all industry that was required from this statement was really not forthcoming. With submissions from industry groups and disclosures in the media during the devising of the statement, the Government was being given plenty of good, practical advice on what industry in Australia needed. The good advice was ignored. Industry said, `No further tariff cuts without meaningful micro-economic reform that will enable us to be more competitive and meet the competition from imports'. Small business said, `Consider the contribution we can make to the Australian economy and work force', but was totally ignored. Of course, rural industry was barely acknowledged, other than its present organisational structures-that is, the statutory marketing authorities-being threatened by trade practices legislation references, and simply equating the rural tariff levels with manufacturing tariff levels. They are two totally different industries with rural industry already out there fully exposed to the vagaries of world market prices.

It is a sorry state when our great rural industry is pleased to hear that in April the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) will announce a rural adjustment program that will ensure farmers most in need during the current rural crisis will receive appropriate assistance. That is not very complimentary to our rural industry. It had a right to be included in this statement and it was rejected. The statement is a disappointment. It follows on the disastrous Government approach of applying theory without reference to realities and practicalities. Therefore, there is the great fear that the effect of this statement, coupled with the inappropriate policies of high interest rates, will only lead to the further rapid decline of Australian industries. Now that the Government has given us a policy for industry, it must ensure that the Australian industry is successful and is ready to go.

In conclusion, I believe that the Government must not only tell Australian industry that it must work smarter and be competitive; it also has to be honest with the worker, it has to take the worker into its confidence. We are out in the international pool where there is no protection. We are a small country with 17 million people and that is a disadvantage in manufacturing, because manufacturing in Australia cannot get the massive production runs. We are starting behind the eight ball. The Government must tell the workers that they have to share the responsibilities and pull their weight too. They are in competition now with countries that do not give comparable benefits to their industries. In America, the basic wage is $3.50 an hour. Of course, there are add-ons for skills; there is no four weeks leave; there is no 17 per cent loading, and there is no long service leave. In Japan, industry works 2,000 hours a year; Australian industry works 1,700 hours a year.

The Prime Minister should be saying to the workers of Australia and to the unionists, `You have to be competitive too; we have pushed you all-industry and workers-off the deep end. You will either sink or swim'. They cannot rely on one particular sector of an industry. If the workers cannot accept that, then jobs will go and it will not be industry's fault. No matter how much the Australian Council of Trade Unions abuses industry and calls it `wishy washy, uncompetitive, wimps' and all other names that are being used at the moment, industry can play a role. But the workers must play their role, and they must realise that the benefits they have received in the past will not be forthcoming in the future. Australian industry certainly cannot compete against other countries that do not provide the benefits and the costs for their workers. If Australian workers realise that, then hopefully we will be competitive and we will go into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Government's statement entitled Building a Competitive Australia. I would like to comment on the needs of the manufacturing industry and the very welcome decisions that are contained in the Government's statement.
