SPEECH.PARA: Manufacturing is a vital part of the economy. Australia can ill-afford to step away from its problems. Manufacturing accounts for about 16 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) and 45 per cent of current exports. It comprises the kernel of the nation's technical skills which are vital in primary resource industries as well, and that, in part, answers what Senator Boswell was just asking.

No other country of significant size has been able to sustain a high standard of living over a long period without a strong manufacturing base. The trade deficit, which has featured so much in this debate, is significant especially as manufactures amounted to $19.9 billion in 1988-89. A further problem is the composition of Australia's manufactured exports. Of the approximately $20 billion only $4.5 billion has a high value added; in other words, elaborately transformed manufactures-goods such as cars, engines, scientific equipment and components. The remaining manufactured exports of about $16 billion comprise raw materials which have received limited processing; for example, the sugar industry that Senator Boswell was referring to.

The other significant reason why I believe it is an important subject and the Government's initiatives are extremely important is that 72 per cent of Australia's imports comprise manufactured goods. Therefore, I welcome the many initiatives that are contained in the statement, particularly the introduction of exemptions from the wholesale sales tax. A simplification of the system will reduce the cost burden in industry. The new exemptions flow from the wholesale sales tax review in the 1990 Budget. Exemptions are extended to include inputs used in manufacturing for research and development design and production processes. Staff training will also be included in the exemptions. So there is a significant raft of proposals which will make it so much easier for industry.

The new depreciation regime will allow manufacturers to claim depreciation on the estimated life over which assets will earn income and provide taxpayers with greater certainty. The example of 125 per cent research and development deduction is a particularly welcome initiative. Research and development is one area where we have to move from such a very low base, especially in the private sector. Private sector research and development is only 0.5 per cent of GDP. That is a very poor performance over many years. The 125 per cent deduction will be retained as a permanent feature of the tax system. It means that we can expect private industry to have a certainty about that proposal. When it is linked with the Government's training levy-in other words, the training of staff and the pressure on people to develop their skilled staff, their scientific staff, instead of pinching them from somebody else-we will have a regime that offers great possibilities for us in the future in the vital area of research and development for industry development.

The enhancement of the capital base of the Export Finance Insurance Corporation is an example of the very appropriate and excellent intervention by the Government in industry to promote exports. This is what the statement Building a Competitive Australia is all about.

Other financial service companies have shown that they are not prepared to accept the risks in securing long term access to export markets. That is part of an Australian problem that has so often been identified where people want very quickly to get returns on their capital. The support for trade and credit insurance is essential in view of the strategic support provided by other governments to support their own exports in securing overseas markets. It is encouraging that the Government is prepared to provide $200m callable capital to a successful and essential government business enterprise.

The Government is to introduce an advanced manufacturing technology strategy to encourage the development, production and use of advanced manufacturing technologies. I welcome the Government's action and, in particular, the decision to maintain and extend the bounty scheme for production of machine tools and robots with effect from 1 July 1991.

The bounty will be extended to cover equipment used in processing advanced materials such as ceramics, carbon fibre and composite materials. This recognises the importance of such materials as alternatives to metal in internationally competitive products and will cater for advances in materials processing technology. The treatment of machines for working of advanced materials will be made consistent with that for metal working machines and robots. To do this duty free by law entry will be extended on a case by case basis to imports, allowing end users access to the latest equipment at world prices.

The decisions in this area reflect the Government's view that the bounty will continue to be an important factor in maintaining a key industrial capacity with an important role in the diffusion of advanced manufacturing technologies. The use of advanced manufacturing technology is very significant because it makes a real contribution to efficiency, productive skills enhancement, employee well-being and the general competitiveness of manufacturing industry.

The Government will introduce a program to assist leading edge customers of advanced manufacturing technology to work more closely with local suppliers and relevant research organisations to develop products and services to meet their needs. The strengthening of core strategic capacities within the Australian advanced manufacturing technology supply sector and the joint development of more indigenous products and services will greatly assist change and improvement in our manufacturing base.

I would like to turn to another aspect of this issue which does not involve a great amount of money but I think it is an important development; that is, the extension of the Australian Quality Awards. Achievement of quality is important for international competitiveness and the Government places priority on businesses achieving international standards of quality in products. Enterprise Australia has organised Australian Quality Awards for the past three years. In 1990 the Government provided $50,000 to fund the awards. Reflecting its initial success, the program is to be substantially upgraded so that the awards recognise outstanding achievement, involve more companies, encourage greater commitment by companies to organisation-wide quality improvement, establish an evaluation process and provide performance benchmarks of international standing.

I mention this because in the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology report entitled Manufacturing Industry Revitalisation: Making it Together, we acknowledged the work of Work Skill Australia which, in 1982, created national work skill competitions. Senator Brownhill is here in the chamber, and he has been one of the people instrumental in promoting the Work Skill Olympics and other aspects of giving credit to people skilled in industry. One of our recommendations was that the Skill Olympics should receive greater public recognition for our winners in this area in exactly the same way as we honour sports men and women. I mention that because the Quality Awards are a move in the same direction.

Many people do not acknowledge that it is very important to have successful models in every sphere of activity; no less than in manufacturing industry which for so long has had an attitude problem. People have seen manufacturing industry as not being as attractive as white collar and other types of industry and commerce-a whole of range of industries that are seen to be more attractive. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said in his industry statement:
The challenge is therefore to make decisions and adopt the practices and attitudes which will enable this and succeeding generations to achieve those basic goals.

In a moment I would like to outline the proposals that address this challenge in a report on new management techniques in manufacturing industry of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. This report put great emphasis on the people side of the manufacturing process; the sort of thing that has been referred to in the Prime Minister's statement as `working for a clever country'. It is the emphasis in this area that will be the basis of success in our manufactures. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the report of the Committee entitled The Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) `Unofficial Account'.
— by leave -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my statement in Hansard and to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PARLIAMENTARY INFORMATION SYSTEM `UNOFFICIAL ACCOUNT'
Mr President,
I present the 308th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts-the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) `Unofficial Account'.

The Committee's task in this Inquiry was to examine the roles and responsibilities of the key players in the establishment and operation of the `unofficial account' and to assess what further action was required in response to the breaches identified in the report of the Auditor-General. Chapter 8 of the Report summarises the Committee's findings in this regard.

The term `unofficial account' has been used throughout the report and the Committee emphasises that the account was clearly illegal. It was set up and operated by a small number of individuals within the Parliamentary Information Systems Office. The Committee considers it likely, because of the extremely unusual nature of the account, that if it had not been for the actions of certain other individuals, the account would have remained undetected for a considerable period. In fact, it may never have been discovered.

With regard to the question of possible disciplinary action against those connected with the `unofficial account', the Committee notes that this responsibility rests solely with the relevant delegates under the Public Service Act 1922. In the Committee's view, consideration of such action will need to take account of the advice of the Attorney-General's Department in relation to the breaches identified by the Auditor-General, as well as the findings of the Public Accounts Committee.

The Committee draws attention to the fact that although it is concerned with issues of accountability, consistent with its charter, this Inquiry differed significantly from the Committee's usual inquiries in that the terms of reference called for an assessment of specific individuals' roles and responsibilities with regard to the `unofficial account'.

The Committee wishes to emphasise that, while its evidence is taken on oath or affirmation, the Committee is not a court of law. Nevertheless, at all times during the Inquiry, the Committee attempted to ensure that the principles of natural justice prevailed. Witnesses were given every right of reply to allegations made against them. Ultimately, however, where there was a conflict in the evidence before the Committee, the Committee was required to make a judgement about whose evidence to believe and has done so.

The Committee has concluded that poor management within both the Parliamentary Library and PISO, together with the lack of effective accountability mechanisms in a situation of devolved responsibility, created the environment which enabled the `unofficial account' to be set up in the first place and remain undetected for so long.

The Committee was shocked to discover that, at the time of the events under review, there was no internal audit function within the Department of the Parliamentary Library nor, indeed, in any of the Parliamentary Departments. In the Committee's view, internal audit is a fundamental link in the chain of accountability. The Committee has recommended, therefore, that each Parliamentary Department that has not already done so should establish, as a matter of priority, an adequately resourced internal audit function.

The Inquiry has also demonstrated the need for all new entrants to the Australian Public Service to be briefed on the financial legal framework affecting public servants' dealings with Commonwealth financial resources and the Committee has made a recommendation accordingly.

Furthermore, the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Government examine ways to ensure that its major contractors comply with relevant Commonwealth legislation and operating policies which impinge on contracts.

However, these last two recommendations in no way relieve senior public servants or contractors to the Commonwealth of their responsibility to be aware of, and comply with, relevant laws and regulations.

The Committee has also recommended that the Department of Administrative Services review the guidelines and procedures regarding the disposal of surplus, unserviceable or obsolete assets to ensure that the arrangements currently in place are adequate, clearly understood and properly implemented.
The Committee emphasises that while the sum involved in this investigation-a total of $88,100-may not be significant in terms of total Commonwealth outlays, the principles involved are significant.

Moreover, the Committee believes that its investigation has proved to be a salutary reminder not only to officers of PISO, but to all Commonwealth public servants of the responsibilities involved in managing and accounting for the taxpayer's dollar.

Finally, the Committee notes that in February 1990 the Presiding Officers transferred PISO to the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and that since that time substantial measures have been taken to improve the management and accountability of PISO within this new Departmental structure. The Committee is satisfied that the serious shortcomings it had identified in this area have now been properly addressed.
I commend the report to honourable senators.
Debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the dinner break I was referring to a number of positive aspects of the industry statement and I particularly want to refer to the reference by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to Australia becoming a clever country:

SPEECH.PARA: I said at the outset that securing the future of the country is in the hands of each one of us. To achieve change, we must mobilise our most valuable resource: the talents of the Australian people.
Later:
The Business Council of Australia has proposed a major research project on international performance benchmarks of business input services.
We have directed the Bureau of Industry Economics, with the cooperation of the BCA, to undertake this project at a cost of $1.8m over four years.

The Pappas Carter report commissioned by the Australian Manufacturing Council, and recent publications by EPAC, have placed particular emphasis on the importance of changing the workplace culture. In cooperation with the AMC, we will develop a program to raise the efficiency of Australian enterprises to world standards. We will draw on the experience of our own world class companies together with the best practices that can be found anywhere in the world in this endeavour.

This attempt to have world class companies has proved very elusive because until now Australia has not had enough companies that could properly be classified as world class. It is significant to note that the Government has appointed Mr John Prescott, the Managing Director of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) and Chairman of the Australian Manufacturing Council, to chair the board that will oversee the new program.

Historically, BHP had a very bad reputation in industrial relations and its general relationships with its staff. It is significant that that has changed dramatically over the past few years. Despite a bad record, as far as I am concerned, BHP has adopted new management techniques which have brought it into the twentieth century and which now mean that many BHP plants are an example for other Australian companies to follow. I welcome the fact that this new program will have $25m spent on it over two years.

Senator Boswell, when he was referring to the costs faced by businesses in Queensland, failed to mention whether management is using modern techniques or doing what BHP did for many years and merely giving instructions and orders to people and wondering why its work force was so passive and resentful. Such businesses have missed out on all the innovation and creativeness that have become characteristic of countries that are successful manufacturers, such as Germany, Japan and, of course, Sweden.

I welcome the Government initiatives to develop the human capital in our manufacturing industry. Although the Government has done many things to help industry become more efficient, the significant reference to Australia becoming the clever country becomes operative only when people are taken into the process through commitment and cooperation and through the shared commitment to agreed goals that have been worked out by people participating in a more democratic process, which can build on the strong foundation the Government has created through award restructuring and the other techniques that have been brought in to try to improve our way of doing things.

The Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology produced a report, which the Government has not yet responded to. I find the Government's tardiness in replying somewhat irritating, although I appreciate that the Government is dealing with reports that have been tabled in both Houses on ways of improving manufacturing industry. As the Government has not yet responded, I commend to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) a consideration, in following through the initiatives in the industry statement, of the proposals contained in the report New Management Techniques in Manufacturing Industry. People and Technology. The emphasis in the report is on people and technology being the secret of success in manufacturing.

The significance of the report is that it proposes the creation of advanced manufacturing technology in Australia based on examples of efficiency in other countries. It recommends that an Australian model be established with uniquely Australian characteristics. For example, Australia is one of the few countries that have so many different languages in its factories, workplaces and industry generally.

I should like to comment specifically on the proposal by the Committee for the development of an Australian model for new management techniques. That will be the principal outcome of a series of national conferences which will serve to raise the awareness of new management techniques referred to in the Prime Minister's statement.

The model would be developed over successive conferences as experience and knowledge of relevant factors increased. The Committee recommended that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce use the recommendations and comments in the report entitled People and Technology as the basis for developing a draft model for consideration at the proposed conferences. The report says:

Development of that draft model should take place following consultation with bodies such as the AMC and NIES. The draft model should form the basis for separate industry models which would clarify the terminology, specify performance indicators and enable the identification of businesses able to meet the standards of that model.

It is very important in this discussion about modernising industry to realise that there are no agreed definitions at this stage of what constitutes the world-class manufacturing organisation. In addition to the national conferences, it was proposed that there be complementary State conferences.

The Committee also recommended that the first national conference cover such matters as the development of an Australian model for new management techniques; development of working groups to discuss experiences with new management techniques; the education system's ability to train the work force; reports by consultants, including case studies; international industry experience, including guest speakers and case studies; and industry sector forecasts and trends. Here there was an attempt to follow the very successful forecasting that occurs in primary industry at a national conference. The parallel is significant: if we are to redress the problems we have in manufacturing, then we need the same sort of intelligence, but we also need the discussion and participation of the players from industry in looking at the future of the industry.

This is particularly important in conjunction with the Government's statement because we do have to change the whole of Australian industry culture so that people will be more interested in, and see the importance of, Australia having successful industry. There is only one way to achieve that: to have a proper democratic public debate about those issues. Unfortunately, that debate does not take place in Australia in a concerted way at the moment. It often occurs only in a negative way. Unfortunately, so many contributions from the Opposition have contributed to that negative debate that does take place in our society instead of the sort of thing that I would see taking place in that national conference on industry. Of course, one of the significant points that we would finally be looking at in such a meeting would be the strategies for developing overseas markets in conjunction and consultation with Austrade.

My final point is that it was proposed that that conference take place with the minimum number of peak organisations, the primary emphasis being on the participants from management and labour so that we did have the people who are experiencing these new management techniques that were referred to in the Prime Minister's report being the dominant people. The people going to that national conference will increase the community awareness of these techniques so that we can get that attitude change referred to in the statements by both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button.

I commend the Government's statement. I think that there are many very satisfactory developments. I think that for too long there has not been a discussion about the strategy that Australian manufacturing industry, in particular, should follow. I hope that, together with the Government accepting the concept of a national conference to highlight industry issues, the Government's statement will help Australian industry to become export oriented, to engage in import replacement and generally to have a more powerful presence in the world. I commend the statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's industry statement, under the pretentious title Building a Competitive Australia, delivered in this place only two days ago on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), and by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the accompanying statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), was widely touted for weeks before the event as this Hawke Government's last chance.
—It is its last chance.

—Its last chance, as Senator Brownhill says, it certainly was. It was touted as the Government's last chance to bring this destructive recession to an end; its last chance to build a competitive Australian economy; its last chance to give the Australian people some hope; and its last chance to salvage some political credibility. It has missed every one of those chances. It has wasted the chance to initiate and accelerate the real reforms-the structural reforms-which the Australian economy so desperately needs. Why? `It is not easy to introduce micro-economic reform quickly, when the Government naturally had to represent union interests'. They are not my words. Those words are reported as being stated by none other than the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin. They bear repeating: `It is not easy to introduce micro-economic reform quickly, when the Government naturally had to represent union interests'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's cover has been blown by this Minister. Despite all the rhetoric, this is a government which claims at best to represent about 30 per cent of the Australian work force in the private sector-those in trade unions; and a somewhat higher number in the public sector-those who make up the new class. These words reinforce that this Government remains the creature of, and is beholden to, the trade union movement.

No wonder the Australian Council of Trade Unions has been given de facto Cabinet status under this Hawke Labor Government. No wonder the statements two days ago were heavy on rhetoric and very short on action. All failed to come to grips with the real crisis on our doorsteps. No wonder each failed to produce real strategies to battle inflation and unemployment and to bolster production, exports and import replacement. No wonder each failed to provide answers to reduce our foreign debt. This Government has, in restating its agenda for growth and reform, simply reinforced that both this country and its economy are completely off the rails. This industry statement is a superb yardstick for the Government's failures.

Who can possibly believe anything that this Labor Government says? Here we are on the verge of economic collapse and this Government holds up a bunch of unpalatable carrots. Even one of its own, the South Australian Premier and National Labor Party President, John Bannon, has come out and criticised this statement. He has criticised his own Party-his own Government, in effect-by saying that, if the economy did not recover later this year, as forecast in the statement, manufacturing industry would be left in a vulnerable state with further job losses in some sections of the industry. Amongst its many other critics, even this Labor Party Premier has criticised the Government for failing to have the guts to tackle the issues head on. In fact, a range of quite diverse groups have given quite negative responses to the statement. From the welfare sector through to a range of industry groups there has been a similar response. It is all a phoney, put-up job, lacking substance.

Senator Button and the Prime Minister have delivered nothing but a bland recipe for more of the same: no labour market reform; no acceleration of waterfront reform; no abolition of cabotage to give us competitive coastal shipping or to get rid of the trans-Tasman restrictive arrangements dictated by the unions; no privatisation; no genuine reform of taxation; no reduction in the centralised bureaucracy-nothing.

This Government has the gall to come into this chamber and tell us that it has the solution to meet the economic challenges facing this country; but it has offered no real solutions. It has done nothing but fail spectacularly and miserably on all fronts. We heard on Tuesday from the third of the triumvirate, Industrial Relations Minister Cook, that we need to rejuvenate the economy and make it more productive; that we need to pull together. He would even have us believe that this Government is instrumental in having us do so.

If this industry statement reflects a carefully planned and phased reform program, as he claimed it did, then I say we are in for much bigger trouble than we have already had. The Minister applauds his Government's actions in handing over $2m through the rationalisation process. That is on top of the generous handouts already earmarked for the retirement of watersiders across the country, on top of the already excessive greed of transport unions. He talks about the $25m for the Australian best practice demonstration program and the $20m for workplace reform programs, as though in merely handing out money problems are solved and strategies for change are in place.

This Minister, with misplaced confidence that the process will produce a catalytic effect of change will, fortunately, not be a Minister after the next election and be able to boast of any success. The Minister talks about no longer accepting that workers should leave their brains at the factory gate. We in the Liberal and National parties have never thought like that. So it is the Labor Party that has had to change its way of thinking with regard to workers. Contrary to the Minister's comments, this statement explains nothing to Australian taxpayers but how this Government will finally empty the larder.

This country's dilemma is not one of success but a question of national inadequacy, of a desperate need to adapt to a rapidly changing world. Professor Peter Drucker, in The Changed World Economy, could not have put it better, and I quote from that book:

From now on any country-but also any business . . . that wants to prosper, will have to accept that it is the world economy that leads and that domestic economic policies will succeed only if they strengthen, or at least do not impair, the country's international competitive position. This may be the most important-it surely is the most striking-feature of the changed world economy.

Australian firms which generate incomes and wealth for this country are restrained by a whole range of policies and manmade institutional arrangements which this Government strictly controls. We have to diversify our export base and take risks in growing markets, like the manufacturing areas of technology. If we do not adapt and conquer these and other areas of change, then we will have to content ourselves with a reduced rate of growth and an impoverished standard of living.

Why does the Government have to wait until it has got us into the worst recession since the Second World War before it feebly attempts to inject some life into the economy? Clearly, it is a case of too little, too late. That this Prime Minister's meagre plan is too little, too late, is confirmed by the fact that it represents about one-eleventh of the urgently needed reform identified by the Business Council of Australia as crucial to national productivity improvement. Without the rest, it will be impossible to reduce our foreign debt and keep our standard of living from falling even further. If the Government had the guts to implement the whole package of reforms identified by the Opposition as necessary, and which we are committed to introducing, then Australian companies would be able to lift their productivity to world best levels and national income would explode by a similar amount over the coming decade.

However, it is quite clear that we are operating below our world best potential. We have a strong store of human resources but we make poor use of them. High labour turnover, absenteeism and an unwillingness to use labour saving technology, combined with management that has failed to adopt the superior quality and service control practices of most other developed countries, have seriously eroded Australia's international competitiveness. In a ranking of 22 countries in the 1990 World Competitiveness Report, published by the World Economic Forum and the International Institute for Management Development, Australia is well below average in every factor, save for human resources and natural endowments. In the other eight areas we rank within the bottom 45 per cent. These include socio-political stability-no doubt as a result of the incompetence of this present Government-innovative forward orientation, State interference, market orientation, dynamism of the economy, financial dynamism, industrial efficiency and outward orientation.

The initiatives announced by the Government will be ineffective and meaningless without total structural reform. Provided each area is tackled simultaneously, reform and revitalisation will take place. Industry will become more efficient and more internationally competitive. Our physical proximity to the newly and rapidly industrialising countries of South East Asia, such as Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand-rather than to the markets of Europe and North America-gives us opportunities, provided we can meet the needs of customers in the region. But we are competing against the successful Asian countries-Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong-and our efforts to date in increasing the focus on Asian markets have not been sufficient to prevent our share of the value of world exports from falling.

We do not have a low wage structure, so to compete we must attain high productivity and quality levels. Our standards of quality and service are below average. Even our best performance is barely above the average levels in other countries and is approximately the same as the worst Japanese performer. There is no longer any safety net for industry. The message cannot be made any clearer: we must simply improve productivity. It is no good saying that we have come a long way in the last 20 years, because our competitors are improving too. Indeed, other nations are improving a lot faster than we are, so that critical gap is widening.

Recent Industry Commission figures indicate that even limited improved efficiency in transport and communications and the public sector provision of services could add as much as $18 billion to our gross domestic product each year, and with reduced protection adding a further $4 billion, that makes an extra national income of $22 billion per year. That equates to about $2,300 per household, 53,000 additional jobs, a 7 per cent reduction in the cost of living, or a real wage increase in excess of 9 per cent. None of these figures takes into account the possible effects of comprehensive industrial relations reform or the introduction of a goods and services tax, which will both be the top priorities for the next coalition government. But the Government simply ignores the need to get on with all of this.

Central to the Government's statement is much rhetoric about the Government's success in winding down import protection for manufacturers and announcements to accelerate that process generally, particularly with regard to textiles, clothing and footwear, and the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. As a result of those decisions, the Australian newspaper columnist Paul Kelly wrote in this morning's edition:
The protection debate in Australia is dead-for companies, industries and politicians. The days of arguing for protection-the biggest game in Canberra-are gone.

In similar vein, earlier this evening at the annual dinner of the Society of Modest Members, I heard this week described as the Bert Kelly Memorial Week. However, when one looks at the announcements in detail, one has to question whether that statement by Paul Kelly, or indeed the claim for this week to be Bert Kelly Memorial Week, is quite the case.

The announcements involve general levels of tariff reduction from 10 per cent and 15 per cent to 5 per cent between 1992 and 1996, while for textiles, clothing and footwear it will come down from the present massive levels to between 15 per cent and 25 per cent by the year 2000, and for passenger motor vehicles to 15 per cent. This is too little, too late, too slow and too unbalanced. It is too little because, as Professor Garnaut and others have clearly demonstrated, the benefits to Australians of reducing tariffs to zero by the year 2000 are considerable. We should also remember that the Industry Commission in its draft report on the motor vehicle industry recommended a phasing down of tariffs more quickly to a zero level by the year 2000. In its final report it slackened that off to 15 per cent, which the Government has accepted. That perhaps indicates that the debate has not quite yet been won. That is why the Liberal and National parties have taken the policy initiative to reduce all industry protection to negligible levels by the year 2000. It is only when that policy is implemented that we will be really able to celebrate Bert Kelly Memorial Week. I certainly hope he is here to see that.

The initiatives are too late as well as being too little, because a more determined attack on protection should have commenced earlier. The initiatives are too slow because the rate of reductions each year should be greater to achieve negligible levels of protection, as I have said, by the year 2000. The statement is unbalanced because it completely ignores the need for structural reform in our economy. Need I repeat it yet again: there is need for reform in the labour market, in all the transport sectors, on the waterfront and in government business enterprises. There is the need for these initiatives to accompany reduced protection so that our industries can compete without protection.

However, the Government's failure to act in these key areas does not provide a valid argument against reducing tariffs. Reducing protection on its own provides net benefits to Australians, even if all other things remain equal. It should ensure that a wider range of goods and services is available to consumers and, more importantly, that they are available at lower prices. It should also ensure that resources of capital and labour are employed in those types of businesses where we are actually efficient and internationally competitive, even allowing for our structural disadvantages, and therefore resources will be allocated to those areas where we can create real wealth through the generation of export income.

Moreover, reducing protection without accompanying structural reform will not make it impossible for Australian manufacturers to compete against imports. Failure to achieve the much needed structural reform will simply mean that the Australian economy remains weak and hence the Australian dollar will continue to fall in value against overseas currencies, as it has for the eight years of Hawke Labor Government economic mismanagement. The only exception to this has been during the period when the Government wrong-headedly enforced high interest rates which in turn attracted hot money into Australia and artificially kept our currency higher than justified by our real economic situation.

In the absence of structural reform, this slide in our dollar's value will continue and more than offset the reduced protection initiated by this statement, even in the case of textiles, clothing and footwear, and motor vehicles. By way of example, over the last seven years the landed cost in Australia of a representative sample of cars imported from Japan and Germany has increased by only 18 per cent in yen and deutschmark currencies respectively. But in Australian dollars, the increase has been a massive 166 per cent, so great has been the depreciation of our currency. This massive increase in landed cost, as a direct result of our currency poor international standing, has much more than offset any reductions in protection designed to make imports more competitive against locally manufactured vehicles. Our currency will continue its slide into oblivion under this Government's policies. That is why the Government should be going all the way in reducing protection to negligible levels by the year 2000, as advocated by the Opposition.

The real tragedy in this statement is for the Australian people, more than for Australian industry. It is our people who will suffer from this too little, too late policy of reducing protection by having to pay higher prices than necessary for goods and services; whereas industry, as I have shown, because of our continuing currency devaluation, would not have suffered from a more rapid reduction in protection. It is our people who will suffer from the failure of this Hawke Labor Government to initiate by this statement much needed structural reform in our economy, the so-called micro-economic reform. This failure condemns our economy to continue its poor performance and low levels of productivity. This means that, even if people are able to extract wage increases, in real terms everyone will be poorer because in real terms everything-goods and services, locally manufactured or imported-will be dearer. So everyone will be able to buy less and will be condemned to a lower standard of living. It is this, rather than reduced protection, which has the capacity to destroy local manufacturers.

The real threat to Australian manufacturers is the ever-diminishing demand for their products because Australians, in real terms, are becoming poorer and poorer, and unable to buy them. This statement, because it fails absolutely to initiate structural reform, offers no hope to Australians for a more productive, more prosperous and brighter future. Instead, at least until a coalition Government is elected to take those initiatives and change things dramatically, it condemns Australia to becoming the poor, white trash of Asia.

Another initiative in this statement which is too little, too late is the reduction in the so-called luxury car tax, introduced nearly a year ago. This initiative was nothing more than a politics-of-envy, soak-the-rich sop to Labor's Left in the lead up to the last election, without any regard to practical policy formulation. It represented a classic case of the static analysis of tax changes, completely ignoring the dynamic effect of such changes. When the legislation was debated last May, I warned the Government that, quite apart from its other shortcomings, it would not result in the extra $100m revenue for roads, which was its claimed purpose, and that it would more likely cause a loss of revenue. But the Government thought it knew better. It thought that the massive increase in prices engendered by a discriminatory sales tax of 50 per cent would not significantly affect sales. It was horribly wrong and I was absolutely right.

Partly as a result of the recession, but largely as a result of this tax, sales of cars subject to the tax plummeted from an annual rate of 15,000 in 1989 to less than 5,000 annual rate in the last half of 1990. Whereas that earlier lower tax regime raised $450m in revenue in 1988-89, instead of the expected $550m for 1990-91, about $225m would have been raised if this tax had continued-about half that earlier generated by the lower rate of tax. The extra $100m was really pie in the sky. The Government claims that reducing the tax, as it has now done, to a still discriminatory level of 30 per cent will cost $15m this financial year and $45m in a full year. I very much doubt this. Again, a static view is being taken.

Undoubtedly, sales will improve as a result of the price reductions because of the reduction in tax, just as they and revenue fell because of the extra impact of the luxury tax. It is therefore more than likely that there will be a net gain in revenue as a result of this change. But more change is needed in this area. There is no justification for any continuation of a discriminatory tax regime. If a sales tax level of 20 per cent is appropriate for most cars, then it is for all. What is really needed is the abolition of sales tax and its replacement with a broad based goods and services tax. Then cars would bear only their fair share of taxation rather than bearing some 17 per cent of the total Government tax take, as is the case at present. Only then will Australia get a first class export-oriented local car industry capable of matching best international practice, which the Government has set as a goal for this statement.

For some years now the Opposition has been calling for extensive micro-economic reform to revitalise the Australian economy, along with major tax reform and the reduction of industry protection to negligible levels by the year 2000. There is no indication in this statement that we are likely to achieve any of that. The statement provides no strategies which would address the severity of our position in a world economy. Finally, no explanation is offered about how we have learned from our past mistakes. Australia cannot afford to wait any longer for these reforms. But sadly, this Government's statement reaffirms that Australia will have to wait for the election of a coalition Government to get any decent reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating the statement put down during the week by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), and Senator Button, Building a Competitive Australia. Unfortunately, I believe that instead of bringing down a statement to turn this country around we have had rather a mishmash of back downs and bandaid situations for the future. The industry that is hurting most in Australia at the present moment is, of course, the rural industry. The Prime Minister did address that point in his delivery to the House of Representatives but laid all the blame on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade situation, the GATT war, the United States export enhancement program, and subsidisation of its products.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that that is the situation. But, unfortunately, those rural industries need immediate help as well as long term help by more pressure being put on the GATT round when it comes around again, and, indeed, all the time, as has happened with the delegation to the United States of America only last week. It is now actively continuing in the Middle East. While I agree that we have to do more and be a stronger force in GATT, I also think we need some measures that will work a lot quicker.

Senator Chapman has already spoken about the statement of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin). In April he will bring out a statement about how the rural industry will be assisted. It will work through the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation of Western Australia, Rafcor. Money will be sent to the farmers most in need. I agree that the ones most in need should be helped. I would like to make two points. First, April is too late, especially for the wheat growing industry in the northern parts of Australia. In many places seeding is taking place. If it is not taking place the planning will be. Fertilisers, chemicals and labour-all that sort of thing-have to be put in place. So April is too late.

The Australian reported a statement made by Mr Kerin. I was very surprised that he made such a statement. I rang his office and the office of the Australian to find the exact source of the article. I give Mr Kerin the benefit of the doubt. He may not have been reported completely accurately. But if it has not been reported as he said it, I wish he would come out and say so. This article is dated 13 March 1991. I will read out the piece that annoyed both me and the rest of rural Australia. Mr Kerin said:
. . . farmers had to realise that it was not easy to introduce micro-economic reform quickly in the area of off-farm costs when the Government naturally had to represent union interests.
I am so incensed and taken aback by that article that I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
Kerin defends decision on wheat submission

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has hit back at farmers who have accused him of disregarding a Grains Council of Australia plan for a base wheat price of $151 per tonne for next season.

His comments followed the Australian Wheat Board's announcement that yesterday's Cabinet decision-involving a watered-down version of the GCA's proposed package-would mean growers receiving a post-harvest payment increase from 30c to up to $6 per tonne.

Mr Kerin told Parliament that Cabinet had examined the GCA plan, which had been included as an annexure to his Cabinet submission on help for the ailing industry, before opting for a solution allowing the AWB to increase its borrowings by $100 million.
But Mr Kerin hinted yesterday's decision was not the final response to the wheat industry's problems, saying ``it was necessary to hold the position while moving to a new policy position''.
He said farmers had to realise that it was not easy to introduce micro-economic reform quickly in the area of off-farm costs when the Government naturally had to represent union interests.
An AWB spokesman said the government decision effectively meant growers would receive money earlier from the 1990-91 wheat pool.
``In very broad terms, that will mean between $5 to $6 a tonne as a national average on Australian standard white post-harvest payment to be made in the third week of March,'' he said.
Mr Kerin also told Parliament that the supplementary payments scheme to wool growers might only cost half the $1 billion predicted by some doomsayers.
Mr Kerin said the recent performance of the wool market in the first free market sales in 17 years had defied many gloom and doom predictions-but warned it was too early to make a judgment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. If that is not what Mr Kerin said, I would like him to say so. I will now move onto other parts of the statement. I will deal with the finer parts. I know that Senator Chapman and others have covered the broad structure of the announcement. I will now move onto resource security as announced both before and in the statement. Resource security, welcome as it may be-I do not believe with the method by which resource security will be put into place-only extends to the timber industry and to a $100m project. What about mining? Mining is doing rather well. It is just as well that it is doing rather well, otherwise Australia would be further behind in our foreign earnings.

SPEECH.PARA: Where does the fishing industry stand? This is another good provider of export income. These industries certainly were not mentioned. What is the Government doing about this? I do not agree with the way that resource security will be applied. State governments will have to pass complementary legislation. The green movement is howling from the rooftops at the first mention of resource security. Senator Coulter and Senator Powell were carrying on about it. I commend the Government for doing something, but it must not forget that there are other industries out there that need-I prefer to call it-access to resources.

I move on to that part of the statement which talked about the `clever country'. I notice that $15m extra has been allocated to CAP-the country areas program-and for school retention in country areas. I congratulate the Government on the initiative to do as much for the country as it has done for the cities. But it could have gone a lot further.

Another aspect is the fringe benefits tax, which will be changed when we are in government. A matter that has been taken up with me in the last few weeks relates to a housemaster in a boarding school who is living on the end of a three storey building with 150 adolescent schoolboys. His quarters are supplied; he has to live in that building, otherwise he does not get the job; he must be in that building 24 hours a day to take care of those children-so why are his quarters taken to be a fringe benefit? I cannot understand that.

The school I was talking about has 27 people on its payroll simply looking after boarders. Of course, whatever wages they receive, there is also the 47 per cent on top. Why is that considered a fringe benefit? I believe in a fringe benefits tax when there are definite fringe benefits. But this is totally ridiculous. The Government should look at this. This school that I am talking about and other schools have been doing their bit to postpone collecting the tuition fees. In fact, they have wiped out tuition fees and given people time to pay boarding fees. The schools are doing their bit. As honourable senators from distant areas such as Senator Collins and others know, boarding schools have to be used or else children do not get an education.

I now move to the apprentice retention scheme. There has been $74m allocated to this. That is a good idea. But what is the Government doing for apprentices who lost their jobs in the last 12 or 18 months because of the economic downturn? Only the other day I was talking to a young fellow from Adelaide. Unfortunately he is off the payroll. Very little will be done for people like him. I also note that $1.6m has been allocated for 1991-92 only. Once again, what will the Government do once that year has gone?

I see that Senator Button hopes to have general tariffs down to 5 per cent by 1996. Passenger motor vehicles are to be reduced to 15 per cent by the year 2000. I welcome this. But I point out to the Senate that primary industries are down to 5 per cent already, or so near it that it does not matter. I believe that Senator Button intends to get it down to 4 per cent in the foreseeable future. Honourable senators can see that primary industries are not treated the same as the manufacturing sector.

I move on to another back down by the Government-and that is the wholesale tax on business inputs. Exemptions will be extended on transportation by rail, pipeline and conveyor belt. Once again, I agree with it. It will cost the Government $200m in 1991-92, $375m in 1992-93 and $405m in 1993-94. Why has the Government left road transport out of this? Road transport has to work in areas where there is no railway. And where there are railways it will give the railways an unfair advantage over road. Once again, the Government has not thought it through.

I move on to another exemption-the wholesale sales tax on lubricants, office furniture, and equipment. On 23 August 1983 the Government decided to put a sales tax on lubricants. During his second reading speech, Mr Hurford said that the Government proposed to tax oil, greases and lubricants at 23 per cent. He went on to explain that the reason it was going to impose a sales tax on them was that a lot of book work was attached to keeping one sales tax on one industry separate from the sales tax on other industries. The Government wanted to make sure the taxes were paid each year. The Government decided to tax the lot. Now it has backed down and decide to take the tax off. It is a piecemeal situation.

I can remember a tax being imposed on hand tools used in agriculture in about 1983. That is another area in which this Government has turned around. I have said before that, out there in the community, people need help through these measures now and not down the track. These measures are going to be introduced in the Budget Session and they are going to be put into action when they have received royal assent. I have already said that people out there are hurting. They should not have to wait for the Governor-General's pleasure after we put it through in the Budget Session. I can see another six to nine months gone before any of these measures get through.

I now move on to depreciation. It is another area in which the Government introduced a hurried measure and now it has turned around. If I can be so bold, I will quote myself. In this chamber on 7 November 1988, I said:

Depreciation changes probably have the greatest effect on primary industry. This Government has been hell-bent on removing any incentives that a succession of coalition governments offered primary industries to keep.
That is where I was cut off. Senator Walsh interjected:
It is called cleaning up rorts.

I retorted that, if we were to return to the practice of writing off over a period as defined in this schedule, it would be more in keeping with the 1950s. It seems to me that the Government is now agreeing with me and my colleagues, as it has reversed this decision also.

I welcome the broad-banding of depreciation rates where there is a schedule between 2 1/2 per cent and 33 1/3 per cent, and one fits into one's own slot. I welcome those measures. I also welcome the measure that allows items of $300 or less to be written off immediately and that allows other items to be written off over a life of three years. Of course, the biggest saving in this sector is in accounting fees, where one can put all one's items together if one writes them off at the same rate. So one has got one item on the schedule instead of 33. Of course, it saves a lot in accounting fees.

The laws on effective life have been changed. That is a measure that this Government altered in 1983. I also welcome the Taxation Commissioner's ability to give rulings. He may change the assessment if one happens to be in the wrong slot, although it was not mentioned whether there would be penalties.

I turn to the sales tax on luxury cars, which I termed quite some time ago a jealousy tax. The Government has finally seen its folly. It has admitted that during the last Federal election campaign one of its advisers-I do not think he is an adviser that I would like to see in our campaign at the next election-advised it to put in a measure to appear to be socking the rich. At the same time, it promised to use that $100m to fix up black spots. Fortunately, the Government has seen the folly of its ways, as Senator Chapman pointed out, and pulled that measure out. There is still a 10 per cent luxury car tax. Other cars, below $28,000 wholesale, are taxed at 20 per cent; but a so-called luxury car over $28,000 wholesale will still be charged that 30 per cent, which is still a 10 per cent luxury car tax or jealousy tax or whatever one likes to call it. I remember at that time that the luxury tax, or jealousy tax, extended to four-wheel drives that are used in remote areas. But fortunately the Government did something about it about six months ago.

I welcome the changes in anti-dumping measures which shorten the period in which investigations take place. Unfortunately, it is nowhere near short enough. As I have said already, there have, unfortunately, been no changes in the fringe benefits tax. Those remote areas and the small businesses in them have lost out time and time again with this fly in, fly out basis, where men and women leave their families in the city and fly out to their jobs and in a fortnight go home. So very little of the money they earn is spent in those small local businesses.

Another measure that was retracted-much to the disgust of the Australian Democrats-by this Government was negative gearing. Along with negative gearing and all those measures in this statement which we are debating tonight, it will have to do more as the time comes if we want to turn this country around. Unfortunately, as I mentioned earlier, there is no support for the Grains Council of Australia. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order agreed to earlier this day, the Senate will now proceed to the consideration of General Business, order of the day No. 53, Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 6 November 1990, on motion by Senator Coulter:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to give my unequivocal support to the Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990 which was introduced by my colleague Senator John Coulter last year. This Bill represents for the first time a plan of action through which Australia can implement a responsible policy on the importation of tropical rainforest timbers and timber products. The Australian Democrats believe that if the Bill is adopted it will have an important demonstration effect on the rest of the world.

SPEECH.PARA: The rate of global tropical deforestation and the inadequacies of the existing multilateral institutions to deal effectively with this issue have made it imperative for responsible countries such as Australia to take a leading role now in arresting the destruction of a key part of our global heritage. Australia is uniquely placed to act on this matter since we are among the few developed countries in the world to still have some tropical rainforest areas intact. After losing two-thirds of our original rainforest cover to clearing and logging, Australia has finally moved to protect some of what remains in this country. It is time for us also to encourage the rest of the world to protect what remains of their forest areas.

As things stand at the moment, our involvement in the destruction of tropical forests continues beyond our shores. Through our trade, our aid programs and our other links with Asia and the Pacific, Australia plays an important part in the destruction of the world's tropical rainforest areas. Australia imports approximately 200,000 cubic metres of tropical forest timber each year. About 80 per cent is from Malaysia, with the bulk of this from the states of Sarawak and Sabah. Another 10 per cent comes from other South East Asian forests. Although small by world standards, our import trade directly implicates Australia in tropical forest destruction. The world is now estimated to be losing some 20 million hectares of tropical forest each year. This figure equates to an area 18 times the size of the Melbourne Cricket Ground being destroyed each minute, or an area equivalent to the State of Victoria being destroyed each year.

Logging in the Asia-Pacific region is largely driven by Western demand for cheap timber. The Democrats believe that the Western world's part in this destruction is quite unacceptable. Tropical timber is under-priced on the world market because of demand for cheap timber from the industrialised world, particularly Japan and the European Community. In some ways it is understandable that the newly industrialised Association of South East Asian Nations (ASEAN) such as the Philippines and Malaysia, in addition to less developed Pacific Island countries, are seeking quick export earnings to aid their development.

In addition, the problem is exacerbated by the willingness of less developed countries to accept what is in effect a very low price in order to attract foreign investment and to earn quick export dollars. As Senator Coulter has alluded to, by importing rainforest timbers from unsustainable sources, Australia is in fact exporting environmental damage. There can be no denying that tropical rainforests are one of the most important global environmental assets in the world today, yet the levels of destruction in some ASEAN countries have now reached critical levels. For instance, the Sarawak forests of Malaysia are disappearing at a rate of over 15 million cubic metres per year, while a staggering 80 per cent of the Philippines forest cover has disappeared during the past 30 years. At this rate, all of Sarawak's primary forests and the remaining forest cover in the district of Palawan will be logged within one decade. It is clear that immediate action is necessary if these tropical forests are to be saved from further destruction.

We need to remember also that tropical rainforests are the most important habitat for protecting global biodiversity because they contain almost half of all world fauna and flora species. The fact is that these are an irreplaceable part of the world's environment. Permanent conversion of rainforest areas to agricultural land, unsustainable slash and burn agriculture and unsustainable demands for fuel wood fodder and other forest products are the three chief causes of tropical deforestation in the world today.

At present, this type of logging represents a substantial threat to the tropical forests of the Asia Pacific region. Moreover, there are no examples of commercial logging regimes that have been shown scientifically to be ecologically or environmentally sustainable. Added to this, we have the situation where the current rates of deforestation are estimated to contribute some 2.8 million metric tonnes of carbon to the atmosphere annually in the form of carbon dioxide. Tropical forests store significant quantities of carbon collected in tree trunks as the forest grows. Left alone, the carbon balance is stable. However, forest fires and the felling of trees for timber products release large quantities of carbon into the air.

I am sure I need not remind the Senate that these types of carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuels and other activities are contributing to the earth's greenhouse effect and causing global warming. By supporting this measure to ban the importation of tropical rainforest timber products, Australia will by necessity be helping to create a domestic market for timber and other products which are produced in an environmentally responsible way in this country.

For instance, one of Australia's chief manufacturing exporting companies, ACI, is currently involved in a fairly new project of exporting a replacement rainforest timber named arakariar from its own plantation areas in the Imbil area near Noosa in Queensland. This is a pale, softwood timber that is perfect for use in housing construction and internal use. I understand that this timber is in fact stronger and more durable than the rainforest timbers which we presently import from Malaysia. This is indeed a real achievement on the part of ACI to be able to produce such a timber from its own plantation areas in Queensland. This type of project must be encouraged.

Of course, apart from the environmental benefits, ACI is an Australian company using Australian workers. In view of our disastrous balance of payments account we are in the situation where we can export a locally made product instead of importing, as we do now. I raise this example to show that this Bill has a great deal of potential to assist Australian industry to engage more positively in the production and export of replacement timber products as some companies are doing at the moment.

Naturally, the environmental considerations are vitally important. But the fact is that this country could do far better by encouraging the sort of local production which ACI now engages in with replacement timbers from this plantation area in Queensland. Banning the importation of tropical rainforest timbers and timber products from other nations is one way of achieving that goal.

Some concern has been expressed that this measure would be in breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) or that somehow it represents an anti-free trading proposal. This is not the case. As the Senate will appreciate, although GATT essentially promotes a liberal international trading regime, there is provision for this sort of trading measure in certain circumstances. For instance, under article 20 of GATT, entitled `General Exceptions', trade measures may be used for:
. . . the conservation of exhaustible natural resources if such measures are made effective in conjunction with restrictions on domestic production or consumption.

In general, therefore, as long as the GATT principles of non-discrimination as laid out in articles 1, 3 and 13 are not violated, trade restrictive measures on a unilateral or bilateral basis such as this are defensible under GATT. Accordingly, we cannot accept any suggestion that action by Australia to restrict imports of tropical timbers would be inconsistent with our obligations under GATT.

Given the rate of tropical deforestation in ASEAN and Pacific countries, and the inadequacies of existing multilateral institutions such as the International Tropical Timber Organisation to deal with this problem, it is imperative that some international attention be directed in a positive way towards this problem right now. In this regard, consumer countries, albeit small ones such as Australia, have an obligation to take immediate action towards slowing down the wholesale destruction of a vital part of our global heritage by adopting measures such as the one which Senator Coulter has introduced.

As the only Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development country with at least some of its tropical rainforests left and protected, Australia should be setting an example to other consumer and producer countries alike, otherwise we may well risk being accused of double standards by protecting a small amount of our own few remaining rainforest areas but viewing as acceptable the trade with those Asia-Pacific nations which, at this rate, will have destroyed virtually all of their rainforest areas in another decade.

Indeed, the current importation of rainforest timber products to this country lies at odds with the Government's previously stated desire to protect the few remaining tropical rainforest areas in the world. For instance, in the Government's own publication Our Country, Our Future from July 1989, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said:
Australia's future timber needs should be met, without placing at risk the long term conservation of the rainforest resources of other countries.

The Democrats believe it is time to act upon that commitment. We have been intrigued by the Government's desire in recent days to portray itself as committed to making environmentally sensitive decisions. The Democrats suggest that the Government's decisions on the south-eastern forests and, particularly at the moment, on resource security legislation indicate a very shallow commitment indeed to the environment.

Under these circumstances it is perfectly understandable that virtually all the major environmental organisations in this country are currently in the process of rejecting the Federal Government precisely because of its poor track record in environment issues. The Government continues to ignore the environment at its own peril. The fact remains that on Australia's doorstep in South East Asia and the South West Pacific is about one-quarter of the world's remaining tropical rainforests. We have an opportunity tonight to do something to protect those remaining forest areas.

Most of these tropical forests are threatened right now. The fate of the world's biological diversity depends on our actions. We have only a few years to rescue the situation and, indeed, to save ourselves. Halting the import of tropical timber products is an important step in this process. Australia must demonstrate our good international citizenship by substantiating our verbal commitment to the protection of the world's tropical rainforests and adopting this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill being debated tonight, which is Senator Coulter's private member's Bill, has obviously been put forward as a public relations exercise to grab a headline or two and was never intended as a serious Bill. Let me give honourable senators just a short rundown as to why this is so. For some time there has been concern around the world about the likely depletion of tropical forests and the impact on the world that may occur if these forests are not managed correctly.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently, three representatives from Sarawak in Malaysia visited Australia, lobbying whoever would listen to them in an attempt to stop their own Government using timber from their State. Obviously, they convinced the Australian Democrats, who are now suggesting that we in this Senate pass a Bill to prohibit the importation into Australia of rainforest timber, not only from their State or indeed their country, the rest of Malaysia-but also from any country which is willing to export these timbers to us.

First, how much of these timbers do we in this country actually import? Coopers and Lybrand, in a report commissioned by the Government on this issue, put our total imports of forest products from tropical countries at $340m per annum-or only 16 per cent of our total forest product imports. Of course, only a minor part of these products from tropical countries is rainforest timber.

Coopers and Lybrand explained the difficulty in getting separate figures. Japan is the dominant importer of tropical timbers and Australia plays a very minor role in this area. Malaysia is the dominant supplier. Australia takes less than 5 per cent of Malaysia's exports of sawn timber. Of Australia's imports of forest products as a whole, 54 per cent comes from Malaysia. According to the Australian Timber Importers Federation, small quantities of sawn timber mouldings and dowels are imported from Sarawak-but that State is not a supplier of any significance and the great bulk of Australia's imports are from the peninsula of Malaysia, which, according to the International Institute for Environment and Development, has the most complete theoretical system of operational management in South East Asia. Of our timber imports, 14 per cent comes from Taiwan, 11 per cent from Singapore, 9 per cent from Indonesia and 6 per cent from the Philippines.

While I am talking about 54 per cent of our timber imports coming from Malaysia, let me point out to the Democrats-and I think it is important to take this into consideration-that the Malaysian Government is very sensitive about suggestions of import bans. Interviewed in August last year, the Malaysian High Commissioner to Australia described allegations of cultural genocide and being a hooligan government-which statements, of course, have come from some elements of Australian conservationists-as very offensive.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is accurate, though.

—That is an interesting comment by Senator Coulter. He said that that is an accurate description of Malaysia. I might add that the High Commissioner found that very offensive. While conceding that there were what he described as law and order issues with the Penan people, the High Commissioner pointedly referred to Australia's treatment of its Aboriginal population and to forest disputes in New South Wales, Tasmania and Fraser Island. He concluded that, even though the Malaysians knew that Australia developed its farms and orchards from raping its rainforests earlier in its history, it is not an issue for Malaysia to ban Australian apples, meat or dairy products as Australia would like to do with Malaysia's timber.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, we have had headlines in the paper saying that Malaysia has decided to downgrade ties with Australia. The Malaysian Cabinet has decided to suspend all non-essential cooperative projects with Australia. The Malaysian Prime Minister has also proposed a regional trade bloc which would exclude Australia. And here we have the Democrats suggesting that we now hurt those people further, suggesting that we no longer accept their timber.

I am not sure what the Democrats want to do. I do not think that they do either. Do they want to ban all rainforest timber? In the second reading speech, Senator Coulter said that the import ban was the focus of this Bill. Is it a total import ban? The Democrats say that they want to ban only logs, sawn timber, veneers or plywood made from tropical forest species listed in this Bill. Other wood products, such as mouldings, window frames, doors and furniture, will still be able to be imported without restrictions. The reason given for this exemption is administrative difficulties in identifying species in the source areas within the particular country of the wood used in the products. The Democrats want only logs, sawn timber, veneers and plywood made from tropical forest species to be banned.

Proposed new subsection 50a (3) in clause 3 of the Bill-that is the most important part-states the conditions under which the Minister can use a licence to import tropical forest timbers. The wood must satisfy all the conditions listed. The conditions state that the wood must be identified as coming from a specific area of the country of origin. The wood must come from either plantations or secondary regrowth forests. How on earth will that be policed?

They say that substantial areas of the forest from which the wood is taken must be adequately protected in secure parks and reserves. I will come back to the stupidity of this in just a moment. They go on to say that the owners and the inhabitants of the forests must approve the felling of the trees. They say that the felling of the trees cannot threaten the integrity of the forest or the ability of the forest to support the traditional inhabitants.

Let me go through those again. The Democrats say that the wood must be identified as coming from a specific area of the country of origin. How are they going to police that? There is no suggestion in their Bill as to how they would police that. They say that the wood must come either from plantations or from secondary regrowth forests. In what way will they be able to establish whether it comes from a primary forest or a regrowth forest? Nothing in the Bill tells us how they intend to do it. They say `substantial areas'. That is good legislation, is it not? What are substantial areas? What does Senator Coulter mean by `substantial'? I am not asking the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins); I am just wondering what on earth the Democrats could possibly mean by `substantial', because there is no indication in their Bill as to what it means.

The Bill goes on to even more ridiculous stuff, saying that the owners and the inhabitants of the forests must approve of the felling of trees, and that the felling of the trees must not threaten the integrity of the forest or the ability of the forest to support the traditional inhabitants. Of course, the fact that the inhabitants could be forced out of the area before the logging was to commence so that their approval for the logging would not be necessary, and the fact that after it was logged there would be no inhabitants anyway, so the forest would not have to support any inhabitants, does not enter their minds. It is just unbelievable nonsense. As I say, I do not believe for one moment that this supposed legislation could ever have been taken seriously. There is nothing in the Democrats' legislation to say how they intend to police this logging.

If we did set the example, if we were good citizens of the world, if we decided to stop the importation of all rainforest timbers, and even if Japan and the other countries that import rainforest timbers joined us, what proof have we that this would stop the felling of the rainforests? We have none at all. Would they be cleared for agriculture?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—Senator Coulter says no. As far as I am concerned he is the only one in the world who has said no. Most people say-indeed, Coopers and Lybrand say-that that is the most important and largest purpose of clearing these forests. We have underdeveloped countries with growing populations, and Senator Coulter is expecting those forests to maintain their original inhabitants without any expansion. Senator Coulter says that he is right and, of course, Coopers and Lybrand-who are perhaps a little more reliable-say that they believe the main cause of tropical deforestation is the shifting of agriculture and formal development of programs, certainly not logging.

SPEECH.PARA: The report also says that there is no justification for the introduction of supply restrictions of any kind. The options it mentions include encouraging substitutions through research and development; consumer education; improved efficiency in the use of timber; aid-related initiatives such as assisting in forest management; establishment of other forest industries in source countries; improved production from already cleared land; and international lobbying with source countries, other importing countries, international agencies and through the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to improve market access for products from developing countries.
