I agree with that entirely.

It is not that the world has no concerns about the depleting rainforests, but they are largely publicly owned forests and almost wholly located in developing countries with rapidly rising populations. These countries have widespread poverty and high levels of foreign debt. We have the Democrats here saying that we should add to those problems by refusing their exports. It is all very well living in this magnificent country, with the security that we have here and with no starvation, to tell them that they must not make use of their resources, that they must not expand, that they must not clear for agriculture and that they have to stay in their native forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who are `they'? Coopers and Lybrand?

—No, that is what the Democrats are saying. It is all very well for the Democrats to tell these developing countries what they must do and that in return we will give them $60m a year in aid and to say that, if we do that, other Organisation for Economic Co- operation and Development countries will build up a rainforest protection fund of several billion dollars. What absolute rubbish! Nobody has suggested that that would or could occur, yet the Democrats are willing to deal a death blow, if you like, to the very poor in these countries.

SPEECH.PARA: These developing countries cannot possibly afford to withdraw their timbers from the market. It is up to Australia to help them with forest management so that these timbers can be an ongoing source of income. The fact that a low level of selective timber harvesting is possible and would add to the productive value of the forest is terribly important. Unlike some of the other products of the forests, such as nuts and latex trees, which are more subsistent in nature, timber is a cash crop. If the world price of rainforest timber were more realistic, then timber products could form an important and essential part of a sustainable rainforest economy.

In the countries that we are talking about it cannot be forgotten that the problem of shifting agriculture will not go away, and that stopping logging will not save the major source of deforestation. The Democrats have to understand that if we stop importing these timbers it will not make one jot of difference to the deforestation of the rainforests in these underdeveloped countries. If these people cannot make money out of the rainforest timber, they will just slash and burn it to make money by growing food through agriculture. We have to make these rain- forests productive for them, and the only way we can do that is to send teams to teach management of those forests-and with that I would agree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to be able in speak in support of the Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990 this evening, in a week that has already seen some significant developments concerning forest management. On Tuesday we had a disastrous decision to commit Australian native forests to woodchipping, despite the strong economic and environmental arguments against that use, and despite the absolutely stated position of all environment groups in Australia that they were totally opposed to that happening through the resource security legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: On Wednesday there was a much healthier sign for Australia when the Rainforest Information Centre released the Australian Rainforest Memorandum, a document I strongly recommend that all honourable senators read for a thorough discussion of the reasons why Australia has a responsibility to act now to protect the world's remaining rainforests. The central premise of the Rainforest Memorandum is that the best way a country can contribute to the protection of rainforests is by examining its own actions. For Australia, this means both protecting our own rainforests-what is left of them and ensuring that no action taken by Australia, be it under the guise of aid or trade, should contribute to the destruction of rainforests in other parts of the world.

I want to remind honourable senators for a moment of the bipartisan support this morning in this chamber when the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill 1991 was debated. I remarked then that it was refreshing to hear an issue debated purely on its merits rather than on party lines, although some party debate did come into it in one or two of the contributions. I hope that honourable senators will accept rainforest protection as worthy of similar support.

Even if it does not get that kind of bipartisan support in this chamber, I think it is highly commendable that Senator Coulter and his office workers have managed to gather the signatures of a record number of 31 members of Federal and State parliaments who are supporting this call for a ban on the import of rainforest timbers. It is very interesting that there is a long list of 31 members of Federal and State parliaments including Australian Democrats, Greens and Independents.

I am very pleased to see that I have been joined in the West Australian list by Dr Ian Alexander, who recently resigned from the Labor Party-he was the member for Perth; Ms Pam Buchanan, Independent member for Ashburton, who also recently resigned from the Labor Party in Western Australia; and Mr Ian Thompson, who resigned some time ago from the Liberal Party and is now an Independent member for the Darling Range. So there is some sense amongst the Independents who have been disaffected with the major parties on environmental and other issues such as social justice issues, the issue of our participation in the Gulf war, the way decisions are made in the larger parties and so on.

It is a very interesting group and I commend Senator Coulter and his staff for getting the support of all those people around the country. It will probably not be the first time that there will be concerted effort on the part of non major party representatives at State and Federal level to work together on important issues of national and international significance. Indeed, in many ways, the need for action to stop the destruction of rainforests is of even more urgency than the issue I mentioned this morning, which was the protection of Antarctica. That is because, as the Rainforest Memorandum points out, the continuation of the present level of deforestation will result in the total destruction of the world's tropical rain- forests within 30 years. This is a fact which should be raising alarm right around the world.

We may see the end of an entire forest type within our lifetime and that should be cause for extreme concern. Without concerted effort from all countries, our grandchildren could grow up in a world without tropical rainforests, and I certainly would not want to see that happen. I am sure that even if Senator Walters thought about it in those terms she would not want to see that either.

There have been efforts through various international programs to stop, or at least slow down, the rate of rainforest destruction but the results have been disappointing. Part of the reason for that is the complexity of the issue. But the sad fact of many of these programs is that they are developed without sufficient participation of the indigenous communities or the relevant non-government organisations. Of course, there is a great deal of power in non-government organisations not only in Australia but also in many countries.

As in Australia, decisions on natural resource use are more likely to be acceptable if they are made in an open manner with adequate opportunities for the involvement of such community organisations. I totally agree with Senator Coulter's comments in his speech on the second reading of this Bill that the restriction of rainforest timber imports is only one part of a comprehensive strategy which is needed. It is, however, a vital part of the action that Australia can and should take.

The Coopers and Lybrand report, which has been mentioned previously by Senator Walters this evening and on previous occasions in this chamber, has been used to deny the effectiveness of an import ban. The report lends support to the need for wider action. But that cannot be used as an excuse to avoid taking the relatively simple action of adopting this Bill as an affirmation of Australia's intent to see the destruction of the world's rainforests stopped. The scale and urgency of the problem is too great for direct and immediate action not to be necessary.

I referred previously to the complexity of the problem of rainforest destruction. Somewhere between 50 and 90 per cent of all plant and animal species may be present in tropical rainforests, as Senator Bourne earlier alluded to, and are therefore at risk of extinction if we keep going at the same rate of destruction that is currently under way. The loss of rain- forests means an incalculable loss of genetic resources and other non-timber forest materials. This increases the gravity of the issue. The role of rainforest global climatic cycles is not yet fully understood, but there is already worrying evidence that climatic disturbances in Brazil and in the Ivory Coast may be related to massive deforestation.

Here I must comment on something Senator Walters just said. I was about to write down her classic quote which she gave us at the end of her speech when suddenly it was my turn. But she said something like, `The countries of the world that we are trying to ban these imports from need the rainforest timbers and if they cannot sell their timber resources then they will clear the forests for agricultural purposes'. Even if they do that-as has happened very widely in a country like Brazil-it has been clearly demonstrated that the soil on which rainforest timbers thrive is not suitable for agriculture. For one or two years there may be satisfactory cropping or there may be satisfactory grazing for cattle, which feed the hamburger market of North America and countries like Australia as well, but all too soon the soil which previously housed and nurtured the tropical rainforests is useless for agriculture. That has been demonstrated over and over again and so that is not a suitable argument to use in this debate.

I want to turn to the Australian Rainforest Memorandum which was launched just this Wednesday. It is important to note that there are other uses on a sustainable level which can be much more useful to the global community than chopping down the timbers, because that is tantamount to mining. Once one has chopped down the rainforest timbers there is nothing there to get another time. But if we use a tropical rainforest in a sustainable way, then there is an ongoing constant yield and that is what I think we should be looking towards. I want to quote from this Rainforest Memorandum:

. . . the governments of most tropical countries do not even gather information on the sustainable economic potential of non-timber rainforest products . . . In the Amazon Basin the livelihood of over two million people is based on the collection of rubber, Brazil nuts and other ``minor'' forest products. These people are able to gain their livelihood without damaging the biological integrity and genetic wealth of the rainforest ecosystems . . . Recent studies have shown that the value of non-timber forest products often far exceeds the value of timber in tropical forests.

That is a most important point; the renewable resources which can be harvested by the indigenous people in the rainforest are actually of greater economic benefit to the countries involved than chopping down the trees-which is a one-off exploitative action. The memorandum continues:

A study in the rainforests in Peru showed that the economic value of the minor forest products including fruits, resins and medicines which were actually being marketed, exceeded the economic value of using the forest for timber by nine to one.

Now that is a very significant figure and I think that the importance of that should not be lost on people who seem to be bent on opposing this legislation. On economic grounds alone there are very good reasons for countries being encouraged to use the renewable resources that the rainforests so generously provide rather than chopping down the trees.

Also, it is important to note that intact primary rainforests have considerable and lasting economic potential as a storehouse of high value drugs useful in modern medicine. A lot of this is still an unknown quantity. A great deal of research is still to be done on the medical benefits to be derived from tropical rain forests.

The economic benefits from the genetic material in rainforests have also been left out of the cost benefit analyses of development projects affecting rainforest areas. The extinction of a single plant species with genes that could be used in an agricultural crop may well represent a loss of billions of dollars. But we do not know enough about that yet. So that is why there is a plea to stop the cutting down of tropical rainforests while further research is undertaken.

The negative effects and poor long term prospects of industrial development in tropical forests make the complete protection of the remaining primary rainforest imperative from an economic as well as an ecological point of view. Exceptions should only be allowed for traditionally established sustainable methods of utilisation or for uses which empirical scientific studies have proved beyond doubt to be ecologically sound. These options exclude widespread forestry practices and other forms of intensive exploitation. We have to remember those final two words, `intensive exploitation' because that is what it amounts to-the mining of the forests.

It is the effect of rainforest destruction on indigenous communities that increases the urgency for this Bill to be passed, and in that sense we have a moral obligation to take action now. The argument has been advanced from time to time that banning the import of rainforest timbers will only put economic hardship on those communities, as Senator Walters alluded to, but I do not think she did it very logically, and certainly it was not convincing to me.

The reality is that in many rainforest areas logging is the start of a process of dispossession of the indigenous people. Logging of tropical rainforests is too often the cause of further iniquities in land and wealth distribution both within and between countries. It seldom seems to have any effect in alleviating poverty but instead contributes to social disruption and, ultimately, the loss of entire cultures.

I want to give the example of the Penan tribespeople of Sarawak. The tribal wisdom of the Penan people is about to be lost to the world for ever unless the logging stops in their traditional rainforest home. It is not only the source of their food and every aspect of their livelihood but it is also the source of their spiritual integrity.

It is really sad to hear people from the Penan, as we were privileged to do last year when some members of that fast disintegrating tribe came to Australia to make a plea to Australians not to buy rainforest timbers. They said, `Chop out the market rather than chop down the trees'. They told very, very sad stories about the disintegration of their tribal life and about the fact that they were losing their tribal homes, which have been theirs for countless generations. How can we consider doing that in this relatively enlightened time towards the end of the twentieth century?

I know that we have just had the most ghastly example of unenlightenment in the Gulf war. Perhaps I should not even use that terminology. But we should know better at this stage of human development than to allow one of the last remaining tribal people to disappear from the face of the earth. I make an impassioned plea that we stop the importation of rainforest timbers because the Penan tribespeople are at risk of disappearing altogether from the face of planet earth or becoming spiritually deadened, even though physically some of them may be left. There are only 60 families left at the moment living according to their tribal culture; a mere 60 families. So it is very close to the end point for the Penan tribespeople, and their forest is being logged 24 hours a day-ruthless destruction of their habitat. If we allow that to happen in the latter part of the twentieth century, all the predictions of doom that have been suggested for people as an endangered species on planet earth will probably come to fruition.

We do not deserve to survive as a species-the rest of us who exploit in that way-if we allow the destruction of these tribal people, whose wisdom we should appreciate, whose wisdom we should respect, and whose age-old customs we should respect and revere as much as we possibly can, to go ahead just because we like their rainforest timbers. If we allow that, there is no doubt that the human species in general will be on the endangered species list itself. That is not a very comfortable place to be but that is where we would deserve to be if we allowed the destruction of the Penan people's habitat to continue at the rate that it is going at the moment, so that within 10 years they will be culturally and spiritually dead. That is a very, very serious responsibility for countries like Australia to think about very carefully.

This Bill does in fact allow the importation of rainforest timbers under licence if certain conditions are met and wisely avoids using the criterion of so-called sustainable logging. The term `sustainable yield' has become as misused as the forest to which it is supposed to refer. A World Bank consultant is quoted in the Rain- forest Memorandum as saying that:

No commercial logging of tropical forests has proven to be sustainable from the standpoint of the forest ecosystem, and any such logging must be recognised as mining, not sustaining the basic resource.

The state of knowledge on tropical forest ecology and silviculture is not adequate to allow any empirical claims as to the sustainability of tropical forest logging operations. Despite this, and the acknowledgment by the International Tropical Timber Organisation that serious attempts at sustainable management are being made on less than 0.125 per cent of the rainforest area currently logged, there are still claims made to justify development assistance on the grounds that it is directed to sustainable forestry operations. How people come to that conclusion is beyond me. The Government's policy on rainforests states that:
Australia's future timber needs should be met without placing at risk the long term conservation of the rainforest resources of other countries.

That is commendable. It assumes that tropical rainforests can be managed and logged on an ecologically sustainable basis which, as I demonstrated, is not possible. As yet, there does not appear to be evidence to support the possibility of ecologically sustainable logging of rainforest timbers.

The role of development assistance is crucial in the protection of the world's rainforests and the populations of people dependent on them, and it is increasingly recognised that the direction of aid to environmental projects and the assessment of the environmental impacts of all development projects is essential. The findings of the Senate Inquiry on the Environmental Impact on Australian Development Assistance are yet to be fully addressed by the Government. But I look forward to the response to that report.

I recommend again to senators that they read carefully the Australian Rainforest Memorandum and note the deplorable record of some Australian companies operating in the Asia-Pacific area. There are far too many examples of projects which have had devastating effects on the landscapes and the lifestyles of the people of the region. This morning during the debate on the Antarctic Mining Prohibition Bill I applauded the inclusion of clauses to prevent the involvement of Australian corporations in mining activities in any part of Antarctica. Reading the list of disastrous projects with which Australian companies are involved in rainforest operations, I am convinced that controls are needed on the activities of Australian companies to ensure that they operate with the same regard to environmental impacts in other counties as they would here in Australia.

I want to quote just a couple of the examples given in this Rainforest Memorandum about Australian operations in other countries, which are most obvious in our region-in Fiji, Papua New Guinea and Indonesia. The memorandum states:
The three largest operations in which there is Australian involvement are the Ok Tedi and Bougainville mines in Papua New Guinea-
although Bougainville has been closed now for two years-
and the Freeport mine in Irian Jaya.

The Ok Tedi mine is located in one of New Guinea's remotest regions, high in the Star Mountains on the banks of the Ok Tedi River. The Ok Tedi flows into the Fly River, Papua New Guinea's major river system. Forty thousand people live beside the banks of the Fly and depend on it for food, water and transportation. BHP is a major shareholder in the consortium which controls this mining operation. Major shareholders in BHP include the Westpac Banking Corporation--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!
—Yes, again-

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government Insurance Office of New South Wales and the National Mutual Life Association.

I visited Ok Tedi just two weeks ago as part of the parliamentary delegation visiting Papua New Guinea. It was a very interesting visit, too. I was personally quite shocked at the amount of devastation which was there before us: a whole mountain had disappeared. The only Papua New Guinea person with us at that time to see this felt the same as I felt. He commented to me, `I bet the people here didn't know, if they were told about it in advance, that a whole mountain would disappear'. It has been gouged now right down to below ground level.

At this operation, 100,000 tonnes of waste a day are moved, most of which-78,000 tonnes a day-goes into the river. It is a very disturbing operation, to say the least. Sixty-six million tonnes of sludge goes into the river per year. Thirty-five million tonnes get to the Fly River mouth, a long way downstream, the rest of it being deposited on the way. The company was keen to point out that it did not affect fishing, but that is really debatable.

In January 1984 a tailings dam which was being constructed was interrupted by a landslide. The cost of building a tailings dam would be $US44m. So it is not being built. There just is not a tailings dam. So all the tailings go down the river, to the extent of 78,000 tonnes per day, taking with them whatever is left after the processing has been done.

It is interesting that the company said that it takes three weeks for the sediment to travel downstream; that there is a massive amount of fine mud at the mouth of the Fly which is coagulating at the river mouth; and that the dilution effect will get rid of a lot of the mud which comes down the river but that there is a collection of the copper at the base of this mud deposit. It is estimated that the mud will hold the copper deposits there for 100 years. How on earth the company comes to that conclusion, I do not know; but that is what it said. It said that, despite the fact that there are five-metre tides twice daily and a high water velocity, the mud would hold the copper sediments right there, so that we in Australia need not worry about the contamination of the Coral Sea with copper leftovers. That is another aspect of it. Apart from that, of course, the destruction of the rainforest timbers has gone into that.

There are many other examples in this rainforest memorandum of Australian companies not being careful about the environment of the countries in which they are operating-for massive profits. That is really where I think there is a big difference between the kind of argument that Senator Walters presented to the chamber and what is being said on the other side of the debate, where people are genuinely concerned about the protection of this resource for future generations. We are not interested in cash cropping the rainforest timbers. We are not interested in quick bucks being made out of a resource which is not renewable.

I will briefly mention rainforest management in Australia. I appreciate that the World Heritage listing of the Queensland wet tropical rainforests has greatly improved the prospects for the survival of those forests, although pressures continue through demands for tourism and mining and, of course, a space port proposal.

I had never actually been to the northern Queensland tropical rainforests until a week or so back, but it was quite an illuminating experience. The rainforests have often been called the womb of life. In the rainforest one can actually hear and feel the vibrancy and the pulsating of the rainforest. It would be a very sad thing if we were actually prepared to mine the rainforests of other countries. It is important that we hang on to what little we have left in Australia, but we must not deprive other countries of their resource, which is, of course, a global resource in terms of cleaning up the atmosphere.

I think it is very interesting that in Victoria temperate rainforests are being logged in contravention of the State conservation strategy because of the overcommitment of the timber resource when long term timber licences were granted. It is interesting that the Victorian Government can say that the resource security legislation did not have an impact on it. The Western Australian Government can claim that, too. But, of course, what has happened is that, because of the overcommitment of timber resource in the past, we are actually logging the remaining bit of temperate rainforest in Victoria. I think that is a crime against future generations. As I said, the same thing is likely to happen in Western Australia, where there is already protection for the timber industry. In Western Australia, there are small patches of rainforest in the Kimberley region, where new species of plants are still being discovered. The rainforest fragments are only one of the many environmental and cultural treasures in the Kimberley region and lend weight to the call for the Kimberley wilderness to be recognised and fully protected.

To come back to one of the comments that Senator Walters made, I agree with her that we cannot really tell other countries what to do with their resources. I had a very signal lesson on this when I went to see the Brazilian Ambassador a couple of years ago and talked to him about the debt for nature idea: to relieve some of the developing countries of their huge international debt, maybe other countries could help by buying some of the rainforest to ensure its preservation for future generations. He told me very politely to go away, which is fair enough. Neither should we tell other countries what to do with their resources. But they have been under enormous pressure in the past to finance their crippling debt repayments. The World Bank has put enormous pressure on them, but now the World Bank, thank goodness, seems to be changing its tune. The World Bank project, global environmental facility (GEF), is one where the World Bank has joined two United Nations agencies in a three-year pilot program which will help ease the pressure which developing countries are placing on the global ecosystem, in particular by chopping down their rainforests. I quote from AM this morning on the ABC:
The GEF is to be funded by contributions from participating nations, but despite our attendance at a funding meeting last November, Australia is yet to commit itself to the project.
The presenter, Peter Thompson, went on to report from Washington-an interview with Matt Peacock:
. . . Australia's reticence has already dented our reputation as a green conscious nation.

So what has happened this week in this place over resource security legislation is matched by what we are doing internationally. We are not coming up with the goods. When a question was asked by Senator Bourne of the Minister this afternoon about that, he said, `Oh well, we can't keep paying for everything'. But Australia has international responsibilities. We are now unlikely to be invited to the first GEF meeting in six weeks time. I think that Australia, in that respect, is opting out of its international responsibilities. I hope that it does not opt out of its international responsibilities as far as banning the importation of rainforest timbers is concerned, in support of Senator Coulter's Bill.

I would like to end by commending the rainforest action groups around Australia, which have undertaken non-violent direct action to highlight the fact that rainforest timbers are constantly coming into Australia through our ports. Their very brave and pointed actions are educating the public to try to change consumer habits. They are also educating timber companies about alternatives to rainforest timbers. That is highly commendable, because there are alternatives; we do not have to use rainforest timbers in the way that they are being used at the moment.

So there is an argument that the market economy should work. We need to educate people about alternatives so that they do not actually demand rainforest products, and so we actually show the countries from whom we buy at the moment that there is not a ready market. As well as that educative process in the community, we need a little legislative help. That is where this Bill is very important. We need education in the community plus legislation, and then there will not be a market for the rainforest timbers. The countries which at the moment exploit rainforest timbers might be encouraged to use the renewable resources in their rainforest timbers to make the money that they so urgently need. We have to stop mining the rainforests. It is the exploitative mentality which is really expressed in the `nothing left' option. The alternative is to allow wise use of rainforests in the truly renewable sense of the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Destruction of tropical rainforests is a major global ecological problem calling for urgent action. If action is not taken now, the world will continue to lose a resource of immense value at an alarming rate. Clearly, action must be taken. The question is: what is the most appropriate and responsible action that can be taken by Australia?

SPEECH.PARA: The approach embodied in the Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill is fundamentally mistaken. If adopted, it would not contribute at all to a reduction in the loss of tropical rainforest. In fact, it would be counterproductive because it ignores the international political realities within which we must operate. Successful action to arrest tropical forest loss can be made only in cooperation with the governments in developing countries which are responsible for the forests. In the face of criticism that this legislation will barely create a ripple in the waters of international trade in tropical timber, the Australian Democrats have singled out the example of Malaysia where, according to Senator Coulter's second reading speech:
. . . the impact . . . would be significant enough to be noticed.

Curiously, Senator Coulter appears to see a move to damage the balance of trade for one of our near neighbours as some sort of a victory. In reality, the mere fact that the Bill is up for debate in this Parliament has put pressure on our very sensitive relationships with Malaysia, and while Senator Coulter and the Democrats no doubt gain some satisfaction out of knowing that something they have done might make one overseas country sit up and take notice, the vast majority of developing countries to which this Bill will apply in practice will hardly notice in terms of lost trade, but they will be justified in criticising a country which prides itself on a commitment to free trade.

It goes to show that the Democrats do not give these countries credit for having the nous to recognise that it is in their own interests to manage the timber resources in a sustainable way. That we need to do it for them by imposing bans-what an absolute insult to these countries, and what a shocking way for any political party in Australia to try to dabble in foreign relations. I can only think that Senator Coulter has absolutely no conception of the conditions in most developing countries which the proposed changes to the Customs Act would affect, and no idea about the resolve in many of the governments concerned to develop proper forest management techniques. One then might ask why the Democrats bothered with the political stunt of introducing this Bill. I suppose we have only to read this morning's newspapers to understand why the Democrats have to resort to these sorts of stunts. The Sydney Morning Herald today leads with a headline that says, `Angry Greens plan new political party'. Peter Garret tonight on the 7.30 Report said the same thing. The Democrats are petrified that a new political party might arise and take from them the measly 7 per cent of the vote which they still hold.

People laughed at me a few months ago when I reported that Senator Vallentine and the Tasmanian Greens were getting together to work out some way to take over the Democrats. They have obviously realised the Democrats are a spent force anyhow and do not want to take them over; they are going to form their own party. Can honourable senators imagine what a new Green party would do to this mob over here? Their 7 per cent vote-which has fallen from 14 per cent at the election-would disappear completely and they would be out of a job. Would that not be a great thing for Australia, and a great thing for Australia's foreign relations? That is what the stunt is all about. The Democrats are trying to recover some lost ground. They thought they were doing well in the Gulf war, but then realised that 66 2/3 of their supporters did not support them, so they are trying to claw back at anything they can- hence the stunt of this sort of rubbishing legislation.

Just over a month ago I spent some time travelling in Indonesia as part of a parliamentary delegation. From what I saw there, I have no doubt that Indonesia has already made some significant steps towards improvement and plans to do much more in the years to come. The changes it has made, and continues to make, aim to reduce the amount of timber felled while increasing export revenue for the people of Indonesia. Three years ago, the Indonesian Government banned the export of round logs, a move which led to significant reductions in logging while maintaining the same financial return to the country. It has more recently imposed a tax on sawn timber, which has led to an increase in the value added timber industries and to reduced timber loss while maintaining income levels. Indonesia has also banned the export of unprocessed rattan cane, again to encourage value added industries and to prevent wholesale destruction of the resource.

I put it to the Democrats that countries such as Indonesia know the value of tropical forests as a resource and want to maintain it for the interests of future generations. Furthermore, governments of these countries know their own backyards far better than we do, and are far better qualified to know what measures to improve forest management are appropriate. We should be encouraging them to do this by working with them, not trying to isolate them. It is no good the developed world lecturing or threatening less developed countries when such actions would have major economic implications for those countries, unless they are prepared to address those consequences. It might make some Australians feel good if their country were to ban imports, but the results on the ground would almost certainly be counterproductive.

What these countries desperately need is forest management technology. I cannot think of any other country in the world better suited to help in this area. Our foresters and scientists, in this area of tropical timber in particular, are second to none in the world. I have had some dealing with our foresters. Last weekend I was on Fraser Island talking to the foresters. I am aware of the timber industry in Ravenshoe, and have been for some time. Those people are dedicated professionals. They know what they are doing. They are university trained, most of them at the Australian National University. They are young, dedicated people who have a real feeling and a concern for the forests that I suspect the Democrats and Senator Vallentine would not know about, would not understand and would not care about.

I was interested to hear Senator Vallentine say she had been up to the northern tropical rainforest. She would not answer my interjection to tell me where she was, but I would guarantee that any of the rainforests that Senator Vallentine was able to get into-and which she marvels about and says are magnificent-are the forests that have been logged for 100 years. Yet people such as Senator Vallentine, and anyone else who might go to see them, will walk through them and say, `Aren't these forests magnificent? Aren't they virginal? Aren't they pristine?'. Yet they are forests that have been logged for 100 years under sensible forest management plans. That is what is needed. In addition, I have spoken with the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation people in Ravenshoe, who understand timber and have some real knowledge about it. They, as well as the Queensland forestry service, are dedicated professionals who have an expertise and learning which would be of immense benefit to the countries to our near north.

We are already involved in the area of forest management in many places. I had the privilege to be in West Timor recently and heard of the plantation projects already under way there in which Australia has been involved. That is being done to help prevent the slash and burn agriculture. We could be doing much more in this area and a concerted assistance to the operation of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) to Indonesia and other countries would be a good point on which to begin. Such cooperation must be based on the premise that it is in the best interests of the developing countries concerned to manage their forests much better than they have in the past. The tropical forests are a valuable resource which can yield a wide range of potential long term benefits to developing countries.

Sometimes this may involve conversion of forests from their pristine state to secondary regrowth, with some loss of biodiversity within defined areas. At other times it may involve very selective logging or harvesting of forest products without logging. The preservation of these resources and their management under conditions of sustainable development are clearly in the interests of the developing countries themselves. It is not clear from what Senator Coulter has said that he accepts this or accepts that the utilisation of timber from the tropical forests has a legitimate place in the range of conditions under which forests are managed and preserved. We should accept that governments of these countries by and large accept the need to improve their management practices, but they are unable to achieve these improvements overnight for the very reason that they are developing countries with limited infrastructure and shortages of key skilled personnel.

Given the institutional deficiencies in the developing countries, the certification process required under this legislation proposed by Senator Coulter is totally unrealistic. It is by no means a simple matter of imposing bans and tough penalties in these countries. The forests are too extensive and mostly in remote locations, institutions are generally too weak and logging is only one of a range of threats facing the forests. Shifting cultivation is a more serious threat than logging and plantations, and pastoral activities have also claimed many rainforests.

Senator Coulter quotes statistics from Sarawak about losses of forests to slash and burn agriculture, but fails to recognise that loss of secondary forests and prevention of regrowth is also a loss of a resource. It may make more sense to ban the importation of beef produced on cleared rainforest, or chocolate produced from cocoa from cleared rainforest or starch produced from casaba, or paper from kenaf and so on. If the market for timber products were severely reduced or disappeared altogether in these countries, the likelihood is that the land uses, such as clearing for agriculture spurred by poverty and population pressures-the major cause of deforestation in tropical countries-would result in even greater forest loss. Senator Coulter should think about that. His simplistic solution to these things shows a narrowness of foresight that is typical of him and his Party.

Only a complex framework of licensing, with incentives to balance utilisation and conservation properly framed, can provide the regulation needed to manage the forests in accordance with the principles of sustainable development. This is no easy task and must take account of the resources and needs of local communities if it is to be implemented. Experience with the total ban on ivory, which was much more uniformly implemented in developed countries than any ban on tropical forest products could ever be, suggests that the lack of incentive to manage a resource for long term benefit can lead to its total destruction. The honourable senator should think about that, too.

What is called for is one of the most complex processes of institution building facing many developing countries. It must simultaneously tackle a wide variety of forest problems-natural forest management, plantation forests, utilisation of forest products-while at the same time dealing with a variety of related agricultural issues. Governments in developing countries need to have access to, amongst other things, proper inventories of their resources. Without this, plans cannot be prepared to optimise the benefits achieved from forest products while ensuring the resources are not degraded.

Without a proper planning base, governments cannot enact regulations cap- able of being enforced. There are also urgent needs for systems of monitoring compliance, including the provision of staff with appropriate training and skills and, no less urgently, a need for communities to be educated about the resources they use. These needs call for large scale investment of resources, including substantial transfers of skills from developed countries.

Australia has the technical capacity to contribute a great deal more than we have thus far. Australian technology in remote sensing, for example, is highly developed and could play a major part in assisting developing countries to manage their resources in accordance with the principles of sustainable development. Scientific expertise available in Australia can also play a part advancing the ability of developing countries' institutions to better manage their forest resources.

Developed countries, as major consumers of value added products from tropical forests that generate substantial tax revenues, have both an obligation to contribute to the improvement of management practices in the tropical forests of the developing world and the technology to enable developing countries to make such improvements. This can only be achieved, however, by working closely with developing countries, accepting that they genuinely want to maintain their forest resources-for reasons of self-interest as much as anything else-and recognising that bans and restrictions would only harm our ability to do something constructive in cooperation with the governments of developing countries in the region. How can one cooperate and give the assistance wanted when one insults these countries by even suggesting legislation as ridiculous as this?

Developing countries should, of course, contribute greater resources themselves. In many cases, the collection of revenues from timber products is less than it should be. There is often widespread avoidance of payment of taxes and fees, which calls for an increased institutional capacity in order to minimise such avoidance. If this can be done, developing countries will be able to afford to allocate far greater resources to forest management. We should also be aware that the fact that timber is generally exported as logs or sawn timber, rather than products with substantial value added, reduces the opportunities for tax collection in developing countries. Such opportunities are passed to the developed country consumers.

As a global problem, tropical forest management calls for global solutions. Unilateral bans or restrictions by Australia fail to see these problems in a global context and, as I said, are a narrow minded attempt to do something warm about the problem. What is called for is a global approach such as the tropical forest action plan program being carried out by the FAO.

This program provides a common framework for assessing programs needed in each country to end the waste and destruction of tropical forests and allows developed countries to provide assistance in support of such programs. This is a constructive and practical way in which Australia can do something to halt the destruction of tropical forests. Conversely, if we adopt a course of imposing bans we will be ignored by developing countries and miss the opportunity to make a contribution that only Australia, a developed country with a substantial tropical forestry resource, can make.

It is interesting, I might say, to note that in this particular debate the Government has not bothered to even list a speaker on the speakers' list. One wonders why the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has not done so. It could be that none of its members could keep a straight face when they read some of the ridiculous provisions of this Bill. Maybe that is the reason why they are not speaking on it. It could be, however, that they are not wanting to offend the greens. In this week they have done enough offending of the greens to turn them away forever. I suppose the Government is trying, a bit like the Democrats, to retrieve something out of the fiasco of this week and is not wanting to speak, and hopefully in a neutral way it will not--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was like the fiasco of the Democrats on the Gulf war.

—The Gulf war. Hopefully in this way the Government will not offend the greens any more. Perhaps that is what the Government is doing. The third reason why ALP members are not talking on this could be, of course, that they are all out in the back room, all the factions, trying to work out some sort of approach to this Bill. The different factions of the ALP would all have different thoughts on it and I guess some of the loony left of the ALP would be over there with their fourth wing mates in wanting to support it. It is probably that all the ALP people are out trying to sort out which factional approach they should take to this particular action. Whatever those reasons, whether it is because it is crazy stuff and they cannot keep a straight face, whether it is because they do not want to offend the greens or whether it is because their factions do not know quite which faction to support in this particular matter, it is of some regret, I would think, that the Government does not have a speaker and apparently is not even going to--
—They should have put Senator Walsh on.

—They should have put Senator Walsh on; he would have had some interesting comments about it. It is a pity that he is not here. It is high time that the Government announced a decision on this matter to remove the concern of Australia's near neighbours about the threats of import bans and to assure them of our desire for some constructive involvement with them, some cooperative involvement with them, to do something about what everyone sees as a very real problem. This is what the Liberal and National parties are advocating, and we would urge that the Government adopt that sort of approach as well.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as that cooperative approach, we should be giving massive assistance to these countries in the techniques of forest management and the ways in which they can protect their forests and deal with them properly. We should be supporting projects to reduce pressures on remaining forests, such as improved production from the already cleared lands, and we should be improving the efficiency of the use of tropical timbers in Australia. These are some positive suggestions, and the main one is cooperative help to the countries to our north. These are some positive ways in which we could help solve this problem, rather than resorting to the type of ridiculousness that this Bill suggests. I urge the Government to support us in rejecting this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In that lengthy meandering, we did not hear anything more than a noisy bag of wind-which is usually a Scottish instrument with a very poor mouthpiece, which usually contributes only a cacophony of useless noise, and does not contribute anything to the progress of human civilisation. It was really only a catalogue of excuses as to why we should do nothing and why we should not care about the rainforests. If Senator Macdonald had any observation powers he would have noticed that, for example, with the preservation of both whales and elephants, the tactic which was adopted-it is the most effective tactic that we can use to preserve unique resources-was that of refusing to buy the products.

SPEECH.PARA: The illustration was given most adequately in the example of elephant tusks. The countries in which the elephants have an origin beg the world not to buy ivory. They even burn the supply to demonstrate how desperate they are to stop the trade. That is the example: do not buy the product; preserve the resource. But Senator Macdonald was not enlightened enough to observe that.

We had some babbling on about Indonesia, assuming what management practices were taking place there. The forest destruction process in that country has been transferred to Irian Jaya. The managed forests which Senator Macdonald assumed were being managed correctly might, eventually, be able to provide products in a sustainable way, but that has not yet been demonstrated and Senator Macdonald's arrogant assumptions will never help that demonstration take place. A similar arrogance was demonstrated by Senator Walters in her confused meanderings and perambulations around the reality which takes place. She quoted Coopers and Lybrand in preference to the people directly involved in the issue. She suggested that because Australia took less than 5 per cent of certain areas that that might be all right; in other words, if somebody else is raping, burning and pillaging, it is all right for us to join in. To suggest that we are helping, as Senator Walters did, native peoples who own rainforests by paying other entrepreneurs to destroy their resource is arrogance and paternalism in the extreme.

Senator Vallentine's figures demonstrated the economic advantages to be gained from taking advantage of the renewable resources which are provided by the rainforests. Such economic advantages can be demonstrated to the people who live in those areas, and such economic advantages should be made available to them. They will not be available if we mine that resource with our international entrepreneurs. Senator Walters also suggested that Malaysia was very sensitive about import bans, that our activities in suggesting that a ban might take place were a little offensive because of what we have done in the past with our forests and what we do now in relation to the Aboriginal people of Australia.

Must we accept the offending products of other countries? Must we buy something simply because, if we do not, the seller might be a bit upset? There is no compulsion to buy things. There is no compulsion to use products of another nation, especially not when substitution with plantation timbers is possible for all the uses to which rainforest timbers are put. This seemed to escape the contributors from the coalition. The Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990, which is before us, really is an open invitation to the Hawke Government to do itself a political favour. It hardly needs pointing out that the Government's environmental stocks have fallen sharply since the last election.

Over the last 11 months we have seen disastrous decisions on the south-eastern forests resource security, a half-hearted commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and a total failure to incorporate sustainability principles in economic policy. Sustainability has been a buzz word which has been mouthed regularly by this Government, but when it comes to applying it to anything so substantial as economic policy, there is a deafening silence. All these failures have a common cause. Had the Government taken the right decision in each case, then significant economic restructuring would have been required. But if the Government were to support this Bill, which would impose selective restrictions on the importation of tropical rainforest timbers, then those problems would not arise. That is because there would not be any major losers in Australia. We could restrict the importation of tropical timbers tomorrow and hardly notice the difference in terms of what products were available.

The major cost to the Australian community would, in fact, arise from the other element of this dual-track strategy; that is, to provide substantial aid to help ecologically sustainable economic alternatives to large scale rainforest logging. That cost would be borne equally by all taxpayers. The Australian Democrats propose that substantial amounts of aid should be offered in the order of $100m to be fully funded by the measures outlined in our alternative Budget proposals for this financial year.

The fact is that there is widespread support in the Australian community for restricting rainforest timber products and very little serious opposition. In a recent newspaper article, which I managed to glean, there was a call by architects for a ceiling on imported goods. Even though it came from a different perspective and that group may have been motivated by different reasons to those which motivates this particular Bill, the call by the Royal Australian Institute of Architects, the Advance Australia Foundation and the Industrial Supplies Office recommended in a joint submission to Senator Button that a content of 90 per cent of Australian materials in new buildings and homes be imposed immediately. The reason that scheme received support from Australia's largest building material manufacturers-BTR Nylex, Boral Ltd and CSR Ltd-was that for every $1m of imported building material, only eight Australians are employed. The Executive Director of the Industrial Supplies Office, Mr Roy Lilley, said that if $1m worth of material were locally produced, 33 Australians would be employed.

There is widespread support for this sort of action throughout the Australian community. It is that widespread support which the Australian Democrats have noticed-contrary to Senator Macdonald's assumptions-and that is what inspires this sort of Bill that has come before us now. The most recent evidence of support comes from the Australian rainforest memorandum which was launched yesterday by the Rainforest Information Centre and the Wilderness Society. It was also endorsed by 36 other organisations including environment groups, development agencies, churches, trade unions and businesses, which together represent some half a million members. Other recent expressions of support for import restrictions have come from a group of prominent actors and artists and from the Local Government Association of New South Wales.

This Bill has won the endorsement of every Democrat and independent member of parliament in the parliaments of this country, with the exception of Senator Harradine. I stress, however, that Senator Harradine has not refused to sign it in endorsement, but is actually listening and bringing his wise deliberations to the debate which is happening now. The 31 parliamentarians who have given their support cover all parliaments of Australia. The Australian campaign to save the world's tropical rainforests is part of a global campaign which is growing daily. Greenpeace's research has found that approximately 1,000 local government authorities in Europe have stopped using tropical timber cut from unsustainable sources and they are recommending that local businesses and individuals do the same. A dozen large city councils, including Berlin and Frankfurt, are also supporting indigenous people's efforts to protect their forests and their cultures- I will emphasise that for Senator Macdonald's benefit-by way of a climate pact that includes measures to limit carbon dioxide emissions.

The Austrian Parliament has declared that imports of unsustainably cut timber will be banned. It is working out ways of implementing that measure. The Netherlands Parliament is due to debate legislation imposing such a ban by 1995 under strict ecological and social definitions of sustainability. The State of Arizona in the United States is reported to have stopped using tropical timbers, as have the federal railways of Germany and Switzerland and the German department of administrative services. So much for the notion that we alone are considering this. So much for the notion that only one vote does not count. Any politician should know that one vote is as important as another.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted by resolution agreed to this day for the consideration of General Business has expired. It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now return to the important discussion of the evening. I was summing up before the dinner recess when we broke to discuss that non-piece of legislation, the Customs (Rainforest Timbers) Amendment Bill, which the Senate has been debating for the last hour and a half. I believe that the Government industry statement represents an undisciplined retreat from the policies that this Government has put in place in the last eight years. It is nothing but that. We were expecting a statement that would get Australia moving again. I am disappointed that the statement will not do that.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very disappointed that Cabinet did not support the submission of the Grains Council of Australia on a one-off cap gross national product of $150 a tonne for wheat at the next harvest. Instead, we got $100m which equates to about $6 per tonne extra in growers' pockets in March for wheat grown last season. Although we are thankful for small mercies, it will not be nearly enough to give wheat growers around Australia the confidence to plant a full crop for next year.

This would have been only a contingent liability over the next three years if the unthinkable happened and we produced another wheat crop sold at low prices. It has been reported in the newspapers that the last wheat sale to Egypt was around $US128 a tonne, which equates roughly to $A170. I believe we are out of the trough. I know that other countries that may wish to buy wheat from Australia in the next few months will have to pay around $US130 a tonne. I believe that, once again, we are climbing out of the trough. If the Government had acceded to this request it would have given growers in the industry confidence to plant. It would have given the banks confidence to lend to the wheat growers. That way we could retain our traditional markets, which we may not be able to hold if we do not grow our normal crop next year.

We must produce our way out of this depression. The only way we can do it is by production. Primary industry can do it if it can get back on an even keel. The mining industry is doing it and has always done it. However, for the mining industry to do that, it needs to have access to resources. I was walking through Members Hall this evening on my way to a meeting on the House of Representatives side of the building when I heard, I think, George Negus lacing Senator Walsh. Which greenie outfit he represents, I do not know. I know that I have criticised Senator Walsh tonight for all the mishmash that he has caused since 1983 in regard to other measures. However, he had the temerity to suggest that mining companies should have access to the resources at Coronation Hill and other such places and George Negus had the temerity to flog Senator Walsh for this view. If we are to produce our way out of this depression, we must have access to those resources.

Of course, there must also be increased productivity on the factory floor, on the waterfront, in transport and all other areas that can help us to become competitive with the rest of the world. That includes the public sector, the people who are on the public payroll. If those people could produce a little more for what they are paid, we would get a lot further in this country.

That is the way we will get out of this recession-or this depression. It is not a recession; it is a depression. It is a long time since it was a recession. It is a full blown depression. It is the biggest depression since 1935 or 1936, or whenever it was. That is the only way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this a history lesson?

—Not the way Senator Faulkner is waving his finger round the chamber. The only way we will get out of this situation is by producing and by getting Australia moving. we will do it that way, not by the mishmash of retractions brought down by the Government in its industry statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate tonight is debating a number of statements by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button and, not to forget, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, under the collective title of Building a Competitive Australia. I wish that we were.

SPEECH.PARA: We welcome one aspect of these statements. Clearly, the Government has now realised that the period when we could use wholesale deregulation and monetary policy to depress the economy as a whole has gone. Now we must rely on specific targeted Government intervention. Very many of the measures contained in these statements, such as the wholesale tax, are indeed welcome. The wholesale tax exemption will now apply to preproduction activities in research, development, engineering and technical design. It will apply also to production related activities such as ordering raw materials and post production activities including storage, handling and dispatch, staff training and others.

Similarly, we welcome the accelerated depreciation for the purpose of upgrading the equipment. This was recommended some time ago by the Australian Manufacturing Council. It has been asked for by the Australian Democrats on numerous occasions. Obviously, we welcome also tax deductibility for environmental impact statements. This is not before time.

TALK.START.PARA: —That will get us out of the trough, won't it?

—If we are going to build a sustainable society and a sustainable economy we must take care not only of our financial profits but also of the long term stock of natural resources. Unless we do we will never build a sustainable economy. I appreciate that Senator Panizza would much prefer to exploit quickly and in the short term rather than build for the future, but I am afraid that will not get us very far.

SPEECH.PARA: In the same vein we support the additional funding that has been allocated to the Export Finance Insurance Corporation. This funding totals $250m. In particular, Australian Democrat support is being extended to the funds being allocated to employers to enable them to maintain apprenticeships and work experience programs.

We note also with interest and approval that the Government is now prepared to extend some sectional assistance to various industries. We note that these particular industry statements do that in the case of the aerospace and information industries. However, we wonder what happened to environmental technology, alternative energy development and the pharmaceutical industry. Clearly, these are industries which would have repaid in ample measure any development investment that the Government might have cared to make to them.

We also note with approval the fact that the Prices Surveillance Authority will be asked to monitor the effect on prices of continuing protection to the extent that the Government is still prepared to extend it. We note that not before time the developing country preferences will be removed from Singapore, Hong Kong, Korea and Taiwan, which are hardly any longer developing countries; they are very much developed countries.

To our regret, many areas in this industry statement ignore the needs of our community, the needs of our economy. The current tax deductibility for research and development of 150 per cent will be reduced to 125 per cent after 1993-hardly the sort of measure we need if we are to become the clever country.

We note the anti-dumping procedures and the promises that the time scales will be reduced; however, we regret that the onus is not reversed after the initial prima facie case is established. I would have thought it was time that we were tougher on those countries that dump their products-produced in conditions which are way below our own in terms of wages, safety conditions at work and environmental protection-and that we protected our own industries much faster, placing the obligation on those countries to prove that they were not dumping and swamping our markets.

Perhaps one of the worst examples of the Government's mistaken strategies in this statement is that it has announced the abolition of the existing higher sales tax rate on luxury cars. We would have gone the other way. We would have included in the higher luxury duty category items similar to high priced luxury cars, such as jewellery and furs. However, the Government has decided that it does not care about the couple of hundred million dollars of additional debt that the import of these high priced cars will bring to us and is more concerned, once again, about the short term implications for revenue.

The fact that there is no equity capital fund for small and medium business is perhaps one of the worst examples of the neglect of our long term strategy in this industry statement. This was one of the forecasts made quite regularly when this statement was being prepared. We read in the media that one insurance company, the AMP, had decided that it would not supply the $100m that the Government expected, and that was sufficient for the Government to abandon the project. Unfortunately, that is not the way to give our small and medium enterprises a chance to participate in the reactivation of our economy. It shows up the failure of specific measures that we need to bolster, in a parallel development, the reduction in tariffs and agricultural subsidies. It should be noted at this particular point that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said:
However much our competitors might bend or break the principles of fair trade, our own self-interest is served by a steadfast refusal to return to the days of protectionism.

In other words, the Prime Minister is saying that, no matter how high the protective tariffs or the subsidies are that the European Community or the United States is prepared to offer its own agricultural producers or its own industries, we will deliver our primary producers and our industries on the altar of the free markets.

We believe that the tariff cuts proposed for agricultural products should not proceed unless the United States, the European Community and Japan agree to liberalise trade in agriculture. Tariffs will, in fact, be increased if necessary in other areas to prevent access to Australian markets in retaliation for such protectionism by other countries. They are prepared to offend the principles of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Why should we be concerned not to protect our own industries, not to protect our jobs, and not to protect our primary producers?

There is another aspect that we should pay attention to when we consider the level of tariffs in our country; that is, the standards that we wish to maintain in Australia: the wage standards; the standards of working conditions in terms of health and occupational safety; and the standards of environmental protection. Where we are competing against countries where wages are perhaps half, perhaps one-tenth, of what we need to pay our workers to maintain reasonable living standards, when we need to enforce environmental standards to ensure that our children have clean water and clean air, we should be prepared to pay to protect our industries to the necessary extent to ensure that we do not suffer from the poor conditions in other countries. I call that the exploitation index, and I give notice that the Australian Democrats will develop such an exploitation index to catalogue the countries where conditions are at such low levels that we cannot be, and should not be, expected to compete with them.

There are other measures which the Government has neglected in this statement and which the Australian Democrats would believe would enable us to help our industries to weather the storm that they are now facing with the reduced tariffs which will come down to an average of 5 per cent by 1996. One of these would be to place a bounty of 5 per cent on the value of new exports, other than minerals and petroleum. This would be a transition measure to ease the competitive disadvantage still suffered by Australian firms in respect of transport costs and through cheaper imports arising from the general tariff cuts. Last year, had that measure been in place, we would have spent $140m to support new exports of $2.8 billion. It would have been cheap to spend another $140m to double that export figure. I trust that the Government will consider such an incentive to our industries in future.

We believe that in general terms genuine micro-economic reform involves a significant shift in the proportion of the national freight handled by rail. This will be achieved only by substantial infrastructure investment, and a proportion of an increased fuel excise should be directed to fund such an infrastructure develop- ment.

The Australian Democrats would have wished to see a number of other measures included in the Government's statement. I will list a few more. The rate of interest withholding tax should be increased from the existing 10 per cent to 15 per cent with treaty countries and to 39 per cent with non-treaty countries. This would be a measure to make it less attractive for foreign lenders to supply loan funds and would have, as a by-product, the result of bringing our exchange rate down, something that would support our exporters and would discourage imports.

In the financial sector we are now facing a situation where only financial re- regulation and savings incentives would increase Australia's savings ratio, thereby closing the existing current account deficit. Interest rates ceilings should be reimposed for small business and home loans and margins on credit cards should be examined by the Prices Surveillance Authority and regulated accordingly. National regulation of non-bank financial institutions is necessary to protect our investors and to ensure that sufficient funds flow into equity funds for our industries.

The resources of the Reserve Bank of Australia should be boosted to cope with the additional workload that this fiduciary supervision would entail. One of the ways to do that would be through the imposition of an annual licence fee on banks who at present pay nothing for the right to trade. There are other areas. The Trade Practices Act should be amended to reintroduce the merger criteria in existence pre-1977 to prevent undue concentration of ownership, particularly in the media area. These are amendments that I will move when the trade practices legislation is before the Senate shortly.

I have mentioned before that we would have expected the Government, when looking at industry sectors deserving of support because of their capacity to repay such support, to boost the recycling industry and other industries dealing with conservation and developing technology designed to protect the environment. We believe, therefore, that the recycling industry should be boosted by removing the existing 20 per cent sales tax on recycled plastic products. The increased use of recycled products would open new markets, reduce imports of plastic products-worth $483m last year-and make waste disposal savings for local government. All recycled paper products would be made sales tax free, just as stationery was some time ago after pressure from the Australian Democrats.

There are other areas in this general area of conservation and alternative energy. We believe that fuel efficiency and emission targets are needed for the motor vehicle industry to ensure that Australian production will match or exceed international best practice. This will give long term access to export markets which will become much more environmentally protective over the coming decades.

Perhaps the worst example that we have had in recent days of the short term, short-sighted approach that the Government is taking to the development of our economy is the resource guarantee legislation that it has foreshadowed. The Australian Democrats believe that, if we put our minds to it, and if we concentrate on alternatives such as the development of plantations, we would have an effective resource guarantee and would not need to hoe into our natural forests and demolish them for short term economic gain. In fact, we believe that taxation should be progressively shifted away from income to the extraction and consumption of natural resources.

If we look at the thrust of this industry statement we become conscious of its myopic nature. In summary, we should look at three areas where action in the long term is absolutely essential to get us finally to the point where we can aim for not only a sustainable economy but indeed a sustainable society. One initiative would be to make us the clever country through a research and development guarantee scheme similar to the model that we have in the training guarantee scheme which is now in place. It is in this way that we could hope to reach the sorts of development expenditure levels existing in Japan, Switzerland, the United States of America and Germany.

I believe that the second major initiative that we need is a comprehensive retraining and income support scheme to ensure that displaced workers are retrained and relocated to subsequent employment instead of merely being made redundant. Currently we are telling unemployed people that they should be retrained, but what do they do if they are breadwinners and have to look after a family of dependants? We must make it possible, through a guaranteed income scheme that gives them the right to retraining, for industry to have the necessary flexibility to cope with the reductions in tariffs and to enable individual people to survive.

Finally, it is time for us to look at our industrial relations system and, rather than move to the free-for-all jungle warfare that Senator Kemp and others on his side would prefer, we should look at the sort of industrial relations system that central European countries have put in place. If they have been able to do that, why do we persist with the adversarial system and why do we on the other side wish to take it even further and have a system where people are at each other's throats instead of a system where the interests of workers and employers are recognised as being complementary?

Clearly, the first step towards such a measure would be for workers to have employee share ownership schemes in the enterprises in which they work and for them to be represented at board level. The Australian Democrats would favour taxation incentives to companies which were prepared to take such a far-sighted step to ensure that the interests of workers and employers are recognised as complementary, and that the industrial relations practice that follows from such structural adjustments results in a climate which will ensure that we have a cooperative effort in our industries rather than a confrontationist one.

I have sketched out a range of initiatives that we would have liked to see in the industry statement. Seeing that the Government has now started to pay some attention to interventionist policies rather than abdicate its responsibility and let the markets take the hindmost, I express the hope that at least some of these measures will be implemented in future.

In expressing that hope I refer to a question asked by Senator Archer as early as 10 December 1990. Senator Archer, who is known for his interest in and support for scientific research, asked Senator Button whether the Government was prepared to look at a rescue strategy involving stronger export development grants and incentives; Government provision of seed capital to selected promising high-tech industries to encourage banks and other lenders to participate; and a mandatory requirement on superannuation funds and other big institutions to invest one per cent of their funds in the technology sector. If Senator Archer from the conservative coalition can express such interest and such hopes, then I believe that our Government and Prime Minister Hawke might well reach that point of thinking as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking very briefly tonight on the industry statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) entitled Building a Competitive Australia, I want to focus on two major areas of considerable concern to me: firstly, labour market and training or, as it is called in the statement, the clever country and, secondly, proposed resource security legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the initiatives detailed in the labour market and training area which cover so many strategies to strengthen the skills of Australian workers and in particular job seekers. These measures-concerning job skills, Skillshare, job seekers, Jobtrain and Jobstart-at a cost of over $100m will ensure that in the current recession training is maintained in readiness for an upturn in the economy.

It is also good to see that a further $130m-plus will be used in three ways: firstly, to assist the States and Territories to provide young people with vocational training; secondly, to help unemployed apprentices and those facing the risk of retrenchment continue or complete their training; and, thirdly, a new program, training and skills, to help employers retain workers under the threat of retrenchment. I am sure that honourable senators will agree, regardless of which side of the chamber they sit on, that these measures are very appropriate in these difficult times.
