Furthermore, the allocation of nearly $23m on literacy and numeracy programs, including workplace literacy, guarantees a three-year program to provide special training and support for unemployed people with limited literacy and numeracy skills. As a former teacher specialising in remedial education, I especially welcome this recognition of some of the very considerable problems that these young people have in making the adjustment from school to work. This is difficult for people with limited literacy and numeracy skills at the best of times, and these are the most disadvantaged of our young job seekers at the moment. Clearly, this initiative in regard to literacy and numeracy will assist these young people.

A further initiative in the Prime Minister's industry statement, the good school strategy, is one that I wonder whether it is copied from the local government scheme that I oversaw for nearly three years, the innovations program in local government. This was a most effective scheme in that it gave opportunity for recognition within local government of innovative ways of approaching the many responsibilities of local government. It was able to spread those very innovative and effective practices around the country.

I know as a teacher that there are many teachers and many individual schools involved in similar innovative fields in education. Yet, we have failed in the past to be able to communicate those ideas and practices effectively around the country. I suppose it has been done to a certain extent through conferences, but it has not been approached in such a comprehensive way.

I certainly hope that the good school strategy with the $10m that has been allocated to identify the best practiced organisations and structures in our 10,000 schools will enable Australia's teachers and students to benefit from a special focus on these proven methods and programs. In addition-as I am well aware of the special problems that young people face in rural areas-the country areas program extension, an educational program that will give special support and recognition to rural students particularly in these difficult times, will give an extra $15m to the program to try to encourage higher retention rates in rural areas. Again, this is an area of considerable need if these young people are going to acquire the skills to move on into the workplace.

The second area of concern to me this evening is the decision to include proposed resource security legislation in the industry statement which, as many people will recognise, is controversial and requires very careful consideration, interpretation and a degree of open-mindedness in the coming months. On the one hand, we have the Federal Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Ros Kelly, assuring us that the proposed legislation will ensure that environmental and heritage protection remain a priority for Australia's native forests. I would commend the Minister on her very strenuous efforts to seek guarantees in this regard. In her press release she says:
Under the proposed legislation environmental, heritage, cultural, social and economic assessments will now be done prior to the granting of resource security to that project.
These assessments will for the first time ensure the identification of conservation needs for the region from which a project will draw its supply before that project can proceed.
By basing the security guarantee on the volume of timber to be supplied for any project, we will retain greater flexibility to protect areas of high conservation value.
Under the new legislation I will have a direct role in ensuring that conservation and heritage values are properly and comprehensively assessed.
I will also have a role in determining appropriate conditions set for forest management and for periodic review of forest management and environmental protection practices.

Furthermore, the Agreement will include a timeframe for establishment of plantations which provide for a long-term timber supply with the object of phasing out woodchip export through value-adding. This will relieve pressure on native forests.
She concludes:
With these safeguards in place, I am confident that the forest industries and conservation needs can be met and that the industry-
that is the forest industry-
will move to a secure, ecologically sustainable footing.

I suppose what many people would ask is: what guarantees are there in relation to the conservation needs? Conservationists and their national organisations are perhaps predictably sceptical of these very well-meaning and earnest assurances. I do not want to denigrate them in any way because I believe the Minister has worked very hard to gain these guarantees. But I think that many people committed to environmental protection are sceptical simply because they fear that legislation in itself may preclude the kind of flexibility that ministerial negotiation and discretion could offer.

I am sure that honourable senators have all been in the situation of taking a particular constituency case to a department or a Minister and being told absolutely genuinely, `Look, there is a case. There is an anomaly. We regret there is nothing we can do about it, but the legislation says and the legislation cannot predict for all contingencies'. We have all had that experience in relation to the necessary rigidity, I suppose, of legislative frameworks. I can understand very much the concerns of conservationists.

The Australian Conservation Foundation (ACF) has put forward in its submissions to the Resource Assessment Commission detailed proposals for an ecologically and sustainable forest industry including a transition strategy. The ACF argues that:

. . . resource security works against such a transition strategy, central to which must be an effective restructuring of the industry. By simply concentrating on the issue of security of access to native forest across the board, governments are in danger of ignoring the other problems faced by industry. Providing resource security in the form demanded by the timber industry runs the risk of entrenching restrictive and inefficient industry practices at a time when there is need for dynamic change through restructuring. Despite existing guarantees of access to public forest resources (such as the Tasmanian timber concession system and 15-year Victorian timber licences) the hardwood sawmilling industry has declined economically with major job loss, has been slow readjusting to further processing, and has been accompanied by the growth in a Third World style export woodchip industry that is economically and ecologically unacceptable.
Finally, the ACF concludes:

Currently no forestry commission selling wood from native forests is making a commercially reasonable dividend payment to the community, the owner of the resource. Nor has there been an adequate evaluation of non-timber values of this public forest resource.
Therefore, in summing up it says:

To go ahead with legislating for resource security, government will be issuing long term contracts to industry in the knowledge that log prices are too low and that a market system has not been established to price, allocate and freely trade the resource.
That is very much putting the views of some of the conservation movement and, in particular, the ACF.

Clearly, there are two eminently reasonable positions: firstly, what the Minister has given in her assurances and, secondly, what the ACF has given us in summary. These conflicting interpretations must be resolved. Over the coming months we are going to need extensive and logical debate between Government and the environment movement to ensure that the proposed legislation does in fact offer as much ecological security as it does resource security. Some people will argue that that is an impossible goal. They will argue that we cannot legislate for that ideal. However, I believe that it is a goal that we all have a responsibility to pursue with considerable vigour.

While I can understand the frustration and the uncertainty of dedicated organisations like Greenpeace and the Wilderness Society in rejecting proposed resource security legislation, I personally very much hope that the Australian Conservation Foundation will remain committed to working in close collaboration with Government to guarantee that the framing of any legislation is balanced and in no way compromises what has been for this Government an outstanding record on the environment.

The Government, I believe, needs the Australian Conservation Foundation to continue its very rational and informed input into the debate that is going to ensue. It would be a tragedy if the ACF were to bail out. I can understand from its point of view that that may well be on its mind but it would be a very short term response and in the long term it would be a decision it would regret. Certainly, as a member of the Government, I would regret it and I think that Australians generally would regret it for many years to come.

Finally this evening I want to sum up some agreements that have been made following the announcement of the industry statement on the proposed resource security legislation. The Government has given an absolute assurance that a caucus committee will be established to liaise with Ministers responsible prior to and during the course of preparation of any legislation. The working group will canvass the broad range of issues in relation to resource security, and one of the first matters that has been put on the table as a result of efforts by a number of my colleagues is a call for the introduction of endangered species legislation to ensure that the Commonwealth Government has a mechanism to put into effect part five of stage three of the development process, that is, safeguards to accommodate major unforeseeable contingencies, for example, rare and endangered species.

We will also be moving to ensure that the legislation complies with the principle that there be strictly enforced provision for the establishment of plantations in a specific time frame in order to facilitate the rapid reservation of native forests of high conservation value and a phasing out of woodchip exports.

We will also be ensuring in discussions that attention is given to the importance of phasing out reliance on the logging of old growth native forests and that accordingly there will be some form of taper over a period of time in any resource guarantee so that there is a practical and effective incentive for companies to comply with this strategy.

I have every confidence that this is a process that can achieve what both sides of the debate want to see achieved in the coming months. It is going to require a great deal of patience, commitment and open mindedness from both the environment movement and indeed from the Government. It is not going to be easy but I am sure that with goodwill on both sides and particularly, as I would like to emphasise, with the Australian Conservation Foundation remaining on board in this critical debate, a good outcome can in fact be negotiated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two days have now elapsed since the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his final fling to restore the credibility of his Government. Judging by the poor reception Mr Hawke's statement has received from business, most sections of the media and many other groups in the community, not the least are the conservation groups as raised by Senator Reynolds this evening, it is clear that Mr Hawke failed in his task. Rather than restoring the economic credentials of his Government, Mr Hawke has in fact confirmed the worst fears of business men and women and the families of Australia. This Government is a government of special interests and of special deals with its mates. It has no capacity to take the decisions which will restore Australian prosperity, and with it our national pride and self-respect.

SPEECH.PARA: This evening Senator Chapman and Senator Panizza outlined, I thought rather well, the enormous restraint which this Government has on its decision-making as a result of its relationship with the trade union movement, and they are obviously very indebted to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) for confirming their views and the views of all people on this side of the chamber.

I also thought Senator Alston in his speech made a similar point very well. `This Government', he said, `has tried to tackle the issue of economic reform with one arm tied behind its back'. The Government's arm, of course, is tied by the trade union bosses, who prevented a clear commitment and timetable for shipping reform, labour market reform, reductions in government spending, a proper privatisation program of government business enterprises and, among other things, the replacement of the wholesale sales tax regime by a consumption tax.

The Australian Conservation Foundation was mentioned at some length this evening by Senator Reynolds, and I can understand why she wants it to stay on board. If she accepts the view that has been promoted by Senator Richardson, having the Conservation Foundation on board was probably the main reason why at least Senator Richardson believed she and her colleagues are over on the other side of chamber. I am not so sure that Senator Richardson is right, but that was certainly the belief he had.

It is interesting that Senator Reynolds believes that the Australian Conservation Foundation can be brought back on board. Certainly the Conservation Foundation believes that Mr Hawke broke his clear promise and commitment on resource security. A lot of us may ask why Phillip Toyne should be surprised. What is surprising is that Phillip Toyne and the Australian Conservation Foundation believed the Prime Minister would keep his word.

Remember the Prime Minister's many promises in the elections during the 1980s? All major election promises on the economy have been broken. We were promised lower taxes and lower interest rates. Does Senator Reynolds remember his famous phrase in 1983? Mr Hawke said there would be no capital gains tax. Again, that was probably one of the early major promises that Mr Hawke broke. As we go through election after election, we cannot forget the famous big lie of them all, the daddy of them all. In 1987 he said, `No child will live in poverty'.

So why, I ask, is Phillip Toyne surprised that the Prime Minister has broken his promise to the Australian Conservation Foundation? He broke his promises to the families and the children of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the veterans.

—And the veterans. I thank Senator Newman. What about the promise that was made to the Australian Bank Employees Union? Do honourable senators remember that one? The Prime Minister said the Commonwealth Bank would not be privatised. I can remember when I was handing out how to vote cards a gentleman from the Commonwealth Bank who was a member of the union berated me and said that he thought that if he and his colleagues voted Liberal, the Commonwealth Bank would be privatised.
—We haven't privatised it.
—Some shares will be sold to the private sector.
—Thirty per cent.

—Thirty per cent? That is a good start. But no, there was another firm commitment by the Prime Minister: no privatisation of the Commonwealth Bank. I have to tell Senator Richardson that it gave me considerable pleasure to vote with Senator Richardson, Senator Loosley and Senator Childs and all the members of the Left on that particular Bill.
—The things that give you pleasure!

—It did indeed. So as we go through all these promises, of course, we come to the great big promise of the 1990 election. Does Senator Richardson remember that one? He went around saying, `There will be no recession'. Senator Sherry said that, I am sure, and so did Senator West and Senator Faulkner. They all repeated it ceaselessly and parroted the Prime Minister, saying that there would be no recession. Within six months of the election, what has happened? We are in the most serious recession since the 1930s.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke and Mr Keating used to tell us that they were not like the Whitlam Government. In fact, they used to go around bagging the Whitlam Government. They were not going to be bad managers of the economy, like the Whitlam Government. We do not hear much of that talk now, do we? We do not hear much of that talk at all. Along with their failed mates-and we can list the role of dishonour: Bourke, Dowding, Lawrence, Cain, Kirner, Field and Bannon; the list mounts up-one would have to say that Hawke and Keating are indeed the true descendants of the Whitlam Government. In fact, Gough looks almost good by comparison. He never had a foreign debt of $130 billion. Senator Richardson always used to go around bagging him, and certainly he made some gross mistakes, but Senator Richardson's Government is chalking up a Gough-like record.

This evening my colleagues have made some very important criticisms of the March economic statement. I will concentrate my remarks on what has been described today by the Australian Financial Review as `the missing link' in the economic statement. I refer to the failure to reform the indirect taxation system. Today's Australian Financial Review said:

There is no doubt that the present indirect taxation system is hugely inefficient. Since its introduction in 1931 it has spawned a veritable industry of corporate lawyers and accountants who have spent endless hours doing battle with the Government in and out of various courts, over loopholes and anomalies.
The Australian Financial Review criticised Mr Keating for attempting to prop up the failed wholesale tax system and praised Dr Hewson for his brave support of a consumption tax.

If we want to find out how Australian industry is being crippled by bureaucracy, red tape and absurd tax laws, we need look no further than the wholesale sales tax regime. It is true that this tax is a nightmare for companies in its complexity. The proposals announced yesterday in the economic statement, while providing some relief, will, if anything, add to the confusion, bureaucracy and inequities resulting from wholesale sales taxes. Further, delaying the date of implementation until August will cause serious disruption to manufacturers and distortions in the market for a variety of goods.

The anomalies, exceptions and absurdities of the current wholesale tax system can be illustrated by reference to innumerable examples. As the hour is late and we are all keen to go home, I propose to refer to just one particular example. It is an example that was raised by Senator Spindler in his speech this evening: the problem of recycled paper products. We can all support the use of recycled paper products. I am sure that all of us do-on each side of the chamber. A minute from the Australian Taxation Office has come into my hands which seeks to explain how the sales tax applies to recycled paper products. This minute exposes the absurdities and anomalies of the current system and testifies to the confusion it has caused among the Department's own officers and, by implication, industry at large.

This minute shows how the Australian Taxation Office interprets the Government's regulations relating to these products. The Office was therefore moved to issue a lengthy minute in an attempt to clear up the confusion about the exceptions and exclusions which apply. As the minute shows, the harder one tries to rationalise the indirect wholesale sales tax system the greater is the confusion.

Not all recycled paper products are exempt from the 20 per cent tax. Where the product has considerable value added to it by printing or some other process the product will not be exempt. How does this work out in fact? Let us take the simple first case. Recycled paper is tax exempt. Recycled paper with lines on it is tax exempt. For the same paper with lines on but with a company logo and some shading-voila, a 20 per cent tax. Recycled paper product companies should beware. If they put a company logo or trademark in solid print and shading over a section of the recycled paper they cop a 20 per cent tax. If the recycled paper merely has lines on it there is no tax, but put a floral design on that same piece of paper and, that is right, Mr Keating taxes them at 20 per cent.

Apparently various branches of the Taxation Office were giving different advice on this complex matter of recycled paper products. For example, in some cases if the recycled paper had a trademark and a logo, exemption was not granted by some offices. However, if the manufacturer was lucky he may have obtained advice from another Tax Office which suggested that recycled paper with a trademark and a logo was exempt. If the Taxation Office is confused, think of the poor producer of the paper.

Envelopes are covered by the same principles. An inter-office envelope on recycled paper would be taxable because of the squares printed across it. Envelopes that now provide squares in which to enter a postcode are, however, exempt. What is the reason for this exemption? Squares on an envelope for the purpose of postcodes are considered to be part of the address, not part of the envelope. The anomaly is, once again, absurd. An inter-office envelope, even when it is printed on new paper, is designed to conserve paper-yet it is taxed. I am advised by some tax experts that last night's statement does nothing to clear up the confusion surrounding the use of recycled paper and the indirect taxes that apply to it. Indeed, it may well add to the problems that recycled paper producers now have.

The absurdities and anomalies of the wholesale sales tax provisions do not stop at recycled paper products. In almost every other category of product-and there are hundreds of them-any one manufacturer can be faced with the difficulties and exceptions of a large number of provisions of the relevant Act in the course of his business. All of these categories come under continual change and review as the bureaucratic red tape seeks to embrace new products, create new exemptions, and as a consequence create further and more profound uncertainty.

The Opposition offered bipartisan support for a comprehensive reform of the indirect tax system. The Treasurer is on record as supporting a consumption tax but, as we know and as history records, this was vetoed by Bill Kelty. When the Government has to choose between Australia's interests and the interests of the trade union movement, Australia loses every time. Australia is the big loser from Mr Hawke's economic statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hawke in his industry statement on Tuesday missed the point so badly that he could be likened to a snooker player who forgets to chalk his cue, does not know how to bridge his fingers, and in pulling back his cue hits the black ball. Tuesday was a black day for Australia: so much promised, so much needed, but ending in an unfulfilled dream. The statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), so eloquently called Building a Competitive Australia, I have to say is much ado about nothing. We are getting quite used to this Government doing its patchwork quilt routine six months or so after every budget it brings down. It seems to have become a hallmark of how this Government runs things. What a weaver it is, weaving the threads of economic despair for Australia, which started eight years ago and is continuing to this very day.

SPEECH.PARA: Given its abysmal record of managing the economy, it is little wonder it needs to resort to these mid-term reports to try to ginger up the troops. Having seen the glossy publication produced for the Prime Minister, one has to ask: why did he bother? Clearly, the statement has done nothing for the man in the street. It most certainly has done nothing for rural Australia and has wasted a few more forests in producing the paperwork. As Senator Kemp has already said, there is nothing to be done abut the recycling of it.

It is not just the Opposition parties which suggest that it has been very much a flop. Scanning through the various headlines and editorials following the statement, one can soon see how it has been received. An article by Max Walsh was headlined, `Hawke muffs it in late bid for salvation'. In the article he said:

Too little, too late, will be the epitaph of the Hawke Government. This weeks package of industry measures fits that description. So, too, does the Government's belated conversion to privatisation, whose policy evolution has been so long and agonising that it is being implemented in the worst possible market environment on a half-baked basis.

The same criticism of ` `too little, too late'' can be directed, as the Prime Minister conceded in his speech on Tuesday, to the Government's operation of monetary policy. And there is the glacial rate of progress towards a genuinely flexible wages system-and every other aspect of micro-economic reform that involves any possibility of disagreement with organised labour.
Barry Jones had a bit to say, too. He is one of the ex-Ministers in the Hawke Labor Government. According to a press report, he said:
And the Hawke Government's industry statement had shown ``unusual bravery'' but was eight years too late in tackling the problem.
He went on to say:
``unless we get a culture shift we're not going to make it . . .

That is really what was meant to happen in the Prime Minister's statement on Tuesday. He was meant to give some indication of where Australia was going. He was meant to give some indication of what was needed from Australia to make it get off its backside and really get going. The Australian, in its editorial, states:
A competitive Hawke fails his own test.

The Prime Minister's industry statement yesterday is in keeping with this Government's record: audacious reforms to the business environment are coupled with a marked reluctance to force change upon Labor's allies-the trade union movement and, as it turns out, the greens.

The Canberra Times states, `Many ingredients but no cake'. Another editorial states, `More faith and hope than charity'. Then we go to the Sydney Morning Herald, which states, `Together we're all prepared-for trouble'. That was by Alan Ramsey. Here we have the Hawke Labor Government, which promised so much to Australia, promised us something to get things going, and has given us absolutely nothing. Many of the people who wrote those editorials and who made those comments in the newspapers a few years ago were saying that the Hawke Labor Government was doing a good job, although I do not think it was. They have now turned because the Hawke Labor Government has failed Australia. It is hardly a vote of confidence from those in the press gallery.

I quite agree with Alan Ramsey and all the editorial writers, who have deserted the Hawke Labor Government. `Crook' was the word that Alan Ramsey used and it is probably as good a word as any other to describe rural Australia at the present time. When farm incomes are likely to fall 67 per cent, when wheat growers are losing up to something like 94 per cent of last year's income and woolgrowers are losing at least half their income, one could suggest that things are crook. The Prime Minister prefers to suggest:
. . . rural Australia in particular is experiencing a very tough period.

I wish to hell the Prime Minister would go out and have a look at what is happening in rural Australia and how he is closing country Australia down. Madam Acting Deputy President, you know what is happening in Queensland and I know what is happening in the country areas of New South Wales. This Prime Minister, his Treasurer (Mr Keating) and this Government are absolutely crucifying the Australian community. This statement that rural Australia in particular is experiencing a very tough period comes from a Prime Minister who, only a few months ago, was denying that things were even tough in the rural areas. I guess it is some concession that he is saying it now.

Given that the Prime Minister has now acknowledged things are tough, farmers could be excused for being angry and disappointed that this statement contains nothing for them. In fact, worse than not giving any assistance, the Prime Minister says:
General agricultural assistance will be reduced in line with the pace of tariff reform in manufacturing.
For wheat growers there is nothing. They are obviously going to be allowed to go the same way as the woolgrowers of Australia.

Senator West is sitting in the chamber. She is supposed to represent and to help country people. Sitting in the city of Orange, what is she doing about trying to get this monolith of a Prime Minister of hers to do something, especially for country New South Wales? It is time Senator West did something in her Party to make sure that the rural industries of Australia have a bit of a fair go.

Obviously, the Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls survey-one would think that the Government would have taken a bit of notice of the survey because the pollster has done a lot of work for the Australian Labor Party-and the paper that it put out recently to tell of the problems in the rural areas and the Agricultural Outlook Conference all fell on deaf ears. The rural sector is to get nothing. In fact, it is getting less than nothing because this Hawke-Keating Labor Government, of which Senator Bolkus is a part, has given nothing to rural Australia.

This Government is effectively giving export incentives to our comparatively inefficient manufacturing sector while refusing to give any similar boost to our efficient and wealth generating rural industries. Agriculture is virtually unprotected and is trying to compete against increasingly corrupted world marketing practices. Yet the Prime Minister says that general agricultural assistance is to be reduced in line with the pace of tariff reform in manufacturing. This is absolutely disgraceful. Those sitting on that side of the chamber who can see the damage being done to rural Australia can hang their heads in shame for what is happening.

It is only through increased agricultural and mineral exports that Australia's precarious and worsening balance of payments problems will improve. But that point seems to have repeatedly escaped the notice of the Prime Minister, his Deputy, the Cabinet and all the other people on the other side of the chamber.

Where are the initiatives to boost the export competitiveness of our products? If the Government is happy to reduce the tax burden on business inputs, it should at least have gone a step further and included rebates on the excise of fuels used in agriculture, forestry, fishing and mining. It is hardly a new concept; it is one for which those industries have been pressing for a very long time.

The Prime Minister's statement uses all the right words. It talks of challenges and refers again to Australia becoming the clever country, working smarter and not harder. What do all those glib statements mean? As Michelle Grattan in the Age suggested, the Hawke statement has fallen victim to its own hype. As she says, the statement was supposed to revitalise the political fortunes of the Government and revive business confidence but `it is hard to see it doing any of these'.

Why is that? It is because we still have the most inefficient waterfront in the world; because it is still cheaper to ship a container halfway around the world than to freight it across the Tasman. We still have industries bogged down with the unnecessary work and pay structures that prevent them from becoming efficient; for example, we still have people getting more on holidays than they do when actually working. We still have high interest rates that have just about wiped out small business across Australia, and we still have a recession with 600,000 people out of work and more on the way.

If Government members can smile and feel happy about that, sitting on that side of this chamber, they should hang their heads in shame once again. All this, and the Prime Minister suggests that during his Government's eight years in office we have made `substantial progress'. If this is progress, Australia definitely does not need it. The Prime Minister's statement smacks of hypocrisy from beginning to end. It is, and could only ever have been, a political stunt because this Government does not really believe Australia is suffering. After all, we needed this recession. I cannot remember if I ever knew why it was we needed it, but according to the Treasurer and the Prime Minister we did.

There has never been any commitment to real reform. In its eight years in office, the Government would have done better to write its Budgets in pencil because for every Budget there has been a counter-Budget or a supplementary Budget. Ask the motor industry. The Government's on-again, off-again tax on cars has sent that industry into collapse, with some 18,000 jobs axed in car dealerships across Australia during the last two years.

There are another couple of reforms that could have been made. Why has Coronation Hill not come into production? Why has something not been done about the three mines uranium policy, with Canada stealing all the uranium markets of the world while Australia has the biggest reserves; with Canada getting billions of dollars in return for its uranium and Australia getting something like $0.4 billion? I will stop now because I believe there are others who want to speak tonight, and I know that we are trying to finish this debate. I will quote just one little statement:

A pilot study of teenagers' attitudes to politics found they were more preoccupied with politicians being ` `old and wrinkly'' and politics being nothing but ` `hassles and lies'' rather than democracy, parliament and elections.
Obviously the teenagers of today were watching the Prime Minister make this industry statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The statements presented by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Button) have been criticised in a number of areas: by the environment movement in respect of the resource security legislation; and by those opposite in respect of the alleged failure to transform our waterfront, trans-Tasman shipping, our railroads and other aspects of our transport system, and in respect of industrial relations and the lack of a consumption tax. Tonight I intend to deal with a couple of these matters, particularly resource legislation and industrial relations. In terms of the resource legislation, I would firstly like to conclude some remarks that I commenced earlier in the week when the Australian Democrats proposed a matter of urgency motion concerning the forestry industry which was based on the accurate, as it proved, media speculation about the statements containing proposals for resource legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The genesis of the proposal for resource guarantee legislation emerged from Tasmania where, over the last two years, the Field Labor Government in that State has completed an extensive research into all aspects of Tasmanian forest industry-the Tasmanian Forests and Forest Industry Strategy, as the report has become known. One of the important aspects about this issue of resource guarantee legislation, which appears to have been missed by most persons who have commented on the matter in the last couple of weeks, is the issue of the concession system in Tasmania which will be replaced by the resource guarantee legislation.

In Tasmania for the last 50 years, there has been a system of concessions operating, five in number, which are established under individual Acts of the Tasmanian Parliament. The rights offered under the concession Acts vary, but the general theme is of conveying exclusive rights to pulpwood from a specified area under specified conditions. In reality, of course, the forestry companies who were granted these concessions were given almost carte blanche to operate, to pulp the wood in whatever way they saw fit-although there have been some extensive changes in the last decade. In return for these concessions, they had to offer to establish a manufacturing facility to utilise that pulpwood.

There were some five concession Acts. The first, the Wood Pulp and Paper Industry Encouragement Act, was passed in 1926 at the same time as the building of the current mill at Burnie. There then followed some four other concession Acts and, if we look at a map showing the concession areas in Tasmania-unlike Senator Shirley Walters, who had a visual aid in the Senate on Tuesday when debating this matter, my map is somewhat smaller and I cannot display it to all the honourable senators present-we find that it shows that access to pulpwood in almost two-thirds of the State was granted to forestry companies in Tasmania. Those companies had access to almost two-thirds of the State. In fact, they had a resource guarantee of monumental proportions with very few controls.

One of the negotiating points that emerged in the forest industry strategy in Tasmania was that those companies agreed that the concession Acts should end and that the land that had been vested under their control should be passed back to the control of the State Government. However, if they are to pass back the lands that they were granted through these concession Acts, it is quite reasonable for those companies to require some sort of resource security guarantee as to the resources they currently need and the resources that they will need to operate a new pulp and paper mill that is proposed for north-west Tasmania.

Although there has been considerable media speculation and hype, it has certainly become apparent that the process outlined in the statement of the Prime Minister is extremely comprehensive in terms of the issues that will be required to be addressed through this resource guarantee legislation. The comprehensive proposals from the States-and obviously Tasmania will be the first to be considered-will have to provide for economically feasible hardwood and softwood plantations in agreed areas and with agreed time frames. There will need to be required consideration of the environmental, cultural, social, economic and heritage issues, and these need to be designed and comprehensively identified.

Also, forest management prescriptions for both public and private forests will need to be encompassed in codes of forest practice. There will need to be provision for periodic review of the operation of management and environmental protection practices under the agreement. There will need to be safeguards to accommodate major unforeseen contingencies-for example, rare and endangered species. So if we look through that statement of the Prime Minister, we find that it is quite clear that a lot of the media hype and statements, particularly from some sections of the environmental movement, were somewhat overstated.

Also in respect of the forest industry strategy that was developed in Tasmania by a State Labor government and which has not been supported by the State Liberal Party over the last decade, in early 1988 some 16 per cent of the area of Tasmania was vested either as national parks or World Heritage area. By 1989, after the Helsham and Salamanca agreements, some 25 per cent of Tasmania was vested in World Heritage and national parks areas. After September 1990, following the completion of the forest industry strategy, some 27 per cent of Tasmania was vested in World Heritage and national parks areas. Some 16 per cent of Tasmania will become wood production forest. This area will be specified as a resource for the paper industry in Tasmania. Some 9 per cent will be deferred as forest that will require some further examination. A comprehensive strategy will be developed and will be presented to the Federal Government in terms of the resource guarantee legislation. Every conceivable factor-the interests of the workers, the environment and the pulp and paper producers-will be taken into account.

The second issue I wish to comment on in regard to the Government's industry statements relates to employment, education and training. A number of very important new initiatives were outlined. I will touch on a couple of them. For example, in regard to research awards, the number of annual postgraduate research awards is to be increased from 1,100 to 1,300 and the number of overseas postgraduate research scholarships will be doubled to around 300 awards a year from the 1992 academic year. There are to be incentives for training and management skills development. Regrettably, management skills development has been sorely neglected in this country. Honourable senators opposite maintain a continual and quite unjustified barrage of criticism against the union movement and workers in this country for alleged malpractices. However, if we examine management skills and practices in this country, we see that they need change as well.

The Government has announced a national management skills formation strategy that will be developed to include research to identify the need for management skills. The measures will also improve education and advisory services and strengthen the links between training providers and employers.

In the area of industrial relations, the new workplace culture, the Australian best practice demonstration program, will identify on a competitive basis enterprises in the process of successfully implementing workplace reform. The achievements of these enterprises will be widely published to encourage other firms to adopt the new workplace culture. These are the types of new strategies in the area of employment, education and training. Of course, these follow a long series of initiatives by this Government over the last eight years to boost the skill of Australian workers and, therefore, to boost the productivity and output of our Australian economy.

Measures such as the training guarantee legislation, restructuring of higher education and incentives to ensure that there are greater retention rates in Australian educational institutions are just a few of the measures taken by this Government over the last eight years under the auspices of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr John Dawkins. They provide a useful example of the way in which the Australian Labor Party has taken a positive approach to restructuring our economy.

I come next to the area of industrial relations. It is an area of much rhetoric from honourable senators opposite. They have called, as they usually do, for the introduction of enterprise agreements, for the freeing up of the labour market and for negotiations between employees and employers. However, when we examine the evidence that has emerged on this issue as to whether, in fact, that is what employers are interested in, we find that employers quite frankly are just not interested in what the Opposition is proposing.

The recently released Australian workplace industrial relations survey provides clear evidence of the sorts of issues that employers are interested in discussing in terms of workplace reform. If we look at the conclusions of this extremely comprehensive survey, we see that the vast majority of employers are not interested in renegotiating or abolishing awards. If we look at the survey we see that some 60 per cent of private employers said that there need not be any changes to awards in this country.

When we look at the issues which they were interested in examining, such as the introduction of career paths, performance pay, increased pay, fewer awards and changed award classifications, we see that they are all initiatives that the Labor Government has under way in the area of labour market reform. The evidence clearly shows that what the Opposition is postulating and pushing, the employers themselves are simply not interested in.

The other area I wish to touch on this evening is the important area of Federal-State relationships in terms of improving our nation's productivity and improving our economy. Again, there is one State in this country that had a predominantly Liberal Government over the last decade, and that is Tasmania. If that Government provides evidence of the sorts of policies that are to be initiated by those opposite, then those opposite should be ashamed of themselves.

We can look at what occurred in Tasmania over the last eight years under the Gray Government. The State was almost left bankrupt; it makes the running of Victoria look like quite responsible fiscal management. Those opposite ought to go down there and see what the Liberal Government has done to the State. Let us look at what it did to Tasmania when it comes to these issues of structural reform.

First of all, the Liberal Government in Tasmania does not have a forest industry strategy. It rejected the forest industry strategy that has been negotiated, which the industry itself supports. But, no, that Government has rejected it. In the area of local government restructuring-as far as the Liberal Party of Australia is concerned, that is some sort of centralist, socialist plot to combine local government.

We can look at the issue of hospital rationalisation in Tasmania. There are two hospitals on the north-western coast of Tasmania-one in the Devonport- Latrobe area and one in Burnie-both operating at 50 per cent capacity. Of course, the State Labor Government, in terms of making State government more efficient by delivering a better health service, has decided that one of those hospitals has to be downgraded. What is the attitude of the Liberal Party? It wants to maintain two hospitals, both operating on 50 per cent capacity, which is an extravagant waste of public resources.

There are half-empty schools in Tasmania all over the place, and when the Labor Government proposed to rationalise the schools, the Liberal Party jumped into bed with the green movement and passed legislation to ensure that there could be no school closures in Tasmania. It must be the only place in the world where one cannot close a school.

In Tasmania there is a petrol rostering system which restricts and controls the way petrol is sold. The Labor Government in Tasmania proposed to abolish this petrol rostering system. But what did the Liberal Party do? One would think that it would be very keen on ensuring free trade occurred in the petrol rostering area; but no, again it jumped into bed with the greens and it refused to abolish the petrol rostering system.

In relation to shop trading hours, Tasmania is the only place in Australia where we do not have shops open on Saturday afternoons. One would think that the Liberal Party-this Party which is in favour of free enterprise and removing restrictions-would be supporting this initiative; but no, it jumped into bed with the greens yet again and it refused to amend the shop trading hours. What a crew we have down in Tasmania. Yet the Tasmanian senators have the gall to come up here and postulate the sorts of theories they have put forward, when the clear evidence shows that the Liberal Party has been an abysmal failure in Tasmania.

In terms of this debate, one of the interesting hallmarks is that those opposite have talked about, in their usual rhetoric, such words as `flexibility', `productivity' and `freedom of choice'. They have talked about `removing the shackles and the chains'. They are into rhetoric. They have even invented a new word- `incentivation'. That is how much they are into rhetoric.

When it comes to addressing the structural problems of this country that we have inherited over 180 years-and which were compounded by those opposite for 30 years under the Menzies regime-this Government is the only one that has addressed them. We cannot sweep away all our problems in 10 years, but we have had a good go. This Government is about hard work; it is about hard, effective, coordinated policies. It is about fact, not about fiction; it is about cooperation, not about confrontation; it is about reason, not about the rhetoric we get from those opposite; it is about success, not about failure-and that is what those opposite will learn.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Bolkus) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.
Friday, 15 March 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Tuesday I asked in this chamber a question relating to the enterprise based agreement that has been negotiated with the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia by National Terminals (Australia) Ltd. My question referred to a speech by Julian Manser, the Chief Executive of National Terminals, which he had addressed to the waterfront, ports and shipping conference in February this year.

SPEECH.PARA: I asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) whether he was aware that Julian Manser could not see any reductions in charges to waterfront use as a result of the enterprise agreements. I then asked: if the savings were not going to flow to the users of the waterfront, what was the purpose of the Government's reforms? In his answer Minister Collins indicated that Julian Manser had been misquoted by the National Farmers Federation, by the Australian shippers users group, by the shadow Minister, John Sharp, and by me. He said that what Julian Manser had actually said was:

The savings that will be achieved on the waterfront in the National Terminals agreement will not be passed on to users if those savings are simply eroded by increases in charges levied by State-controlled port authorities.

When I asked the question, I had Mr Manser's speech with me and I knew that he was not referring to port charges when he said that it might not be possible to pass the cost on to users. Therefore, I asked the Minister a supplementary question and indicated that the costs referred to by Julian Manser were, in fact, the costs of multiskilling, retraining, and investment in new technology. In answer to the supplementary question, the Minister said that the multiskilling program that was being introduced into National Terminals substantially would produce a great deal of productivity that was going to be delivered as a result of the National Terminals agreement. However, he refused to say more than that and failed to give any response to other costs involved in the enterprise agreement. Instead, the Minister said that he would send me a copy of Julian Manser's speech, which he subsequently did. Actually, I already had the speech and I was fully acquainted with all of its contents.

Because the answer provided by the Minister was so unsatisfactory and had failed to address my question, I again asked whether Julian Manser had actually said that cost savings created by reductions in manning levels on the wharves would be offset-and I now quote Mr Manser:

. . . by the cost of reclassification of positions with multi-skills which will cost in the region of 8 per cent of payroll, plus significant costs of retraining and multi-skilling employees. Additionally our investment program in new equipment and technology will incur significant financial costs.

For the information of honourable senators, I indicate that this quote comes from the final paragraph on page 12 of Mr Manser's speech. I finally asked why the Minister had misled the Senate on the previous day. In his answer, Senator Collins indicated that I had not read far enough in the speech and that I had not read the next paragraph. However, this time he did answer part of my question-that part which related to investment-and quoted the investment costs of upgrading the port facilities in Sydney. The Minister finally quoted Julian Manser again when he said:

The long term benefits that will be given to users from all this cumulative effect and the investment the company is putting in will be eroded and lost to the users if they are simply picked up by opportunistic lifts in port authority pricing.

Incidentally, that particular quotation is nowhere to be found in Mr Manser's speech, which was tabled by the Minister. In a supplementary question I acknowledged the problem of State port charges for ship users, but it is, of course, a quite separate problem from the one which I was attempting to clarify with the Minister. Again I asked about the fact that the very high cost of implementing the enterprise agreement and the Government's reforms, including increased idle time and the extremely generous redundancy packages, would prevent any financial gain for some time.

The Minister did not answer the question. Instead, he subjected the Senate to a lecture about redundancy schemes for politicians. I understand that there are no redundancy schemes for politicians. There is in fact a parliamentary retirement benefits scheme, which has absolutely nothing to do with the redundancy packages for surplus labour on wharves.

Finally, the Minister could not or would not answer the question. I have been asking it now over two days. He simply tabled Mr Manser's speech and left honourable senators to make up their own minds about its accuracy. So that honourable senators will be in no doubt about the accuracy or non-accuracy of the Minister, let me inform you, Mr Deputy President, that I am now dealing only with the copy of the speech tabled by the Minister, which I obtained from the Table Office. It is identical to the speech which I used as the basis for all the questions I asked in the Senate on Tuesday and Wednesday.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell me the Minister was fibbing.

—I think the Senate should judge that for itself. First, I refer all honourable senators to the final paragraph on page 12, which I have already quoted, referring to the offsetting costs of reclassification, retraining, multiskilling and investment. In the Minister's answer on Wednesday he referred me to the next paragraph of the answer, which he kept repeating: savings in reduction of manpower on the wharves would be eroded by port charges.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators may not be surprised to find that the next paragraph, which comes at the top of page 13 of the tabled document, has nothing whatsoever to do with State port charges. In his speech, Mr Manser was outlining to the conference the process by which National Terminals had formed the enterprise agreement and the problems and costs related to the next stage of implementation of the agreement. Only at the very end of his speech did he make a passing reference to port charges, although not in relation to the cost of implementation of the agreement but as another area for future reform.

I know as well as the Minister does that State port charges are a problem. The Australian National Line made a special point of that in its latest annual report, which states in relation to the unsatisfactory situation on the wharves:
. . . has been exacerbated by the Port Authorities in Sydney, Melbourne and Fremantle implementing major increases in their port pricing charges without adequate consultation with port users.
Julian Manser substantiates this when he says on page 14 of his speech:
it occurs to me that the recent changes to Port Pricing Policies have highlighted one of the areas where significant opportunities exist for further reform.
He goes on:
This leads me to believe that the next stage in Waterfront Reform must be a review of Port Authorities of equal intensity to that experienced by the stevedoring industry.

I do not deny that, and I would support a review of port authorities and their pricing policies. But that was not the issue in my questions on Tuesday or Wednesday; nor is it the issue of greatest concern in the waterfront industry reform strategy and enterprise based agreements.

What is of concern are the costs of negotiating and implementing the reforms. Yes, there will be a saving eventually to users when new rosters and productivity improvements eventuate. But what Julian Manser said quite categorically on page 12 was `It is too early to be estimating tariff rate reductions', although he assures users that any financial benefits the industry derives will be passed on to users because of market pressure. I recommend Julian Manser's speech to the Senate for careful perusal. Honourable senators will find it very revealing.

The enterprise based agreements negotiated by National Terminals (Australia) Ltd with the waterfront unions have been long and tortuous. Let me briefly outline to the Senate the steps by which the agreement was reached as Julian Manser set them out in his speech. By February 1991 National Terminals had had 100 meetings with the unions and it had achieved a signed document of over 200 pages. That document represents the final enterprise agreement. The National Terminals enterprise agreement was approved by the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority in December last year.

Implementation commenced finally at the end of January when the agreed ship manning levels and work practices were adopted. Note the word `adopted', not `implemented'. It was admitted that the agreed manning levels would not be implemented for some months while training and multiskilling were progressively introduced. In fact, Julian Manser said that in the early stages there would be an actual increase in idle time while the surpluses in the work force were identified. In mid-February Mr Manser thought that the surplus labour would be removed to the transitory labour lists or removed from the industry under the Government's redundancy package. Nothing further happens until March 1992, when negotiations will occur to decide the future of those employees who are on the transitory labour lists.

Therefore, despite the much vaunted statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) about the two enterprise based agreements achieved to date, nothing has really happened, and the Minister knows nothing has happened. All that National Terminals has is a document, and it faces very significant costs, as I have pointed out during the past two days-the costs of reclassification, retraining and multiskilling as well as the investment in new technology and new equipment.
To make the point very clearly, let me quote again from the latest annual report of the wholly Government-owned Australian National Line:
By comparison with the progress of shipping reform, criticism of the pace of waterfront reform is justified.

As a major Australian ship-operator ANL's shipping competitiveness continues to be seriously handicapped by waterfront inefficiencies. Waterfront costs constitute 50%-60% of total door-to-door shipping costs on the short, but important, sea routes, e.g. Bass Strait and the Tasman.
Now its own subsidiary, National Terminals (Australia), has told it quite categorically that it cannot expect any relief in the short term.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! On 20 February, Senator Bishop sought certain information from the President in relation to security arrangements at Parliament House. The President has prepared a statement in response to the questions posed by Senator Bishop. With the concurrence of the Senate, the statement will be incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: The statement read as follows-

During debate on 20 February on a motion to take note of a statement I had made in response to a question by Senator Bishop relating to security arrangements at Parliament House, the honourable Senator referred to a number of additional matters to which I will now respond in turn.

Senator Bishop expressed her concern that I had not been advised about a scuffle which occurred among the demonstrators at the front of Parliament House on Sunday, 17 February. The Australian Protective Service has reported that the incident involved two or three people engaged in a shouting match, which included bad language, and some pushing and shoving. I understand no punches were thrown. I do not believe that an incident of this nature warranted a special report to the Speaker and me.

The duration of protests at Parliament House is not something over which I have control, neither would I wish to have control. My only concern is to ensure that protests are orderly and do not threaten injury to people or damage to property.

Senator Bishop referred to the unrestricted access to the public underground carpark. While few restrictions can be effective in such a public area, the carpark is equipped with closed-circuit television monitors, is regularly patrolled and is subjected to a detailed search daily. Short of closing it down, I am satisfied that all prudent measures had been taken and continue to be taken to ensure its security.
On the general subject of underground carparks it is worth noting that, following security advice during the design of this building, none of the carparks is under any part of Parliament House.

As Senator Bishop has stated, I have been advised that six people connected with the anti-war demonstration spent part of the night of 21 January in the public underground carpark. They had initially sought to camp under the verandah at the main entrance because of the threat of rain. They were advised by the Australian Protective Service officer on duty that they could not sleep within the precincts.

Honourable Senators will recall that impassioned anti-war demonstrations had occurred earlier in the day. In attempting to avoid further confrontation with the demonstrators, the officer advised the six people that in the event of rain they could shelter in the carpark. I accept that the officer's actions, while contrary to the guidelines, were reasonable in the circumstances. No one has been permitted to sleep in the carpark since that date. The Australian Protective Service has advised that demonstrators' goods and chattels have not been left unattended in the carpark.

Australian Protective Service officers on duty at Parliament House are employed under an arrangement between the Presiding Officers and the Minister administering the Service. Pursuant to that arrangement, and in respect of the Australian Protective Service, the Speaker and I exercise our responsibility for the control and management of security in the precincts through the Security Controller. Because of the need for effective co-ordination of security arrangements among the Senate, House of Representatives and the Ministry and with the police and intelligence services, the Security Controller is well-placed to exercise control over the Protective Service officers on duty in the precincts. The Speaker and I receive regular reports from the Security Controller and we are immediately advised of any serious matters.

There would appear to be some misunderstanding about the number of holding cells in Parliament House. I have stated previously that there are two. Provision was made in the original design of the building for an additional two cells in the basement of the Ministerial Wing. Construction of those cells was not completed. Those areas are without doors and could not be used as cells. They are currently used as an office and storage area.

Senator Bishop also referred to an incident which involved a member of her staff who had parked a vehicle adjacent to the Senate entrance to the building. In my statement on 20 February, I said that the Speaker and I had accepted advice that vehicles should not be permitted to remain unattended in the immediate vicinity of the entrances to the building.

Investigations have revealed that on 28 January a car was found to be parked at the Senate entrance contrary to the parking restrictions in force. The Parliamentary Security Attendant on duty immediately requested the security control room to arrange for a check of the vehicle's registration number. The Attendant recognised the name of the vehicle's owner to be the same as a person who had previously been signed into the building by a member of Senator Bishop's staff. A call to the Senator's office resulted in the vehicle being removed immediately.
I wish to assure Senator Bishop that the normal course of action was followed in tracing the driver of the vehicle.

These matters having been raised by Senator Bishop, I take the opportunity to advise the Senate that the Speaker and I, prior to the end of the 1990 Budget Sittings, approved a contingency plan which comprised a range of measures to be implemented in the event of increased levels of threat to Parliament House. Security of the building was increased following an assessment of increased threats stemming from Australia's involvement in the Gulf War.

In tightening the security of the building, several valuable lessons have been learned about the efficacy of the security procedures. Given that experience, all procedures are to be reviewed and altered where necessary to improve their effectiveness in providing appropriate levels of security for Parliament House.
14 March 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tierney has come very late to this debate in every sense of the word. I guess one of his other problems is that he got so carried away with being able to deliver a maiden speech without getting a biff under the ear that he may well have thought--
—First speech.

—I have been in this business for 15 years and old habits die hard. He delivered his maiden speech in this chamber and thought that he would not get a biff under the ear in any other speech that he delivered. Allow me to give him his first biff under the ear, Mr Deputy President.
—We are all terrified. Ha, ha!
—Does Senator Baume want to prolong this for longer at a quarter past 12 in the morning?
—He caught you out.

—I will let Senator Baume interject all night. I am going to the airport at half past five so it does not worry me. I am not going home tonight. Senator Tierney is not up to date because a lot has happened in the six months since he read those documents, including changes to the transitional labour lists.
—What about the letter you tabled which did not support your claim?
—Come on, get on with it.
—Order! Senator Collins has the floor.

—I am not going to respond to interjections, and if honourable senators opposite wish at a quarter past 12 in the morning, I will just stay here until I finish. Senator Tierney talked about arrangements that were part of the original process-which were, in fact, some of the `structural difficulties' that I identified with the process last year and which we have been successfully able to negotiate our way out of. Senator Tierney would have had no more firm an advocate of concern about the slowness of waterfront reform last year than me. I think I stated that at every industry function I publicly addressed in order to put the maximum pressure on the process.

SPEECH.PARA: I need to identify very clearly, and it is not hard, the panic stricken reaction that the Opposition is delivering at the moment on waterfront reform for what it is. We had it again in the House of Representatives this evening from Mr Sharp, when he ran the piece of nonsense, for the fourth time, that the Conaust agreement, successful as it is-and, of course, that is the problem-when it is consummated will have been done outside the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority process, rather than inside.

Of course, the real difficulty is very clear indeed. The Opposition's position on waterfront reform is that it does not want it to succeed; it wants it to fail. Senator Macdonald, of course, over the last 12 months has been one of the greatest white ants of the process. The Opposition is not interested in the national good, it is not interested in any real productivity gains; it wants it to fall in a heap.

As I said in the Senate the other day, there is a particular view in this country that really irritates me-and the Opposition is the foremost advocate of it-and that is this: if one goes into a negotiation with a union to get some improvements in the workplace, one does that as we have done with the shipping industry reform program-which everyone inside the industry acknowledges to me every time they see me as being spectacularly successful in terms of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!
—Can I quote the honourable senator? Shipping reform?
—Compared to other ports?

—Why does the honourable senator not go and have a drink? We are not talking about ports. We are talking about the shipping reform program of the Government. I know the honourable senator cannot tell the difference between a ship and a port.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy President, even though the success has been acknowledged, there has hardly been any publicity or credit given to it at all, which is something that the participants find very frustrating. Why? Because it was all achieved without any industrial disputation. It is a major problem we have in this country, and it is being pushed--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have still got massive overmanning.

—We have brought average crewing levels down from an average of 33 per ship to 25 currently, and currently running nine months ahead of schedule. It will be 21 by the middle of this year, the equivalent of any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development nation, and on all the technologically advanced ships that are now coming into service, in the biggest re-equipment of the Australian fleet ever in history-$1 billion worth of new ships commissioned-it will be down to 18 within 12 months. I am afraid we cannot get it down much lower than that without putting robots on board.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Opposition's benchmark of success in the maritime industry? I will tell honourable senators what it is. If we go into a negotiation process and get a 50 per cent improvement in productivity by negotiation without a stoush, without a day lost in industrial disputation, that is classified as a failure. But if one wants to get hairy-chested, take on the unions, have a brawl, and get 25 per cent, that would be classified as being a huge success because there has been a stoush with the unions. These people measure success in waterfront reform not by the number of extra containers lifted per hour but by the amount of union blood that is spilt on the wharf.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—It is absolute nonsense; I agree absolutely with the honourable senator. It is nonsense. If it is done without a stoush it has to be a failure. The Opposition has a real problem. It is now absolutely terrified, having seen the comments made by Captain Richard Setchell, knowing that the Conaust agreement is about to be delivered, that in fact we will actually get real reform on the waterfront-something it has been running terrified of seeing achieved for 12 months. The Opposition does not want it; it wants cheap political point scoring. The Opposition does not want reform on the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as Senator Tierney's understanding of Julian Manser's speech is concerned, I will explain it to him in very simple terms. I will give Senator Tierney a very interesting quote from the Prices Surveillance Authority which is involved in monitoring whether these savings will be passed on to the users. Julian Manser, quite correctly, said that there will be some additional costs short term in award restructuring. He said that there will be some additional costs short term in multi-skilling but that they will produce gains for users in the long term which will be eroded if port authorities engage in opportunistic lifting of their port charges to take up the slack. That is what he said. It is absolutely correct.

Senator Tierney ran a piece of nonsense in here yesterday where he actually said that the $60m worth of new investment that National Terminals (Australia) Ltd is putting into what will then be the most modern terminal facility in Australia was a cost that eroded the benefits of waterfront reform. He read it out yesterday. What a piece of arrant nonsense. That is precisely what this Government is trying to achieve.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a cost that flows through.

—Senator Tierney has said it again-it is a cost of the program; it is a cost initially. What a piece of nonsense. National Terminals is putting $60m worth of new investment into a totally rejuvenated terminal facility in Sydney directly because of the success of the waterfront reform program. Senator Tierney, who I am told has some qualifications in education, continues now in this debate to say that that is a cost of the program-$60m worth of new investment that is going to erode the gains for the users.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me tell you, Mr Deputy President, what the Prices Surveillance Authority (PSA) had to say about that. In its report the Authority first of all finds that there was little justification for claims of excessive charges in the stevedoring industry and therefore formal surveillance by the PSA was not warranted. It also recognises that additional costs imposed by the reform process would offset some of the savings in the short term. The Authority says that retraining and multi-skilling will impose additional labour costs but:
. . . will confer a substantial long term productivity improvement on stevedoring operations with subsequent scope for further reductions in stevedoring charges in the medium term.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have made no immediate gain.

—Senator Tierney has never been the same since his frontal lobotomy. How can this senator, with any credibility, continue to assert-while a company, because of the savings that it gets, decides to carry out the biggest rejuvenation of the terminal in Sydney ever seen; a $60m new investment into the port-that that is a cost of the waterfront reform program that is going to be of no benefit to the users? I think the interjections in the Hansard will speak for themselves; it is nonsense. The PSA also recognised that productivity improvements will be enhanced by increased capital expenditure such as the National Terminals investment.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by taking up another piece of nonsense delivered in the House of Representatives tonight. Mr Sharp, the shadow Minister for waterfront reform-

TALK.START.PARA: —He is badly named.

—Indeed; that is all he has got to do. He put out a press statement the day before yesterday saying that the Conaust agreement had been negotiated outside of the waterfront industry reform program and that there was no mention of any involvement of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in the agreement. Of course, the motivation for Mr Sharp saying that is, having noted the statement of Captain Richard Setchell about what that agreement is going to deliver, that the Opposition is absolutely terrified that it is actually going to succeed.

SPEECH.PARA: Even at this last gasp when one of the most public critics of the process-that is, Captain Richard Setchell-has delivered the statement he has, instead of just accepting that, a little more white-anting goes on. I want to take you, Mr Deputy President, through a Dr John Hewson approach to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —This will be silly.
—It will not be silly--

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy President at this interlude in the Minister's contribution: only a couple of minutes ago the Minister referred to the matter of the Hansard reflecting Senator Tierney's interjections. The point of order is that Senator Collins referred to Senator Tierney by saying that he had never been the same since he had had a frontal lobotomy, which I consider to be unparliamentary. It should be withdrawn so that it does not appear in the Hansard.
—It takes a while for the penny to drop.

—Senator Campbell, I accept your point of order. You are very late with your point of order. If you want to make a such a point of order in future, you should do it immediately. Senator Collins, would you withdraw that statement?

—Absolutely, unconditionally. The reason Mr Sharp put that statement out is that he is frightened. I will take a leaf out of Dr Hewson's book. Despite the interjections of my colleagues, I do have a number of things in common with Dr Hewson, apart from our obvious physical similarities. I will take the same approach that Dr Hewson does. I will give the same offer to Mr Sharp as he does to us. As soon as Mr Sharp says something positive, reasonable, sensible and supportive about the waterfront industry reform program, I will publicly support him. We will cast it out into the electorate like a lure after a barramundi, which Dr Hewson does. We will wait to see whether there is a nibble. If there is no nibble we will reel it back in again. I am quite happy to adopt that approach with Mr Sharp. If he says something sensible I will publicly support him.

SPEECH.PARA: So far, and this is a matter of record, Mr Sharp has not issued one single public statement-and I have a file full of them-on waterfront or shipping reform that has not been absolutely wrong, factually. To my astonishment, he did it again last night and he has repeated it in the House of Representatives this evening.

I got up in the Senate and referred to clause 4 of the agreement. I said, `I can't understand why Mr Sharp makes these outrageous claims because the specific reference in the agreement to the involvement of the Commission is on the first page of that agreement', and it is. I read it out. Mr Sharp issued another press statement last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no!

—Oh, yes, wait for this. Last night Mr Sharp conceded that the in principle agreement did contain a reference to the Industrial Commission. Oh, yes, he has made some progress! In his press release issued last night he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The IPA included one reference to the Industrial Relations Act . . . which enterprises or unions may refer disputes for arbitration.

I am not quite sure what the relevance is of having to say it six times. If it is in the agreement it is in the agreement. Mr Sharp, having finally read the agreement, thought this was a matter of some great note. He said it was in there. That was a step forward from the statement of the day before when he said it was not. In his press release he went on to say that the one reference in the agreement to the Industrial Commission was in clause 4 of the agreement.

If only Mr Sharp had screwed his courage to the sticking place and had just taken one small step further. I refer to clause 5 of the agreement. I know personally, because I spent 10 years there myself, that being in opposition is sometimes hard, but it is not that hard. If Mr Sharp cannot have enough interest in his own shadow portfolio to do even a little bit of work then perhaps at least he should hire a press secretary who can. He made the statement, not me. Two days ago he said there was no reference. Last night he said there was one reference but it was only in clause 4.

Clause 5 of the agreement not only specifically mentions the Industrial Commission but also lays down the full process for resolving disputes under the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, which I can say categorically Conaust followed to the letter. Clause 5.2, subparagraph (d), of the in principle agreement says that if things get sticky any party can go to WIRA and seek assistance. Clause 5.3 says that if that fails they can go to the Commission.

Conaust not only did that but the two chief executives of Conaust, Richard Hein and Richard Setchell, came to see me in Canberra before they went to the Commission. They had a meeting with me in my office. It was in October, from memory.
