They said, `We want to know if you as the Government are satisfied that we have complied with all of the processes laid down in the Government's program in the in principle agreement. If you think there is any point in having further private negotiations-and we have followed the agreement to the letter-then we will, if you think that is worth while. But if you agree that that process has been effectively exhausted and we should now go to 5.3 in the agreement and seek the assistance of the Commission in getting a conciliated settlement to the six outstanding issues, we will'.

I said to them, `I agree with you that there is no point in having any more private conferences. You have been to WIRA as required under this agreement. You now have the right to go to the Commission. Not only do I say that you should do that but we will intervene in the Commission and put the Government's position to that hearing', and that is exactly what we did. It is beyond argument that the Commission processes are an absolute integral part of the arrangements laid down for reform of the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —Won't they let you put down a ministerial statement on this so that you don't have to speak on the adjournment?

—Let me say this in response: if the Opposition wants to bring senators in here at 12.15 in the morning to attack me and to attack this program, they can expect a rebuttal on the last sitting night when we are getting up for three weeks. If I hear nonsense delivered, I am going to correct it. We not only had the nonsense delivered in the Senate but we also had it simultaneously delivered in the House of Representatives. To my total astonishment, a couple of hours ago, Mr Sharp repeated, in his response to the industry statement, the same nonsense about the Conaust agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that he said it because the clear inference is that he acknowledges that this agreement is significant and that it is going to do what Captain Setchell says it will. He says that it will turn the Australian waterfront into an efficient, reliable and competitive industry. The Opposition is terrified of that prospect being realised and even at this last gasp is attempting to white-ant the process and discredit it. It does the Opposition no credit that it continues to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure you have an agreement?

—No. In response to that interjection, I am not sure that we have an agreement, and I will not be sure that we have an agreement until it has been drafted and signed. That interjection has as much relevance as the idiot delivery we had from Senator Macdonald when he attacked the union the night before they went back into the Commission-and it is in the transcript-and confidently predicted that the unions would reject Commissioner Sweeney's recommendations the following morning and bring the process down.
—That is a deliberate lie.
—Senator Macdonald will withdraw that now.
—Order! Senator Macdonald will withdraw that statement.
—I withdraw it.

—I do not want to detain the Senate much longer, and I will not. I simply conclude by saying that the Government has noted the commitments that have been given by the Waterside Workers Federation-and this is in response to Senator Tierney's interjection-inside and outside the Commission by Tas Bull, that both the union and the company will agree to abide by Commissioner Sweeney's recommendations and will put together a working group to draft the agreement. The first all day meeting of that working group was today and tonight I received a report from the company negotiator, not the union, who told me that it had been an extremely successful day's negotiation. Sorry about that, senator.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will not believe the agreement exists, as I did not believe the National Terminals agreement exists, until it is through WIRA and has been formally approved and signed by the parties. That is when I will believe it.

The parties know that the Government expects both the company and the unions to honour the commitments they have given in the Commission and outside the Commission. I have absolutely no reason to believe that they will not do such a thing.

I want to conclude by putting a view from the docks about the waterfront reform program in respect of the non-stop interjections we have heard here tonight and the tenor of them, which totally singled out the unions for the blame, constantly said the company is the shining knight, said that it is always the union's fault and attacked the unions-even the night before they were due to go into the Commission to agree or not agree to this very important agreement.

I will tell honourable senators what the blokes down on the docks say to me, and they have said it to me in the last six months. They say, `Why should we have any interest or incentive to cooperate and deliver A-grade reform in this country when we are going to get attacked no matter what we do?'. They are attacked by the Opposition, attacked by the National Farmers Federation and attacked by the Australian Shipping Users Group.

As I said earlier in the debate, I have a letter from an industry group complaining about the manning reductions we achieved in a grain handling terminal port where the manning reductions were 80 per cent of the work force and where WIRA, the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority, had recommended an absolute minimum number required to work the port. The union agreed to reduce it down to that number, a reduction of 80 per cent, and I received a letter saying that it was inadequate, it was not good enough.

If that is going to be the benchmark constantly applied-there is a fair bit of feeling on the docks-it will not help the negotiating process. In a perfect world it should not matter, but in the real world it does matter, and the people there say, `Look, why don't we just deliver the basics? Why don't we just give the minimum we have to? Let us give a C-grade result because, as far as we are concerned, in terms of the public abuse we have copped non-stop, there is no difference for us. If we deliver an A-grade result, we get abused; we might as well get a C-grade result and get the same abuse'.

I have to say, with respect, that that is a view which I think in the current circumstances is valid. Fortunately, that view is not shared by the union leadership, which is taking a longer term view, but I understand the frustration of the people in the workplace who express that view to me. That is what members of the rank and file are saying. But the union leadership is taking an extremely responsible attitude. It believes-and I think it is right-that the judgment of this nation at the end of the day will be whether the actual dollars and cents productivity is being delivered; that will be the real measure, and people will acknowledge or not acknowledge, based on that, whether the union's involvement in this process has been a positive or negative one. That is the benchmark that I apply to it.

In conclusion, I have no doubt that the Conaust agreement will be delivered. When it is delivered in accordance with the undertakings given in the Commission, it will immediately give rise to the Conaust agreements being delivered in all of the other ports in which they operate around Australia. Halfway through this year we can confidently look forward to a situation where 80 per cent of the entire waterfront work force is in fact actively engaged in implementing the reform program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, pursuant to Standing Orders, I wish to make a personal explanation that I was being deliberately misquoted by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), who I see is now running out of the chamber. I told the Senator that that was a deliberate lie, and you, Mr Deputy President, made me withdraw that, which I did quite willingly. It was a complete and deliberate mis-truth on the part of the Minister. I have been out to get the Hansard. The Minister is crawling away.
—Order! I think you should use acceptable language.

—I am sorry. The Minister has left in the middle of the explanation because he knows quite well that what he said was a deliberate mistruth and misstatement of my position. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to address a matter of some serious concern to people right across Australia but particularly in Western Australia. The matter relates to actions of the Custom Credit Corporation in Western Australia and the way in which that group has managed its commercial property mortgages and associated facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I do not intend to pursue the specific cases, as there are now many of them, and a number of those cases are before the courts and others will be going before the courts before too long. I do not want to prejudge the legality of the actions of Custom Credit or its clients in these matters. What I seek to do is to raise the matters that do require public attention and resolution.

At the outset it is important to note that many of the difficulties being experienced in the commercial world-and most cruelly evident in the commercial property development world-are the result of mismanagement of economic policy by the Hawke-Keating Government. These policies caused a runaway boom and then runaway interest rates to slow that boom. To paraphrase what Senator Button and Mr Keating have said of late: the brakes were left off for a bit too long and now clearly the brakes have been put on a bit too hard.

One only needs to glance at figures for building activity, absorption rates of retail or office space in capital cities and commercial prime lending rates over the past five or six years to see what a rough place Australia currently is to do business. Of course, I particularly refer to commercial property development.

I have received detailed representations and documents from many constituents in Western Australia who are quite dismayed by their treatment by Custom Credit. They detail a number of matters concerning the handling of loans and facilities during this period of recession and associated asset price depreciation.

I will briefly visit the history of Custom Credit in Western Australia over the last couple of years. During the 1988-89 period, Custom Credit in Western Australia aggressively expanded its property loan book to in the vicinity of $350m. To place that in some context, Western Australia has a population of only 1.2 million people. By way of comparison, New South Wales has a population of approximately six million people and, in that State, Custom Credit's property loan book is in the vicinity of $180m, nearly half of the Western Australia loan book in a much larger State.

This aggressive and seemingly successful Western Australia expansion was strongly supported by the national management of Custom Credit. During 1989 and 1990 a dramatic downturn has occurred in the property market, a downturn which, I suggest to the Senate, is yet to show its full consequences and repercussions across Australia. This downturn is reflected in office vacancy rates in the major capitals-by way of example-which in most major capitals is approaching 20 per cent within the next 12 months. If we put that in terms which people driving past our skylines can understand, it means that virtually one in every five buildings we look at will be empty by the end of this year.

In 1990 a very radical change took place in the management of the Western Australian office of Custom Credit, with the Western Australian team being sacked and a new team, comprising eastern States operatives, taking control. During the past nine months or so this team seems to have approached the task of reducing the size of its property loan book-that is, its exposure in Western Australia-with some great gusto, and this is where the problems start to occur.

The representations from my constituents inform me that agreements they had made with the former management of Custom Credit have been totally ignored. Specifically, with the financing of property developments, where it is a not uncommon practice to capitalise interest during the construction phase of a project, such arrangements entered into by the previous management have been totally ignored and thrown aside by the new management team. Payment of interest has been demanded of these people, and where this has not been made a foreclosure has ensued. I have also been informed that in a number of cases Custom Credit in Western Australia has approached clients and sought more security-that is, collateral-for its existing facilities. Custom Credit has used the inducement of threatening to withdraw its existing facilities if this extra security is not given. In some cases, this is extra security over people's private homes and other possessions.

Some of these clients had reluctantly agreed to provide this security, only to find a few days later that their facilities had been withdrawn anyway. This action has, of course, forced sales of all the property owned by the people in question. It would seem that the motive is obviously to reduce the size of the company's exposure as rapidly as possible.

I seek to make no judgment on the legality or otherwise of these actions-that is something properly for the courts to decide. But a recent decision in the Supreme Court of Victoria has found that banks may be forced to honour loan agreements reached by staff members and cannot unilaterally dishonour or change these agreements to suit their needs. In the case I refer to, which was reported in the Australian property pages, I think it was, in January 1991, Justice Ormiston in the Supreme Court of Victoria found against the ANZ Bank in favour of a Melbourne property developer, Logan Swan and Associates Pty Ltd, which claimed that the bank had breached an agreement with the developer because it apparently wanted to review its security position on the loan.

In many development situations, as in the case of Logan Swan in Victoria, the developer requires the commitment and support of the lender all the way through the life of the project. In the case of my constituents in Western Australia, when Custom Credit executives do decide to withdraw an interest capitalising facility the developer has absolutely no source of funds. This places extreme pressure on the developer, who already has contracts with builders, architects, subcontractors and all the other associated professionals involved in building any commercial property.

In the current property development environment, with the normal construction delays that we are used to in Australia, caused by our dismal industrial relations regime and compounded further by the broader economic environment, developers are totally at the mercy of their lenders. If the pin is pulled on the developer before the project is finished, generally the developer has no source of funds even to fight a legal battle. This is the situation that so many of my constituents find themselves in with Custom Credit in Western Australia.

This raises the cost of justice questions that have been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I think these matters should be investigated by that Committee. Senator O'Chee does not want any more references to the Committee, but I will seek to provide details of these cases to the Committee for its consideration.

The other question on which it focuses attention is the prudential supervisory environment that has clearly not adapted to the post-deregulatory era. Custom Credit in its annual report, released in November last year, made provision for doubtful debts of $87.6m across all its divisions-including property, retail and other divisions. In a press release dated 28 February 1991, the National Australia Bank, which owns Custom Credit, announced a virtual doubling of this provision for bad and doubtful debts-that is, an increase of another $87m for Custom Credit. I think we would all agree that that is an unusually large increase in the provision for doubtful debts in a period of only three months.

The National Bank also announced that it would absorb the management and assets of Custom Credit's Property Division after these provisions are made. I am informed that, in making the original provisions for bad debts, the Western Australian Property Division of Custom Credit submitted a figure of $11.4m. Former Custom Credit executives believe that the provision for the Property Division should have been in the vicinity of $40m or $50m for Western Australia alone. This again raises serious questions about the whole operations of Custom Credit in Western Australia and, of course, the prudential supervisory requirements which I referred to earlier.

It is fair to say that many clients of banks and financial institutions around Australia will today find themselves in hopeless financial circumstances as a consequence of factors such as the boom mentality of the late 1980s, the crushing interest rates of 1989-90, and now the recession of 1991-the recession we were all promised we would not have but are now told we had to have. In many circumstances mortgagee auctions and business closures are the result and are the only course of action that the bank or the financial institution can take because the cases are so hopeless. But in other cases, where equity or reasonable expectations of commercial returns in future are evident, lenders can and do seek an arrangement to manage the borrowers through these troubled times.

The variations between the two options-that is, closing people down and selling them up, or managing them through the troubled times-are varied, and these are clearly a matter for the lending institutions and their clients to come to agreement on. But I put it to the Senate that the actions of these lending institutions properly deserve rigorous public scrutiny. I believe that the matters I have raised in relation to Custom Credit in Western Australia-particularly its Property Division-deserve close scrutiny, and accordingly I will seek to put all the information and documents I have on the cases I have referred to briefly in the Senate this evening before the House of Representatives Committee on Finance and Public Administration inquiry into the Australian banking industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators who read the Sydney Morning Herald may have seen the lead article last Saturday on page one, under the headline, `Middle East Arms Race on Again'. The great search for peace, spearheaded by United States Secretary of State, James Baker, was also an exercise in justifying the resumption of multimillion dollar arms sales to Washington's Middle East allies. It seems to be incredibly stupid after the havoc that has been wrought by weapons systems on both sides of the political divide in the war that has just finished-at least in the direct sense. It could be a shopping list worth $US30 billion, as the Administration has already reportedly submitted to Congress a classified report indicating that it is considering $US18 billion in arms sales to Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Egypt and Turkey.

SPEECH.PARA: The Saudi deal, in two stages, could ultimately be worth $US21 billion and includes F15 aircraft, Patriot missiles, Apache anti-tank helicopters, 400 MI-A1 tanks and 500 Bradley armoured fighting vehicles. These are all familiar household names now that we have been sanitised into the jargon of high tech weapons. At the same time, Israel is claiming that Syria is set to receive more Scud missiles from North Korea. These have a range of 500 kilometres, having been improved by the North Koreans, and can carry warheads nearly three times heavier than those used by Iraq. Israel is reportedly locked in negotiations with the United States to obtain four Patriot missile batteries worth a total of least $US400m. No wonder shares in Raytheon, which make the Patriot missile, have gone up from $US12 to $US75, while shares in General Dynamics have gone up almost 50 per cent in recent weeks.

War is always profitable for the merchants of death. Yet it was not so long ago, on 6 February, that we heard Senator Robert Ray addressing the National Press Club here in Canberra acknowledging that most of the Iraqi equipment that faced the coalition was supplied by the major powers themselves. He also observed that:
A major lesson for the future relates to the need to control and reduce the international arms trade.
Further on, he commented:
Priority will have to be given to controlling the trade in weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems.

Another warning appeared in the Canberra Times on 5 March this year when columnist Tom Connors asked, `Has the West learned a lesson?' Bluntly, he referred to the arms trade as a blot on modern civilisation. He admits that it would be virtually impossible--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 187 that a senator shall not read a speech. I notice that Senator Vallentine is doing just that.

—I must admit that I had not been paying careful attention as to whether Senator Vallentine was reading her speech. I was paying careful attention to her speech. I shall pay careful attention now. I am sure that Senator Vallentine is aware of the standing order.

—I am and I was actually quoting directly from newspaper articles in the last few comments that I just made. Again, I am quoting from columnist Tom Connors when he asked, `Has the West learned a lesson?' Bluntly, he referred to the arms trade as a blot on modern civilisation. He admits that it would be virtually impossible to stop the illegal arms trade, but asks:

SPEECH.PARA: How about the so-called civilised nations of the world doing something, presumably through the United Nations, to stop governments selling arms holus-bolus to everybody. It is time the lesson was learned or are the Western nations happy to have their own troops attacked with the weapons they sold to despots?

Further afield, in September last year the Washington Post ran an excellent article entitled `Arms in the New World Order' by Haynes Johnson. The writer said that the Gulf conflict was about oil, about a critical juncture in history-according to the Secretary of State-and about arms, though not nearly enough has been heard about that perspective. He went on to say:

It is self-evident that oil, lifeblood of the industrial world, and the necessity to forge a new order to preserve peace and guarantee global stability are among the principal stakes facing the United States.
It is not as obvious, but should be, that in the long run, how America deals with curbing the flow of arms in the world's tinderboxes may be even more important.
Last week, Newsweek magazine carried a feature item on lessons we must learn from the Gulf war. I quote:
In all the euphoria over America's triumph in the Gulf, one thing shouldn't be forgotten: This war could have been avoided.

If Western States hadn't armed Iraq to the teeth, if Washington hadn't misjudged Saddam's designs on Kuwait, if Americans weren't so hooked on cheap Middle Eastern oil, the United States might not have had to send over a half-million troops to fight Operation Desert Storm.
The article dealt with the arms bazaar as the first mistake not to be repeated. The article went on to say:
To keep Saddam or any other menace from acquiring that kind of war machine again, there must be new limits on arms exports to the Middle East and other Third World hot spots.

Those are brave words well spoken, but of course it will not be easy. I have already spoken at some length on the weapons sold to Iraq in the 1980s by anyone and everyone and Australia's attempt to come in after the cease-fire in 1988-that is, the cease-fire of the Iran-Iraq war-and to sell aircraft spare parts to the Iraqi air force which dropped chemical weapons--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I again raise standing order 187 regarding the reading of a speech.
—I shall pay careful attention again.

—As I was saying, the Iraqi air force, to which the Australian Government was attempting to sell spare parts, was the same air force which presumably dropped chemical weapons on the Kurds in 1988. So our hands are far from clean.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Robert Ray said that the parts were only for trainer aircraft, but the fact is that the pilots trained in those planes will be the pilots who fight in the next war in the Gulf. It could be a war which involves Iraq and its neighbours, maybe Israel, oppression of the Kurds in the north or the Shiite Moslems in the south, as we are seeing unfolding right now. But we would share in the responsibility, even though it meant an $850,000 contract for Hawker de Havilland in Australia. I guess that is meant to justify Australia's participation. It does not, in my estimation. Perhaps after Senator Robert Ray's change of heart things might be different as far as Australia is concerned. I certainly hope so.

The litmus test will be to see if the Minister does as he has indicated he is considering-that is to withdraw Government support from the AIDEX exhibition which is due to be held in Canberra in November this year-and to see if the export control guidelines will be tightened this week when the Committee finishes its deliberations.

These will be two test points for the Minister's sentiments, as expressed in the National Press Club address of 6 February. It would be nice if Australia were to bow out of the arms trade, just as Denmark was the first country to abolish the slave trade back in the late eighteenth century. We should take a lead, along with Czechoslovakia, in banning the international arms trade because we cannot expect the major players to move first. Somebody has to set the standard, and I think that Australia should be one of those countries to do so.

It remains a fact, however, that the United States and the Soviet Union account for almost two-thirds of global arms sales. That is why it is so depressing to see not only Secretary of State Baker justifying a new round of arms sales in the Middle East but also United States Defense Secretary Dick Cheney defending the need to sell US arms to Saudi Arabia, this time to follow up a deal worth $15 billion on top of last year's $9 billion deal.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy President, and this may be third time lucky: I refer to standing order 187, `Speeches not to be read'.

—I do accept that Senator Vallentine has copious notes. Senator Vallentine is not reading all the time because I notice her looking at the Chair. I would rule at this stage that Senator Vallentine is using copious notes and ask her to continue.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. Unfortunately, this is the contradiction we face and one of the lessons of the Gulf war which we will ignore at our peril in the future. One of the claims that has been made very clearly from the coalition's point of view is that might is right-it pays to be well armed and, if you have the cash, you get the latest high-tech military equipment. Of course, so do your neighbours.

SPEECH.PARA: I must admit that I share the pessimism of Professor Michael Klare from the University of Massachusetts who was interviewed on the P.M. program on 4 March. He told P.M. that he was pessimistic about the chances for a comprehensive arms control agreement, mainly because the United States had made all kinds of promises to countries like Israel, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Turkey, to the effect that they would get arms in exchange for their assistance in the cashbox coalition.

The US role as the world's most prolific and diversified arms trafficker is so well entrenched that it has come to be taken for granted, as if it were a natural state of affairs not subject to political analysis or public debate. Before the recent US- Soviet rapprochement, US arms sales, particularly those to Third World nations, were routinely justified as essential tools in the global struggle for position and influence against the Soviet Union and its allies.

The dangers inherent in transferring advanced military technology to a series of dictatorial and frequently unstable regimes in the Third World have generally been overlooked by United States policy makers preoccupied with larger policy goals such as combating the Soviet Union and its allies and keeping the Third World safe for US investment and trade. The popularity of arms transfers is rooted in powerful, strategic, political and economic interests that have so far blocked any meaningful efforts to exert congressional control or to encourage public scrutiny of the real impact of America's arms sales habit. In what is probably the ultimate strategic folly, United States policy makers have frequently armed both sides of a potential conflict in an attempt to create or maintain a balance of power favourable to United States interests.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) (i) Costs for each centre will vary according to size and function, with annual cost expected to be between about $300 000 and $500 000 per centre per annum. Costs could be expected to increase over the next three years in line with price and wage movements.
(ii) Community organisations will be funded to establish and operate Family Resource Centres (FRCs) with 6 to 8 staff, in areas of socio-economic disadvantage, to:
* ensure more co-ordinated delivery of services for families by working with family-related services provided in the area by all levels of government and non-government agencies;
* improve service delivery to individual families by linking them to appropriate services and support, and improving the effectiveness and responsiveness of those services;
* provide feedback to services on user rights, access difficulties for families, demographic change and other issues observed in dealing with families;
* promote prevention and early intervention strategies;
* consult with, and involve, family service users and their advocates in all aspects of service provision;
* provide feed-back to Government and the community on the effectiveness of the range of programs provided for families;
* promote greater awareness among service providers of the special needs of people from non-English speaking backgrounds, disabled people, Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders;
* increase the Commonwealth's awareness of regional and local issues; and
* be an integral part of the local community, involving and encouraging the participation of families and service providers in the processes outlined above.
Each FRC will be expected to define its own particular focus and major functions within the limitations of the available resources utilising knowledge of the local area and its needs.

(iii) State and Territory Governments have been invited to provide advice on suitable locations for FRCs. Four locations in South Australia and Queensland were recently approved- Elizabeth/Salisbury/Munno Para (SA), Ipswich (Qld), Logan (Qld) and Cairns (Qld).
(iv) Family Resource Centres will be accessible to all families with children in the area and to providers of local family related services.
(1) (b) No estimates have been made of the numbers of families and children expected to benefit from each centre at this stage.

It is expected that the FRCs will bring about lasting improvements in the way that services in the identified areas work together to provide support for families and enhance service delivery outcomes. All existing and potential users of these services stand to benefit through more effective and efficient delivery of services.

(2) (a) 17 500 new places is the target for 1990-91 (not 12 500). These will be provided in Centre Based Long Day Care (CBLDC), 700 to 800 places; Family Day Care (FDC), 2 500 to 2 800 places; Occasional Care (OCC), 700 to 800 places; and Outside School Hours Care (OSHC), 13 000 to 13 500 places.

(b) The precise location of these places is not known. Places are allocated on the basis of advice from the Children's Services Planning Committees in each State. These Committees identify high need areas and then seek locations and sponsors for services in these areas. New places are allocated to each State in relation to the target population. Over the three years of the 1988 National Child Care Strategy (NCCS) the allocation of total places is as follows:

(c) The actual number of centres will depend on the size and locations recommended by the Planning Committees. It is expected that about 15 new LDCC will be established, about 25 new FDC schemes, and over 400 new OSHC services. The new occasional care places will, in the main, be added to existing community or neighbourhood centres.
(d) The Commonwealth Government's contribution to these new places in 1990-91 is estimated at:
* $4.14 million for capital, equipment and establishment grants; and
* $14 million per year for recurrent costs when places are fully operational.

State and local Governments will contribute the balance of the capital costs through the provision of land and funding. State Governments will also contribute approximately $l.9 million per year for recurrent costs when the places are fully operational.

(e) The 17 500 new places will be established in co-operation with the States and Territories under agreed cost sharing and construction arrangements. The allocation of places across States is based on proportional target population distribution. The target population for LDC is defined as children aged 0-4 years with parents in the labour-force and for OSHC as children aged 5-12 years with parents in the labour-force.

Planning Committees in each State/Territory provide advice on the geographic areas where there is a need for children's services, together with the most appropriate service types for these high need areas and the relative priorities for such services. High need areas are identified using both statistical analysis of demand and supply and community consultations.
Commonwealth and State Ministers jointly approve the high need areas, sites, sponsors and funding for the services.

(g) As the demand for child care exceeds the supply it is necessary to allocate available places to families whose children have the highest priority. Priority of access guidelines for LDC and OSHC assist service providers to establish priority as follows:
1. Children of workforce participants where a sole parent or two parents are employed, seeking employment or studying/training for employment.
2. Children or parents with a continuing disability or incapacity.
3. Children at risk of serious abuse or neglect.
4. Parents at home with more than one child below school age, and single parents.
Priority of access guidelines do not apply to occasional care services which provide respite or ` `take a break'' care for the children of women at home.
(3) (a) An increase in employer provision of child care will be supported and encouraged by identifying and publicising the advantages to employers and their staff by:

* providing information to employers about the workforce benefits which flow from the provision of child care for their employees, and about child care options available and how to pursue these options; distributing information on taxation concessions available for employer contributions to child care provision; and by providing information on joint venture models for child care service provision;
* holding a forum for senior executives of major corporations covering major issues in employer provided child care in Melbourne in April 1991; and

* holding seminars for small groups of employers in all capital cities to provide detailed information on the workforce benefits of child care provision, the child care service options available and taxation issues.

(b) The target figure of 2 000 employer provided places is an estimate of the number of places that might be established by July 1992. The estimate is based on the increased level of employer interest expressed by employers (private, public and semi-government).

(c) The Government announced in the 1990 Budget that income related fee relief assistance would be available to users of employer provided child care from 1 January 1991, and that payments made to service proprietors by employers to secure access to child care places for employees would be exempt from Fringe Benefits Tax from 1 January 1991.

(4) (a) The administrative and accountability requirements placed on Government funded community-based services will be reviewed in light of the simplified procedures developed for the administration of fee relief assistance to commercial and employer provided centres. It is proposed to extend these simplified procedures to the community-based sector.
(b) Administrative efficiencies put in place in recent years include:
(i) the transfer of the assessment of family income for fee relief purposes from service proprietors to Department of Social Security (DSS);
(ii) the introduction of a streamlined fee relief claiming and payments system for previously unfunded centres from 1 January 1991; and

(ii) Further devolution of responsibilities from Canberra to State offices allows recommendations on projects to be developed in closer consultation with Planning Committees, service providers and the community and should reduce the time delays associated with approvals being handled centrally.

(B) recurrent costs (ie fee relief) for services in previously unfunded commercial, employer and non profit centres;
(C) funds for expansion of special services and program support;
(D) the cost of the enhancements to the previous fee relief system to increase affordability for users of existing Government-funded LDC, FDC, OCC and OSHC services; and
(E) the Department's additional running costs to implement the expansion of the Program.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Australian requirements for clearance of agricultural chemicals in relation to mutagenicity, teratogenicity and carcinogenicity equivalent to the requirements specified by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA); if not, what are the specific differences between the Australian requirements and those of the USEPA.

(2) Is it a fact that the USEPA in 1987 stated that there were data gaps and outstanding toxicological data requirements for fenitrothion in relation to the mutagenicity, teratogenicity and oncogenicity of this pesticide; if so, what were the specific studies the USEPA required to be done.
(3) When did the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) last review the toxicology of fenitrothion.

(4) Did the NHMRC recognise that there were data gaps and outstanding toxicological data requirements for fenitrothion in relation to the mutagenicity, teratogenicity and oncogenicity of this pesticide; if not, why not and if so, what were the outstanding toxicological data requirements specified by the NHMRC.
(5) Did the NHMRC's review of the literature on fenitrothion miss references referring to the ocular effects of fenitrothion; if not, why did the NHMRC fail to mention these effects.
(6) If the references referred to in question 5 were missed, what steps will the Minister take to ensure that coverage of toxicological literature is as comprehensive as possible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian requirements for data for the clearance of agricultural chemicals are listed in the document ``Requirements for Clearance of Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals'' issued by the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council. These requirements include data in relation to mutagenicity, teratogenicity and carcinogenicity and are comparable to those of other industrialised nations including the United States.

(2) As part of a routine re-registration process, the United States Environmental Protection Agency, in 1987, requested to be supplied with data on the chemical/physical characteristics of technical fenitrothion and on its toxicological, environmental and ecological characteristics. Such data may not have been previously supplied to the Environmental Protection Agency as there are no domestic United States uses for fenitrothion on food or feed commodities and hence full United States registration procedures may not previously have been undertaken for this chemical.
(3) The last toxicological review of fenitrothion by NHMRC was in 1987.

(4) At that time the NHMRC did have toxicological data available to it in the relevant areas referred to by the EPA. These areas have also been addressed in the course of comprehensive international reviews of the toxicology of fenitrothion (Joint Food and Agriculture Organisation/World Health Organisation Meeting on Pesticide Residues 1969, 1974, 1977, 1982, 1984, 1986 and 1988. International Programme on Chemical Safety draft report April 1990).
(5) The ocular toxicity of fenitrothion was addressed by a number of studies and the review found no grounds for concern.
(6) All available bibliographic databases of relevance to toxicological assessment of chemicals are routinely consulted during the review of any chemical.
